sentence: Four alternative approaches have been described , and many others could be listed .
gloss: Make a list of.
eg_sent: I have listed four reasons below
bis_def_collins: To list several things such as reasons or names means to write or say them one after another, usually in a particular order.
exps_collins: ['The pupils were asked to list the sports they loved most and hated most.', 'Manufacturers must list ingredients in order of the amount used.']
bis_def_longman: to write a list, or mention things one after the other
exps_longman: ['The guidebook lists 1,000 hotels and restaurants.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to write a list of things in a particular order
exps_oxford_advanced: ['We were asked to list our ten favourite songs.', 'Towns in the guide are listed alphabetically.']

sentence: I wanted to say , you see , that I know you thought Frannie should n't have gone , and that it 's ruined your holiday plans , and , on behalf of us all , I 'm sorry .
gloss: Move from one place to another; travel.
eg_sent: he went out to the shops
bis_def_collins: When you go somewhere, you move or travel there.
exps_collins: ['We went to Rome.', 'Gladys had just gone into the kitchen.', 'I went home at the weekend.', 'Four of them had gone off to find help.', 'It took us an hour to go three miles.']
bis_def_longman: to travel or move to a place that is away from where you are or where you live
exps_longman: ['There’s nothing more we can do here. Let’s go home.', 'Where are you going?', 'We’re going to Canada in the summer.', 'Dinah went into the kitchen.', 'She went over and put her arm around him.', 'I’m going round to her house to find out what’s wrong.', 'I’ll just go up  and ask him what he wants.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to move or travel from one place to another
exps_oxford_advanced: ['She went into her room and shut the door behind her.', 'He goes to work by bus.', 'I have to go to Rome on business.', 'She has gone to China (= is now in China or is on her way there).', 'She has been to China (= she went to China and has now returned).', "I think you should go to the doctor's.", 'Are you going home for Christmas?', 'She has gone to see her sister this weekend.']

sentence: The one with you chop the chop and then there will be squares
gloss: Cut (something) into pieces with repeated sharp blows of an axe or knife.
eg_sent: they chopped up the pulpit for firewood
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;;; If you chop something, you cut it into pieces with strong downward movements of a knife or an axe. ;;;
exps_collins: ['Chop the butter into small pieces.', 'Chop the onions very finely.', 'Visitors were set to work chopping wood.', '...chopped tomatoes.']
bis_def_longman: to cut something into smaller pieces
exps_longman: ['He went outside to chop some more wood for the fire.', 'Can you chop up some carrots for me?', 'Add two finely chopped onions and a clove of garlic.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to cut something into pieces with a sharp tool such as a knife
exps_oxford_advanced: ['He was chopping logs for firewood.', 'Add the finely chopped onions.', 'Chop the carrots up into small pieces.', 'The country was chopped up into small administrative areas.']

sentence: Given that most GIS are rather dumb systems , requiring intelligent , very computer literate users , managing natural and technological hazards means that this knowledge base must be built into the system so that it can be utilized quickly by untrained users after a disaster has taken place or in an emergency .
gloss: Need for a particular purpose.
eg_sent: three patients required operations
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; If you require something or if something is required, you need it or it is necessary. ; [formal]
exps_collins: ['If you require further information, you should consult the registrar.', "This isn't the kind of crisis that requires us to drop everything else.", 'Some of the materials required for this technique may be difficult to obtain.']
bis_def_longman: to need something
exps_longman: ['Campbell’s broken leg will probably require surgery.', 'What’s required is a complete reorganization of the system.', 'Most houseplants require regular watering.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to need something; to depend on somebody/something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['These pets require a lot of care and attention.', 'Deciphering the code requires an expert.', 'This condition requires urgent treatment.', 'Do you require anything else? (= in a shop/store, for example)', 'True marriage requires us to show trust and loyalty.', 'The situation required that he be present.', 'The situation required that he should be present.', 'Lentils do not require soaking before cooking.']

sentence: Lacking a goal that might have altered its chemistry , it remained a matter of dull physics .
gloss: Change in character or composition, typically in a comparatively small but significant way.
eg_sent: Eliot was persuaded to alter the passage
bis_def_collins: If something alters or if you alter it, it changes.
exps_collins: ['Little had altered in the village.', 'They have never altered their programmes by a single day.']
bis_def_longman: to change, or to make someone or something change
exps_longman: ['Her face hadn’t altered much over the years.', 'The city centre has altered beyond recognition .', 'Nothing can alter the fact that the refugees are our responsibility.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to become different; to make somebody/something different
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Prices did not alter significantly during 2014.', 'He had altered so much I scarcely recognized him.', "It doesn't alter the way I feel.", 'Nothing can alter the fact that we are to blame.', 'The landscape has been radically altered, severely damaging wildlife.', 'This incident altered the whole course of events.']

sentence: Equally intriguing will be the line-out performance of the young London Irish lock , Neil Francis , who has been left out of the current Ireland squad .
gloss: Go away from.
eg_sent: she left London on June 6
bis_def_collins: If you leave a place or person, you go away from that place or person.
exps_collins: ['He would not be allowed to leave the country.', "I simply couldn't bear to leave my little girl.", 'My flight leaves in less than an hour.', 'The last of the older children had left for school.']
bis_def_longman: to go away from a place or a person
exps_longman: ['My baby gets upset when I leave the room.', 'Before leaving the train, make sure you have all your belongings with you.', 'The plane leaves at 12.30.', 'I tried calling him, but he’d already left for work.', 'If he left immediately, he’d catch the 7.30 train.', 'Frances left work early to meet her mother.', 'Never leave children playing near water unattended.', 'I’ll leave you to it.', 'My youngest boy has not left my side since his daddy was killed.', 'Just a few more questions, then we’ll leave you in peace.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to go away from a person or a place
exps_oxford_advanced: ["Come on, it's time we left.", 'The plane leaves for Dallas at 12.35.', 'I hate leaving home.', 'The plane leaves Heathrow at 12.35.']

sentence: Thus , wherever one looks , one finds people engaged in the construction of the blocks that will make up the Palestinian state .
gloss: Direct one's gaze toward someone or something or in a specified direction.
eg_sent: people were looking at him
bis_def_collins: If you look in a particular direction, you direct your eyes in that direction, especially so that you can see what is there or see what something is like.
exps_collins: ['I looked down the hallway to room number nine.', 'She turned to look at him.', 'He looked away, apparently enraged.', "If you look, you'll see what was a lake.", 'If you want to say that someone is paying attention to something they can see, you say that they are looking at it or watching it. In general, you look at something that is not moving, while you watch something that is moving or changing. I asked him to look at the picture above his bed... He watched Blake run down the stairs. Look is never followed directly by an object. You must always use at or some other preposition. I looked towards the plane. You use see to talk about things that you are aware of because a visual impression reaches your eyes. You often use can in this case. I can see the fax here on the desk.']
bis_def_longman: to turn your eyes towards something, so that you can see it
exps_longman: ['We sneaked out while Jessie’s mom wasn’t looking.', 'If you look carefully you can see that the painting represents a human figure.', 'Gina covered her eyes, afraid to look.', '‘It’s time we left, ’ Ian said, looking at his watch.', 'The men all turned to look at her as she entered the room.', 'Dad looked up from his paper and smiled.', '‘We can’t go out in this weather, ’ said Bob, looking out of the window.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to turn your eyes in a particular direction
exps_oxford_advanced: ['If you look carefully you can just see our house from here.', 'She looked at me and smiled.', "‘Has the mail come yet?’ ‘I'll look and see.’", "Look! I'm sure that's Brad Pitt!", "Don't look now, but there's someone staring at you!"]

sentence: As for his colleagues , Mr Smith said : We 're all agreed that we can not spend what we have not earned and we intend to earn it before we spend it .
gloss: Give (money) to pay for goods, services, or so as to benefit someone or something.
eg_sent: the firm has spent £100,000 on hardware
bis_def_collins: VERB  ();() When you spend money, you pay money for things that you want. ();()
exps_collins: ['By the end of the holiday I had spent all my money.', 'Businessmen spend enormous amounts advertising their products.', 'Juventus have spent £23m on new players.', 'The survey may cost at least £100 but is money well spent.']
bis_def_longman: to use your money to pay for goods or services
exps_longman: ['I can’t afford to spend any more money this week.', 'I only want to spend about $20.', 'More money should be spent on education.', 'Mum never spends any money on herself.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to give money to pay for goods, services, etc.
exps_oxford_advanced: ["I've spent all my money already.", 'She spent £100 on a new dress.', 'The company has spent thousands of pounds updating their computer systems.', "I just can't seem to stop spending."]

sentence: The red and green of the Aztec necklace links it compositionally with the indigenous plants to the south of the painting , the pink colonial-style dress tonally blending with the skyscrapers to the north .
gloss: Make, form, or suggest a connection with or between.
eg_sent: rumours that linked his name with Judith
bis_def_collins: If someone or something links two things or situations, there is a relationship between them, for example because one thing causes or affects the other.  [Also + V n with]
exps_collins: ['The UN Security Council has linked any lifting of sanctions to compliance with the ceasefire terms.', 'The study further strengthens the evidence linking smoking with early death.', 'Liver cancer is linked to the hepatitis B virus.', 'The detention raised two distinct but closely linked questions.']
bis_def_longman: if two things are linked, they are related in some way
exps_longman: ['Police think the murders are linked.', 'Some birth defects are linked to smoking during pregnancy.', 'Our economy is inextricably linked with America’s.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to make a physical or electronic connection between one object, machine, place, etc. and another
exps_oxford_advanced: ['The video cameras are linked to a powerful computer.', 'The Channel Tunnel links Britain with the rest of Europe.', 'When computers are networked, they are linked together so that information can be transferred between them.']

sentence: Jesus wept ! he continued , hackles rising .
gloss: Shed tears.
eg_sent: a grieving mother wept over the body of her daughter
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; If someone weeps, they cry. ; [literary]
exps_collins: ['She wanted to laugh and weep all at once.', 'The weeping family hugged and comforted each other.', 'She wept tears of joy.']
bis_def_longman: to cry, especially because you feel very sad
exps_longman: ['She wept for the loss of her mother.', 'He wept bitterly when it was time for us to leave.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to cry, usually because you are sad
exps_oxford_advanced: ['She started to weep uncontrollably.', "I could have wept thinking about what I'd missed.", 'He wept for joy.', 'I do not weep over his death.', 'She wept bitter tears of disappointment.', 'I wept to see him looking so sick.', "‘I'm so unhappy!’ she wept."]

sentence: This is a stout-bodied fish , something like a perch in general proportions , with long , low fins on upper and lower rear of the body ( fin rays finely divide near their ends ) .
gloss: Separate or be separated into parts.
eg_sent: consumer magazines can be divided into a number of categories
bis_def_collins: V-ERG  ; When people or things are divided or divide into smaller groups or parts, they become separated into smaller parts. ; [Also VERB n]
exps_collins: ['The physical benefits of exercise can be divided into three factors.', 'It will be easiest if we divide them into groups.', 'Divide the pastry in half and roll out each piece.', 'We divide into pairs and each pair takes a region.', 'Bacteria reproduce by dividing and making copies of themselves.']
bis_def_longman: if something divides, or if you divide it, it separates into two or more parts
exps_longman: ['Scientists traditionally divide the oceans into zones.', 'The book is divided into six sections.', 'Here, the river divides into three channels.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to separate or make something separate into parts
exps_oxford_advanced: ['The cells began to divide rapidly.', 'A sentence can be divided up into meaningful segments.']

sentence: Adam decided to hold back Miranda 's bombshell until later , after Elinor drank her evening glass of champagne .
gloss: Come or bring to a resolution in the mind as a result of consideration.
eg_sent: she decided that she liked him
bis_def_collins: If you decide to do something, you choose to do it, usually after you have thought carefully about the other possibilities.  [Also V + in favour of]
exps_collins: ['She decided to do a secretarial course.', "He has decided that he doesn't want to embarrass the movement and will therefore step down.", 'The house needed totally rebuilding, so we decided against buying it.', "I had a cold and couldn't decide whether to go to work or not.", 'Think about it very carefully before you decide.']
bis_def_longman: to make a choice or judgment about something, especially after considering all the possibilities or arguments
exps_longman: ['Has anything been decided yet?', 'Tina’s decided to go to Rome for her holidays.', 'It was decided that four hospitals should close.', 'I can’t decide whether I like him or not.', 'People have a right to decide how to spend their own money.', 'A meeting was called to decide between the three candidates.', 'You must decide for yourself.', 'The trainees decide among themselves what programs to take.', 'He eventually decided against telling her.', 'After a long discussion, they decided in favour of  the older applicant.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to think carefully about the different possibilities that are available and choose one of them
exps_oxford_advanced: ["It's up to you to decide.", "I can't tell you what to do—you'll have to decide for yourself.", 'It was difficult to decide between the two candidates.', 'They decided against taking legal action.', "I can't decide what to wear.", 'She couldn’t decide whether he was telling the truth or not.', 'She decided (that) she wanted to live in France.', "We've decided not to go away after all.", 'Why did you decide to look for a new job?', 'We might be hiring more people but nothing has been decided yet.', 'It was decided (that) the school should purchase new software.']

sentence: Let puritans and pessimists damn , disapprove or dismiss these appetites ; that is their loss .
gloss: Have or express an unfavourable opinion.
eg_sent: Bob strongly disapproved of drinking and driving
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; If you disapprove of something or someone, you feel or show that you do not like them or do not approve of them. ;;
exps_collins: ['Most people disapprove of such violent tactics.', 'Her mother disapproved of her working in a pub.', 'The Prime Minister made it clear that he disapproved.']
bis_def_longman: to think that someone or their behaviour, ideas etc are bad or wrong
exps_longman: ['I knew my parents would disapprove, but I went anyway.', 'I disapprove of diets; it’s better to eat sensibly.', 'Her family strongly disapproved of her behaviour.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to think that somebody/something is not good or suitable; to not approve of somebody/something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['She wants to be an actress, but her parents disapprove.', 'He strongly disapproved of the changes that had been made.', 'A solid majority disapproves the way the president is handling the controversy.']

sentence: He had come , he believed , because he needed to discuss certain administrative problems with Frederica .
gloss: Talk about (something) with a person or people.
eg_sent: I discussed the matter with my wife
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; If people discuss something, they talk about it, often in order to reach a decision. ;; [Also VERB wh]
exps_collins: ['I will be discussing the situation with colleagues tomorrow.', 'The cabinet met today to discuss how to respond to the ultimatum.']
bis_def_longman: to talk about something with another person or a group in order to exchange ideas or decide something
exps_longman: ['Littman refused to discuss the case publicly.', 'If you would like to discuss the matter further, please call me.', 'Pupils should be given time to discuss the book with their classmates.', 'Your accountant will discuss with you how to complete these forms.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to talk about something with somebody, especially in order to decide something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Have you discussed the problem with anyone?', "I'm not prepared to discuss this on the phone.", 'They met to discuss the possibility of working together.', 'We need to discuss when we should go.', 'We briefly discussed buying a second car.']

sentence: There are no instruments capable to measure the magnitude or direction of A.
gloss: Ascertain the size, amount, or degree of (something) by using an instrument or device marked in standard units.
eg_sent: the amount of water collected is measured in pints
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; If you measure the quality, value, or effect of something, you discover or judge how great it is. ;;
exps_collins: ["I continued to measure his progress against the charts in the doctor's office.", "A grammar school's success was measured in terms of the number of pupils who got into university.", 'It was difficult to measure the precise impact of the labor action.']
bis_def_longman: to find the size, length, or amount of something, using standard units such as inches, metres etc
exps_longman: ['The rainfall was measured over a three-month period.', 'She was being measured for her wedding dress.', 'We can measure the energy that food provides in calories.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to find the size, quantity, etc. of something in standard units
exps_oxford_advanced: ["A ship's speed is measured in knots.", 'a device that measures the level of radiation in the atmosphere', 'measuring equipment/instruments', "He's gone to be measured for a new suit.", 'A dipstick is used to measure how much oil is left in an engine.']

sentence: It is also urging the conference to oppose a motion , supported by the National Union of Mineworkers , to commit a Labour government to abolishing all nuclear power within 15 years .
gloss: Try earnestly or persistently to persuade (someone) to do something.
eg_sent: he urged her to come and stay with us

sentence: You have to hope that its blankness will slowly dissolve and let life in .
gloss: Not prevent or forbid; allow.
eg_sent: my boss let me leave early
bis_def_collins: If you let something happen, you allow it to happen without doing anything to stop or prevent it.
exps_collins: ['People said we were interfering with nature, and that we should just let the animals die.', 'Thorne let him talk.', 'She let the door slam.', "I can't let myself be distracted by those things."]
bis_def_longman: to allow someone to do something

exps_oxford_advanced: ['Let them splash around in the pool for a while.', "Don't let her upset you.", 'Let your body relax.', "He'd eat chocolate all day long if I let him."]

sentence: Extensive use of line drawings , schematic diagrams , algorithmic lists is desirable , and where prose is used this also should be structured into short sentences with meaningful separation into paragraphs .
gloss: Construct or arrange according to a plan; give a pattern or organization to.
eg_sent: services must be structured so as to avoid pitfalls
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; If you structure something, you arrange it in a careful, organized pattern or system. ;;
exps_collins: ["By structuring the course this way, we're forced to produce something the companies think is valuable."]
bis_def_longman: to arrange the different parts of something into a pattern or system in which each part is connected to the others
exps_longman: ['The exhibition is structured around three topics.', 'software that helps users structure their work and their data', 'Mr. Reed has set a course that ultimately will dismantle much of the bank’s huge bureaucratic structure.', 'a complex structure of affiliated companies']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to arrange or organize something into a system or pattern
exps_oxford_advanced: ['How well does the teacher structure the lessons?', 'Make use of the toys in structured group activities.', 'The exhibition is structured around the themes of work and leisure.']

sentence: They had slept well , eaten well , slept again and eventually got bored with the passing countryside .

I don’t eat meat .', 'Does Rob eat fish?']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to put food in your mouth, chew it and swallow it

sentence: So she said er it wo n't only be fiver cos she said
gloss: Utter words so as to convey information, an opinion, a feeling or intention, or an instruction.
eg_sent: ‘Thank you,’ he said
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; When you say something, you speak words. ; [Also VERB to-infinitive]
exps_collins: ["'I'm sorry,' he said.", 'She said they were very impressed.', 'Forty-one people are said to have been seriously hurt.', 'I packed and said goodbye to Charlie.', "I hope you didn't say anything about Gretchen.", "You didn't say much when you telephoned.", 'Did he say where he was going?.', "It doesn't sound exactly orthodox, if I may say so."]

Oh, please say yes!', 'He looked as if he was going to say something.', 'I wished I had said nothing about Jordi.', 'Does anyone else have anything to say?', 'Although he didn’t say so, it was clear that he was in pain.', 'What makes you say that (=why do you think that) ? 你怎么会那么说呢？', 'Nina said to meet her at 4.30.', 'I’d like to say a few words.', '‘So what are your plans now?’ ‘I’d rather not say.’']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to speak or tell somebody something, using words

sentence: The abstract talk of commuting by rail or road being replaced by information technology finds a concrete expression in the idea of telecottages .

sentence: He was thumbing through USA Today for the umpteenth time , looking for something he might have missed , when he heard her giggling .
gloss: Press, move, or touch (something) with one's thumb.
eg_sent: as soon as she thumbed the button, the door slid open

sentence: Such substances and thresholds include , for instance , 25 tonnes of flammable liquid petroleum gas and the explosive sodium chlorate , and 10 tonnes of toxic chlorine gas .
gloss: Comprise or contain as part of a whole.
eg_sent: the price includes dinner, bed, and breakfast
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; If one thing includes another thing, it has the other thing as one of its parts. ;
exps_collins: ['A good British breakfast always includes sausages.', 'The trip has been extended to include a few other events.', 'The list includes many British internationals.']
bis_def_longman: if one thing includes another, the second thing is part of the first
exps_longman: ['Does the price include postage?', 'His job includes looking after under-21 teams.', 'The curriculum includes courses in computing.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: if one thing includes another, it has the second thing as one of its parts

sentence: When he was little he was sat in his buggy
gloss: Adopt or be in a position in which one's weight is supported by one's buttocks rather than one's feet and one's back is upright.
eg_sent: I sat next to him at dinner
bis_def_collins: If you are sitting somewhere, for example in a chair, your bottom is resting on the chair and the upper part of your body is upright.  [Also VERB]
exps_collins: ['Mother was sitting in her chair in the kitchen.', 'They sat there in shock and disbelief.', 'They had been sitting watching television.', 'He was unable to sit still for longer than a few minutes.']
bis_def_longman: to be on a chair or seat, or on the ground, with the top half of your body upright and your weight resting on your buttocks
exps_longman: ['I sat on the shore and looked at the sea.', 'She was sitting in a chair by the fire.', 'She’s the girl who sits next to me at school.', 'In the driving seat sat a man of average height.', 'Jean sat at the table writing a letter.', 'They sat sipping their drinks.', 'We used to sit and listen to her for hours.']

Oh, please say yes!', 'He looked as if he was going to say something.', 'I wished I had said nothing about Jordi.', 'Does anyone else have anything to say?', 'Although he didn’t say so, it was clear that he was in pain.', 'What makes you say that (=why do you think that) ? 你怎么会那么说呢？', 'Nina said to meet her at 4.30.', 'I’d like to say a few words.', '‘So what are your plans now?’ ‘I’d rather not say.’']

exps_collins: ["I don't know the name of the place.", 'I know that you led a rifle platoon during the Second World War.', "'People like doing things for nothing.' — 'I know they do.'.", "I don't know what happened to her husband.", "'How did he meet your mother?' — 'I don't know.'.", 'We all know about his early experiments in flying.', 'They looked younger than I knew them to be.', 'Radon is known to be harmful to humans in large quantities.', 'It is not known whether the bomb was originally intended for the capital itself.', "It's always been known that key figures in the government do very well for themselves."]

exps_longman: ['Who knows the answer?', 'There are instructions telling you everything you need to know.', 'Didn’t you know that?', 'Do you know what time it is?', 'I don’t know where to go.', 'I need to know more about the job before I decide whether to apply for it.', 'Little is known about the author’s childhood.', 'I know all about David and what he’s been up to!', 'I wonder if he knew of the plan?', 'Do you know of any good restaurants in the area?', 'You know nothing of this business.', 'We know that greenhouse gases can affect the climate.', 'Let me know what time you’re planning to arrive.', 'I thought you’d want to know immediately.', 'If you must know, I was with James last night .', 'He slipped out of the house without his parents knowing .', 'How did he know our names?', '‘I’m divorced, as you know, ’ she said briefly.', 'Smoking is known to increase a person’s risk of developing lung cancer.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have information in your mind as a result of experience or because you have learned or been told it
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Do you know his address?', 'The cause of the fire is not yet known.', 'All I know is that she used to work in a bank (= I have no other information about her).', 'I know (that) people’s handwriting changes as they get older.', 'It is widely known that CFCs can damage the ozone layer.', 'I knew where he was hiding.', "I didn't know what he was talking about.", "‘You've got a flat tyre.’ ‘I know.’", "‘What's the answer?’ ‘I don't know.’", "‘There's no one in.’ ‘How do you know?’", "You know about Amanda's baby, don't you?", "I don't know about you, but I'm ready for something to eat.", 'I know of at least two people who did the same thing.', '‘Is anyone else coming?’ ‘Not that I know of.’', '‘Isn’t that his car?’ ‘I wouldn’t know./How should I know?’ (= I don’t know and I am not the person you should ask.)', "‘What are you two whispering about?’ ‘You don't want to know’ (= because you would be shocked or wouldn't approve).", 'Does he know to come here (= that he should come here) first?', 'We know her to be honest.', 'Two women are known to have died.']

exps_collins: ["You can't see colours at night.", 'I saw a man making his way towards me.', 'She can see, hear, touch, smell, and taste.', 'As he neared the farm, he saw that a police car was parked outside it.', 'Did you see what happened?', 'You use see to talk about things that you are aware of because a visual impression reaches your eyes. You often use can in this case. I can see the fax here on the desk. If you want to say that someone is paying attention to something they can see, you say that they are looking at it or watching it. In general, you look at something that is not moving, while you watch something that is moving or changing. I asked him to look at the picture above his bed... He watched Blake run down the stairs.']

gloss: Engage in activity for enjoyment and recreation rather than a serious or practical purpose.

gloss: Combine or cause to combine to form a single entity.

bis_def_collins: V-RECIP-ERG  );() If one thing merges with another, or is merged with another, they combine or come together to make one whole thing. You can also say that two things merge, or are merged . );() [Also VERB n + into]
exps_collins: ['My life merged with his.', 'Bank of America merged with a rival bank.', 'The rivers merge just north of a vital irrigation system.', 'The two countries merged into one.', 'He sees sense in merging the two agencies while both are new.', 'Then he showed me how to merge the graphic with text on the same screen.']

sentence: The Social Services Department also provided thirteen short-term and long-term residential units for children in care ( by 1988 their number had been reduced to eleven ) , none with wheelchair access and only one with any experience of caring for children with learning difficulties .

sentence: The Government 's record on unemployment was a heavily politicized issue , and just as in 1981 it vehemently denied any responsibility for the riots through its pursuit of free-market policies .

sentence: Such techniques are now standard in environmental science ( see Streit 1981 for an application to rainfall monitoring ) and need to be promoted vigorously in hazard studies ( Estes et al. 1987 ) .
gloss: Perceive with the eyes; discern visually.
eg_sent: in the distance she could see the blue sea
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont] ; When you see something, you notice it using your eyes. ;
exps_collins: ["You can't see colours at night.", 'I saw a man making his way towards me.', 'She can see, hear, touch, smell, and taste.', 'As he neared the farm, he saw that a police car was parked outside it.', 'Did you see what happened?', 'You use see to talk about things that you are aware of because a visual impression reaches your eyes. You often use can in this case. I can see the fax here on the desk. If you want to say that someone is paying attention to something they can see, you say that they are looking at it or watching it. In general, you look at something that is not moving, while you watch something that is moving or changing. I asked him to look at the picture above his bed... He watched Blake run down the stairs.']
bis_def_longman: to notice or examine someone or something, using your eyes
exps_longman: ['He crouched down so he couldn’t be seen.', 'Can I see your ticket, please?', 'You can see the Houses of Parliament from here.', 'Can you see where the marks are on the wall?', 'The suspect was seen entering the building.', 'As you can see, the house needs some work doing on it.', 'Have you seen Chris ?', 'The accommodation was so awful it had to be seen to be believed.']

sentence: Mr Livingstone said he was against pacts , but 10 years of Thatcherism had demonstrated the dangers of giving power to elites .

Oh, please say yes!', 'He looked as if he was going to say something.', 'I wished I had said nothing about Jordi.', 'Does anyone else have anything to say?', 'Although he didn’t say so, it was clear that he was in pain.', 'What makes you say that (=why do you think that) ? 你怎么会那么说呢？', 'Nina said to meet her at 4.30.', 'I’d like to say a few words.', '‘So what are your plans now?’ ‘I’d rather not say.’']

sentence: Punters often try to avoid paying .

bis_def_oxford_advanced: to give somebody money for work, goods, services, etc.

sentence: Has he got that thing going ?

sentence: He did not loosen his links with the athletes when projected upwards into the Presidency .

sentence: Finally , after the third month passed with no rent received , Debbie phoned the tenants , asked them to pay her directly , and sent Landlords a recorded-delivery letter , which was returned , and finally one by ordinary post stating that Landlords were no longer employed as the managing agents .
gloss: Give work to (someone) and pay them for it.

exps_collins: ['The company employs 18 staff.', 'More than 3,000 local workers are employed in the tourism industry.', 'The government counted 27,600,000 employed persons in West Germany.']
bis_def_longman: to pay someone to work for you

sentence: She 's not allowed to move
gloss: Go in a specified direction or manner; change position.
eg_sent: she moved to the door
bis_def_collins: V-ERG  ; When you move something or when it moves, its position changes and it does not remain still. ;
exps_collins: ['She moved the sheaf of papers into position.', 'You can move the camera both vertically and horizontally.', 'A traffic warden asked him to move his car.', 'I could see the branches of the trees moving back and forth.', 'The train began to move.']
bis_def_longman: to change from one place or position to another, or to make something do this
exps_longman: ['‘Come on, ’ Sue said. No one moved.', 'Could you move your car, please? It’s blocking the road.', 'The plane moved slowly along the runway, then stopped.', 'He moved closer to her.', 'Becca moved down the steps and into the yard.', 'I could hear someone moving around upstairs.', 'The bar was so crowded you could hardly move.', 'At Christmas, you couldn’t move for toys in this house .', 'Paul couldn’t move a muscle he was so scared.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to change position or make somebody/something change position in a way that can be seen, heard or felt

sentence: Equally , the improvements in fortification needed to withstand their effects thick stone walls , inner as well as outer defences required incomes greater than those of simple lords .
gloss: Remain undamaged or unaffected by; resist.
eg_sent: the structure had been designed to withstand winds of more than 100 mph

bis_def_longman: to be strong enough to remain unharmed by something such as great heat, cold, pressure etc

bis_def_oxford_advanced: to be strong enough not to be hurt or damaged by extreme conditions, the use of force, etc.
exps_oxford_advanced: ['The materials used have to be able to withstand high temperatures.', 'They had withstood siege, hunger and deprivation.']

sentence: Afterwards they lay quietly side by side , not speaking , until he said , I must go .
gloss: Say something in order to convey information or to express a feeling.

exps_collins: ['He tried to speak, but for once, his voice had left him.', 'He speaks with a lisp.', 'I rang the hotel and spoke to Louie.', 'She says she must speak with you at once.', 'She cried when she spoke of Oliver.', '...as I spoke these idiotic words.']

bis_def_oxford_advanced: to talk to somebody about something; to have a conversation with somebody

sentence: Peter Yeo , who had known this particular juggernaut since he had his first small factory and two stores and dirt under his fingernails from shifting packing-cases personally , was not fazed by the question .
gloss: Move or cause to move from one place to another, especially over a small distance.

exps_collins: ['He stopped, shifting his cane to his left hand.', 'He shifted from foot to foot.', 'The entire pile shifted and slid, thumping onto the floor.', '...the squeak of his boots in the snow as he shifted his weight.']

sentence: Although the proposed method is novel , it is but one of an increasingly large number of methods designed to detect and model clusters of disease ( see , for example , Cuzick and Edwards 1990 ) .
gloss: Fashion or shape (a three-dimensional figure or object) in a malleable material such as clay or wax.

sentence: The arguments therefore tend to focus on three borderline questions : What is the minimum fault required for conviction of murder ?
gloss: Regularly or frequently behave in a particular way or have a certain characteristic.
eg_sent: written language tends to be formal
bis_def_collins: If something tends to happen, it usually happens or it often happens.
exps_collins: ['A problem for manufacturers is that lighter cars tend to be noisy.', 'In older age groups women predominate because men tend to die younger.', 'They tend to buy cheap processed foods like canned chicken and macaroni.']
bis_def_longman: if something tends to happen, it happens often and is likely to happen again
exps_longman: ['People tend to need less sleep as they get older.', 'My car tends to overheat in the summer.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to be likely to do something or to happen in a particular way because this is what often or usually happens
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Women tend to live longer than men.', "When I'm tired, I tend to make mistakes.", 'It tends to get very cold here in the winter.', 'People tend to think that the problem will never affect them.']

sentence: Modern audiences no longer accept plastic bushes , and the southern Californian suburban sprawl means the production companies have to take their horses and cows to locations far away in Arizona or Montana .
gloss: Lay hold of (something) with one's hands; reach for and hold.
eg_sent: Mrs Morgan took another biscuit
bis_def_collins: You can use take followed by a noun to talk about an action or event, when it would also be possible to use the verb that is related to that noun. For example, you can say 'she took a shower' instead of 'she showered'.
exps_collins: ['She was too tired to take a shower.', 'Betty took a photograph of us.', "I've never taken a holiday since starting this job.", "There's not enough people willing to take the risk.", 'Walk around the property and take a good look at it from the outside.', 'We took a long walk through the pines.']
bis_def_longman: to move or go with someone or something from one place to another
exps_longman: ['Barney took us to the airport.', 'Would you mind taking Susie home?', 'When he refused to give his name, he was taken into custody.', 'My job has taken me all over the world.', 'His wife went to Australia, taking the children with her.', 'I have to take Steve the money tonight.', 'He took me to meet his parents.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to carry or move something from one place to another
exps_oxford_advanced: ['I forgot to take my bag with me when I got off the bus.', 'Take this to the bank for me, would you?', 'Shall I take a gift to my host family?', 'Shall I take my host family a gift?']

sentence: To his right the ground rose gently towards the southern cliffs and he could see the dark mouth of a concrete pillbox , undemolished since the war , and as seemingly indestructible as the great hulks of wave-battered concrete , remnants of the old fortifications which lay half-submerged in the sand along part of the beach .
gloss: Move from a lower position to a higher one; come or go up.
eg_sent: the tiny aircraft rose from the ground
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; If something rises, it moves upwards. ;;
exps_collins: ['He watched the smoke rise from his cigarette.', 'The powdery dust rose in a cloud around him.', 'Spray rose up from the surface of the water.', 'Black dense smoke rose up.']
bis_def_longman: to increase in number, amount, or value
exps_longman: ['Sales rose by 20% over the Christmas period.', 'The research budget rose from £175,000 in 1999 to £22.5 million in 2001.', 'Temperatures rarely rise above freezing.', 'The number of people seeking asylum in Britain has risen sharply.', 'The divorce rate has risen steadily since the 1950s.', 'The country faces economic recession and rising unemployment.', 'The police seem unable to cope with the rising tide of car crime.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to come or go upwards; to reach a higher level or position
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Smoke was rising from the chimney.', 'The river has risen (by) several metres.']

sentence: In his minute , inaccessible capital , which today has only 15,000 inhabitants , Nicholas erected a miniature European court and an exquisitely furnished Victorian palace .
gloss: Put together and set upright (a building, wall, or other structure)
eg_sent: the guest house was erected in the eighteenth century

sentence: Actually can you really face the from the other pathfinders
gloss: Be positioned with the face or front towards (someone or something)
eg_sent: he turned to face her
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; If someone or something faces a particular thing, person, or direction, they are positioned opposite them or are looking in that direction. ;;
bis_def_longman: if you face or are faced with a difficult situation, or if a difficult situation faces you, it is going to affect you and you must deal with it
exps_longman: ['Emergency services are facing additional problems this winter.', 'The president faces the difficult task of putting the economy back on its feet.', 'McManus is facing the biggest challenge of his career.', 'As the project comes to an end, many workers now face an uncertain future.', 'He must face the prospect of financial ruin.', 'I was faced with the awful job of breaking the news to the girl’s family.', 'the difficulties faced by the police', 'If he is found guilty, he faces up to 12 years in jail.', 'He was the first member of the former government to face criminal charges.']

exps_oxford_advanced: ['She turned and faced him.', 'Most of the rooms face the sea.', 'The terrace faces south.', 'a north-facing wall', 'Stand with your feet apart and your hands facing upwards.', 'Which direction are you facing?']

sentence: I stay in the car cos er I do n't want to walk , too cold
gloss: Move at a regular pace by lifting and setting down each foot in turn, never having both feet off the ground at once.
eg_sent: I walked across the lawn
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; When you walk, you move forward by putting one foot in front of the other in a regular way. ;;
exps_collins: ['Rosanna and Forbes walked in silence for some while.', 'We walked into the foyer.', 'She turned and walked away.', 'They would stop the car and walk a few steps.', 'When I was your age I walked five miles to school.']
bis_def_longman: to move forward by putting one foot in front of the other
exps_longman: ['‘How did you get here?’ ‘We walked.’', 'Doctors said he’d never walk again.', 'Carrie walked into the room and sat down in her chair.', 'He loved walking in the hills.', 'We must have walked ten miles today.', 'I walked all the way to San Rafael.', 'There are plenty of bars and restaurants within walking distance of the hotel.']

sentence: If the person in default fails to comply with an abatement notice the local authority is obliged to make a complaint to the magistrates .
gloss: Make (someone) legally or morally bound to do something.
eg_sent: doctors are obliged by law to keep patients alive while there is a chance of recovery
bis_def_collins: VERB  ) If you are obliged to do something, a situation, rule, or law makes it necessary for you to do that thing. )
exps_collins: ['The storm got worse and worse. Finally, I was obliged to abandon the car and continue on foot.', 'This decree obliges unions to delay strikes.']
bis_def_longman: if you are obliged to do something, you have to do it because the situation, the law, a duty etc makes it necessary

sentence: This is particularly important in a field where many of the demands made by users are highly specialized in nature .
gloss: Concentrate on and become expert in a particular subject or skill.
eg_sent: he could specialize in tropical medicine
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;;; If you specialize in a thing, you know a lot about it and concentrate a great deal of your time and energy on it, especially in your work or when you are studying or training. You also use specialize to talk about a restaurant which concentrates on a particular type of food. ;;;
exps_collins: ['...a University professor who specializes in the history of the Russian empire.', '...a Portuguese restaurant which specializes in seafood.']
bis_def_longman: to limit all or most of your study, business etc to a particular subject or activity

sentence: Moreover , recent work has shown that much of the heat energy in the seas of the North Atlantic ( every square kilometre of which gives off as much energy as a nuclear power station and hence influences our weather ) is absorbed from sunlight in the tropical Pacific and is carried by ocean currents through the Drake Passage and up into the Atlantic .
gloss: Support and move (someone or something) from one place to another.

bis_def_oxford_advanced: to support the weight of somebody/something and take them or it from place to place; to take somebody/something from one place to another

sentence: Communists allow burial of Montenegro 's last king
gloss: Let (someone) have or do something.
eg_sent: the dissident was allowed to leave the country

bis_def_longman: to walk or move unsteadily, almost falling over

sentence: Campbell 's hard-working side are still trying to sort out their system , which involves a spare defender and , as far as one can see , a good deal of improvisation .
gloss: Perceive with the eyes; discern visually.
eg_sent: in the distance she could see the blue sea
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont] ; When you see something, you notice it using your eyes. ;
exps_collins: ["You can't see colours at night.", 'I saw a man making his way towards me.', 'She can see, hear, touch, smell, and taste.', 'As he neared the farm, he saw that a police car was parked outside it.', 'Did you see what happened?', 'You use see to talk about things that you are aware of because a visual impression reaches your eyes. You often use can in this case. I can see the fax here on the desk. If you want to say that someone is paying attention to something they can see, you say that they are looking at it or watching it. In general, you look at something that is not moving, while you watch something that is moving or changing. I asked him to look at the picture above his bed... He watched Blake run down the stairs.']

sentence: Do you want to be found washed up on the seashore with a few vital bits missing ?
gloss: Have a desire to possess or do (something); wish for.
eg_sent: I want an apple
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont, no passive] ; If you want something, you feel a desire or a need for it. ;
exps_collins: ['I want a drink.', 'Ian knows exactly what he wants in life.', 'People wanted to know who this talented designer was.', 'They began to want their father to be the same as other daddies.', "They didn't want people staring at them as they sat on the lawn, so they put up high walls.", 'He wanted his power recognised.', 'I want my car this colour.', 'And remember, we want him alive.', "Note that want and wish have similar meanings, but are used differently. If you want something, you feel a need for it or a desire to have it. You can say that you want to do something, that you want someone to do something, or that you want something to happen. If you use wish with a 'to' infinitive, this has the same meaning as want but is more formal. I want to get out of here... She wished to consult him about her future."]
bis_def_longman: to have a desire for something
exps_longman: ['I really want a drink.', 'What do you want for your birthday?', 'She’d always wanted to go to Thailand.', 'I don’t want Linda to  hear about this.', 'He didn’t want the holiday to end.', 'You can order whatever you want.', 'This shampoo is mild enough to use every day if you want.', 'If she doesn’t get what she wants, she’s not happy.', 'He wanted that job so badly he was willing to kill for it.', 'They desperately wanted a son.', 'What I want to know is when we’re going to get paid.', 'All I want is the chance to prove myself.', 'Oh thank you, it’s just what I’ve always wanted.']

exps_oxford_advanced: ['Do you want some more tea?', "She's always wanted a large family.", 'All I want is the truth.', "Thanks for the present—it's just what I wanted.", 'I can do whatever I want.', 'The last thing I wanted was to upset you.', 'The party wants her as leader.', 'What do you want to do tomorrow?', "‘It's time you did your homework.’ ‘I don't want to!’", 'There are two points which I wanted to make.', 'I just wanted to know if everything was all right.', 'You can come too, if you want.', 'Do you want me to help?', "We didn't want this to happen.", 'I want it (to be) done as quickly as possible.', "I don't want you coming home so late.", 'Do you want your coffee black or white?']

sentence: We shall elaborate on this simple division below but suggest here that the wealth of literature on the former ( see , for instance , Burton et al. 1978 and Perry 1981 ) has yet to be matched by a similar volume of work on the latter .
gloss: Perceive with the eyes; discern visually.
eg_sent: in the distance she could see the blue sea
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont] ; When you see something, you notice it using your eyes. ;
exps_collins: ["You can't see colours at night.", 'I saw a man making his way towards me.', 'She can see, hear, touch, smell, and taste.', 'As he neared the farm, he saw that a police car was parked outside it.', 'Did you see what happened?', 'You use see to talk about things that you are aware of because a visual impression reaches your eyes. You often use can in this case. I can see the fax here on the desk. If you want to say that someone is paying attention to something they can see, you say that they are looking at it or watching it. In general, you look at something that is not moving, while you watch something that is moving or changing. I asked him to look at the picture above his bed... He watched Blake run down the stairs.']

bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont]  If you understand someone or understand what they are saying, you know what they mean.
exps_collins: ['I think you heard and also understand me.', 'Rusty nodded as though she understood the old woman.', "I don't understand what you are talking about.", 'He was speaking poor English, trying to make himself understood.']
bis_def_longman: to know the meaning of what someone is telling you, or the language that they speak
exps_longman: ['She doesn’t understand English.', 'I’m sorry, I don’t understand. Can you explain that again?', 'The woman had a strong accent, and I couldn’t understand what she was saying.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to know or realize the meaning of words, a language, what somebody says, etc.
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Can you understand French?', 'Do you understand the instructions?', "She didn't understand the form she was signing.", "I'm not sure that I understand. Go over it again.", "I don't want you doing that again. Do you understand?", "I don't understand what he's saying."]

sentence: As George Graham indicated upon his side 's accession to the title , they would need more composure and sophistication to match Liverpool in the longer term .
gloss: Correspond or cause to correspond in some essential respect; make or be harmonious.
eg_sent: I thought we'd have primrose walls to match the bath
bis_def_collins: V-RECIP-ERG  …… If something of a particular colour or design matches another thing, they have the same colour or design, or have a pleasing appearance when they are used together. ……
exps_collins: ['Her nails were painted bright red to match her dress.', 'All the chairs matched.', "You don't have to match your lipstick exactly to your outfit.", 'Mix and match your tableware and textiles from the new Design House collection.', 'The pillow cover can match up with the sheets.', "Because false eyelashes come in various lengths and shades, it's so easy to match them up with your own."]
bis_def_longman: if one thing matches another, or if two things match, they look attractive together because they are a similar colour, pattern etc
exps_longman: ['We painted the cabinets green to match the rug.', 'Do you think this outfit matches?', 'a beech dining table with four chairs to match ']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: if two things match, or if one thing matches another, they have the same colour, pattern, or style and therefore look attractive together
exps_oxford_advanced: ['The doors were painted blue to match the walls.', 'a scarf with gloves to match', 'None of these glasses match (= they are all different).']

sentence: If there are small children in the equation , there will need to be a flat , soft area where they can fall off swings and climbing frames .
gloss: Move from a higher to a lower level, typically rapidly and without control.

bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; If someone or something falls, they move quickly downwards onto or towards the ground, by accident or because of a natural force. ;;
exps_collins: ['Her father fell into the sea after a massive heart attack.', 'Prince Charles has again fallen from his horse.', 'Bombs fell in the town.', "I ought to seal the boxes up. I don't want the books falling out.", 'Twenty people were injured by falling masonry.']
bis_def_longman: to move or drop down from a higher position to a lower position

sentence: What was surely the last ever Montenegrin royal event was masterminded by the republic 's new Communist leadership , which has abruptly stopped describing Nicholas as a class enemy , to ride the same wave of popular patriotism and royal fervour which swept Serbia in the recent celebrations of the 600th anniversary of the battle of Kosovo .
gloss: Clean (an area) by brushing away dirt or litter.

sentence: so whether they think , well so it 's after six months ,
gloss: Have a particular opinion, belief, or idea about someone or something.
eg_sent: she thought that nothing would be the same again
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont] ; If you think that something is the case, you have the opinion that it is the case. ; [Also VERB n to-infinitive]
exps_collins: ['I certainly think there should be a ban on tobacco advertising.', 'Do you think I ought to seal the boxes up?.', 'A generation ago, it was thought that babies born this small could not survive.', 'Tell me, what do you think of my theory?.', 'Peter is useless, far worse than I thought.', 'He manages a good deal better than I thought possible.', "'It ought to be stopped.' — 'Yes, I think so.'"]
bis_def_longman: to have a particular opinion or to believe that something is true
exps_longman: ['I think that you’re being unfair.', 'I thought I heard something.', 'He didn’t think anyone would believe him.', 'Do you think I should call him?', 'For some reason, I keep thinking it’s Friday today.', 'The recession lasted longer than anyone thought it would.', 'Am I right in thinking that you have a brother?', 'I can’t help thinking that he’s made a mistake.', 'Do you honestly think I would do something so stupid?', 'What do you think of your new school?', 'I thought it best to call first.', 'I thought it appropriate to invite her to speak at the meeting.', 'We must start thinking in terms of reducing costs.', 'Fraud is thought to be costing software companies millions of dollars a year.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have a particular idea or opinion about something/somebody; to believe something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Do you think (that) they’ll come?', 'I thought I heard a scream.', "I didn't think you liked sports.", 'Am I right in thinking that you used to live here?', "I think this is their house, but I'm not sure.", 'He ought to resign, I think.', "We'll need about 20 chairs, I should think.", 'It was once thought that the sun travelled around the earth.', 'What did you think about the idea?', 'Well, I like it. What do you think?', '‘Will we make it in time?’ ‘I think so.’', "‘Is he any good?’ ‘I don't think so.’", "I think it highly unlikely that I'll get the job.", 'She thought him kind and generous.', "He's thought to be one of the richest men in Europe."]

sentence: Almost a third of group profits are earned overseas , interest and tax charges are down on last year and gearing stands at 13 per cent .

exps_longman: ['He earns nearly £20,000 a year.', 'You don’t earn much money being a nurse.', 'He did all sorts of jobs to earn a living.', 'I was the only person in the house who was earning.', 'She was earning good money at the bank.', 'Chris will pay – he’s earning a fortune.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to get money for work that you do

sentence: but I said no , this time I said
gloss: Utter words so as to convey information, an opinion, a feeling or intention, or an instruction.

bis_def_collins: VERB  ; When you say something, you speak words. ; [Also VERB to-infinitive]
exps_collins: ["'I'm sorry,' he said.", 'She said they were very impressed.', 'Forty-one people are said to have been seriously hurt.', 'I packed and said goodbye to Charlie.', "I hope you didn't say anything about Gretchen.", "You didn't say much when you telephoned.", 'Did he say where he was going?.', "It doesn't sound exactly orthodox, if I may say so."]

exps_longman: ['‘Don’t cry, ’ he said softly.', 'Don’t believe anything he says.', 'A spokesman said that the company had improved its safety standards.', 'I always said I would buy a motorbike when I had enough money.', 'Did she say what happened?', 'I would like to say how much we appreciate your hard work.', '‘Why did she leave?’ ‘I don’t know – she didn’t say.’', 'What did you say to her?', 'What a silly thing to say!', 'She left without saying goodbye.', 'I’ve said I’m sorry – what more do you want?', 'Can I go, Mum? Oh, please say yes!', 'He looked as if he was going to say something.', 'I wished I had said nothing about Jordi.', 'Does anyone else have anything to say?', 'Although he didn’t say so, it was clear that he was in pain.', 'What makes you say that (=why do you think that) ? 你怎么会那么说呢？', 'Nina said to meet her at 4.30.', 'I’d like to say a few words.', '‘So what are your plans now?’ ‘I’d rather not say.’']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to speak or tell somebody something, using words
exps_oxford_advanced: ['‘Hello!’ she said.', '‘That was marvellous,’ said Daniel.', 'Be quiet, I have something to say.', "I didn't believe a word she said.", "That's a terrible thing to say.", "He knew that if he wasn't back by midnight, his parents would have something to say about it (= be angry).", 'She said nothing to me about it.', "I said to myself (= thought), ‘That can't be right!’", 'He said (that) his name was Sam.', 'It is said that she lived to be over 100.', 'She finds it hard to say what she feels.', "‘That's impossible!’ ‘So you say (= but I think you may be wrong).’", "‘Why can't I go out now?’ ‘Because I say so.’", "‘What do you want it for?’ ‘I'd rather not say.’", 'He said to meet him here.', 'He is said to have been a brilliant scholar.']

sentence: Parents also wanted an increased availability of specialist therapy time , but wanted it to be used in a more flexible way .
gloss: Take, hold, or deploy (something) as a means of accomplishing or achieving something; employ.
eg_sent: she used her key to open the front door
bis_def_collins: If you use something, you do something with it in order to do a job or to achieve a particular result or effect.  [written]
exps_collins: ['Trim off the excess pastry using a sharp knife.', 'He had simply used a little imagination.', 'Officials used loud hailers to call for calm.', "The show uses Zondo's trial and execution as its framework."]
bis_def_longman: if you use a particular tool, method, service, ability etc, you do something with that tool, by means of that method etc, for a particular purpose
exps_longman: ['Can I use your phone?', 'I’ll show you which room you can use.', 'I always use the same shampoo.', 'She booked the flight using a false name.', 'Drop-down menus make the program very easy to use.', 'They were using animals for scientific experiments.', 'Bob uses the van for picking up groceries.', 'My parents use the house as a holiday home.', 'Most people now use their cars to go shopping.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to do something with a machine, a method, an object, etc. for a particular purpose
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Can I use your phone?', 'Have you ever used this software before?', 'How often do you use (= travel by) the bus?', 'They were able to achieve a settlement without using military force.', 'The applicator makes the glue easy to use.', 'The oven looked as if it had never been used.', 'I have some information you may be able to use (= to get an advantage from).', 'We used a carrot for the snowman’s nose.', 'The blue files are used for storing old invoices.', 'Police used tear gas to disperse the crowds.', 'The building is currently being used as a warehouse.', "You can't keep using your bad back as an excuse."]

sentence: Walking here , you leave the 20th century behind on the outskirts of the forest and enter the reconstructed emptiness in which the reivers and cross-border raiders of the past could operate unhindered .
gloss: Go away from.
eg_sent: she left London on June 6
bis_def_collins: If you leave a place or person, you go away from that place or person.

bis_def_longman: to go away from a place or a person
exps_longman: ['My baby gets upset when I leave the room.', 'Before leaving the train, make sure you have all your belongings with you.', 'The plane leaves at 12.30.', 'I tried calling him, but he’d already left for work.', 'If he left immediately, he’d catch the 7.30 train.', 'Frances left work early to meet her mother.', 'Never leave children playing near water unattended.', 'I’ll leave you to it.', 'My youngest boy has not left my side since his daddy was killed.', 'Just a few more questions, then we’ll leave you in peace.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to go away from a person or a place

sentence: getting paid again .
gloss: Give (someone) money that is due for work done, goods received, or a debt incurred.
eg_sent: the traveller paid a guide to show him across
bis_def_collins: When you pay an amount of money to someone, you give it to them because you are buying something from them or because you owe it to them. When you pay something such as a bill or a debt, you pay the amount that you owe.
exps_collins: ['Accommodation is free — all you pay for is breakfast and dinner.', 'We paid £35 for each ticket.', 'The wealthier may have to pay a little more in taxes.', 'He proposes that businesses should pay taxes to the federal government.', 'You can pay by credit card.']
bis_def_longman: to give someone money for something you buy or for a service
exps_longman: ['How would you like to pay?', 'Mum paid for my driving lessons.', 'You’d get a discount for paying cash.', 'Can I pay by credit card?', 'He didn’t even offer to pay me for the ticket.', 'Ray paid some kids to wash the car.', 'I paid him $5 to cut the grass.', 'He wanted to be paid in dollars.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to give somebody money for work, goods, services, etc.
exps_oxford_advanced: ["I'll pay for the tickets.", 'Are you paying in cash or by credit card?', 'My company pays well (= pays high salaries).', 'Her parents paid for her to go to Canada.', 'to pay cash', 'She pays £200 a week for this apartment.', 'Would you mind paying the taxi driver?', "He still hasn't paid me the money he owes me.", "I'm paid $100 a day.", "I don't pay you to sit around all day doing nothing!"]

sentence: Beneath this man-made mechanism of oppression are the people , literally distanced from their surroundings by Kahlo 's use of photo-collage .
gloss: Make (someone or something) far off or remote in position or nature.
eg_sent: her mother wished to distance her from the rough village children
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;…; If you distance yourself from a person or thing, or if something distances you from them, you feel less friendly or positive towards them, or become less involved with them. ;…;
exps_collins: ['The author distanced himself from some of the comments in his book.', 'Television may actually be distancing the public from the war.']
bis_def_longman: to say that you are not involved with someone or something, especially to avoid being connected with them

sentence: Thank you .
gloss: Express gratitude to (someone), especially by saying ‘Thank you’

sentence: You ca n't get away with that any more .
gloss: Come to have (something); receive.
eg_sent: I got a letter from him the other day
bis_def_collins: You use get with adjectives to mean 'become'. For example, if someone gets cold, they become cold, and if they get angry, they become angry.

sentence: Mrs Henry refused the drug treatment given to reduce the chances of a relapse , but there are many who would remain well without it , Dr Slevin said .
gloss: Freely transfer the possession of (something) to (someone)
eg_sent: she gave him presents and clothes
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont]  You can use give with nouns that refer to physical actions. The whole expression refers to the performing of the action. For example, She gave a smile means almost the same as 'She smiled'.

sentence: The frond of this fossil fern is preserved as a compression on the surface of a fine-grained , mica-rich siltstone .
gloss: Maintain (something) in its original or existing state.

bis_def_collins: If you preserve a situation or condition, you make sure that it remains as it is, and does not change or end.

exps_oxford_advanced: ['He was anxious to preserve his reputation.', 'Efforts to preserve the peace have failed.', 'She managed to preserve her sense of humour under very trying circumstances.']

sentence: I agree with you .
gloss: Have the same opinion about something; concur.
eg_sent: I completely agree with your recent editorial
bis_def_collins: V-RECIP  ;; If people agree with each other about something, they have the same opinion about it or say that they have the same opinion. ;;
exps_collins: ["If we agreed all the time it would be a bit boring, wouldn't it?.", 'Both have agreed on the need for the money.', "So we both agree there's a problem?.", "I see your point but I'm not sure I agree with you.", 'I agree with you that the open system is by far the best.', "'It's appalling.' — 'It is. I agree.'.", 'I agree that the demise of London zoo would be terrible.', "I agree with every word you've just said.", "'Frankly I found it rather frightening.' — 'A little startling,' Mark agreed."]

sentence: The poet Marbod of Rennes celebrated ( in Latin ) the vengeance which would befall a wicked castellan and his troops :
gloss: Acknowledge (a significant or happy day or event) with a social gathering or enjoyable activity.

sentence: To help ensure the harmonization and comparability of environmental data in the Community as well as the integration of European environmental data into international environmental monitoring programmes , such as those established within the framework of the United Nations and its system of agencies .

sentence: Link that with Trimmler 's death , Goodenache 's sudden departure for Germany and the mention of the Lucy Ghosts during their conversation , and I think you will agree that is the strongest lead we have to follow .
gloss: Make, form, or suggest a connection with or between.

bis_def_collins: If someone or something links two things or situations, there is a relationship between them, for example because one thing causes or affects the other.  [Also + V n with]
exps_collins: ['The UN Security Council has linked any lifting of sanctions to compliance with the ceasefire terms.', 'The study further strengthens the evidence linking smoking with early death.', 'Liver cancer is linked to the hepatitis B virus.', 'The detention raised two distinct but closely linked questions.']

sentence: Anyway I asked her if she 'd heard from your dad , and she has heard from your dad apparently on Friday he went to the consultant
gloss: Say something in order to obtain an answer or some information.

sentence: Clare almost fainted from surprise and anxiety , horror and shame .

sentence: You go round in the sales , have a look .

Let’s go home.', 'Where are you going?', 'We’re going to Canada in the summer.', 'Dinah went into the kitchen.', 'She went over and put her arm around him.', 'I’m going round to her house to find out what’s wrong.', 'I’ll just go up  and ask him what he wants.']

exps_collins: ['I want a drink.', 'Ian knows exactly what he wants in life.', 'People wanted to know who this talented designer was.', 'They began to want their father to be the same as other daddies.', "They didn't want people staring at them as they sat on the lawn, so they put up high walls.", 'He wanted his power recognised.', 'I want my car this colour.', 'And remember, we want him alive.', "Note that want and wish have similar meanings, but are used differently. If you want something, you feel a need for it or a desire to have it. You can say that you want to do something, that you want someone to do something, or that you want something to happen. If you use wish with a 'to' infinitive, this has the same meaning as want but is more formal. I want to get out of here... She wished to consult him about her future."]

sentence: After seeing him , because he thought that once he 'd seen the consultant it would then take some time to get the treatment started , but they must have got themselves over that .
gloss: Come to have (something); receive.
eg_sent: I got a letter from him the other day

sentence: Let's not argue about something that happened over thirty years ago , Adam said finally .

exps_longman: ['Who knows the answer?', 'There are instructions telling you everything you need to know.', 'Didn’t you know that?', 'Do you know what time it is?', 'I don’t know where to go.', 'I need to know more about the job before I decide whether to apply for it.', 'Little is known about the author’s childhood.', 'I know all about David and what he’s been up to!', 'I wonder if he knew of the plan?', 'Do you know of any good restaurants in the area?', 'You know nothing of this business.', 'We know that greenhouse gases can affect the climate.', 'Let me know what time you’re planning to arrive.', 'I thought you’d want to know immediately.', 'If you must know, I was with James last night .', 'He slipped out of the house without his parents knowing .', 'How did he know our names?', '‘I’m divorced, as you know, ’ she said briefly.', 'Smoking is known to increase a person’s risk of developing lung cancer.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have information in your mind as a result of experience or because you have learned or been told it

sentence: He hesitated .

gloss: Be engaged in physical or mental activity in order to achieve a result; do work.
