bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; People who work have a job, usually one which they are paid to do. ;;
exps_collins: ['Weiner works for the US Department of Transport.', 'I started working in a recording studio.', 'Where do you work?.', "He worked as a bricklayer's mate.", "I want to work, I don't want to be on welfare."]
bis_def_longman: to do a job that you are paid for
exps_longman: ['Where do you work?', 'Many young people in the area have never worked.', 'The injury means he’ll probably never work again.', 'He works for a law firm.', 'I work at the university.', 'She works as a consultant for a design company.', 'The studies were undertaken by people working in education.', 'I work part-time in a library.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to do something that involves physical or mental effort, especially as part of a job
exps_oxford_advanced: ["I can't work if I'm cold.", "I've been working at my assignment all day.", 'He is working on a new novel.', "She's outside, working on the car.", 'Doctors often work very long hours.']

sentence: Lewis asked him if he could remember the day when he heard he had inherited Wyvis Hall and had walked in here and astounded them with his news .
gloss: Say something in order to obtain an answer or some information.
eg_sent: I asked her what she meant
bis_def_collins: If you ask someone something, you say something to them in the form of a question because you want to know the answer.  [Also V about n]
exps_collins: ["'How is Frank?' he asked.", 'I asked him his name.', "I wasn't the only one asking questions.", "She asked me if I'd enjoyed my dinner.", 'If Daniel asks what happened in court we will tell him.', 'You will have to ask David about that.', "'I'm afraid to ask what it cost.' — 'Then don't ask.'"]
bis_def_longman: to speak or write to someone in order to get an answer, information, or a solution
exps_longman: ['‘What’s your name?’ she asked.', 'Don’t ask him – he won’t know.', 'That kid’s always asking awkward questions.', 'I asked him where he lived.', 'We’ll have to ask someone the way to the station.', 'Go and ask Tom whether he’s coming tonight.', 'Visitors usually ask about the history of the castle.', 'I’ll ask around, see if I can find you a place to stay.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to say or write something in the form of a question, in order to get information
exps_oxford_advanced: ['How old are you—if you don’t mind me/my asking?', 'He asked about her family.', 'Can I ask a question?', 'Did you ask the price?', '‘Where are you going?’ she asked.', '‘Are you sure?’ he asked her.', 'She asked the students their names.', 'I often get asked that!', 'The interviewer asked me about my future plans.', 'He asked where I lived.', 'I had to ask the teacher what to do next.', 'I was asked if/whether I could drive.']

sentence: In some instances such data will suffice ; in many cases they will have to suffice as nothing better is available .
gloss: Be enough or adequate.
eg_sent: a quick look should suffice
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont] ; If you say that something will suffice, you mean it will be enough to achieve a purpose or to fulfil a need. ; [formal] [Also VERB to-infinitive]
exps_collins: ['A cover letter should never exceed one page; often a far shorter letter will suffice.']
bis_def_longman: to be enough
exps_longman: ['A light lunch will suffice.', 'A few brief observations will suffice for present purposes.', 'A few more statistics will suffice to show the trends of the time.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to be enough for somebody/something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Generally a brief note or a phone call will suffice.', 'One example will suffice to illustrate the point.']

sentence: You do n't want to walk where ?
gloss: Have a desire to possess or do (something); wish for.
eg_sent: I want an apple
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont, no passive] ; If you want something, you feel a desire or a need for it. ;
exps_collins: ['I want a drink.', 'Ian knows exactly what he wants in life.', 'People wanted to know who this talented designer was.', 'They began to want their father to be the same as other daddies.', "They didn't want people staring at them as they sat on the lawn, so they put up high walls.", 'He wanted his power recognised.', 'I want my car this colour.', 'And remember, we want him alive.', "Note that want and wish have similar meanings, but are used differently. If you want something, you feel a need for it or a desire to have it. You can say that you want to do something, that you want someone to do something, or that you want something to happen. If you use wish with a 'to' infinitive, this has the same meaning as want but is more formal. I want to get out of here... She wished to consult him about her future."]
bis_def_longman: to have a desire for something
exps_longman: ['I really want a drink.', 'What do you want for your birthday?', 'She’d always wanted to go to Thailand.', 'I don’t want Linda to  hear about this.', 'He didn’t want the holiday to end.', 'You can order whatever you want.', 'This shampoo is mild enough to use every day if you want.', 'If she doesn’t get what she wants, she’s not happy.', 'He wanted that job so badly he was willing to kill for it.', 'They desperately wanted a son.', 'What I want to know is when we’re going to get paid.', 'All I want is the chance to prove myself.', 'Oh thank you, it’s just what I’ve always wanted.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have a desire or a wish for something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Do you want some more tea?', "She's always wanted a large family.", 'All I want is the truth.', "Thanks for the present—it's just what I wanted.", 'I can do whatever I want.', 'The last thing I wanted was to upset you.', 'The party wants her as leader.', 'What do you want to do tomorrow?', "‘It's time you did your homework.’ ‘I don't want to!’", 'There are two points which I wanted to make.', 'I just wanted to know if everything was all right.', 'You can come too, if you want.', 'Do you want me to help?', "We didn't want this to happen.", 'I want it (to be) done as quickly as possible.', "I don't want you coming home so late.", 'Do you want your coffee black or white?']

sentence: You let me go rabitting on .
Labour would be acquiescing in a democratic outrage if it continued arguing that , because the Conservatives had got away with being undemocratic for so long , it was now Labour 's turn .
gloss: Give reasons or cite evidence in support of an idea, action, or theory, typically with the aim of persuading others to share one's view.
eg_sent: sociologists argue that inequalities in industrial societies are being reduced
bis_def_collins: V-RECIP  ; If one person argues with another, they speak angrily to each other about something that they disagree about. You can also say that two people argue . ; [Also V + about/over]
exps_collins: ["The committee is concerned about players' behaviour, especially arguing with referees.", 'They were still arguing; I could hear them down the road.']
bis_def_longman: to disagree with someone in words, often in an angry way
exps_longman: ['Gallacher continued to argue with the referee throughout the game.', 'They were arguing about how to spend the money.', 'The children were arguing over which TV programme to watch.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to speak angrily to somebody because you disagree with them
exps_oxford_advanced: ['My brothers are always arguing.', "He's offering to pay so who am I to argue?", "We're always arguing with each other about money.", "I don't want to argue with you—just do it!"]

sentence: If she has vanished , I 'm going to see that solicitor about whether I can get her presumed dead .
gloss: Disappear suddenly and completely.
eg_sent: Moira vanished without trace
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; If someone or something vanishes, they disappear suddenly or in a way that cannot be explained. ;;
exps_collins: ['He just vanished and was never seen again.', 'The aircraft vanished without trace.', 'Anne vanished from outside her home last Wednesday.', 'The gunmen paused only to cut the wires to the house, then vanished into the countryside.']
bis_def_longman: to disappear suddenly, especially in a way that cannot be easily explained
exps_longman: ['My keys were here a minute ago but now they’ve vanished.', 'The youngster vanished without a trace one day and has never been found.', 'The bird vanished from sight.', 'She seemed to have just vanished into thin air.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to disappear suddenly and/or in a way that you cannot explain
exps_oxford_advanced: ['He turned around and vanished into the house.', 'The magician vanished in a puff of smoke.', 'My glasses seem to have vanished.', 'He vanished without trace.']

sentence: I 'll give you a ring .
gloss: Freely transfer the possession of (something) to (someone)
eg_sent: she gave him presents and clothes
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont]  You can use give with nouns that refer to physical actions. The whole expression refers to the performing of the action. For example, She gave a smile means almost the same as 'She smiled'.
exps_collins: ['She stretched her arms out and gave a great yawn.', 'Giving a sigh, she fell to her knees at my feet.', 'He gave her a fond smile.', 'He reached for her hand and gave it a reassuring squeeze.']
bis_def_longman: to let someone have something as a present, or to provide something for someone
exps_longman: ['What did Bob give you for your birthday?', 'Researchers were given a £10,000 grant to continue their work.', 'I’ve got some old diaries that my grandmother gave me years ago.', 'a ring which was given to him by his mother', 'I didn’t steal it! Maria gave it to me!', 'Most people are willing to give to charity.', 'The situation is now desperate, so please give generously.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to hand something to somebody so that they can look at it, use it or keep it for a time
exps_oxford_advanced: ["Give the letter to your mother when you've read it.", 'She gave her ticket to the woman at the check-in desk.', 'Give your mother the letter.', 'They were all given a box to carry.']

sentence: All this formed a background to the first century of crusading ; and it goes some way to explaining the more secular aspects of the magnetism which drew French knights to take up the cross in their thousands .
gloss: Bring together parts or combine to create (something)
eg_sent: the company was formed in 1982
bis_def_collins: V-ERG  ;();… When a particular shape forms or is formed, people or things move or are arranged so that this shape is made. ;();… [Also VERB n + into]
exps_collins: ["A queue forms outside Peter's study.", "They formed a circle and sang 'Auld Lang Syne'.", 'The General gave orders for the cadets to form into lines.']
bis_def_longman: to establish an organization, committee, government etc
exps_longman: ['The winning party will form the government.', 'CARE was formed in 1946 and helps the poor in 38 countries.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to begin to exist and gradually develop into a particular shape; to make something begin to exist in a particular shape
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Flowers appeared, but fruits failed to form.', 'Storm clouds are forming on the horizon.', 'These hills were formed by glaciation.']

sentence: And you 've got the heater here over in the corner as well so it 's gon na
gloss: Come to have (something); receive.
eg_sent: I got a letter from him the other day

sentence: It 's cheaper than phoning is n't it ?

sentence: In this one can draw obvious parallels to the appeal of Van Gogh , a traditionally popular artist recently made fashionable by the media attention generated during the centennial of his death .
gloss: Produce (a picture or diagram) by making lines and marks on paper with a pencil, pen, etc.
eg_sent: he drew a map
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; When you draw, or when you draw something, you use a pencil or pen to produce a picture, pattern, or diagram. ;;
exps_collins: ['She would sit there drawing with the pencil stub.', 'Draw a rough design for a logo.', 'He starts a painting by quickly drawing simplified shapes.']
bis_def_longman: to produce a picture of something using a pencil, pen etc
exps_longman: ['Katie had drawn a cottage with a little stream running next to it.', 'She asked the little girl to draw a picture of the man she’d spoken to.', 'Keith was drawing a complicated-looking graph.', 'I’ve never been able to draw very well.', 'Can you draw me a map of how to get there?']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to make pictures, or a picture of something, with a pencil, pen or chalk (but not paint)
exps_oxford_advanced: ['You draw beautifully.', 'to draw a picture/diagram/graph', 'She drew a house.', 'He drew a circle in the sand with a stick.', 'The report drew a grim picture of inefficiency and corruption.']

sentence: You get used to it .
gloss: Take, hold, or deploy (something) as a means of accomplishing or achieving something; employ.
eg_sent: she used her key to open the front door
bis_def_collins: If you use something, you do something with it in order to do a job or to achieve a particular result or effect.  [written]
exps_collins: ['Trim off the excess pastry using a sharp knife.', 'He had simply used a little imagination.', 'Officials used loud hailers to call for calm.', "The show uses Zondo's trial and execution as its framework."]
bis_def_longman: if you use a particular tool, method, service, ability etc, you do something with that tool, by means of that method etc, for a particular purpose
exps_longman: ['Can I use your phone?', 'I’ll show you which room you can use.', 'I always use the same shampoo.', 'She booked the flight using a false name.', 'Drop-down menus make the program very easy to use.', 'They were using animals for scientific experiments.', 'Bob uses the van for picking up groceries.', 'My parents use the house as a holiday home.', 'Most people now use their cars to go shopping.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to do something with a machine, a method, an object, etc. for a particular purpose
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Can I use your phone?', 'Have you ever used this software before?', 'How often do you use (= travel by) the bus?', 'They were able to achieve a settlement without using military force.', 'The applicator makes the glue easy to use.', 'The oven looked as if it had never been used.', 'I have some information you may be able to use (= to get an advantage from).', 'We used a carrot for the snowman’s nose.', 'The blue files are used for storing old invoices.', 'Police used tear gas to disperse the crowds.', 'The building is currently being used as a warehouse.', "You can't keep using your bad back as an excuse."]

sentence: The tiny single room was jammed with the mossy timbers of disused sheep pens , but the little iron fire grate that once warmed the hardy men who worked here was still set in the foot of the hut 's tottering gable end , and the massive stone lintel had not yet fallen from its place above the doorway .
gloss: Move in a feeble or unsteady way.
eg_sent: a hunched figure was tottering down the path
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; If someone totters somewhere, they walk there in an unsteady way, for example because they are ill or drunk. ;;
exps_collins: ['He tottered to the fridge, got a beer and slumped at the table.', 'The baby began to crawl, then managed her first tottering steps.']
bis_def_longman: to walk or move unsteadily from side to side as if you are going to fall over
exps_longman: ['Lorrimer swayed a little, tottered, and fell.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to walk or move with weak unsteady steps, especially because you are drunk or ill/sick
exps_oxford_advanced: ['She managed to totter back to her seat.']

sentence: Many people have suffered from sales falling through and from house-buying chains , and some of our vendors feel that now 's as good a time as any to sell .
gloss: Be aware of (a person or object) through touching or being touched.
eg_sent: she felt someone touch her shoulder
bis_def_collins: V-LINK  ;; If you feel a particular emotion or physical sensation, you experience it. ;;
exps_collins: ['I am feeling very depressed.', 'I will always feel grateful to that little guy.', 'I remember feeling sick.', '...soldiers who once felt proud to wear their uniforms.', 'Suddenly I felt a sharp pain in my shoulder.', "You won't feel a thing.", 'I felt as if all my strength had gone.', 'I felt like I was being kicked in the teeth every day.']
bis_def_longman: to experience a particular physical feeling or emotion
exps_longman: ['Do you still feel hungry?', 'You can never tell what he’s feeling.', 'Stop exercising if you feel any pain.', 'I’m feeling a little better today.']

sentence: But the structure and functioning of grinding or chewing teeth in other mammals , in which opposing teeth co-operate in action , and which can be matched in extinct , unrelated mammals , is a much more subtle matter , involving detailed studies on the operation of living dental systems to help elucidate the functioning of fossil ones .
gloss: Make (something) clear; explain.
eg_sent: work such as theirs will help to elucidate this matter
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; If you elucidate something, you make it clear and easy to understand. ; [formal]
exps_collins: ['Haig went on to elucidate his personal principle of war.', 'There was no need for him to elucidate.']
bis_def_longman: to explain something that is difficult to understand by providing more information
exps_longman: ['The full picture has not yet been elucidated.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to make something clearer by explaining it more fully
exps_oxford_advanced: ['He elucidated a point of grammar.', 'The aim of the report is to elucidate the main points of the new regulations.', 'Let me elucidate.', 'I will try to elucidate what I think the problems are.']

sentence: His noble gesture appeased those churchmen who had been appalled by his early obstinacy over the archbishopric of Bourges .
gloss: Pacify or placate (someone) by acceding to their demands.
eg_sent: amendments have been added to appease local pressure groups
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; If you try to appease someone, you try to stop them from being angry by giving them what they want. ;; [disapproval]
exps_collins: ['Gandhi was accused by some of trying to appease both factions of the electorate.', 'The offer has not appeased separatists.']
bis_def_longman: to make someone less angry or stop them from attacking you by giving them what they want
exps_longman: ['They attempted to appease international opposition by promising to hold talks.', 'Chamberlain’s policy of appeasement towards Hitler in the 30s']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to make somebody calmer or less angry by giving them what they want
exps_oxford_advanced: ['The move was widely seen as an attempt to appease critics of the regime.']

sentence: Er mum it does n't matter where everything 's got milk on does it ?
gloss: Be important or significant.
eg_sent: it doesn't matter what the guests wear
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont] ;; If you say that something does not matter, you mean that it is not important to you because it does not have an effect on you or on a particular situation. ;;
bis_def_longman: to be important, especially to be important to you, or to have an effect on what happens
exps_longman: ['Will it matter if I’m a little late?', 'If I have to stay late at work tonight, it won’t matter because we can go out another night.', 'It doesn’t matter what you wear, as long as you look neat and tidy.', 'Does it matter what I think?', 'It does not matter that the gun was in fact unloaded.', 'Do you think it matters that the cups and saucers don’t match?', 'Just give me $5 – it doesn’t matter about the rest.', 'He had lost many of the people who mattered to him.', 'It mattered a great deal to her what other people thought of her.', 'I don’t think it matters much what you study.', 'campaigning on issues that really matter', 'All that matters is that you are safe.', 'Money was the only thing which mattered to him.', 'I don’t care what it looks like – what matters is that it works.', 'At last she was with the man she loved and nothing else mattered.', 'She said very little during the meal. Not that it mattered.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to be important or have an important effect on somebody/something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['The children matter more to her than anything else in the world.', "‘What did you say?’ ‘Oh, it doesn't matter’ (= it is not important enough to repeat).", "‘I'm afraid I forgot that book again.’ ‘It doesn't matter (= it is not important enough to worry about).’", "What does it matter if I spent $100 on it—it's my money!", "As long as you're happy, that's all that matters.", 'After his death, nothing seemed to matter any more.', "He's been in prison, you know—not that it matters (= that information does not affect my opinion of him).", 'Does it really matter who did it?', "It doesn't matter to me what you do.", "It didn't matter that the weather was bad."]

sentence: Against Chamberlain it was remembered that he was a Liberal Unionist ( as was Lansdowne , who led the Unionists in the Lords ) and that he had not been entirely loyal to Balfour since the referendum pledge .
gloss: Have in or be able to bring to one's mind an awareness of (someone or something from the past)
eg_sent: I remember the screech of the horn as the car came towards me
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; If you remember people or events from the past, you still have an idea of them in your mind and you are able to think about them. ;;
exps_collins: ["You wouldn't remember me. I was in another group.", "I certainly don't remember talking to you at all.", 'I remember her being a dominant figure.', 'I remembered that we had drunk the last of the coffee the week before.', 'I can remember where and when I bought each one.', 'I used to do that when you were a little girl, remember?']
bis_def_longman: to have a picture or idea in your mind of people, events, places etc from the past
exps_longman: ['Do you remember Rosa Davies?', 'I can’t remember her exact words.', 'I remember you two couldn’t stand each other at first!', 'I remember meeting her at a party once.', 'I remember my father bringing home a huge Christmas tree.', 'I remember it well; I’d never seen my mother so angry.', 'She clearly remembers the excitement as they boarded the train.', 'I vaguely remember reading something about it in the paper.', 'They had three children, if I remember rightly.', 'They’ve lived here for as long as I can remember.', 'No one got drunk as far as I can remember.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have or keep an image in your memory of an event, a person, a place, etc. from the past
exps_oxford_advanced: ['This is Carla. Do you remember her?', "I don't remember my first day at school.", "He still remembered her as the lively teenager he'd known years before.", "As far as I can remember, this is the third time we've met.", 'Do you remember switching the lights off before we came out?', 'I vaguely remember hearing him come in.', 'I can still vividly remember my grandfather teaching me to play cards.', "I can't remember his taking a single day off work.", 'I remember (that) we used to go and see them most weekends.']

sentence: But the Government did find a way of accepting a link between the riots and social problems without bringing its main policies into the debate : namely by linking the growth of violent disorder to crime and drugs .
gloss: Take or go with (someone or something) to a place.

bis_def_oxford_advanced: to come to a place with somebody/something
exps_oxford_advanced: ["Don't forget to bring your books with you.", 'She brought her boyfriend to the party.', 'Bring a present for Helen.', 'Bring Helen a present.']

sentence: It is a stylised drama with understated dialogue that depends on recognition of key words and concepts .
gloss: Describe or represent (something) as being smaller or less good or important than it really is.
eg_sent: the press have understated the extent of the problem
bis_def_collins: VERB  … If you understate something, you describe it in a way that suggests that it is less important or serious than it really is. …
exps_collins: ['The government chooses deliberately to understate the increase in prices.', 'That understates my commitment to the orchestra.']
bis_def_longman: to describe something in a way that makes it seem less important or serious than it really is
exps_longman: ['The press have tended to understate the extent of the problem.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to state that something is smaller, less important or less serious than it really is
exps_oxford_advanced: ['It would be a mistake to understate the seriousness of the problem.', 'The figures probably understate the real unemployment rate.', 'To say that the reviews were mixed is to understate the case—the cons far outweighed the pros.']

sentence: I 'm here , just tell me if you want anything else shifted .
gloss: Communicate information to someone in spoken or written words.
eg_sent: I told her you were coming
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; If you tell someone something, you give them information. ; [Also V of n]
exps_collins: ['In the evening I returned to tell Phyllis our relationship was over.', 'I called Andie to tell her how spectacular the stuff looked.', 'Claire had made me promise to tell her the truth.', 'I only told the truth to the press when the single was released as it seemed the perfect time to do it.', 'Tell us about your moment on the summit.', "Her voice breaking with emotion, she told him: 'It doesn't seem fair'."]

sentence: Just too late I see .
gloss: Perceive with the eyes; discern visually.

exps_collins: ["You can't see colours at night.", 'I saw a man making his way towards me.', 'She can see, hear, touch, smell, and taste.', 'As he neared the farm, he saw that a police car was parked outside it.', 'Did you see what happened?', 'You use see to talk about things that you are aware of because a visual impression reaches your eyes. You often use can in this case. I can see the fax here on the desk. If you want to say that someone is paying attention to something they can see, you say that they are looking at it or watching it. In general, you look at something that is not moving, while you watch something that is moving or changing. I asked him to look at the picture above his bed... He watched Blake run down the stairs.']

gloss: Direct one's gaze toward someone or something or in a specified direction.
eg_sent: people were looking at him
bis_def_collins: If you look in a particular direction, you direct your eyes in that direction, especially so that you can see what is there or see what something is like.
exps_collins: ['I looked down the hallway to room number nine.', 'She turned to look at him.', 'He looked away, apparently enraged.', "If you look, you'll see what was a lake.", 'If you want to say that someone is paying attention to something they can see, you say that they are looking at it or watching it. In general, you look at something that is not moving, while you watch something that is moving or changing. I asked him to look at the picture above his bed... He watched Blake run down the stairs. Look is never followed directly by an object. You must always use at or some other preposition. I looked towards the plane. You use see to talk about things that you are aware of because a visual impression reaches your eyes. You often use can in this case. I can see the fax here on the desk.']
bis_def_longman: to turn your eyes towards something, so that you can see it
exps_longman: ['We sneaked out while Jessie’s mom wasn’t looking.', 'If you look carefully you can see that the painting represents a human figure.', 'Gina covered her eyes, afraid to look.', '‘It’s time we left, ’ Ian said, looking at his watch.', 'The men all turned to look at her as she entered the room.', 'Dad looked up from his paper and smiled.', '‘We can’t go out in this weather, ’ said Bob, looking out of the window.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to turn your eyes in a particular direction
exps_oxford_advanced: ['If you look carefully you can just see our house from here.', 'She looked at me and smiled.', "‘Has the mail come yet?’ ‘I'll look and see.’", "Look! I'm sure that's Brad Pitt!", "Don't look now, but there's someone staring at you!"]

sentence: At present , the executive takes decisions to release some murderers after only a few years and to keep others in prison for extremely long periods .
gloss: Have or retain possession of.
eg_sent: return one copy to me, keeping the other for your files
bis_def_collins: If someone keeps or is kept in a particular state, they remain in it.
exps_collins: ['The noise kept him awake.', 'Reggie was being kept busy behind the bar.', 'To keep warm they burnt wood in a rusty oil barrel.', 'For several years I kept in touch with her.']
bis_def_longman: to stay in a particular state, condition, or position, or to make someone or something do this
exps_longman: ['We huddled around the fire to keep warm.', 'I was struggling to keep awake.', 'some toys to keep the kids amused', 'You won’t be able to keep it secret forever.', 'Peter cycles to work to keep fit.', 'Don’t keep us in suspense any longer!', 'The police put up barriers to keep the crowds back.', 'If I were you, I’d keep away from that area at night.', 'The little boy kept close to his mother.', 'You keep out of this, Mother . It’s no concern of yours.', 'How can I cut your hair if you won’t keep still!', 'Jane kept the engine running.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to stay in a particular condition or position; to make somebody/something do this
exps_oxford_advanced: ['We huddled together to keep warm.', 'The notice said ‘Keep off (= Do not walk on) the grass’.', 'Keep left along the wall.', 'She kept the children amused for hours.', 'He kept his coat on.', "Don't keep us in suspense—what happened next?", 'She had trouble keeping her balance.', "I'm very sorry to keep you waiting."]

sentence: Now you 've got ta get your coat on .
gloss: Come to have (something); receive.
eg_sent: I got a letter from him the other day
bis_def_collins: You use get with adjectives to mean 'become'. For example, if someone gets cold, they become cold, and if they get angry, they become angry.
exps_collins: ['The boys were getting bored.', "There's no point in getting upset.", 'From here on, it can only get better.']
bis_def_longman: to receive something that someone gives you or sends you
exps_longman: ['She got loads of presents.', 'What did you get for Christmas?', 'We get a lot of junk mail.', 'We got a letter from Pam this morning.', 'I got it off my Dad.', 'I got a few games free when I bought my computer.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to receive something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['I got a letter from Dave this morning.', 'What (= What presents) did you get for your birthday?', 'He gets (= earns) about $40\u2009000 a year.', 'This room gets very little sunshine.', 'I got a shock when I saw the bill.', 'I get the impression that he is bored with his job.']

sentence: At its most simple , La Chingada , as the mother of Mestizo culture is the Mother forcibly opened , violated or deceived .
gloss: Deliberately cause (someone) to believe something that is not true, especially for personal gain.
eg_sent: I didn't intend to deceive people into thinking it was French champagne
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; If you deceive someone, you make them believe something that is not true, usually in order to get some advantage for yourself. ;
exps_collins: ['He has deceived and disillusioned us all.', "If you can make the last 10 seconds exciting, you can deceive your audience into thinking it's been like that all along."]
bis_def_longman: to make someone believe something that is not true
exps_longman: ['He had been deceived by a young man claiming to be the son of a millionaire.', 'He tried to deceive the public into thinking the war could still be won.', 'I wouldn’t deceive you about anything as important as this.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to make somebody believe something that is not true
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Her husband had been deceiving her for years.', 'She deceived him into handing over all his savings.']

sentence: They held their line and competed hard in midfield , damping down Oldham 's initial verve and preparing themselves for more of the same in the second half .
gloss: Strive to gain or win something by defeating or establishing superiority over others.
eg_sent: universities are competing for applicants
bis_def_collins: When one firm or country competes with another, it tries to get people to buy its own goods in preference to those of the other firm or country. You can also say that two firms or countries compete .  [Also VERB]
exps_collins: ["The banks have long competed with American Express's charge cards and various store cards.", 'The stores will inevitably end up competing with each other in their push for increased market shares.', 'Banks and building societies are competing fiercely for business.', 'The American economy, and its ability to compete abroad, was slowing down according to the report.']
bis_def_longman: if one company or country competes with another, it tries to get people to buy its goods or services rather than those available from another company or country
exps_longman: ['They found themselves competing with foreign companies for a share of the market.', 'The Renault Clio competes against such cars as the Peugeot 206.', 'The stores have to compete for customers in the Christmas season.', 'The company must be able to compete in the international marketplace.', 'Several advertising agencies are competing to get the contract.', 'Small independent bookstores simply can’t compete with the big national chains.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to try to be more successful or better than somebody else who is trying to do the same as you
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Several companies are competing for the contract.', "We can't compete with them on price.", "Young children will usually compete for their mother's attention.", 'Small traders cannot compete in the face of cheap foreign imports.', 'There are too many magazines competing to attract readers.']

sentence: It 's gon na have to

When Raymond of Toulouse , Robert II of Flanders , Robert Curthose , Stephen of Blois , and Hugh of Vermandois responded to the call , past and present members of their military households fell almost automatically into rank behind them , to test themselves against terrible dangers , but also to enjoy the companionship in arms , the adventure , the deeds of daring which were the stuff of the chansons de geste .
gloss: Move from a higher to a lower level, typically rapidly and without control.
eg_sent: five inches of snow fell through the night
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; If someone or something falls, they move quickly downwards onto or towards the ground, by accident or because of a natural force. ;;
exps_collins: ['Her father fell into the sea after a massive heart attack.', 'Prince Charles has again fallen from his horse.', 'Bombs fell in the town.', "I ought to seal the boxes up. I don't want the books falling out.", 'Twenty people were injured by falling masonry.']
bis_def_longman: to move or drop down from a higher position to a lower position
exps_longman: ['The tree was about to fall.', 'Enough rain had fallen to flood the grounds.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to drop down from a higher level to a lower level
exps_oxford_advanced: ['September had come and the leaves were starting to fall.', 'They were injured by falling rocks.', 'Several of the books had fallen onto the floor.', 'One of the kids fell into the river.', 'The handle had fallen off the drawer.', 'He fell 20 metres onto the rocks below.', 'The rain was falling steadily.']

sentence: Ron Todd , the general secretary of the transport workers ' union , said that today 's vote on the multilaterist nuclear defence policy would not yield the massive and overwhelming majority predicted by right-wingers , and he warned that party leaders could not expect everybody to goose-step in the same direction once the policy had been carried .
gloss: Say or estimate that (a specified thing) will happen in the future or will be a consequence of something.
eg_sent: it is too early to predict a result
bis_def_collins: If you predict an event, you say that it will happen.
exps_collins: ['The latest opinion polls are predicting a very close contest.', "He predicted that my hair would grow back 'in no time'.", "It's hard to predict how a jury will react.", "'The war will continue another two or three years,' he predicted."]
bis_def_longman: to say that something will happen, before it happens
exps_longman: ['Sales were five percent lower than predicted.', 'Newspapers predicted that Davis would be re-elected.', 'It is difficult to predict what the long-term effects of the accident will be.', 'As Liz had predicted, the rumours were soon forgotten.', 'Unemployment is predicted to increase to 700,000 by the end of the year.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to say that something will happen in the future
exps_oxford_advanced: ['a reliable method of predicting earthquakes', 'Nobody could predict the outcome.', 'The party is predicting a majority of 20 seats.', 'It is impossible to predict what will happen.', 'She predicted (that) the election result would be close.', 'He predicted (that) it would be a smash hit.', 'It was predicted that inflation would continue to fall.', 'The trial is predicted to last for months.', 'This figure is predicted to rise to one billion by the year 2015.']

sentence: And God knows who else .
gloss: Be aware of through observation, inquiry, or information.
eg_sent: most people know that CFCs can damage the ozone layer
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont]  If you know a fact, a piece of information, or an answer, you have it correctly in your mind.
exps_collins: ["I don't know the name of the place.", 'I know that you led a rifle platoon during the Second World War.', "'People like doing things for nothing.' — 'I know they do.'.", "I don't know what happened to her husband.", "'How did he meet your mother?' — 'I don't know.'.", 'We all know about his early experiments in flying.', 'They looked younger than I knew them to be.', 'Radon is known to be harmful to humans in large quantities.', 'It is not known whether the bomb was originally intended for the capital itself.', "It's always been known that key figures in the government do very well for themselves."]
bis_def_longman: to have information about something
exps_longman: ['Who knows the answer?', 'There are instructions telling you everything you need to know.', 'Didn’t you know that?', 'Do you know what time it is?', 'I don’t know where to go.', 'I need to know more about the job before I decide whether to apply for it.', 'Little is known about the author’s childhood.', 'I know all about David and what he’s been up to!', 'I wonder if he knew of the plan?', 'Do you know of any good restaurants in the area?', 'You know nothing of this business.', 'We know that greenhouse gases can affect the climate.', 'Let me know what time you’re planning to arrive.', 'I thought you’d want to know immediately.', 'If you must know, I was with James last night .', 'He slipped out of the house without his parents knowing .', 'How did he know our names?', '‘I’m divorced, as you know, ’ she said briefly.', 'Smoking is known to increase a person’s risk of developing lung cancer.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have information in your mind as a result of experience or because you have learned or been told it
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Do you know his address?', 'The cause of the fire is not yet known.', 'All I know is that she used to work in a bank (= I have no other information about her).', 'I know (that) people’s handwriting changes as they get older.', 'It is widely known that CFCs can damage the ozone layer.', 'I knew where he was hiding.', "I didn't know what he was talking about.", "‘You've got a flat tyre.’ ‘I know.’", "‘What's the answer?’ ‘I don't know.’", "‘There's no one in.’ ‘How do you know?’", "You know about Amanda's baby, don't you?", "I don't know about you, but I'm ready for something to eat.", 'I know of at least two people who did the same thing.', '‘Is anyone else coming?’ ‘Not that I know of.’', '‘Isn’t that his car?’ ‘I wouldn’t know./How should I know?’ (= I don’t know and I am not the person you should ask.)', "‘What are you two whispering about?’ ‘You don't want to know’ (= because you would be shocked or wouldn't approve).", 'Does he know to come here (= that he should come here) first?', 'We know her to be honest.', 'Two women are known to have died.']

sentence: He is given an opportunity to do so , and if he does not , he is subject to sanctions by the court to compel him to do so .
gloss: Force or oblige (someone) to do something.
eg_sent: a sense of duty compelled Harry to answer her questions
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; If a situation, a rule, or a person compels you to do something, they force you to do it. ; [Also VERB n]
exps_collins: ['...the introduction of legislation to compel cyclists to wear a helmet.', "Leonie's mother was compelled to take in washing to help support her family.", 'Local housing authorities have been compelled by the housing crisis to make offers of sub-standard accommodation.']
bis_def_longman: to force someone to do something
exps_longman: ['The law will compel employers to provide health insurance.', 'She felt compelled to resign because of the scandal.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to force somebody to do something; to make something necessary
exps_oxford_advanced: ['The law can compel fathers to make regular payments for their children.', 'I feel compelled to write and tell you how much I enjoyed your book.', 'The court has powers to compel witnesses to attend.', 'Last year ill health compelled his retirement.']

sentence: In Warner v Lambeth London Borough Council ( 1985 ) 15 HLR 45 , 50 , Lord Justice Glidewell said a private person could lay an information alleging the failure to abate a statutory nuisance without first giving notice requiring abatement .
gloss: (of something unpleasant or severe) become less intense or widespread.
eg_sent: the storm suddenly abated
bis_def_collins: If something bad or undesirable abates, it becomes much less strong or severe.  [formal]
exps_collins: ['The storms had abated by the time they rounded Cape Horn.', '...a crime wave that shows no sign of abating.']
bis_def_longman: to become less strong or decrease
exps_longman: ['We waited for the storm to abate.', 'The level of wage settlements has shown no signs of abating in recent months.', 'the cost of investing in pollution abatement equipment']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to become less strong; to make something less strong
exps_oxford_advanced: ['The storm showed no signs of abating.', 'They waited for the crowd’s fury to abate.', 'Steps are to be taken to abate pollution.']

sentence: The war , declared by one whose moral authority was unimpeachable , was to free the Eastern churches , to end Muslim guardianship of the holy places , to restore Jerusalem to its proper state .
gloss: Bring back or re-establish (a previous right, practice, or situation)
eg_sent: the policy restored confidence in the banking system
bis_def_collins: To restore a situation or practice means to cause it to exist again.
exps_collins: ['The army has recently been brought in to restore order.', 'As they smiled at each other, harmony was restored again.', 'The death penalty was never restored.']
bis_def_longman: to make something return to its former state or condition
exps_longman: ['The government promises to restore the economy to full strength.', 'She was hoping that the Mediterranean climate would restore her to full health.', 'The National Guard was called in to restore order when riots broke out.', 'initiatives to restore peace in the Middle East', 'Vietnam restored diplomatic relations with South Korea on December 22.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to bring back a situation or feeling that existed before
exps_oxford_advanced: ['The measures are intended to restore public confidence in the economy.', 'Order was quickly restored after the riots.', 'Such kindness restores your faith in human nature (= makes you believe most people are kind).', 'The operation restored his sight (= made him able to see again).']

sentence: Pencil skirts and batwing sweaters and spiky stilettos , tottering with their hard little behinds sticking out , and all that red lipstick .
gloss: Go round or past the edge of.
eg_sent: he did not go through the city but skirted it
bis_def_collins: VERB  …;…; Something that skirts an area is situated around the edge of it. …;…;
exps_collins: ['We raced across a large field that skirted the slope of a hill.']
bis_def_longman: to go around the outside edge of a place or area
exps_longman: ['The old footpath skirts around the village.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to be or go around the edge of something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['They followed the road that skirted the lake.', 'They skirted the forest and emerged on to a path.', 'I skirted around the field and crossed the bridge.']

sentence: At its most simple , La Chingada , as the mother of Mestizo culture is the Mother forcibly opened , violated or deceived .
gloss: Break or fail to comply with (a rule or formal agreement)
eg_sent: they violated the terms of a ceasefire
bis_def_collins: If someone violates an agreement, law, or promise, they break it.  [formal]
exps_collins: ['They went to prison because they violated the law.', 'They violated the ceasefire agreement.']
bis_def_longman: to disobey or do something against an official agreement, law, principle etc
exps_longman: ['Thirty-four protesters were arrested for violating criminal law.', 'regimes that violate human rights']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to go against or refuse to obey a law, an agreement, etc.
exps_oxford_advanced: ['to violate international law']

sentence: You know what she 's gon na do go to school and put them down !
gloss: Move to or place in a particular position.
eg_sent: I put my hand out towards her
bis_def_collins: When you put something in a particular place or position, you move it into that place or position.
exps_collins: ['Leaphorn put the photograph on the desk.', "She hesitated, then put her hand on Grace's arm.", 'Mishka put down a heavy shopping bag.']
bis_def_longman: to move something to a particular place or position, especially using your hands
exps_longman: ['He put the coffee on the table.', 'Where did you put the programmes?']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to move something into a particular place or position
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Put the cases down there, please.', 'Did you put sugar in my coffee?', 'Put your hand up if you need more paper.']

sentence: Electors are always prepared to criticise the Government in answer to pollsters ' questions , but when the same individuals arrive at the polling booth they simply can not bring themselves to vote Labour into power .
gloss: Indicate the faults of (someone or something) in a disapproving way.
eg_sent: the opposition criticized the government's failure to consult adequately

sentence: This made the survey difficult to interpret .
gloss: Form (something) by putting parts together or combining substances; create.
eg_sent: my grandmother made a dress for me
bis_def_collins: VERB  ) You can use make with a wide range of nouns to indicate that someone performs an action or says something. For example, if you make a suggestion, you suggest something. )
exps_collins: ["I'd just like to make a comment.", 'I made a few phone calls.', "I think you're making a serious mistake.", 'The Pope said the world had made some progress towards peace in 1991.', 'Science and technology have made major changes to the way we live.', 'She had made us an offer too good to refuse.']
bis_def_longman: to produce something, for example by putting the different parts of it together
exps_longman: ['I’m going to show you how to make a box for your tools.', 'A family of mice had made their nest in the roof.', 'She made her own wedding dress.', 'The company has been making quality furniture for over 200 years.', 'They met while they were making a film.', 'He made her a toy horse, using just some straw and bamboo twigs.', 'Paper is made from wood.', 'a shirt made of silk', 'She’s very good at making things from old scraps of material.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to create or prepare something by combining materials or putting parts together
exps_oxford_advanced: ['to make a table/dress/cake', 'to make bread/cement/paper', 'She makes her own clothes.', 'made in France (= on a label)', "What's your shirt made of?", 'Wine is made from grapes.', 'The grapes are made into wine.', 'She made coffee for us all.', 'She made us all coffee.']

sentence: But er no , we were talking and she said if I give you the money you wo n't go and spend it on the
gloss: Give (money) to pay for goods, services, or so as to benefit someone or something.
eg_sent: the firm has spent £100,000 on hardware
bis_def_collins: VERB  ();() When you spend money, you pay money for things that you want. ();()
exps_collins: ['By the end of the holiday I had spent all my money.', 'Businessmen spend enormous amounts advertising their products.', 'Juventus have spent £23m on new players.', 'The survey may cost at least £100 but is money well spent.']
bis_def_longman: to use your money to pay for goods or services
exps_longman: ['I can’t afford to spend any more money this week.', 'I only want to spend about $20.', 'More money should be spent on education.', 'Mum never spends any money on herself.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to give money to pay for goods, services, etc.
exps_oxford_advanced: ["I've spent all my money already.", 'She spent £100 on a new dress.', 'The company has spent thousands of pounds updating their computer systems.', "I just can't seem to stop spending."]

sentence: She was moving back on board Wavebreaker in preparation for the next day 's early departure .
gloss: Go in a specified direction or manner; change position.
eg_sent: she moved to the door
bis_def_collins: V-ERG  ; When you move something or when it moves, its position changes and it does not remain still. ;
exps_collins: ['She moved the sheaf of papers into position.', 'You can move the camera both vertically and horizontally.', 'A traffic warden asked him to move his car.', 'I could see the branches of the trees moving back and forth.', 'The train began to move.']
bis_def_longman: to change from one place or position to another, or to make something do this
exps_longman: ['‘Come on, ’ Sue said. No one moved.', 'Could you move your car, please? It’s blocking the road.', 'The plane moved slowly along the runway, then stopped.', 'He moved closer to her.', 'Becca moved down the steps and into the yard.', 'I could hear someone moving around upstairs.', 'The bar was so crowded you could hardly move.', 'At Christmas, you couldn’t move for toys in this house .', 'Paul couldn’t move a muscle he was so scared.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to change position or make somebody/something change position in a way that can be seen, heard or felt
exps_oxford_advanced: ["Don't move—stay perfectly still.", 'The bus was already moving when I jumped onto it.', 'He could hear someone moving around in the room above.', 'Phil moved towards the window.', 'You can hardly move in this pub on Saturdays (= because it is so crowded).', "You can't move for books in her room.", "I can't move my fingers.", 'We moved our chairs a little nearer.']

sentence: You never believe that the gods will really let it burn you .
gloss: (of a fire) produce flames and heat while consuming a material such as coal or wood.
eg_sent: a fire burned and crackled cheerfully in the grate
bis_def_collins: If there is a fire or a flame somewhere, you say that there is a fire or flame burning there.
exps_collins: ['Fires were burning out of control in the center of the city.', 'There was a fire burning in the large fireplace.', 'The furnace has a design that allows the flame to burn at a lower temperature.']
bis_def_longman: if a fire burns, it produces heat and flames
exps_longman: ['There was a fire burning in the fireplace.', 'An average household candle will burn for about six hours.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to produce flames and heat
exps_oxford_advanced: ['A welcoming fire was burning in the fireplace.', 'Fires were burning all over the city.']

sentence: You two can manage , she said calmly .
gloss: Utter words so as to convey information, an opinion, a feeling or intention, or an instruction.
eg_sent: ‘Thank you,’ he said
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; When you say something, you speak words. ; [Also VERB to-infinitive]
exps_collins: ["'I'm sorry,' he said.", 'She said they were very impressed.', 'Forty-one people are said to have been seriously hurt.', 'I packed and said goodbye to Charlie.', "I hope you didn't say anything about Gretchen.", "You didn't say much when you telephoned.", 'Did he say where he was going?.', "It doesn't sound exactly orthodox, if I may say so."]
bis_def_longman: to express an idea, feeling, thought etc using words
exps_longman: ['‘Don’t cry, ’ he said softly.', 'Don’t believe anything he says.', 'A spokesman said that the company had improved its safety standards.', 'I always said I would buy a motorbike when I had enough money.', 'Did she say what happened?', 'I would like to say how much we appreciate your hard work.', '‘Why did she leave?’ ‘I don’t know – she didn’t say.’', 'What did you say to her?', 'What a silly thing to say!', 'She left without saying goodbye.', 'I’ve said I’m sorry – what more do you want?', 'Can I go, Mum? Oh, please say yes!', 'He looked as if he was going to say something.', 'I wished I had said nothing about Jordi.', 'Does anyone else have anything to say?', 'Although he didn’t say so, it was clear that he was in pain.', 'What makes you say that (=why do you think that) ? 你怎么会那么说呢？', 'Nina said to meet her at 4.30.', 'I’d like to say a few words.', '‘So what are your plans now?’ ‘I’d rather not say.’']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to speak or tell somebody something, using words
exps_oxford_advanced: ['‘Hello!’ she said.', '‘That was marvellous,’ said Daniel.', 'Be quiet, I have something to say.', "I didn't believe a word she said.", "That's a terrible thing to say.", "He knew that if he wasn't back by midnight, his parents would have something to say about it (= be angry).", 'She said nothing to me about it.', "I said to myself (= thought), ‘That can't be right!’", 'He said (that) his name was Sam.', 'It is said that she lived to be over 100.', 'She finds it hard to say what she feels.', "‘That's impossible!’ ‘So you say (= but I think you may be wrong).’", "‘Why can't I go out now?’ ‘Because I say so.’", "‘What do you want it for?’ ‘I'd rather not say.’", 'He said to meet him here.', 'He is said to have been a brilliant scholar.']

sentence: He turned and smiled at Adam .
gloss: Form one's features into a pleased, kind, or amused expression, typically with the corners of the mouth turned up and the front teeth exposed.
eg_sent: she was smiling broadly
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; When you smile, the corners of your mouth curve up and you sometimes show your teeth. People smile when they are pleased or amused, or when they are being friendly. ;
exps_collins: ['When he saw me, he smiled and waved.', 'He rubbed the back of his neck and smiled ruefully at me.', 'His smiling face appears on T-shirts, billboards, and posters.']
bis_def_longman: to make your mouth curve upwards, in order to be friendly or because you are happy or amused
exps_longman: ['Susan smiled at him and waved.', 'She had to smile at his enthusiasm .', 'her smiling face', 'I haven’t had much to smile about lately.', 'Mark read the message and smiled to himself.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to make a smile appear on your face
exps_oxford_advanced: ['to smile sweetly/faintly/broadly, etc.', 'He smiled with relief.', 'He never seems to smile.', 'He smiled to think how naive he used to be.', 'She smiled at him and he smiled back.', 'I had to smile at (= was amused by) his optimism.', 'Her eyes smiled up at him.']

sentence: So they bought immunity .
gloss: Obtain in exchange for payment.
eg_sent: she bought six first-class stamps
bis_def_collins: If you buy something, you obtain it by paying money for it.
exps_collins: ['He could not afford to buy a house.', 'They can now be bought fresh in supermarkets.', 'Lizzie bought herself a mountain bike.', "I'd like to buy him lunch."]
bis_def_longman: to get something by paying money for it
exps_longman: ['Where did you buy that dress?', 'Ricky showed her the painting he’d bought that morning.', 'Let me buy you a drink.', 'The money will be used to buy equipment for the school.', 'It’s cheaper to buy direct from the manufacturer.', 'Dan bought the car for $2,000.', 'It’s much cheaper to buy in bulk.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to obtain something by paying money for it
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Where did you buy that dress?', "If you're thinking of getting a new car, now is a good time to buy.", 'I bought it from a friend for £10.', 'He bought me a new coat.', 'He bought a new coat for me.', 'I bought my car second-hand.']

sentence: In applications of this kind the authors argue that geographic information management in general and GIS in particular have an important role to play and they give a number of examples from research in progress to illustrate the current state of the art in this field .
gloss: Provide (a book, newspaper, etc.) with pictures.
eg_sent: the guide is illustrated with full-colour photographs
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; If you say that something illustrates a situation that you are drawing attention to, you mean that it shows that the situation exists. ;;

sentence: You all know me , says Paddy , and a fat lady with good timing says , I do n't know you .

exps_oxford_advanced: ['The horse snorted and tossed its head.', 'to snort with laughter', 'She snorted in disgust.', '‘You!’ he snorted contemptuously.']

sentence: I squelched across tiny burns running in black channels of peat , and stood looking down from the hillside on to the grey roofs of Scaup Farm .
gloss: Move at a speed faster than a walk, never having both or all the feet on the ground at the same time.
eg_sent: the dog ran across the road
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; When you run, you move more quickly than when you walk, for example because you are in a hurry to get somewhere, or for exercise. ;
exps_collins: ['I excused myself and ran back to the telephone.', 'Police believe the gunmen ran off into the woods.', 'Neighbouring shopkeepers ran after the man and caught him.', 'He ran the last block to the White House with two cases of gear.', 'Antonia ran to meet them.']
bis_def_longman: to move very quickly, by moving your legs more quickly than when you walk
exps_longman: ['I ran down the stairs as fast as I could.', 'He was running towards the door.', 'She turned and ran away.', 'The boys ran off into the crowd.', 'Several people ran to help her when she fell.', 'The children came running out of the house.', 'Women ran screaming, with children in their arms.', 'Jane struggled free and ran for her life.', 'He picked up the child and ran like hell.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to move using your legs, going faster than when you walk
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Can you run as fast as Mike?', 'They turned and ran when they saw us coming.', 'She came running to meet us.', 'I had to run to catch the bus.', 'The dogs ran off as soon as we appeared.', 'He ran home in tears to his mother.']

sentence: She and her boyfriend have had their future planned for some time : they want to start farming in a nearby village , where they also intend to build a bungalow .
gloss: Construct (something) by putting parts or material together.

bis_def_longman: to make something, especially a building or something large
exps_longman: ['The purpose is to build new houses for local people.', 'The road took many years to build.', 'They needed $3 million to build the bridge.', 'It is the female birds that build the nests.', 'Developers want to build on the site of the old gasworks.', 'a row of recently built houses', 'He’s going to build the children a doll’s house.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to make something, especially a building, by putting parts together

sentence: THANK God it 's Saturday .
gloss: Express gratitude to (someone), especially by saying ‘Thank you’

sentence: I mean
gloss: Intend to convey or refer to (a particular thing); signify.
eg_sent: I don't know what you mean
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont] ;…;… If you want to know what a word, code, signal, or gesture means, you want to know what it refers to or what its message is. ;…;…
exps_collins: ["In modern Welsh, 'glas' means 'blue'.", "What does 'evidence' mean?.", 'The red signal means you can shoot.']
bis_def_longman: to have or represent a particular meaning

sentence: I wo n't go anywhere with , I do n't want to go without him !
gloss: Have a desire to possess or do (something); wish for.
eg_sent: I want an apple
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont, no passive] ; If you want something, you feel a desire or a need for it. ;
exps_collins: ['I want a drink.', 'Ian knows exactly what he wants in life.', 'People wanted to know who this talented designer was.', 'They began to want their father to be the same as other daddies.', "They didn't want people staring at them as they sat on the lawn, so they put up high walls.", 'He wanted his power recognised.', 'I want my car this colour.', 'And remember, we want him alive.', "Note that want and wish have similar meanings, but are used differently. If you want something, you feel a need for it or a desire to have it. You can say that you want to do something, that you want someone to do something, or that you want something to happen. If you use wish with a 'to' infinitive, this has the same meaning as want but is more formal. I want to get out of here... She wished to consult him about her future."]
bis_def_longman: to have a desire for something
exps_longman: ['I really want a drink.', 'What do you want for your birthday?', 'She’d always wanted to go to Thailand.', 'I don’t want Linda to  hear about this.', 'He didn’t want the holiday to end.', 'You can order whatever you want.', 'This shampoo is mild enough to use every day if you want.', 'If she doesn’t get what she wants, she’s not happy.', 'He wanted that job so badly he was willing to kill for it.', 'They desperately wanted a son.', 'What I want to know is when we’re going to get paid.', 'All I want is the chance to prove myself.', 'Oh thank you, it’s just what I’ve always wanted.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have a desire or a wish for something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Do you want some more tea?', "She's always wanted a large family.", 'All I want is the truth.', "Thanks for the present—it's just what I wanted.", 'I can do whatever I want.', 'The last thing I wanted was to upset you.', 'The party wants her as leader.', 'What do you want to do tomorrow?', "‘It's time you did your homework.’ ‘I don't want to!’", 'There are two points which I wanted to make.', 'I just wanted to know if everything was all right.', 'You can come too, if you want.', 'Do you want me to help?', "We didn't want this to happen.", 'I want it (to be) done as quickly as possible.', "I don't want you coming home so late.", 'Do you want your coffee black or white?']

sentence: The literature of the last few years is thronged with papers proposing that these must be taken into account but with few realistic proposals on how this is to be achieved .
gloss: Lay hold of (something) with one's hands; reach for and hold.
eg_sent: Mrs Morgan took another biscuit
bis_def_collins: You can use take followed by a noun to talk about an action or event, when it would also be possible to use the verb that is related to that noun. For example, you can say 'she took a shower' instead of 'she showered'.
exps_collins: ['She was too tired to take a shower.', 'Betty took a photograph of us.', "I've never taken a holiday since starting this job.", "There's not enough people willing to take the risk.", 'Walk around the property and take a good look at it from the outside.', 'We took a long walk through the pines.']
bis_def_longman: to move or go with someone or something from one place to another
exps_longman: ['Barney took us to the airport.', 'Would you mind taking Susie home?', 'When he refused to give his name, he was taken into custody.', 'My job has taken me all over the world.', 'His wife went to Australia, taking the children with her.', 'I have to take Steve the money tonight.', 'He took me to meet his parents.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to carry or move something from one place to another
exps_oxford_advanced: ['I forgot to take my bag with me when I got off the bus.', 'Take this to the bank for me, would you?', 'Shall I take a gift to my host family?', 'Shall I take my host family a gift?']

sentence: You sure know how to give a girl a good time .
gloss: Freely transfer the possession of (something) to (someone)
eg_sent: she gave him presents and clothes
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont]  You can use give with nouns that refer to physical actions. The whole expression refers to the performing of the action. For example, She gave a smile means almost the same as 'She smiled'.
exps_collins: ['She stretched her arms out and gave a great yawn.', 'Giving a sigh, she fell to her knees at my feet.', 'He gave her a fond smile.', 'He reached for her hand and gave it a reassuring squeeze.']
bis_def_longman: to let someone have something as a present, or to provide something for someone
exps_longman: ['What did Bob give you for your birthday?', 'Researchers were given a £10,000 grant to continue their work.', 'I’ve got some old diaries that my grandmother gave me years ago.', 'a ring which was given to him by his mother', 'I didn’t steal it! Maria gave it to me!', 'Most people are willing to give to charity.', 'The situation is now desperate, so please give generously.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to hand something to somebody so that they can look at it, use it or keep it for a time
exps_oxford_advanced: ["Give the letter to your mother when you've read it.", 'She gave her ticket to the woman at the check-in desk.', 'Give your mother the letter.', 'They were all given a box to carry.']

sentence: Does that mean he may lay an information and bring the matter before the magistrates without first putting the person alleged to be in default on notice of what is alleged ?
gloss: Claim or assert that someone has done something illegal or wrong, typically without proof.
eg_sent: he alleged that he had been assaulted
bis_def_collins: If you allege that something bad is true, you say it but do not prove it.  [formal] [Also VERB with quote]
exps_collins: ['She alleged that there was rampant drug use among the male members of the group.', 'The accused is alleged to have killed a man.', 'It was alleged that the restaurant discriminated against black customers.']
bis_def_longman: to say that something is true or that someone has done something wrong, although it has not been proved

sentence: Some agencies deduct it every month , others want it all up front , so shop around .
gloss: Subtract or take away (an amount or part) from a total.
eg_sent: tax has been deducted from the payments
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; When you deduct an amount from a total, you subtract it from the total. ; [Also VERB n]

bis_def_longman: to take away an amount or part from a total

sentence: He is working on a scheme with the National Federation of WI to organise a competition to celebrate next year 's 75th anniversary by offering 10 telecottages as prizes for its 9,000 branches and he is hoping the WI will establish a pilot telecottage near its college in Denman , Oxfordshire .
gloss: Present or proffer (something) for (someone) to accept or reject as desired.

bis_def_collins: If you offer something to someone, you ask them if they would like to have it or use it.
exps_collins: ['He has offered seats at the conference table to the Russian leader and the president of Kazakhstan.', 'The number of companies offering them work increased.', 'Rhys offered him an apple.', 'Western governments have offered aid.']
bis_def_longman: to ask someone if they would like to have something, or to hold something out to them so that they can take it

bis_def_oxford_advanced: to say that you are willing to do something for somebody or give something to somebody

sentence: It was Grizel Huntley 's own view that her brother had not been fooled at all but had been charmed and diverted by a dashing girl thirty years his junior , and had seen no reason at all why she should not have a share of his considerable estate when that left a very decent down-setting for his niece as well .
gloss: Perceive with the eyes; discern visually.
eg_sent: in the distance she could see the blue sea
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont] ; When you see something, you notice it using your eyes. ;
exps_collins: ["You can't see colours at night.", 'I saw a man making his way towards me.', 'She can see, hear, touch, smell, and taste.', 'As he neared the farm, he saw that a police car was parked outside it.', 'Did you see what happened?', 'You use see to talk about things that you are aware of because a visual impression reaches your eyes. You often use can in this case. I can see the fax here on the desk. If you want to say that someone is paying attention to something they can see, you say that they are looking at it or watching it. In general, you look at something that is not moving, while you watch something that is moving or changing. I asked him to look at the picture above his bed... He watched Blake run down the stairs.']
bis_def_longman: to notice or examine someone or something, using your eyes
exps_longman: ['He crouched down so he couldn’t be seen.', 'Can I see your ticket, please?', 'You can see the Houses of Parliament from here.', 'Can you see where the marks are on the wall?', 'The suspect was seen entering the building.', 'As you can see, the house needs some work doing on it.', 'Have you seen Chris ?', 'The accommodation was so awful it had to be seen to be believed.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to become aware of somebody/something by using your eyes

sentence: Such techniques are now standard in environmental science ( see Streit 1981 for an application to rainfall monitoring ) and need to be promoted vigorously in hazard studies ( Estes et al. 1987 ) .

sentence: I mean , I do n't know I , you see I left I had to come here so I left before Bob Monkhouse and everything , I just , I , all I did was go for couple of free drinks and plate of free food , which , I do n't think I got .

sentence: Sentiment , loyalty , service and track record , none of these things will come into it .

sentence: And good Russians , I suppose .

bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; You can use suppose or supposing before mentioning a possible situation or action. You usually then go on to consider the effects that this situation or action might have. ;;
