(= showing anger)."]

sentence: Mrs Thatcher , a recent convert to environmental conservation , clearly held the opinion that environmental problems are not only soluble but that solving them can be shown to be cost-effective :
gloss: Change the form, character, or function of something.
eg_sent: modernization has converted the country from a primitive society to a near-industrial one
bis_def_collins: V-ERG  );;() If one thing is converted or converts into another, it is changed into a different form. );;()
exps_collins: ['The signal will be converted into digital code.', '...naturally occurring substances which the body can convert into vitamins.', '...a table that converts into an ironing board.']
bis_def_longman: to change something into a different form, or to change something so that it can be used for a different purpose or in a different way
exps_longman: ['They converted the spare bedroom into an office.', 'The stocks can be easily converted to cash.', 'a 19th-century converted barn']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to change or make something change from one form, purpose, system, etc. to another
exps_oxford_advanced: ['The hotel is going to be converted into a nursing home.', 'The pub is a converted warehouse.', 'What rate will I get if I convert my dollars into euros?', 'Hot water is converted to electricity by a turbine.', "We've converted from oil to gas central heating."]

sentence: She said ooh , you know can I invite a couple of friends , can I invite sort of you know , people back to lunch but when it 's sort of the list I mean , cos I I 'm not
gloss: Be aware of through observation, inquiry, or information.
eg_sent: most people know that CFCs can damage the ozone layer
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont]  If you know a fact, a piece of information, or an answer, you have it correctly in your mind.
exps_collins: ["I don't know the name of the place.", 'I know that you led a rifle platoon during the Second World War.', "'People like doing things for nothing.' — 'I know they do.'.", "I don't know what happened to her husband.", "'How did he meet your mother?' — 'I don't know.'.", 'We all know about his early experiments in flying.', 'They looked younger than I knew them to be.', 'Radon is known to be harmful to humans in large quantities.', 'It is not known whether the bomb was originally intended for the capital itself.', "It's always been known that key figures in the government do very well for themselves."]
bis_def_longman: to have information about something
exps_longman: ['Who knows the answer?', 'There are instructions telling you everything you need to know.', 'Didn’t you know that?', 'Do you know what time it is?', 'I don’t know where to go.', 'I need to know more about the job before I decide whether to apply for it.', 'Little is known about the author’s childhood.', 'I know all about David and what he’s been up to!', 'I wonder if he knew of the plan?', 'Do you know of any good restaurants in the area?', 'You know nothing of this business.', 'We know that greenhouse gases can affect the climate.', 'Let me know what time you’re planning to arrive.', 'I thought you’d want to know immediately.', 'If you must know, I was with James last night .', 'He slipped out of the house without his parents knowing .', 'How did he know our names?', '‘I’m divorced, as you know, ’ she said briefly.', 'Smoking is known to increase a person’s risk of developing lung cancer.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have information in your mind as a result of experience or because you have learned or been told it
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Do you know his address?', 'The cause of the fire is not yet known.', 'All I know is that she used to work in a bank (= I have no other information about her).', 'I know (that) people’s handwriting changes as they get older.', 'It is widely known that CFCs can damage the ozone layer.', 'I knew where he was hiding.', "I didn't know what he was talking about.", "‘You've got a flat tyre.’ ‘I know.’", "‘What's the answer?’ ‘I don't know.’", "‘There's no one in.’ ‘How do you know?’", "You know about Amanda's baby, don't you?", "I don't know about you, but I'm ready for something to eat.", 'I know of at least two people who did the same thing.', '‘Is anyone else coming?’ ‘Not that I know of.’', '‘Isn’t that his car?’ ‘I wouldn’t know./How should I know?’ (= I don’t know and I am not the person you should ask.)', "‘What are you two whispering about?’ ‘You don't want to know’ (= because you would be shocked or wouldn't approve).", 'Does he know to come here (= that he should come here) first?', 'We know her to be honest.', 'Two women are known to have died.']

sentence: And I went down , I went somewhere else there was a few places I saw them so erm I said to , I said to Robert now you know those shirts , that shirt I bought you for Christmas ?
gloss: Utter words so as to convey information, an opinion, a feeling or intention, or an instruction.
eg_sent: ‘Thank you,’ he said
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; When you say something, you speak words. ; [Also VERB to-infinitive]
exps_collins: ["'I'm sorry,' he said.", 'She said they were very impressed.', 'Forty-one people are said to have been seriously hurt.', 'I packed and said goodbye to Charlie.', "I hope you didn't say anything about Gretchen.", "You didn't say much when you telephoned.", 'Did he say where he was going?.', "It doesn't sound exactly orthodox, if I may say so."]
bis_def_longman: to express an idea, feeling, thought etc using words
exps_longman: ['‘Don’t cry, ’ he said softly.', 'Don’t believe anything he says.', 'A spokesman said that the company had improved its safety standards.', 'I always said I would buy a motorbike when I had enough money.', 'Did she say what happened?', 'I would like to say how much we appreciate your hard work.', '‘Why did she leave?’ ‘I don’t know – she didn’t say.’', 'What did you say to her?', 'What a silly thing to say!', 'She left without saying goodbye.', 'I’ve said I’m sorry – what more do you want?', 'Can I go, Mum? Oh, please say yes!', 'He looked as if he was going to say something.', 'I wished I had said nothing about Jordi.', 'Does anyone else have anything to say?', 'Although he didn’t say so, it was clear that he was in pain.', 'What makes you say that (=why do you think that) ? 你怎么会那么说呢？', 'Nina said to meet her at 4.30.', 'I’d like to say a few words.', '‘So what are your plans now?’ ‘I’d rather not say.’']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to speak or tell somebody something, using words
exps_oxford_advanced: ['‘Hello!’ she said.', '‘That was marvellous,’ said Daniel.', 'Be quiet, I have something to say.', "I didn't believe a word she said.", "That's a terrible thing to say.", "He knew that if he wasn't back by midnight, his parents would have something to say about it (= be angry).", 'She said nothing to me about it.', "I said to myself (= thought), ‘That can't be right!’", 'He said (that) his name was Sam.', 'It is said that she lived to be over 100.', 'She finds it hard to say what she feels.', "‘That's impossible!’ ‘So you say (= but I think you may be wrong).’", "‘Why can't I go out now?’ ‘Because I say so.’", "‘What do you want it for?’ ‘I'd rather not say.’", 'He said to meet him here.', 'He is said to have been a brilliant scholar.']

sentence: To name an object is to suppress three-quarters of the enjoyment of the poem , which is created by the gradual pleasure of apprehending it .
gloss: Bring (something) into existence.
eg_sent: he created a thirty-acre lake
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; To create something means to cause it to happen or exist. ;;
exps_collins: ['We set business free to create more jobs in Britain.', 'She could create a fight out of anything.', "The lights create such a glare it's next to impossible to see anything behind them.", 'Criticizing will only destroy a relationship and create feelings of failure.']
bis_def_longman: to make something exist that did not exist before
exps_longman: ['Some people believe the universe was created by a big explosion.', 'Her behaviour is creating a lot of problems.', 'The new factory is expected to create more than 400 new jobs.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to make something happen or exist
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Scientists disagree about how the universe was created.', 'The main purpose of industry is to create wealth.', 'The government plans to create more jobs for young people.', 'Create a new directory and put all your files into it.', 'Try this new dish, created by our head chef.']

sentence: They lost over ÇÎ£4,000 dealing with two letting agencies which closed down without paying them the rent and tenants ' deposit owed on their Wembley flat .
gloss: Have an obligation to pay or repay (something, especially money) in return for something received.
eg_sent: they have denied they owe money to the company
bis_def_collins: If you owe money to someone, they have lent it to you and you have not yet paid it back. You can also say that the money is owing .
exps_collins: ['The company owes money to more than 60 banks.', 'Blake already owed him nearly £50.', "I'm broke, Livy, and I owe a couple of million dollars.", 'He could take what was owing for the rent.']
bis_def_longman: to need to pay someone for something that they have done for you or sold to you, or to need to give someone back money that they have lent you
exps_longman: ['I owe my brother $50.', 'I still owe you for the taxi.', 'How much do I owe you ?', 'the money owed to credit card companies']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have to pay somebody for something that you have already received or return money that you have borrowed
exps_oxford_advanced: ['She still owes her father £3\u2009000.', "I'm still owed three days' leave.", 'How much do I owe you for the groceries?', 'She still owes £3\u2009000 to her father', 'The country owes billions of dollars to foreign creditors.']

sentence: The chapter as a whole draws attention to a number of key methodological issues that are involved in environmental monitoring and prediction .
gloss: Produce (a picture or diagram) by making lines and marks on paper with a pencil, pen, etc.
eg_sent: he drew a map
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; When you draw, or when you draw something, you use a pencil or pen to produce a picture, pattern, or diagram. ;;
exps_collins: ['She would sit there drawing with the pencil stub.', 'Draw a rough design for a logo.', 'He starts a painting by quickly drawing simplified shapes.']
bis_def_longman: to produce a picture of something using a pencil, pen etc
exps_longman: ['Katie had drawn a cottage with a little stream running next to it.', 'She asked the little girl to draw a picture of the man she’d spoken to.', 'Keith was drawing a complicated-looking graph.', 'I’ve never been able to draw very well.', 'Can you draw me a map of how to get there?']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to make pictures, or a picture of something, with a pencil, pen or chalk (but not paint)
exps_oxford_advanced: ['You draw beautifully.', 'to draw a picture/diagram/graph', 'She drew a house.', 'He drew a circle in the sand with a stick.', 'The report drew a grim picture of inefficiency and corruption.']

sentence: Particular attention should be focused on hospital incinerators , since these have been subject to Crown immunity for many years and most are technically ill-equipped to burn at sufficiently high temperatures for adequate disposal of wastes ( Gatrell and Lovett 1991 ) .
gloss: (of a fire) produce flames and heat while consuming a material such as coal or wood.
eg_sent: a fire burned and crackled cheerfully in the grate
bis_def_collins: If there is a fire or a flame somewhere, you say that there is a fire or flame burning there.
exps_collins: ['Fires were burning out of control in the center of the city.', 'There was a fire burning in the large fireplace.', 'The furnace has a design that allows the flame to burn at a lower temperature.']
bis_def_longman: if a fire burns, it produces heat and flames
exps_longman: ['There was a fire burning in the fireplace.', 'An average household candle will burn for about six hours.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to produce flames and heat
exps_oxford_advanced: ['A welcoming fire was burning in the fireplace.', 'Fires were burning all over the city.']

sentence: No , but you also like playing with fire .
gloss: Engage in activity for enjoyment and recreation rather than a serious or practical purpose.
eg_sent: the children were playing by a pool
bis_def_collins: When children, animals, or perhaps adults play, they spend time doing enjoyable things, such as using toys and taking part in games.
exps_collins: ['...invite the children round to play.', 'They played in the little garden.', 'Polly was playing with her teddy bear.']
bis_def_longman: when children play, they do things that they enjoy, often with other people or with toys
exps_longman: ['Kids were playing and chasing each other.', 'Outside, the children were playing cowboys and Indians.', 'Did you like to play with dolls when you were little?', 'Parents need to spend time just playing with their children.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to do things for pleasure, as children do; to enjoy yourself, rather than work
exps_oxford_advanced: ["You'll have to play inside today.", "There's a time to work and a time to play.", 'A group of kids were playing with a ball in the street.', "I haven't got anybody to play with!", "Let's play a different game."]

sentence: Go away !
gloss: Move from one place to another; travel.
eg_sent: he went out to the shops
bis_def_collins: When you go somewhere, you move or travel there.
exps_collins: ['We went to Rome.', 'Gladys had just gone into the kitchen.', 'I went home at the weekend.', 'Four of them had gone off to find help.', 'It took us an hour to go three miles.']
bis_def_longman: to travel or move to a place that is away from where you are or where you live
exps_longman: ['There’s nothing more we can do here. Let’s go home.', 'Where are you going?', 'We’re going to Canada in the summer.', 'Dinah went into the kitchen.', 'She went over and put her arm around him.', 'I’m going round to her house to find out what’s wrong.', 'I’ll just go up  and ask him what he wants.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to move or travel from one place to another
exps_oxford_advanced: ['She went into her room and shut the door behind her.', 'He goes to work by bus.', 'I have to go to Rome on business.', 'She has gone to China (= is now in China or is on her way there).', 'She has been to China (= she went to China and has now returned).', "I think you should go to the doctor's.", 'Are you going home for Christmas?', 'She has gone to see her sister this weekend.']

sentence: But within a month , she could n't get through the day without tranquillizers ; she felt less anxious , calmer .
gloss: Come to have (something); receive.
eg_sent: I got a letter from him the other day

exps_collins: ['The boys were getting bored.', "There's no point in getting upset.", 'From here on, it can only get better.']

sentence: I twisted around and almost blinded myself by staring straight into the sun , but then , through the dizzying glare , I made out the long silhouette of a tall man who seemed , incongruously , to be dressed in a long , transparent dressing gown .
gloss: (of a film, play, or other show) have (someone) as a principal performer.
eg_sent: a film starring Liza Minnelli
bis_def_collins: VERB  ) If an actor or actress stars in a play or film, he or she has one of the most important parts in it. )
exps_collins: ['The previous year Adolphson had starred in a play in which Ingrid had been an extra.', "He's starred in dozens of films."]
bis_def_longman: if someone stars in a film, television show etc, they are one of the main characters in it
exps_longman: ['Eastwood starred in ‘The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly’.', 'DeVito stars opposite Dreyfuss in the movie.', 'Hugh Grant stars as the romantic hero.', '‘The Freshman’ was Brando’s first starring role in ten years.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have one of the main parts in a film/movie, play, etc.

sentence: Paul Harrison 's Inside the Inner City : Life under the Cutting Edge focused on Hackney , a London borough ranked among the worst off on any scale of urban deprivation ( Harrison , 1983 ) .
gloss: Give (someone or something) a rank or place within a grading system.
eg_sent: students ranked the samples in order of preference
bis_def_collins: V-ERG  …;… If an official organization ranks someone or something 1st, 5th, or 50th, for example, they calculate that the person or thing has that position on a scale. You can also say that someone or something ranks 1st, 5th, or 50th, for example. …;…
exps_collins: ['The report ranks the UK 20th out of 22 advanced nations.', 'He was at the time ranked 10th in the world and had a regular place in the Swedish Davis Cup team.', 'The United States ranks 20th in its infant mortality rate.', "...the only British woman to be ranked in the top 50 of the women's world rankings.", "Mr Short does not even rank in the world's top ten."]
bis_def_longman: to have a particular position in a list of people or things that have been put in order of quality or importance
exps_longman: ['Today’s match ranks as one of the most exciting games that these two have ever played.', 'We rank among the safest countries in the world.', 'Cuvier wanted to turn natural history into a science that would rank with physics and chemistry.', 'He ranked high among the pioneers of 20th century chemical technology.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to give somebody/something a particular position on a scale according to quality, importance, success, etc.; to have a position of this kind
exps_oxford_advanced: ['The tasks have been ranked in order of difficulty.', 'She is currently the highest ranked player in the world.', 'top-ranked players', 'Voters regularly rank education as being more important than defence.', 'Last year, he was ranked second in his age group.', 'At the height of her career she ranked second in the world.', 'The university is ranked number one in the country for engineering.', "It certainly doesn't rank as his greatest win.", 'The restaurant ranks among the finest in town.', 'This must rank with (= be as good as) the greatest movies ever made.', 'Health and education rank highly with voters.', "You just don't rank (= you're not good enough)."]

sentence: I know it drives you mad , the music but er
gloss: Operate and control the direction and speed of a motor vehicle.
eg_sent: he got into his car and drove off
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; When you drive somewhere, you operate a car or other vehicle and control its movement and direction. ; [Also VERB n preposition/adverb]
exps_collins: ['I drove into town and went to a restaurant for dinner.', 'He put the bags in the car and drove off.', 'She never learned to drive.', "Mrs Glick drove her own car and the girls went in Nancy's convertible."]
bis_def_longman: to make a car, truck, bus etc move along
exps_longman: ['I am planning to drive to Morocco next year.', 'the man driving the car', 'Can you drive?', 'So when did you learn to drive?', 'He drives 12 miles to work.', 'He drives  a BMW estate.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to operate a vehicle so that it goes in a particular direction
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Can you drive?', "Don't drive so fast!", 'I drove to work this morning.', 'Shall we drive (= go there by car) or go by train?', 'He drives a taxi (= that is his job).']

sentence: So I thought well !
gloss: Have a particular opinion, belief, or idea about someone or something.
eg_sent: she thought that nothing would be the same again
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont] ; If you think that something is the case, you have the opinion that it is the case. ; [Also VERB n to-infinitive]
exps_collins: ['I certainly think there should be a ban on tobacco advertising.', 'Do you think I ought to seal the boxes up?.', 'A generation ago, it was thought that babies born this small could not survive.', 'Tell me, what do you think of my theory?.', 'Peter is useless, far worse than I thought.', 'He manages a good deal better than I thought possible.', "'It ought to be stopped.' — 'Yes, I think so.'"]
bis_def_longman: to have a particular opinion or to believe that something is true
exps_longman: ['I think that you’re being unfair.', 'I thought I heard something.', 'He didn’t think anyone would believe him.', 'Do you think I should call him?', 'For some reason, I keep thinking it’s Friday today.', 'The recession lasted longer than anyone thought it would.', 'Am I right in thinking that you have a brother?', 'I can’t help thinking that he’s made a mistake.', 'Do you honestly think I would do something so stupid?', 'What do you think of your new school?', 'I thought it best to call first.', 'I thought it appropriate to invite her to speak at the meeting.', 'We must start thinking in terms of reducing costs.', 'Fraud is thought to be costing software companies millions of dollars a year.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have a particular idea or opinion about something/somebody; to believe something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Do you think (that) they’ll come?', 'I thought I heard a scream.', "I didn't think you liked sports.", 'Am I right in thinking that you used to live here?', "I think this is their house, but I'm not sure.", 'He ought to resign, I think.', "We'll need about 20 chairs, I should think.", 'It was once thought that the sun travelled around the earth.', 'What did you think about the idea?', 'Well, I like it. What do you think?', '‘Will we make it in time?’ ‘I think so.’', "‘Is he any good?’ ‘I don't think so.’", "I think it highly unlikely that I'll get the job.", 'She thought him kind and generous.', "He's thought to be one of the richest men in Europe."]

sentence: It was interesting discussing various chaps after
gloss: Talk about (something) with a person or people.
eg_sent: I discussed the matter with my wife
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; If people discuss something, they talk about it, often in order to reach a decision. ;; [Also VERB wh]
exps_collins: ['I will be discussing the situation with colleagues tomorrow.', 'The cabinet met today to discuss how to respond to the ultimatum.']
bis_def_longman: to talk about something with another person or a group in order to exchange ideas or decide something
exps_longman: ['Littman refused to discuss the case publicly.', 'If you would like to discuss the matter further, please call me.', 'Pupils should be given time to discuss the book with their classmates.', 'Your accountant will discuss with you how to complete these forms.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to talk about something with somebody, especially in order to decide something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Have you discussed the problem with anyone?', "I'm not prepared to discuss this on the phone.", 'They met to discuss the possibility of working together.', 'We need to discuss when we should go.', 'We briefly discussed buying a second car.']

sentence: Many documents are written on the implicit assumption that the reader is much like the writer in terms of expertise and style of thinking .
gloss: Mark (letters, words, or other symbols) on a surface, typically paper, with a pen, pencil, or similar implement.
eg_sent: he wrote his name on the paper
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; When you write something on a surface, you use something such as a pen or pencil to produce words, letters, or numbers on the surface. ;;
exps_collins: ["If you'd like one, simply write your name and address on a postcard and send it to us.", 'They were still trying to teach her to read and write.', "He wrote the word 'pride' in huge letters on the blackboard."]
bis_def_longman: to produce a new book, article, poem etc
exps_longman: ['He wrote some very famous books.', 'Who wrote ‘Harry Potter’?', 'I can’t come with you – I have an essay to write.', "O'Brien often writes about her native Ireland."]
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to make letters or numbers on a surface, especially using a pen or a pencil
exps_oxford_advanced: ["In some countries children don't start learning to read and write until they are six.", 'Please write in pen on both sides of the paper.', "I haven't got anything to write with.", 'Write your name at the top of the paper.', 'The teacher wrote the answers on the board.', 'The ‘b’ had been wrongly written as a ‘d’.']

sentence: From the resulting corner Rhodes made another fine save , hurtling to his right to deflect away Dixon 's rising shot .
gloss: Form (something) by putting parts together or combining substances; create.
eg_sent: my grandmother made a dress for me
bis_def_collins: VERB  ) You can use make with a wide range of nouns to indicate that someone performs an action or says something. For example, if you make a suggestion, you suggest something. )
exps_collins: ["I'd just like to make a comment.", 'I made a few phone calls.', "I think you're making a serious mistake.", 'The Pope said the world had made some progress towards peace in 1991.', 'Science and technology have made major changes to the way we live.', 'She had made us an offer too good to refuse.']
bis_def_longman: to produce something, for example by putting the different parts of it together
exps_longman: ['I’m going to show you how to make a box for your tools.', 'A family of mice had made their nest in the roof.', 'She made her own wedding dress.', 'The company has been making quality furniture for over 200 years.', 'They met while they were making a film.', 'He made her a toy horse, using just some straw and bamboo twigs.', 'Paper is made from wood.', 'a shirt made of silk', 'She’s very good at making things from old scraps of material.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to create or prepare something by combining materials or putting parts together
exps_oxford_advanced: ['to make a table/dress/cake', 'to make bread/cement/paper', 'She makes her own clothes.', 'made in France (= on a label)', "What's your shirt made of?", 'Wine is made from grapes.', 'The grapes are made into wine.', 'She made coffee for us all.', 'She made us all coffee.']

sentence: like that still unnerve me .

gloss: Keep safe or rescue (someone or something) from harm or danger.

sentence: What do you want ?

exps_collins: ['I want a drink.', 'Ian knows exactly what he wants in life.', 'People wanted to know who this talented designer was.', 'They began to want their father to be the same as other daddies.', "They didn't want people staring at them as they sat on the lawn, so they put up high walls.", 'He wanted his power recognised.', 'I want my car this colour.', 'And remember, we want him alive.', "Note that want and wish have similar meanings, but are used differently. If you want something, you feel a need for it or a desire to have it. You can say that you want to do something, that you want someone to do something, or that you want something to happen. If you use wish with a 'to' infinitive, this has the same meaning as want but is more formal. I want to get out of here... She wished to consult him about her future."]

bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; If someone or something faces a particular thing, person, or direction, they are positioned opposite them or are looking in that direction. ;;
bis_def_longman: if you face or are faced with a difficult situation, or if a difficult situation faces you, it is going to affect you and you must deal with it
exps_longman: ['Emergency services are facing additional problems this winter.', 'The president faces the difficult task of putting the economy back on its feet.', 'McManus is facing the biggest challenge of his career.', 'As the project comes to an end, many workers now face an uncertain future.', 'He must face the prospect of financial ruin.', 'I was faced with the awful job of breaking the news to the girl’s family.', 'the difficulties faced by the police', 'If he is found guilty, he faces up to 12 years in jail.', 'He was the first member of the former government to face criminal charges.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to be opposite somebody/something; to have your face or front pointing towards somebody/something or in a particular direction
exps_oxford_advanced: ['She turned and faced him.', 'Most of the rooms face the sea.', 'The terrace faces south.', 'a north-facing wall', 'Stand with your feet apart and your hands facing upwards.', 'Which direction are you facing?']

sentence: You do n't know the area , no .
gloss: Be aware of through observation, inquiry, or information.
eg_sent: most people know that CFCs can damage the ozone layer
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont]  If you know a fact, a piece of information, or an answer, you have it correctly in your mind.
exps_collins: ["I don't know the name of the place.", 'I know that you led a rifle platoon during the Second World War.', "'People like doing things for nothing.' — 'I know they do.'.", "I don't know what happened to her husband.", "'How did he meet your mother?' — 'I don't know.'.", 'We all know about his early experiments in flying.', 'They looked younger than I knew them to be.', 'Radon is known to be harmful to humans in large quantities.', 'It is not known whether the bomb was originally intended for the capital itself.', "It's always been known that key figures in the government do very well for themselves."]
bis_def_longman: to have information about something
exps_longman: ['Who knows the answer?', 'There are instructions telling you everything you need to know.', 'Didn’t you know that?', 'Do you know what time it is?', 'I don’t know where to go.', 'I need to know more about the job before I decide whether to apply for it.', 'Little is known about the author’s childhood.', 'I know all about David and what he’s been up to!', 'I wonder if he knew of the plan?', 'Do you know of any good restaurants in the area?', 'You know nothing of this business.', 'We know that greenhouse gases can affect the climate.', 'Let me know what time you’re planning to arrive.', 'I thought you’d want to know immediately.', 'If you must know, I was with James last night .', 'He slipped out of the house without his parents knowing .', 'How did he know our names?', '‘I’m divorced, as you know, ’ she said briefly.', 'Smoking is known to increase a person’s risk of developing lung cancer.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have information in your mind as a result of experience or because you have learned or been told it
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Do you know his address?', 'The cause of the fire is not yet known.', 'All I know is that she used to work in a bank (= I have no other information about her).', 'I know (that) people’s handwriting changes as they get older.', 'It is widely known that CFCs can damage the ozone layer.', 'I knew where he was hiding.', "I didn't know what he was talking about.", "‘You've got a flat tyre.’ ‘I know.’", "‘What's the answer?’ ‘I don't know.’", "‘There's no one in.’ ‘How do you know?’", "You know about Amanda's baby, don't you?", "I don't know about you, but I'm ready for something to eat.", 'I know of at least two people who did the same thing.', '‘Is anyone else coming?’ ‘Not that I know of.’', '‘Isn’t that his car?’ ‘I wouldn’t know./How should I know?’ (= I don’t know and I am not the person you should ask.)', "‘What are you two whispering about?’ ‘You don't want to know’ (= because you would be shocked or wouldn't approve).", 'Does he know to come here (= that he should come here) first?', 'We know her to be honest.', 'Two women are known to have died.']

sentence: The visual inspiration for the book was the famous advert for Start-rite shoes , showing a small boy and girl walking off down a tree-lined avenue an innocent image if ever there was one .
gloss: Allow or cause (something) to be visible.
eg_sent: a white blouse will show the blood
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; If something shows that a state of affairs exists, it gives information that proves it or makes it clear to people. ;;
exps_collins: ['Research shows that a high-fibre diet may protect you from bowel cancer.', 'He was arrested at his home in Southampton after a breath test showed he had drunk more than twice the legal limit for driving.', 'These figures show an increase of over one million in unemployment.', 'It was only later that the drug was shown to be addictive.', "You'll be given regular blood tests to show whether you have been infected."]
bis_def_longman: to let someone see something
exps_longman: ['The children proudly showed me their presents.', 'The man grinned, showing bad teeth.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to make something clear; to prove something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['The figures clearly show that her claims are false.', "The government's popularity is declining rapidly, as the opinion polls show.", 'Market research has shown us that people want quality, not just low prices.', 'a report showing the company’s current situation', 'His new book shows him to be a first-rate storyteller.', 'This shows how people are influenced by TV advertisements.']

sentence: Listing , in theory , is an objective assessment of architectural or historical importance which does not necessarily prevent demolition .
gloss: Keep (something) from happening.
eg_sent: action must be taken to prevent further accidents
bis_def_collins: To prevent something means to ensure that it does not happen.
exps_collins: ['These methods prevent pregnancy.', 'Further treatment will prevent cancer from developing.', 'We recognized the possibility and took steps to prevent it happening.']
bis_def_longman: to stop something from happening, or stop someone from doing something
exps_longman: ['The rules are intended to prevent accidents.', 'His back injury may prevent him from playing in tomorrow’s game.', 'We were prevented from entering the site.', 'Wrap small ornaments in paper to prevent them being damaged.', 'preventable diseases', 'Every one of these deaths is preventable.', 'government regulators working to prevent fraud', 'The region’s huge economic problems will prevent it from realizing its potential.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to stop somebody from doing something; to stop something from happening
exps_oxford_advanced: ['The accident could have been prevented.', 'The government took steps to prevent a scandal.', 'He is prevented by law from holding a licence.', 'Nothing would prevent him from speaking out against injustice.', 'Nothing would prevent him/his speaking out against injustice.']

sentence: In describing its vision of effective supervision the White Paper goes on to note :
gloss: Notice or pay particular attention to (something)
eg_sent: he noted his mother's unusual gaiety
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; If you note a fact, you become aware of it. ;
bis_def_longman: to notice or pay careful attention to something
exps_longman: ['He carefully noted the time when they left the building.', 'Please note that the bill must be paid within ten days.', 'It should be noted that parking without a permit attracts a charge of £5.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to notice or pay careful attention to something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Note the fine early Baroque altar inside the chapel.', 'Please note (that) the office will be closed on Monday.', 'Note how these animals sometimes walk with their tails up in the air.', 'It should be noted that dissertations submitted late will not be accepted.']

sentence: The ideal hotel from which to explore is Dedham Hall , set among tall trees in the Vale of Dedham , looking directly across towards Dedham church on one side and Flatford Mill on the other : both painted by Constable .
gloss: Put, lay, or stand (something) in a specified place or position.
eg_sent: Delaney set the mug of tea down
bis_def_collins: VERB  ) If you set something somewhere, you put it there, especially in a careful or deliberate way. )
bis_def_longman: to carefully put something down somewhere
exps_longman: ['She set the tray down on a table next to his bed.', 'Mark filled the pan and set it on the stove.', 'The workmen set the box down carefully on the floor.', 'Remove the mushrooms and set them aside.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to put something/somebody in a particular place or position
exps_oxford_advanced: ['She set a tray down on the table.', 'They ate everything that was set in front of them.', 'The house is set (= located) in fifty acres of parkland.']

sentence: We can use the methods described above to elucidate some of these occupations , and get a glimpse , albeit an imperfect one , of the trilobite as it lived .
gloss: Make (something) clear; explain.
eg_sent: work such as theirs will help to elucidate this matter
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; If you elucidate something, you make it clear and easy to understand. ; [formal]
exps_collins: ['Haig went on to elucidate his personal principle of war.', 'There was no need for him to elucidate.']
bis_def_longman: to explain something that is difficult to understand by providing more information
exps_longman: ['The full picture has not yet been elucidated.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to make something clearer by explaining it more fully
exps_oxford_advanced: ['He elucidated a point of grammar.', 'The aim of the report is to elucidate the main points of the new regulations.', 'Let me elucidate.', 'I will try to elucidate what I think the problems are.']

sentence: The usual tactic was to march troops across the enemy 's territory , plundering and looting ; to take fortified places if the task was easy ; to obtain allies among the lords of the locality ; and to retreat without fighting a battle if at all possible in effect an application to a wider canvas of the some technique of warfare which had earlier made castellans formidable in the immediate environs of their castles .
gloss: Form (something) by putting parts together or combining substances; create.
eg_sent: my grandmother made a dress for me
bis_def_collins: VERB  ) You can use make with a wide range of nouns to indicate that someone performs an action or says something. For example, if you make a suggestion, you suggest something. )
exps_collins: ["I'd just like to make a comment.", 'I made a few phone calls.', "I think you're making a serious mistake.", 'The Pope said the world had made some progress towards peace in 1991.', 'Science and technology have made major changes to the way we live.', 'She had made us an offer too good to refuse.']
bis_def_longman: to produce something, for example by putting the different parts of it together
exps_longman: ['I’m going to show you how to make a box for your tools.', 'A family of mice had made their nest in the roof.', 'She made her own wedding dress.', 'The company has been making quality furniture for over 200 years.', 'They met while they were making a film.', 'He made her a toy horse, using just some straw and bamboo twigs.', 'Paper is made from wood.', 'a shirt made of silk', 'She’s very good at making things from old scraps of material.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to create or prepare something by combining materials or putting parts together
exps_oxford_advanced: ['to make a table/dress/cake', 'to make bread/cement/paper', 'She makes her own clothes.', 'made in France (= on a label)', "What's your shirt made of?", 'Wine is made from grapes.', 'The grapes are made into wine.', 'She made coffee for us all.', 'She made us all coffee.']

sentence: Scots law treats as murder killings with wicked recklessness , a phrase which directs the court 's attention to the circumstances of the killing .
gloss: Control the operations of; manage or govern.
eg_sent: an economic elite directed the nation's affairs
bis_def_collins: VERB  …;… If you direct something at a particular thing, you aim or point it at that thing. …;…
exps_collins: ['I directed the extinguisher at the fire without effect.', 'He directed the tiny beam of light at the roof.']
bis_def_longman: to aim something in a particular direction or at a particular person, group etc
exps_longman: ['The machine directs an X-ray beam at the patient’s body.', 'The new route directs lorries away from the town centre.', 'I’d like to direct your attention to paragraph four.', 'I want to direct my efforts more towards my own projects.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to aim something in a particular direction or at a particular person
exps_oxford_advanced: ['The machine directs a powerful beam at the affected part of the body.', 'Was that remark directed at me?', 'There are three main issues that we need to direct our attention to.', 'Most of his anger was directed against himself.']

sentence: I 've just left them and I 'm going back .
gloss: Move from one place to another; travel.
eg_sent: he went out to the shops
bis_def_collins: When you go somewhere, you move or travel there.
exps_collins: ['We went to Rome.', 'Gladys had just gone into the kitchen.', 'I went home at the weekend.', 'Four of them had gone off to find help.', 'It took us an hour to go three miles.']
bis_def_longman: to travel or move to a place that is away from where you are or where you live
exps_longman: ['There’s nothing more we can do here. Let’s go home.', 'Where are you going?', 'We’re going to Canada in the summer.', 'Dinah went into the kitchen.', 'She went over and put her arm around him.', 'I’m going round to her house to find out what’s wrong.', 'I’ll just go up  and ask him what he wants.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to move or travel from one place to another
exps_oxford_advanced: ['She went into her room and shut the door behind her.', 'He goes to work by bus.', 'I have to go to Rome on business.', 'She has gone to China (= is now in China or is on her way there).', 'She has been to China (= she went to China and has now returned).', "I think you should go to the doctor's.", 'Are you going home for Christmas?', 'She has gone to see her sister this weekend.']

sentence: In practice , legislation generally forbids such data being held thus and distributed in anything other than area aggregate form ; the cross-tabulations commonly employed ( e.g. to give tables of population numbers broken down by age and sex ) often result in a great multiplication of the data volumes .
gloss: Occur or follow as the consequence of something.
eg_sent: anger may result from an argument
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; If something results in a particular situation or event, it causes that situation or event to happen. ;;
exps_collins: ['Fifty per cent of road accidents result in head injuries.', 'Regular trips back to her adopted motherland have resulted in her first book, Tiger Balm.']
bis_def_longman: if something results from something else, it is caused by it
exps_longman: ['We are still dealing with problems resulting from errors made in the past.', 'How would you cope with unemployment and the resulting loss of income?']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to happen because of something else that happened first
exps_oxford_advanced: ['job losses resulting from changes in production', 'When water levels rise, flooding results.', 'It was a large explosion and the resulting damage was extensive.']

sentence: I never realized it 's first time price .
gloss: Become fully aware of (something) as a fact; understand clearly.
eg_sent: he realized his mistake at once
bis_def_collins: If you realize that something is true, you become aware of that fact or understand it.
exps_collins: ['As soon as we realised something was wrong, we moved the children away.', "People don't realize how serious this recession has actually been.", 'Once they realised their mistake the phone was reconnected again.', "'That's my brother.'—'Oh, I hadn't realized.'"]
bis_def_longman: to know and understand something, or suddenly begin to understand it
exps_longman: ['I suddenly realized that the boy was crying.', 'Do you realize you’re an hour late?', 'I’m sorry, I didn’t realize who you were.', 'It took us a while to realize the extent of the tragedy.', 'It was only later that I realized my mistake.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to understand or become aware of a particular fact or situation
exps_oxford_advanced: ['I didn’t realize (that) you were so unhappy.', 'The moment I saw her, I realized something was wrong.', "I don't think you realize how important this is to her.", 'I hope you realize the seriousness of this crime.', 'Only later did she realize her mistake.', 'The situation was more complicated than they had at first realized.', 'They managed to leave without any of us realizing.', 'There was a cheer when it was realized that everyone was safely back.']

sentence: Mark asked .
gloss: Say something in order to obtain an answer or some information.
eg_sent: I asked her what she meant
bis_def_collins: If you ask someone something, you say something to them in the form of a question because you want to know the answer.  [Also V about n]
exps_collins: ["'How is Frank?' he asked.", 'I asked him his name.', "I wasn't the only one asking questions.", "She asked me if I'd enjoyed my dinner.", 'If Daniel asks what happened in court we will tell him.', 'You will have to ask David about that.', "'I'm afraid to ask what it cost.' — 'Then don't ask.'"]
bis_def_longman: to speak or write to someone in order to get an answer, information, or a solution
exps_longman: ['‘What’s your name?’ she asked.', 'Don’t ask him – he won’t know.', 'That kid’s always asking awkward questions.', 'I asked him where he lived.', 'We’ll have to ask someone the way to the station.', 'Go and ask Tom whether he’s coming tonight.', 'Visitors usually ask about the history of the castle.', 'I’ll ask around, see if I can find you a place to stay.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to say or write something in the form of a question, in order to get information
exps_oxford_advanced: ['How old are you—if you don’t mind me/my asking?', 'He asked about her family.', 'Can I ask a question?', 'Did you ask the price?', '‘Where are you going?’ she asked.', '‘Are you sure?’ he asked her.', 'She asked the students their names.', 'I often get asked that!', 'The interviewer asked me about my future plans.', 'He asked where I lived.', 'I had to ask the teacher what to do next.', 'I was asked if/whether I could drive.']

sentence: Obviously striving to be as controlled as possible , she smiled .
gloss: Form one's features into a pleased, kind, or amused expression, typically with the corners of the mouth turned up and the front teeth exposed.
eg_sent: she was smiling broadly
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; When you smile, the corners of your mouth curve up and you sometimes show your teeth. People smile when they are pleased or amused, or when they are being friendly. ;
exps_collins: ['When he saw me, he smiled and waved.', 'He rubbed the back of his neck and smiled ruefully at me.', 'His smiling face appears on T-shirts, billboards, and posters.']
bis_def_longman: to make your mouth curve upwards, in order to be friendly or because you are happy or amused
exps_longman: ['Susan smiled at him and waved.', 'She had to smile at his enthusiasm .', 'her smiling face', 'I haven’t had much to smile about lately.', 'Mark read the message and smiled to himself.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to make a smile appear on your face
exps_oxford_advanced: ['to smile sweetly/faintly/broadly, etc.', 'He smiled with relief.', 'He never seems to smile.', 'He smiled to think how naive he used to be.', 'She smiled at him and he smiled back.', 'I had to smile at (= was amused by) his optimism.', 'Her eyes smiled up at him.']

sentence: And it does , once you 've actually heated the water it keeps hot for so long it 's amazing .
gloss: Make or become hot or warm.
eg_sent: the room faces north and is difficult to heat

exps_collins: ['Meanwhile, heat the tomatoes and oil in a pan.', "...a gas that absorbs the sun's energy and heats the air above it.", '...heated swimming pools.']
bis_def_longman: to make something become warm or hot

exps_oxford_advanced: ['Heat the oil and add the onions.', 'The system produced enough energy to heat several thousand homes.']

sentence: I remember him saying it was a shame that he had to punish us both when only one of us was being naughty .
gloss: Have in or be able to bring to one's mind an awareness of (someone or something from the past)
eg_sent: I remember the screech of the horn as the car came towards me
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; If you remember people or events from the past, you still have an idea of them in your mind and you are able to think about them. ;;
exps_collins: ["You wouldn't remember me. I was in another group.", "I certainly don't remember talking to you at all.", 'I remember her being a dominant figure.', 'I remembered that we had drunk the last of the coffee the week before.', 'I can remember where and when I bought each one.', 'I used to do that when you were a little girl, remember?']
bis_def_longman: to have a picture or idea in your mind of people, events, places etc from the past
exps_longman: ['Do you remember Rosa Davies?', 'I can’t remember her exact words.', 'I remember you two couldn’t stand each other at first!', 'I remember meeting her at a party once.', 'I remember my father bringing home a huge Christmas tree.', 'I remember it well; I’d never seen my mother so angry.', 'She clearly remembers the excitement as they boarded the train.', 'I vaguely remember reading something about it in the paper.', 'They had three children, if I remember rightly.', 'They’ve lived here for as long as I can remember.', 'No one got drunk as far as I can remember.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have or keep an image in your memory of an event, a person, a place, etc. from the past
exps_oxford_advanced: ['This is Carla. Do you remember her?', "I don't remember my first day at school.", "He still remembered her as the lively teenager he'd known years before.", "As far as I can remember, this is the third time we've met.", 'Do you remember switching the lights off before we came out?', 'I vaguely remember hearing him come in.', 'I can still vividly remember my grandfather teaching me to play cards.', "I can't remember his taking a single day off work.", 'I remember (that) we used to go and see them most weekends.']

bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; If you remember people or events from the past, you still have an idea of them in your mind and you are able to think about them. ;;
exps_collins: ["You wouldn't remember me. I was in another group.", "I certainly don't remember talking to you at all.", 'I remember her being a dominant figure.', 'I remembered that we had drunk the last of the coffee the week before.', 'I can remember where and when I bought each one.', 'I used to do that when you were a little girl, remember?']
bis_def_longman: to have a picture or idea in your mind of people, events, places etc from the past
exps_longman: ['Do you remember Rosa Davies?', 'I can’t remember her exact words.', 'I remember you two couldn’t stand each other at first!', 'I remember meeting her at a party once.', 'I remember my father bringing home a huge Christmas tree.', 'I remember it well; I’d never seen my mother so angry.', 'She clearly remembers the excitement as they boarded the train.', 'I vaguely remember reading something about it in the paper.', 'They had three children, if I remember rightly.', 'They’ve lived here for as long as I can remember.', 'No one got drunk as far as I can remember.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have or keep an image in your memory of an event, a person, a place, etc. from the past
exps_oxford_advanced: ['This is Carla. Do you remember her?', "I don't remember my first day at school.", "He still remembered her as the lively teenager he'd known years before.", "As far as I can remember, this is the third time we've met.", 'Do you remember switching the lights off before we came out?', 'I vaguely remember hearing him come in.', 'I can still vividly remember my grandfather teaching me to play cards.', "I can't remember his taking a single day off work.", 'I remember (that) we used to go and see them most weekends.']

sentence: It is generally accepted ( p. 145 ) that hygiene type variables such as pay and working conditions can , if they are inappropriately specified , depress morale and motivation but they will not in themselves result in very high levels of these parameters .

sentence: In the early 1980s social workers were funded jointly by the ILEA and Islington Social Services Department to work with children attending two special schools and two specialist units for partially hearing children .
gloss: Provide with money for a particular purpose.

bis_def_collins: VERB  ;… When a person or organization funds something, they provide money for it. ;…

sentence: At Bankside , however , he was able to persuade the engineers , Mott , Hay & Anderson , to gather all the flues into a single slender tower or campanile .
gloss: Induce (someone) to do something through reasoning or argument.

sentence: No shower curtain mind you .

sentence: Those with an interest in health and air pollution should note the availability of a very detailed database from the Warren Springs Laboratory , containing details of smoke and sulphur dioxide emissions at a large number of sites in the UK .

Let’s go home.', 'Where are you going?', 'We’re going to Canada in the summer.', 'Dinah went into the kitchen.', 'She went over and put her arm around him.', 'I’m going round to her house to find out what’s wrong.', 'I’ll just go up  and ask him what he wants.']

sentence: If the approach was that way he would get no warning at all , and it would be on top of George his name for the dummy sitting like a drunken son-of-a-bitch before he knew it .
gloss: Come to have (something); receive.
eg_sent: I got a letter from him the other day
bis_def_collins: You use get with adjectives to mean 'become'. For example, if someone gets cold, they become cold, and if they get angry, they become angry.

sentence: Delaney took the lead .
gloss: Lay hold of (something) with one's hands; reach for and hold.
eg_sent: Mrs Morgan took another biscuit
bis_def_collins: You can use take followed by a noun to talk about an action or event, when it would also be possible to use the verb that is related to that noun. For example, you can say 'she took a shower' instead of 'she showered'.

bis_def_longman: to move or go with someone or something from one place to another

sentence: For their part , Leinster are boosted by the presence of four players already selected for Ireland to play New Zealand in Dublin on November 18 .
gloss: Engage in activity for enjoyment and recreation rather than a serious or practical purpose.

sentence: He was a sensible and capable boy , an eldest child , so he moved closer , trying not to breathe , and stood steadfastly looking until he was confident of what he had seen : a body , must be a girl because it was wearing a skirt , lying face down , head towards the bottom of the embankment as if she had dived off the top .
gloss: Perceive with the eyes; discern visually.
eg_sent: in the distance she could see the blue sea
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont] ; When you see something, you notice it using your eyes. ;
exps_collins: ["You can't see colours at night.", 'I saw a man making his way towards me.', 'She can see, hear, touch, smell, and taste.', 'As he neared the farm, he saw that a police car was parked outside it.', 'Did you see what happened?', 'You use see to talk about things that you are aware of because a visual impression reaches your eyes. You often use can in this case. I can see the fax here on the desk. If you want to say that someone is paying attention to something they can see, you say that they are looking at it or watching it. In general, you look at something that is not moving, while you watch something that is moving or changing. I asked him to look at the picture above his bed... He watched Blake run down the stairs.']
bis_def_longman: to notice or examine someone or something, using your eyes
exps_longman: ['He crouched down so he couldn’t be seen.', 'Can I see your ticket, please?', 'You can see the Houses of Parliament from here.', 'Can you see where the marks are on the wall?', 'The suspect was seen entering the building.', 'As you can see, the house needs some work doing on it.', 'Have you seen Chris ?', 'The accommodation was so awful it had to be seen to be believed.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to become aware of somebody/something by using your eyes

sentence: It would also be necessary to smash the decrepit , effete constitution that allows a minority to capture power , and then use it ruthlessly in the interests of the privileged few .

exps_collins: ['He examined her passport and stamped it.', "Forensic scientists are examining what police believe to have been the bombers' car."]

exps_longman: ['A team of divers was sent down to examine the wreck.', 'Hegel’s philosophy will be examined in detail in Chapter 4.', 'In the course, we will examine how and why Spain became a democracy in 1931.', 'The police will have to examine the weapon for fingerprints.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to consider or study an idea, a subject, etc. very carefully
exps_oxford_advanced: ['These ideas will be examined in more detail in Chapter 10.', 'It is necessary to examine how the proposals can be carried out.']

sentence: Going through France ah the Severn and then all these towns .
gloss: Move from one place to another; travel.
eg_sent: he went out to the shops
bis_def_collins: When you go somewhere, you move or travel there.
exps_collins: ['We went to Rome.', 'Gladys had just gone into the kitchen.', 'I went home at the weekend.', 'Four of them had gone off to find help.', 'It took us an hour to go three miles.']
bis_def_longman: to travel or move to a place that is away from where you are or where you live
exps_longman: ['There’s nothing more we can do here. Let’s go home.', 'Where are you going?', 'We’re going to Canada in the summer.', 'Dinah went into the kitchen.', 'She went over and put her arm around him.', 'I’m going round to her house to find out what’s wrong.', 'I’ll just go up  and ask him what he wants.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to move or travel from one place to another
exps_oxford_advanced: ['She went into her room and shut the door behind her.', 'He goes to work by bus.', 'I have to go to Rome on business.', 'She has gone to China (= is now in China or is on her way there).', 'She has been to China (= she went to China and has now returned).', "I think you should go to the doctor's.", 'Are you going home for Christmas?', 'She has gone to see her sister this weekend.']

sentence: On the other hand , if there is usually insufficient notice of need it may be necessary to keep staff who have periods with little to do between projects .
gloss: Have or retain possession of.
eg_sent: return one copy to me, keeping the other for your files
bis_def_collins: If someone keeps or is kept in a particular state, they remain in it.
exps_collins: ['The noise kept him awake.', 'Reggie was being kept busy behind the bar.', 'To keep warm they burnt wood in a rusty oil barrel.', 'For several years I kept in touch with her.']
bis_def_longman: to stay in a particular state, condition, or position, or to make someone or something do this
exps_longman: ['We huddled around the fire to keep warm.', 'I was struggling to keep awake.', 'some toys to keep the kids amused', 'You won’t be able to keep it secret forever.', 'Peter cycles to work to keep fit.', 'Don’t keep us in suspense any longer!', 'The police put up barriers to keep the crowds back.', 'If I were you, I’d keep away from that area at night.', 'The little boy kept close to his mother.', 'You keep out of this, Mother . It’s no concern of yours.', 'How can I cut your hair if you won’t keep still!', 'Jane kept the engine running.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to stay in a particular condition or position; to make somebody/something do this
exps_oxford_advanced: ['We huddled together to keep warm.', 'The notice said ‘Keep off (= Do not walk on) the grass’.', 'Keep left along the wall.', 'She kept the children amused for hours.', 'He kept his coat on.', "Don't keep us in suspense—what happened next?", 'She had trouble keeping her balance.', "I'm very sorry to keep you waiting."]

sentence: Intellectuals claimed a formative influence in the second too : John of Marmoutier declared that monks from his own monastery had read Vegetius ' De Re Militari to Geoffrey le Bel when he was investing the castle of a rebellious castellan , and ascribed his success to their advice on firebombs .
gloss: Say something in a solemn and emphatic manner.
eg_sent: the prime minister declared that the programme of austerity had paid off
bis_def_collins: VERB  …() If you declare that something is true, you say that it is true in a firm, deliberate way. You can also declare an attitude or intention. …() [written] [Also V n n, V n to-inf]
exps_collins: ['Speaking outside Ten Downing Street, she declared that she would fight on.', "'I'm absolutely thrilled to have done what I've done,' he declared.", 'He declared his intention to become the best golfer in the world.', 'Glasses of Madeira wine were brought to us. We declared it delicious.', 'He turned up in northern Cyprus, declaring himself happy to be home.']
bis_def_longman: to state officially and publicly that a particular situation exists or that something is true
exps_longman: ['A state of emergency has been declared.', 'The court declared that Brown’s case should be reviewed.', 'Several countries wanted Antarctica to be declared a ‘world park’.', 'The city was declared to be in a state of siege.', 'I declare you man and wife.', 'The war was declared illegal by the International Court of Justice.', 'Mr Steel has been declared bankrupt.', 'We celebrate September 16, the day when Mexico declared independence from Spain .']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to say something officially or publicly
exps_oxford_advanced: ['The government has declared a state of emergency.', 'Germany declared war on France on 1 August 1914.', 'The government has declared war on (= officially stated its intention to stop) illiteracy.', 'The court declared that strike action was illegal.', 'The area has been declared a national park.', 'The painting was declared to be a forgery.', 'The contract was declared void.', 'I declare this bridge open.']

sentence: Dress not only covers and decorates the body but instils in the wearer its own characteristic strengths and weaknesses .
gloss: Gradually but firmly establish (an idea or attitude) in a person's mind.
eg_sent: the standards her parents had instilled into her
bis_def_collins: If you instil an idea or feeling in someone, especially over a period of time, you make them think it or feel it.
exps_collins: ['They hope that their work will instil a sense of responsibility in children.', 'The motive of the executions would be to instil fear.']
bis_def_longman: to teach someone to think, behave, or feel in a particular way over a period of time
exps_longman: ['A manager’s job is to instil determination into his players.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to gradually make somebody feel, think or behave in a particular way over a period of time
exps_oxford_advanced: ['to instil confidence/discipline/fear into somebody']

sentence: I hope you 're ready to help me , she said .
gloss: Want something to happen or be the case.
eg_sent: he's hoping for an offer of compensation
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; If you hope that something is true, or if you hope for something, you want it to be true or to happen, and you usually believe that it is possible or likely. ;
exps_collins: ['She had decided she must go on as usual, follow her normal routine, and hope and pray.', 'He hesitates before leaving, almost as though he had been hoping for conversation.', 'I hope to get a job within the next two weeks.', "The researchers hope that such a vaccine could be available in about ten years' time.", "'We'll speak again.' — 'I hope so.'", "'Will it happen again?' — 'I hope not, but you never know.'"]
bis_def_longman: to want something to happen or be true and to believe that it is possible or likely
exps_longman: ['We hope that more women will decide to join the course.', 'I do hope everything goes well.', 'It was hoped that the job would be filled by a local person.', 'Let’s just hope someone finds her bag.', 'I hope to God I haven’t left the car window open.', 'Liam decided to ignore the warning and just hope for the best.', 'I rang my parents, hoping against hope that they hadn’t left yet.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to want something to happen and think that it is possible
exps_oxford_advanced: ['We are hoping for good weather on Sunday.', 'All we can do now is wait and hope.', '‘Do you think it will rain?’ ‘I hope not.’', '‘Will you be back before dark?’ ‘I hope so, yes.’', 'The exam went better than I’d dared hope.', 'I’ll see you next week, I hope.', 'I hope (that) you’re okay.', 'I can only hope (that) there has been some mistake.', 'Detectives are hoping (that) witnesses will come forward.', "Let's hope we can find a parking space.", 'It is hoped that over £10\u2009000 will be raised.', 'She is hoping to win the gold medal.', 'We hope to arrive around two.', 'What had he hoped to achieve?']

sentence: Ellen , usually so quick with a scornful reply , just stood and stared at the elegant stranger who stopped one pace away from her , took her hand , then bowed above her fingers .
gloss: Lay hold of (something) with one's hands; reach for and hold.
eg_sent: Mrs Morgan took another biscuit
bis_def_collins: You can use take followed by a noun to talk about an action or event, when it would also be possible to use the verb that is related to that noun. For example, you can say 'she took a shower' instead of 'she showered'.
exps_collins: ['She was too tired to take a shower.', 'Betty took a photograph of us.', "I've never taken a holiday since starting this job.", "There's not enough people willing to take the risk.", 'Walk around the property and take a good look at it from the outside.', 'We took a long walk through the pines.']
bis_def_longman: to move or go with someone or something from one place to another
exps_longman: ['Barney took us to the airport.', 'Would you mind taking Susie home?', 'When he refused to give his name, he was taken into custody.', 'My job has taken me all over the world.', 'His wife went to Australia, taking the children with her.', 'I have to take Steve the money tonight.', 'He took me to meet his parents.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to carry or move something from one place to another
exps_oxford_advanced: ['I forgot to take my bag with me when I got off the bus.', 'Take this to the bank for me, would you?', 'Shall I take a gift to my host family?', 'Shall I take my host family a gift?']

sentence: And they were saying , they were saying that , you know , you associate strokes with older people , but there 's a hundred young people a week have strokes !
gloss: Be aware of through observation, inquiry, or information.
eg_sent: most people know that CFCs can damage the ozone layer
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont]  If you know a fact, a piece of information, or an answer, you have it correctly in your mind.
exps_collins: ["I don't know the name of the place.", 'I know that you led a rifle platoon during the Second World War.', "'People like doing things for nothing.' — 'I know they do.'.", "I don't know what happened to her husband.", "'How did he meet your mother?' — 'I don't know.'.", 'We all know about his early experiments in flying.', 'They looked younger than I knew them to be.', 'Radon is known to be harmful to humans in large quantities.', 'It is not known whether the bomb was originally intended for the capital itself.', "It's always been known that key figures in the government do very well for themselves."]
bis_def_longman: to have information about something
exps_longman: ['Who knows the answer?', 'There are instructions telling you everything you need to know.', 'Didn’t you know that?', 'Do you know what time it is?', 'I don’t know where to go.', 'I need to know more about the job before I decide whether to apply for it.', 'Little is known about the author’s childhood.', 'I know all about David and what he’s been up to!', 'I wonder if he knew of the plan?', 'Do you know of any good restaurants in the area?', 'You know nothing of this business.', 'We know that greenhouse gases can affect the climate.', 'Let me know what time you’re planning to arrive.', 'I thought you’d want to know immediately.', 'If you must know, I was with James last night .', 'He slipped out of the house without his parents knowing .', 'How did he know our names?', '‘I’m divorced, as you know, ’ she said briefly.', 'Smoking is known to increase a person’s risk of developing lung cancer.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have information in your mind as a result of experience or because you have learned or been told it
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Do you know his address?', 'The cause of the fire is not yet known.', 'All I know is that she used to work in a bank (= I have no other information about her).', 'I know (that) people’s handwriting changes as they get older.', 'It is widely known that CFCs can damage the ozone layer.', 'I knew where he was hiding.', "I didn't know what he was talking about.", "‘You've got a flat tyre.’ ‘I know.’", "‘What's the answer?’ ‘I don't know.’", "‘There's no one in.’ ‘How do you know?’", "You know about Amanda's baby, don't you?", "I don't know about you, but I'm ready for something to eat.", 'I know of at least two people who did the same thing.', '‘Is anyone else coming?’ ‘Not that I know of.’', '‘Isn’t that his car?’ ‘I wouldn’t know./How should I know?’ (= I don’t know and I am not the person you should ask.)', "‘What are you two whispering about?’ ‘You don't want to know’ (= because you would be shocked or wouldn't approve).", 'Does he know to come here (= that he should come here) first?', 'We know her to be honest.', 'Two women are known to have died.']

bis_def_collins: If you limit something, you prevent it from becoming greater than a particular amount or degree.

bis_def_longman: to stop an amount or number from increasing beyond a particular point
exps_longman: ['a decision to limit imports of foreign cars', 'Seating is limited to 500.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to stop something from increasing beyond a particular amount or level
exps_oxford_advanced: ['measures to limit carbon dioxide emissions from cars', 'The amount of money you have to spend will limit your choice.']

sentence: I 've so much news to tell you .
gloss: Communicate information to someone in spoken or written words.
eg_sent: I told her you were coming
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; If you tell someone something, you give them information. ; [Also V of n]
exps_collins: ['In the evening I returned to tell Phyllis our relationship was over.', 'I called Andie to tell her how spectacular the stuff looked.', 'Claire had made me promise to tell her the truth.', 'I only told the truth to the press when the single was released as it seemed the perfect time to do it.', 'Tell us about your moment on the summit.', "Her voice breaking with emotion, she told him: 'It doesn't seem fair'."]
bis_def_longman: if someone tells you something, they communicate information, a story, their feelings etc to you
exps_longman: ['I wish someone had told me the meeting was canceled.', 'The Chief of Police told reporters that two people were killed in the blast.', 'Jack had to go, but he didn’t tell me why.', 'I think you’d better tell me exactly what’s been going on around here.', 'No one had told them about the drug’s side effects.', 'I’ll tell you all about it when I get back.', 'She told us some funny stories about her sister.', 'Sheppard was telling the truth.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to give information to somebody by speaking or writing
exps_oxford_advanced: ['He told the news to everybody he saw.', 'He told everybody he saw the news.', 'Did she tell you her name?', 'What did I tell you? (= you should have listened to my advice)', "Why wasn't I told about the accident?", 'They’ve told us (that) they’re not coming.', 'I kept telling myself (that) everything was OK.', "Are you telling me you didn't have any help with this? (= I don't believe what you have said)", 'Tell me where you live.', "‘I'm ready to go now,’ he told her."]

sentence: Adam might have escaped the file memories for years , suppressed them and jerked violently away from them , but he had never been able to pretend he was unscathed by those events .
gloss: Behave so as to make it appear that something is the case when in fact it is not.
eg_sent: I closed my eyes and pretended I was asleep
bis_def_collins: If you pretend that something is the case, you act in a way that is intended to make people believe that it is the case, although in fact it is not.
exps_collins: ["I pretend that things are really okay when they're not.", 'Sometimes the boy pretended to be asleep.', 'I had no option but to pretend ignorance.']
bis_def_longman: to behave as if something is true when in fact you know it is not, in order to deceive people or for fun
exps_longman: ['We can’t go on pretending that everything is OK.', 'Let’s pretend we’re on the Moon.', 'She pretended not to notice.', 'He’s not asleep – he’s just pretending.', 'To pretend ignorance of the situation would be irresponsible.', 'I can’t marry her and to pretend otherwise would be wrong.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to behave in a particular way, in order to make other people believe something that is not true
exps_oxford_advanced: ["I'm tired of having to pretend all the time.", 'Of course I was wrong; it would be hypocritical to pretend otherwise.', 'He pretended to his family that everything was fine.', 'We pretended (that) nothing had happened.', 'She pretended (that) she was his niece.', 'I pretended to be asleep.', 'He pretended not to notice.', "She didn't love him, though she pretended to.", 'She pretended an interest she did not feel.']

sentence: Heseltine 's vision was of partnerships which recognise that there are some things that only governments can pay for , but also that the ingenuity and flexibility of the private sector is indispensable ( p. 156 ) .
gloss: Identify (someone or something) from having encountered them before; know again.
eg_sent: Julia hardly recognized Jill when they met

sentence: Both companies expected to bring the bass Vladimir Ognovenko to sing Boris and the mezzo-soprano Irina Bogatcheva .
gloss: Regard (something) as likely to happen.
eg_sent: it's as well to expect the worst
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; If you expect something to happen, you believe that it will happen. ;;
exps_collins: ['...a council workman who expects to lose his job in the next few weeks.', 'They no longer expect corporate profits to improve.', 'The talks are expected to continue until tomorrow.', 'Few expected that he would declare his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for the presidency.', "It is expected that the new owner will change the yacht's name.", 'They expect a gradual improvement in sales of new cars.']
bis_def_longman: to think that something will happen because it seems likely or has been planned
exps_longman: ['I expect to be back within a week.', 'The company expects to complete work in April.', 'Emergency repairs were expected to take three weeks.', 'I didn’t expect him to stay so long.', 'There’s the doorbell – I expect it’ll be my mother.', 'He will be hard to beat. I fully expect that and I’m ready.', '‘Who are you?’ he murmured, only half expecting her to answer.', 'He didn’t get his expected pay rise.', 'As expected, the whole family was shocked by the news.', 'A little nervousness is only to be expected when you are starting a new job.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to think or believe that something will happen or that somebody will do something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['We are expecting a rise in food prices this month.', "Don't expect sympathy from me!", "That's not the sort of behaviour I expect of you!", "You can't expect to learn a foreign language in a few months.", 'I looked back, half expecting to see someone following me.', 'House prices are expected to rise sharply.', 'I didn’t expect him to become a successful writer.', 'Do you really expect me to believe you?', 'Many people were expecting (that) the peace talks would break down.', 'It is expected that the report will suggest some major reforms.']

sentence: She looked about sixteen and beautiful .
gloss: Direct one's gaze toward someone or something or in a specified direction.
eg_sent: people were looking at him
bis_def_collins: If you look in a particular direction, you direct your eyes in that direction, especially so that you can see what is there or see what something is like.
exps_collins: ['I looked down the hallway to room number nine.', 'She turned to look at him.', 'He looked away, apparently enraged.', "If you look, you'll see what was a lake.", 'If you want to say that someone is paying attention to something they can see, you say that they are looking at it or watching it. In general, you look at something that is not moving, while you watch something that is moving or changing. I asked him to look at the picture above his bed... He watched Blake run down the stairs. Look is never followed directly by an object. You must always use at or some other preposition. I looked towards the plane. You use see to talk about things that you are aware of because a visual impression reaches your eyes. You often use can in this case. I can see the fax here on the desk.']
bis_def_longman: to turn your eyes towards something, so that you can see it
exps_longman: ['We sneaked out while Jessie’s mom wasn’t looking.', 'If you look carefully you can see that the painting represents a human figure.', 'Gina covered her eyes, afraid to look.', '‘It’s time we left, ’ Ian said, looking at his watch.', 'The men all turned to look at her as she entered the room.', 'Dad looked up from his paper and smiled.', '‘We can’t go out in this weather, ’ said Bob, looking out of the window.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to turn your eyes in a particular direction
exps_oxford_advanced: ['If you look carefully you can just see our house from here.', 'She looked at me and smiled.', "‘Has the mail come yet?’ ‘I'll look and see.’", "Look! I'm sure that's Brad Pitt!", "Don't look now, but there's someone staring at you!"]

sentence: A fly landed on the empty , staring vizor , and crawled across it .
gloss: Move forward on the hands and knees or by dragging the body close to the ground.
