bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; When you crawl, you move forward on your hands and knees. ;;
exps_collins: ["Don't worry if your baby seems a little reluctant to crawl or walk.", 'I began to crawl on my hands and knees towards the door.', 'As he tried to crawl away, he was hit in the shoulder.']
bis_def_longman: to move along on your hands and knees with your body close to the ground
exps_longman: ['The baby crawled across the floor.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to move forward on your hands and knees, with your body close to the ground
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Our baby is just starting to crawl.', 'A man was crawling away from the burning wreckage.', 'She crawled under the fence.']

sentence: Come to think of it , neither hunger nor randiness hits quite the spot .
gloss: Move or travel towards or into a place thought of as near or familiar to the speaker.
eg_sent: Jessica came into the kitchen
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; When a person or thing comes to a particular place, especially to a place where you are, they move there. ;
exps_collins: ['Two police officers came into the hall.', 'Come here, Tom.', "You'll have to come with us.", 'We want you to come to lunch.', 'I came over from Ireland to start a new life after my divorce.', 'We heard the train coming.', 'Can I come too?.', 'The impact blew out some of the windows and the sea came rushing in.']
bis_def_longman: to move towards you or arrive at the place where you are
exps_longman: ['Let me know when they come.', 'Can you come here for a minute?', 'What time will you be coming home?', 'There was a knock on the door and a young woman came into the room.', 'I could see a figure coming towards me.', 'As they came down the track, the car skidded.', 'I’ve come to see Philip.', 'I’ll come and help you move the rest of the boxes.', 'Jess came flying round the corner and banged straight into me.', 'What day are your folks coming to dinner?', 'Ah, here comes the bus at last!']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to move to or towards a person or place
exps_oxford_advanced: ['He came into the room and shut the door.', 'She comes to work by bus.', 'My son is coming home soon.', 'Come here!', 'Come and see us soon!', 'Here comes Jo! (= Jo is coming)', "There's a storm coming.", "They're coming to stay for a week."]

sentence: By 1990 , IGBP had progressed as far as defining a set of seven core projects ( IGBP 1990 ) addressing these four themes .
gloss: Write the name and address of the intended recipient on (an envelope, letter, or parcel)

exps_oxford_advanced: ['The letter was correctly addressed, but delivered to the wrong house.', 'Address your application to the Personnel Manager.']

sentence: The specific role of bishops which is to be exercised in communion with the see of Peter in ensuring the unity and continuity of the faith is vital if we are to hand on the faith of Peter , Gregory and Augustine .

sentence: In the later Vogue piece only the style remained as the far more overtly sexual , Kahloesque models lounged and pouted in their Mexican interiors .
gloss: Continue to exist, especially after other similar people or things have ceased to do so.

exps_collins: ['The three men remained silent.', 'The situation remains tense.', 'The government remained in control.', 'He remained a formidable opponent.', "It remains possible that bad weather could tear more holes in the tanker's hull."]
bis_def_longman: to continue to be in the same state or condition
exps_longman: ['Please remain seated until all the lights are on.', 'We remained friends.', 'The boy remained silent.', 'Despite the job losses, Parker remained as manager.', 'Many scientists remain unconvinced by the current evidence.']

sentence: It 's not anyhow , I mean , it 's alright living longer if you , if you , if you 've got all your faculties .
gloss: Come to have (something); receive.
eg_sent: I got a letter from him the other day
bis_def_collins: You use get with adjectives to mean 'become'. For example, if someone gets cold, they become cold, and if they get angry, they become angry.
exps_collins: ['The boys were getting bored.', "There's no point in getting upset.", 'From here on, it can only get better.']
bis_def_longman: to receive something that someone gives you or sends you
exps_longman: ['She got loads of presents.', 'What did you get for Christmas?', 'We get a lot of junk mail.', 'We got a letter from Pam this morning.', 'I got it off my Dad.', 'I got a few games free when I bought my computer.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to receive something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['I got a letter from Dave this morning.', 'What (= What presents) did you get for your birthday?', 'He gets (= earns) about $40\u2009000 a year.', 'This room gets very little sunshine.', 'I got a shock when I saw the bill.', 'I get the impression that he is bored with his job.']

sentence: This did not , however , stop the question of political marginality and the need to reform existing policies from being raised at all , as can be seen subsequently by the attempts after 1981 to introduce both locally and nationally measures which were meant to address some of the grievances of the rioters and to ensure that further disturbances did not occur .
gloss: Make changes in (something, especially an institution or practice) in order to improve it.

bis_def_oxford_advanced: to improve a system, an organization, a law, etc. by making changes to it
exps_oxford_advanced: ['proposals to reform the social security system', 'The law needs to be reformed.', 'a reforming administration']

sentence: Gorgeous location overlooking a quiet bay .

bis_def_oxford_advanced: to fail to see or notice something

sentence: The farm stands on a spur of moorland on the northern edge of the forest , and within 10 minutes I had turned my back on the corduroy battalions of trees and was striding under a still , cloudy sky over tussocks of rush and coarse grass , with my face to the long , bare shoulders of open hillside that flank the winding shallows of the East Kielder Burn .
gloss: Be on each or on one side of.

sentence: Both women looked at him in joint appeal and he marched to the door , pulling it open with unnecessary force .
gloss: Exert force on (someone or something) so as to cause movement towards oneself.

bis_def_collins: When you pull something, you hold it firmly and use force in order to move it towards you or away from its previous position.
exps_collins: ["They have pulled out patients' teeth unnecessarily.", 'He pulled on a jersey.', 'Erica was solemn, pulling at her blonde curls.', 'I helped pull him out of the water.', 'Someone pulled her hair.', 'He knew he should pull the trigger, but he was suddenly paralysed by fear.', 'Pull as hard as you can.', 'I let myself out into the street and pulled the door shut.']

sentence: Coincidentally , as the community and their lives together broke up , so did the weather .
gloss: Separate or cause to separate into pieces as a result of a blow, shock, or strain.
eg_sent: the branch broke with a loud snap

exps_collins: ['He fell through the window, breaking the glass.', 'The plate broke.', 'Break the cauliflower into florets.', 'The plane broke into three pieces.', '...bombed-out buildings, surrounded by broken glass and rubble.', 'The only sound was the crackle of breaking ice.']

sentence: And you go round the corner

Let’s go home.', 'Where are you going?', 'We’re going to Canada in the summer.', 'Dinah went into the kitchen.', 'She went over and put her arm around him.', 'I’m going round to her house to find out what’s wrong.', 'I’ll just go up  and ask him what he wants.']

sentence: If he wants to import vehicles or components from Taiwan or Singapore or Hong Kong into Europe , he 'll go ahead and do it , regardless of the economic consequences for the European countries concerned .
gloss: Have a desire to possess or do (something); wish for.
eg_sent: I want an apple
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont, no passive] ; If you want something, you feel a desire or a need for it. ;
exps_collins: ['I want a drink.', 'Ian knows exactly what he wants in life.', 'People wanted to know who this talented designer was.', 'They began to want their father to be the same as other daddies.', "They didn't want people staring at them as they sat on the lawn, so they put up high walls.", 'He wanted his power recognised.', 'I want my car this colour.', 'And remember, we want him alive.', "Note that want and wish have similar meanings, but are used differently. If you want something, you feel a need for it or a desire to have it. You can say that you want to do something, that you want someone to do something, or that you want something to happen. If you use wish with a 'to' infinitive, this has the same meaning as want but is more formal. I want to get out of here... She wished to consult him about her future."]
bis_def_longman: to have a desire for something
exps_longman: ['I really want a drink.', 'What do you want for your birthday?', 'She’d always wanted to go to Thailand.', 'I don’t want Linda to  hear about this.', 'He didn’t want the holiday to end.', 'You can order whatever you want.', 'This shampoo is mild enough to use every day if you want.', 'If she doesn’t get what she wants, she’s not happy.', 'He wanted that job so badly he was willing to kill for it.', 'They desperately wanted a son.', 'What I want to know is when we’re going to get paid.', 'All I want is the chance to prove myself.', 'Oh thank you, it’s just what I’ve always wanted.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have a desire or a wish for something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Do you want some more tea?', "She's always wanted a large family.", 'All I want is the truth.', "Thanks for the present—it's just what I wanted.", 'I can do whatever I want.', 'The last thing I wanted was to upset you.', 'The party wants her as leader.', 'What do you want to do tomorrow?', "‘It's time you did your homework.’ ‘I don't want to!’", 'There are two points which I wanted to make.', 'I just wanted to know if everything was all right.', 'You can come too, if you want.', 'Do you want me to help?', "We didn't want this to happen.", 'I want it (to be) done as quickly as possible.', "I don't want you coming home so late.", 'Do you want your coffee black or white?']

sentence: The first four chapters in this part examine issues relating to geographic information handling in terms of four potential applications fields .

sentence: In short , if life was always harder in the inner cities than elsewhere , and if conditions may temporarily have been alleviated by the impact of the welfare state and rising incomes , the last decade has been widely represented as a period of deterioration .
gloss: Be entitled or appointed to act or speak for (someone), especially in an official capacity.
eg_sent: for purposes of litigation, an infant can and must be represented by an adult
bis_def_collins: If someone such as a lawyer or a politician represents a person or group of people, they act on behalf of that person or group.
exps_collins: ['...the politicians we elect to represent us.', 'The offer has yet to be accepted by the lawyers representing the victims.']
bis_def_longman: to officially speak or take action for another person or group of people
exps_longman: ['Mr Kobayashi was chosen to represent the company at the conference.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to be a member of a group of people and act or speak on their behalf at an event, a meeting, etc.
exps_oxford_advanced: ['The competition attracted over 500 contestants representing 8 different countries.', 'Local businesses are well represented on the committee (= there are a lot of people from them on the committee).', 'The opening speech was by Bob Alan representing Amnesty International.', 'The President was represented at the ceremony by the Vice-President.']

sentence: Carl said he , he looked er well er , his face did , it were very he 's got a very poxy skin .
gloss: Direct one's gaze toward someone or something or in a specified direction.
eg_sent: people were looking at him
bis_def_collins: If you look in a particular direction, you direct your eyes in that direction, especially so that you can see what is there or see what something is like.
exps_collins: ['I looked down the hallway to room number nine.', 'She turned to look at him.', 'He looked away, apparently enraged.', "If you look, you'll see what was a lake.", 'If you want to say that someone is paying attention to something they can see, you say that they are looking at it or watching it. In general, you look at something that is not moving, while you watch something that is moving or changing. I asked him to look at the picture above his bed... He watched Blake run down the stairs. Look is never followed directly by an object. You must always use at or some other preposition. I looked towards the plane. You use see to talk about things that you are aware of because a visual impression reaches your eyes. You often use can in this case. I can see the fax here on the desk.']
bis_def_longman: to turn your eyes towards something, so that you can see it
exps_longman: ['We sneaked out while Jessie’s mom wasn’t looking.', 'If you look carefully you can see that the painting represents a human figure.', 'Gina covered her eyes, afraid to look.', '‘It’s time we left, ’ Ian said, looking at his watch.', 'The men all turned to look at her as she entered the room.', 'Dad looked up from his paper and smiled.', '‘We can’t go out in this weather, ’ said Bob, looking out of the window.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to turn your eyes in a particular direction
exps_oxford_advanced: ['If you look carefully you can just see our house from here.', 'She looked at me and smiled.', "‘Has the mail come yet?’ ‘I'll look and see.’", "Look! I'm sure that's Brad Pitt!", "Don't look now, but there's someone staring at you!"]

sentence: It was when she described seeing film of the results of the bombing on television , and thinking : They think I did that !
gloss: Perceive with the eyes; discern visually.
eg_sent: in the distance she could see the blue sea
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont] ; When you see something, you notice it using your eyes. ;
exps_collins: ["You can't see colours at night.", 'I saw a man making his way towards me.', 'She can see, hear, touch, smell, and taste.', 'As he neared the farm, he saw that a police car was parked outside it.', 'Did you see what happened?', 'You use see to talk about things that you are aware of because a visual impression reaches your eyes. You often use can in this case. I can see the fax here on the desk. If you want to say that someone is paying attention to something they can see, you say that they are looking at it or watching it. In general, you look at something that is not moving, while you watch something that is moving or changing. I asked him to look at the picture above his bed... He watched Blake run down the stairs.']
bis_def_longman: to notice or examine someone or something, using your eyes
exps_longman: ['He crouched down so he couldn’t be seen.', 'Can I see your ticket, please?', 'You can see the Houses of Parliament from here.', 'Can you see where the marks are on the wall?', 'The suspect was seen entering the building.', 'As you can see, the house needs some work doing on it.', 'Have you seen Chris ?', 'The accommodation was so awful it had to be seen to be believed.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to become aware of somebody/something by using your eyes
exps_oxford_advanced: ["She looked for him but couldn't see him in the crowd.", 'I looked out of the window but saw nothing.', 'The opera was the place to see and be seen (= by other important or fashionable people).', 'He could see (that) she had been crying.', 'Did you see what happened?', 'If you watch carefully, you’ll see how it is done.', 'I hate to see you unhappy.', 'She was seen running away from the scene of the crime.', 'I saw you put the key in your pocket.', 'He was seen to enter the building about the time the crime was committed.']

sentence: Kinnock was saying to erm the candidates , you know , we I realize that a lot of you are getting it rough at the moment , cos there 's about five Labour
gloss: Utter words so as to convey information, an opinion, a feeling or intention, or an instruction.
eg_sent: ‘Thank you,’ he said
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; When you say something, you speak words. ; [Also VERB to-infinitive]
exps_collins: ["'I'm sorry,' he said.", 'She said they were very impressed.', 'Forty-one people are said to have been seriously hurt.', 'I packed and said goodbye to Charlie.', "I hope you didn't say anything about Gretchen.", "You didn't say much when you telephoned.", 'Did he say where he was going?.', "It doesn't sound exactly orthodox, if I may say so."]
bis_def_longman: to express an idea, feeling, thought etc using words
exps_longman: ['‘Don’t cry, ’ he said softly.', 'Don’t believe anything he says.', 'A spokesman said that the company had improved its safety standards.', 'I always said I would buy a motorbike when I had enough money.', 'Did she say what happened?', 'I would like to say how much we appreciate your hard work.', '‘Why did she leave?’ ‘I don’t know – she didn’t say.’', 'What did you say to her?', 'What a silly thing to say!', 'She left without saying goodbye.', 'I’ve said I’m sorry – what more do you want?', 'Can I go, Mum? Oh, please say yes!', 'He looked as if he was going to say something.', 'I wished I had said nothing about Jordi.', 'Does anyone else have anything to say?', 'Although he didn’t say so, it was clear that he was in pain.', 'What makes you say that (=why do you think that) ? 你怎么会那么说呢？', 'Nina said to meet her at 4.30.', 'I’d like to say a few words.', '‘So what are your plans now?’ ‘I’d rather not say.’']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to speak or tell somebody something, using words
exps_oxford_advanced: ['‘Hello!’ she said.', '‘That was marvellous,’ said Daniel.', 'Be quiet, I have something to say.', "I didn't believe a word she said.", "That's a terrible thing to say.", "He knew that if he wasn't back by midnight, his parents would have something to say about it (= be angry).", 'She said nothing to me about it.', "I said to myself (= thought), ‘That can't be right!’", 'He said (that) his name was Sam.', 'It is said that she lived to be over 100.', 'She finds it hard to say what she feels.', "‘That's impossible!’ ‘So you say (= but I think you may be wrong).’", "‘Why can't I go out now?’ ‘Because I say so.’", "‘What do you want it for?’ ‘I'd rather not say.’", 'He said to meet him here.', 'He is said to have been a brilliant scholar.']

sentence: I think .
gloss: Have a particular opinion, belief, or idea about someone or something.
eg_sent: she thought that nothing would be the same again
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont] ; If you think that something is the case, you have the opinion that it is the case. ; [Also VERB n to-infinitive]
exps_collins: ['I certainly think there should be a ban on tobacco advertising.', 'Do you think I ought to seal the boxes up?.', 'A generation ago, it was thought that babies born this small could not survive.', 'Tell me, what do you think of my theory?.', 'Peter is useless, far worse than I thought.', 'He manages a good deal better than I thought possible.', "'It ought to be stopped.' — 'Yes, I think so.'"]
bis_def_longman: to have a particular opinion or to believe that something is true
exps_longman: ['I think that you’re being unfair.', 'I thought I heard something.', 'He didn’t think anyone would believe him.', 'Do you think I should call him?', 'For some reason, I keep thinking it’s Friday today.', 'The recession lasted longer than anyone thought it would.', 'Am I right in thinking that you have a brother?', 'I can’t help thinking that he’s made a mistake.', 'Do you honestly think I would do something so stupid?', 'What do you think of your new school?', 'I thought it best to call first.', 'I thought it appropriate to invite her to speak at the meeting.', 'We must start thinking in terms of reducing costs.', 'Fraud is thought to be costing software companies millions of dollars a year.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have a particular idea or opinion about something/somebody; to believe something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Do you think (that) they’ll come?', 'I thought I heard a scream.', "I didn't think you liked sports.", 'Am I right in thinking that you used to live here?', "I think this is their house, but I'm not sure.", 'He ought to resign, I think.', "We'll need about 20 chairs, I should think.", 'It was once thought that the sun travelled around the earth.', 'What did you think about the idea?', 'Well, I like it. What do you think?', '‘Will we make it in time?’ ‘I think so.’', "‘Is he any good?’ ‘I don't think so.’", "I think it highly unlikely that I'll get the job.", 'She thought him kind and generous.', "He's thought to be one of the richest men in Europe."]

gloss: Require (something) because it is essential or very important rather than just desirable.
eg_sent: I need help now
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont] ) If you need something, or need to do something, you cannot successfully achieve what you want or live properly without it. )
exps_collins: ['He desperately needed money.', 'These diets provide everything your body needs.', 'I need to make a phone call.', 'A baby does not need to wear shoes until he starts to walk.', 'I need you to do something for me.', 'I need you here, Wally.', 'I need you sane and sober.']
bis_def_longman: to have to have something or someone, because you cannot do something without them, or because you cannot continue or cannot exist without them
exps_longman: ['You don’t really need a car.', 'Plants need light in order to survive.', 'The camcorder needs a new battery.', 'Are you sure that you have everything you need?', 'I need glasses for reading.', 'I need you to help me with the cooking.', 'More blood donors are urgently needed.', 'a much needed boost to the local economy']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to require something/somebody because they are essential or very important, not just because you would like to have them
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Do you need any help?', "It's here if you need it.", "Don't go—I might need you.", 'They badly needed a change.', 'Food aid is urgently needed.', 'What do you need your own computer for? You can use ours.', "I don't need your comments, thank you.", 'I need to get some sleep.', 'He needs to win this game to stay in the match.', "You don't need to leave yet, do you?", 'This shirt needs to be washed.', 'This shirt needs washing.']

sentence: she 's got a ginormous one .
gloss: Come to have (something); receive.
eg_sent: I got a letter from him the other day
bis_def_collins: You use get with adjectives to mean 'become'. For example, if someone gets cold, they become cold, and if they get angry, they become angry.
exps_collins: ['The boys were getting bored.', "There's no point in getting upset.", 'From here on, it can only get better.']
bis_def_longman: to receive something that someone gives you or sends you
exps_longman: ['She got loads of presents.', 'What did you get for Christmas?', 'We get a lot of junk mail.', 'We got a letter from Pam this morning.', 'I got it off my Dad.', 'I got a few games free when I bought my computer.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to receive something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['I got a letter from Dave this morning.', 'What (= What presents) did you get for your birthday?', 'He gets (= earns) about $40\u2009000 a year.', 'This room gets very little sunshine.', 'I got a shock when I saw the bill.', 'I get the impression that he is bored with his job.']

sentence: There is a temptation to make these final diagrams very large , but often it is more useful to separate into small units with cross-referencing .

eg_sent: both owners were trying to separate the dogs

Stephen returned to the square.', "They're separated from the adult inmates."]

sentence: Her sole purpose in being there was to meet him and she was content that he should know it .
gloss: Arrange or happen to come into the presence or company of (someone)
eg_sent: a week later I met him in the street
bis_def_collins: V-RECIP  ; If you meet someone, you happen to be in the same place as them and start talking to them. You may know the other person, but be surprised to see them, or you may not know them at all. ;
exps_collins: ['I have just met the man I want to spend the rest of my life with.', "He's the kindest and sincerest person I've ever met.", 'We met by chance.', 'When he was in the supermarket, he met up with a buddy he had at Oxford.', 'They met up in 1956, when they were both young schoolboys.']
bis_def_longman: to go to a place where someone will be at a particular time, according to an arrangement, so that you can talk or do something together
exps_longman: ['I’ll meet you by the main reception desk.', 'Why don’t we meet for lunch on Friday?', 'We arranged to meet outside the theatre.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to be in the same place as somebody by chance and talk to them
exps_oxford_advanced: ["Maybe we'll meet again some time.", 'Did you meet anyone in town?']

sentence: Their minds had not reached out to the terror of what had in fact happened .
gloss: Take place; occur.
eg_sent: two hours had passed and still nothing had happened
bis_def_collins: Something that happens occurs or is done without being planned.
exps_collins: ['We cannot say for sure what will happen.', "The accident happened close to Martha's Vineyard."]
bis_def_longman: when something happens, there is an event, especially one that is not planned
exps_longman: ['When did the accident happen?', 'It’s impossible to predict what will happen next.', 'Something terrible has happened.', 'She carried on as if nothing had happened.', 'This was bound to happen sooner or later.', 'This kind of thing happens all the time.', 'We’ll still be friends, whatever happens.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to take place, especially without being planned
exps_oxford_advanced: ["You'll never guess what's happened!", 'Accidents like this happen all the time.', "Let's see what happens next week.", "I'll be there whatever happens.", 'Is this really happening or is it a dream?', "I don't know how this happened."]

sentence: Although destroyed , she has also escaped .
gloss: Break free from confinement or control.
eg_sent: two burglars have just escaped from prison
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no passive] ; If you escape from a place, you succeed in getting away from it. ;
exps_collins: ['A prisoner has escaped from a jail in northern England.', 'They are reported to have escaped to the other side of the border.', 'He was fatally wounded as he tried to escape.']
bis_def_longman: to leave a place when someone is trying to catch you or stop you, or when there is a dangerous situation
exps_longman: ['He broke down the locked door and escaped.', 'He escaped from prison in October.', 'She escaped to Britain in 1938.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to get away from a place where you have been kept as a prisoner or not allowed to leave
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Two prisoners have escaped.', 'They were caught trying to escape.', 'He escaped from prison this morning.']

sentence: A large sports-fishing boat was moored alongside Wavebreaker , but moored so crudely that whoever had brought the powerboat alongside the schooner had not bothered to put out fenders , but instead had gouged long ugly gashes in Wavebreaker 's white paint .
gloss: Take the trouble to do something.
eg_sent: scientists rarely bother with such niceties
bis_def_collins: If you do not bother to do something or if you do not bother with it, you do not do it, consider it, or use it because you think it is unnecessary or because you are too lazy.
exps_collins: ["Lots of people don't bother to go through a marriage ceremony these days.", "Most of the papers didn't even bother reporting it.", 'Nothing I do makes any difference anyway, so why bother?', '...and he does not bother with a helmet either.']
bis_def_longman: to make the effort to do something
exps_longman: ['He didn’t bother to answer the question.', 'He didn’t bother with a reply.', 'Many young people didn’t bother voting.', '‘Do you want me to wait for you?’ ‘No, don’t bother.’', 'Why bother to go abroad, when there are so many nice places here?']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to spend time and/or energy doing something
exps_oxford_advanced: ["‘Shall I wait?’ ‘No, don't bother’.", "I don't know why I bother! Nobody ever listens!", 'If that’s all the thanks I get, I won’t bother in future!', "It's not worth bothering with (= using) an umbrella—the car's just outside.", "I don't know why you bother with that crowd (= why you spend time with them).", 'He doesn’t bother much about his appearance.', "He didn't even bother to let me know he was coming.", "Why bother asking if you're not really interested?"]

sentence: She took out a handkerchief and mopped her eyes .
gloss: Lay hold of (something) with one's hands; reach for and hold.
eg_sent: Mrs Morgan took another biscuit
bis_def_collins: You can use take followed by a noun to talk about an action or event, when it would also be possible to use the verb that is related to that noun. For example, you can say 'she took a shower' instead of 'she showered'.
exps_collins: ['She was too tired to take a shower.', 'Betty took a photograph of us.', "I've never taken a holiday since starting this job.", "There's not enough people willing to take the risk.", 'Walk around the property and take a good look at it from the outside.', 'We took a long walk through the pines.']
bis_def_longman: to move or go with someone or something from one place to another
exps_longman: ['Barney took us to the airport.', 'Would you mind taking Susie home?', 'When he refused to give his name, he was taken into custody.', 'My job has taken me all over the world.', 'His wife went to Australia, taking the children with her.', 'I have to take Steve the money tonight.', 'He took me to meet his parents.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to carry or move something from one place to another
exps_oxford_advanced: ['I forgot to take my bag with me when I got off the bus.', 'Take this to the bank for me, would you?', 'Shall I take a gift to my host family?', 'Shall I take my host family a gift?']

sentence: Some integrated services emerged in the early 1980s one playscheme was developed through a parent 's initiative , and an integrated adventure playground was established by a voluntary organisation .
gloss: Combine (one thing) with another to form a whole.
eg_sent: transport planning should be integrated with energy policy
bis_def_collins: V-ERG  );() If someone integrates into a social group, or is integrated into it, they behave in such a way that they become part of the group or are accepted into it. );()
exps_collins: ["He didn't integrate successfully into the Italian way of life.", 'Integrating the kids with the community, finding them a role, is essential.', 'The way Swedes integrate immigrants is, she feels, 100% more advanced.', "If they want to integrate, that's fine with me."]
bis_def_longman: if two or more things integrate, or if you integrate them, they combine or work together in a way that makes something more effective
exps_longman: ['Colourful illustrations are integrated into the text.', 'Transport planning should be integrated with energy policy.', 'computers of different makes that integrate with each other']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to combine two or more things so that they work together; to combine with something else in this way
exps_oxford_advanced: ['These programs will integrate with your existing software.', 'These programs can be integrated with your existing software.']

sentence: The Conservative manifesto contained a commitment to increase , year by year , the level of real resources committed to the NHS though it put no figure on the extra money to be allocated .
gloss: Distribute (resources or duties) for a particular purpose.
eg_sent: in past years we didn't allocate enough funds to infrastructure maintenance
bis_def_collins: If one item or share of something is allocated to a particular person or for a particular purpose, it is given to that person or used for that purpose.  [Also V n n, V n]
exps_collins: ['Tickets are limited and will be allocated to those who apply first.', 'The 1985 federal budget allocated $7.3 billion for development programmes.', 'Our plan is to allocate one member of staff to handle appointments.']
bis_def_longman: to use something for a particular purpose, give something to a particular person etc, especially after an official decision has been made
exps_longman: ['the importance of allocating resources to local communities', 'You should allocate the same amount of time to each question.', 'One million dollars was allocated for disaster relief.', 'Several patients were waiting to be allocated a bed.', 'The company has allocated funds for the design of four plants.', 'Directors allocated $100 million to the search for oil.', 'Their job is to allocate homes to ordinary people.', 'They allocated me a window seat at check-in.', 'The regulators did not like the way in which the company allocated expenses to its bank units.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to give something officially to somebody/something for a particular purpose
exps_oxford_advanced: ['A large sum has been allocated for buying new books for the library.', 'They intend to allocate more places to mature students this year.', 'More resources are being allocated to the project.', 'The project is being allocated more resources.', "Millions have been allocated to improve students' performance."]

sentence: He also kissed Frederica and introduced the woman , fumbling her name , as " a colleague " and Frederica as " Frederica you must forgive me , I never know what name you re working under , women these days are so protean . "
gloss: Bring (something, especially a product, measure, or concept) into use or operation for the first time.
eg_sent: various new taxes were introduced
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; To introduce something means to cause it to enter a place or exist in a system for the first time. ;;
exps_collins: ['The Government has introduced a number of other money-saving moves.', 'I kept the birds indoors all winter and introduced them into an aviary the following June.', "The word 'Pagoda' was introduced to Europe by the 17th century Portuguese."]
bis_def_longman: if you introduce someone to another person, you tell them each other’s names for the first time
exps_longman: ['Have you two been introduced? Tom, this is Greg.', 'June, let me introduce you to Bob.', 'May I introduce myself? My name is Meg Johnson.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to tell two or more people who have not met before what each other’s names are; to tell somebody what your name is
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Can I introduce my wife?', 'He introduced me to a Greek girl at the party.', 'She was introduced to me as a well-known novelist.', "We've already been introduced.", "Can I introduce myself? I'm Helen Robins.", "‘Kay, this is Steve.’ ‘Yes, I know—we've already introduced ourselves.’"]

sentence: The NAACP denounces The Silence of the Lambs because Hannibal the Cannibal shares his name with an African general , and the killer is Buffalo Bill ( yes , that 's a white man 's nickname , but the buffalo , NAACP explain patiently , is associated with Native Americans ) .
gloss: Connect (someone or something) with something else in one's mind.
eg_sent: I associated wealth with freedom
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; If you associate someone or something with another thing, the two are connected in your mind. ;
exps_collins: ["Through science we've got the idea of associating progress with the future.", 'Rap groups have been barred from large musical events because they are associated with vandalism.']
bis_def_longman: to make a connection in your mind between one thing or person and another
exps_longman: ['I don’t associate him with energetic sports.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to make a connection between people or things in your mind
exps_oxford_advanced: ['I always associate the smell of baking with my childhood.', 'He is closely associated in the public mind with horror movies.', 'Most people immediately associate addictions with drugs, alcohol and cigarettes.', 'You wouldn’t normally associate these two writers—their styles are completely different.']

sentence: It was a dramatic and impractical outfit of a kind I only expected to see on the male models who posed in the more outlandish fashion magazines that our rich clients brought aboard Wavebreaker , yet Jesse Isambard Sweetman managed to wear the elaborate style with an elegant insouciance .
gloss: Present or constitute (a problem or danger)
eg_sent: the sheer number of visitors is posing a threat to the area
bis_def_collins: If something poses a problem or a danger, it is the cause of that problem or danger.
exps_collins: ['This could pose a threat to jobs in the coal industry.', 'His ill health poses serious problems for the future.']
bis_def_longman: to exist in a way that may cause a problem, danger, difficulty etc
exps_longman: ['Officials claim the chemical poses no real threat.', 'The events pose a challenge to the church’s leadership.', 'Rising unemployment is posing serious problems for the administration.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to create a threat, problem, etc. that has to be dealt with
exps_oxford_advanced: ['to pose a threat/challenge/danger/risk', 'The task poses no special problems.']

sentence: Adam did not want at this point to speculate , it made hiÎ__ê feel sick .
gloss: Have a desire to possess or do (something); wish for.
eg_sent: I want an apple
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont, no passive] ; If you want something, you feel a desire or a need for it. ;
exps_collins: ['I want a drink.', 'Ian knows exactly what he wants in life.', 'People wanted to know who this talented designer was.', 'They began to want their father to be the same as other daddies.', "They didn't want people staring at them as they sat on the lawn, so they put up high walls.", 'He wanted his power recognised.', 'I want my car this colour.', 'And remember, we want him alive.', "Note that want and wish have similar meanings, but are used differently. If you want something, you feel a need for it or a desire to have it. You can say that you want to do something, that you want someone to do something, or that you want something to happen. If you use wish with a 'to' infinitive, this has the same meaning as want but is more formal. I want to get out of here... She wished to consult him about her future."]
bis_def_longman: to have a desire for something
exps_longman: ['I really want a drink.', 'What do you want for your birthday?', 'She’d always wanted to go to Thailand.', 'I don’t want Linda to  hear about this.', 'He didn’t want the holiday to end.', 'You can order whatever you want.', 'This shampoo is mild enough to use every day if you want.', 'If she doesn’t get what she wants, she’s not happy.', 'He wanted that job so badly he was willing to kill for it.', 'They desperately wanted a son.', 'What I want to know is when we’re going to get paid.', 'All I want is the chance to prove myself.', 'Oh thank you, it’s just what I’ve always wanted.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have a desire or a wish for something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Do you want some more tea?', "She's always wanted a large family.", 'All I want is the truth.', "Thanks for the present—it's just what I wanted.", 'I can do whatever I want.', 'The last thing I wanted was to upset you.', 'The party wants her as leader.', 'What do you want to do tomorrow?', "‘It's time you did your homework.’ ‘I don't want to!’", 'There are two points which I wanted to make.', 'I just wanted to know if everything was all right.', 'You can come too, if you want.', 'Do you want me to help?', "We didn't want this to happen.", 'I want it (to be) done as quickly as possible.', "I don't want you coming home so late.", 'Do you want your coffee black or white?']

sentence: Yes , I suppose it was .

bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; You can use suppose or supposing before mentioning a possible situation or action. You usually then go on to consider the effects that this situation or action might have. ;;

(= showing anger)."]

sentence: Well ring her up and see .

eg_sent: in the distance she could see the blue sea

exps_collins: ["You can't see colours at night.", 'I saw a man making his way towards me.', 'She can see, hear, touch, smell, and taste.', 'As he neared the farm, he saw that a police car was parked outside it.', 'Did you see what happened?', 'You use see to talk about things that you are aware of because a visual impression reaches your eyes. You often use can in this case. I can see the fax here on the desk. If you want to say that someone is paying attention to something they can see, you say that they are looking at it or watching it. In general, you look at something that is not moving, while you watch something that is moving or changing. I asked him to look at the picture above his bed... He watched Blake run down the stairs.']

exps_longman: ['She still needs to analyse the data.', 'You need to sit down and analyse why you feel so upset.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to examine the nature or structure of something, especially by separating it into its parts, in order to understand or explain it
exps_oxford_advanced: ['The job involves gathering and analysing data.', 'He tried to analyse his feelings.', 'The first step is to define and analyse the problem.', 'The results must be analysed in detail.', 'We need to analyse what went wrong.']

sentence: I 'm not sure that I really knew her and I 'm left wishing I 'd tried harder .
gloss: Be aware of through observation, inquiry, or information.
eg_sent: most people know that CFCs can damage the ozone layer
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont]  If you know a fact, a piece of information, or an answer, you have it correctly in your mind.
exps_collins: ["I don't know the name of the place.", 'I know that you led a rifle platoon during the Second World War.', "'People like doing things for nothing.' — 'I know they do.'.", "I don't know what happened to her husband.", "'How did he meet your mother?' — 'I don't know.'.", 'We all know about his early experiments in flying.', 'They looked younger than I knew them to be.', 'Radon is known to be harmful to humans in large quantities.', 'It is not known whether the bomb was originally intended for the capital itself.', "It's always been known that key figures in the government do very well for themselves."]
bis_def_longman: to have information about something
exps_longman: ['Who knows the answer?', 'There are instructions telling you everything you need to know.', 'Didn’t you know that?', 'Do you know what time it is?', 'I don’t know where to go.', 'I need to know more about the job before I decide whether to apply for it.', 'Little is known about the author’s childhood.', 'I know all about David and what he’s been up to!', 'I wonder if he knew of the plan?', 'Do you know of any good restaurants in the area?', 'You know nothing of this business.', 'We know that greenhouse gases can affect the climate.', 'Let me know what time you’re planning to arrive.', 'I thought you’d want to know immediately.', 'If you must know, I was with James last night .', 'He slipped out of the house without his parents knowing .', 'How did he know our names?', '‘I’m divorced, as you know, ’ she said briefly.', 'Smoking is known to increase a person’s risk of developing lung cancer.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have information in your mind as a result of experience or because you have learned or been told it
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Do you know his address?', 'The cause of the fire is not yet known.', 'All I know is that she used to work in a bank (= I have no other information about her).', 'I know (that) people’s handwriting changes as they get older.', 'It is widely known that CFCs can damage the ozone layer.', 'I knew where he was hiding.', "I didn't know what he was talking about.", "‘You've got a flat tyre.’ ‘I know.’", "‘What's the answer?’ ‘I don't know.’", "‘There's no one in.’ ‘How do you know?’", "You know about Amanda's baby, don't you?", "I don't know about you, but I'm ready for something to eat.", 'I know of at least two people who did the same thing.', '‘Is anyone else coming?’ ‘Not that I know of.’', '‘Isn’t that his car?’ ‘I wouldn’t know./How should I know?’ (= I don’t know and I am not the person you should ask.)', "‘What are you two whispering about?’ ‘You don't want to know’ (= because you would be shocked or wouldn't approve).", 'Does he know to come here (= that he should come here) first?', 'We know her to be honest.', 'Two women are known to have died.']

sentence: I suppose Mueller saw to that , Mark said sarcastically .
gloss: Think or assume that something is true or probable but lack proof or certain knowledge.
eg_sent: I suppose I got there about noon
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; You can use suppose or supposing before mentioning a possible situation or action. You usually then go on to consider the effects that this situation or action might have. ;;
exps_collins: ['Suppose someone gave you an egg and asked you to describe exactly what was inside.', "Supposing he's right and I do die tomorrow? Maybe I should take out an extra insurance policy."]
bis_def_longman: used to say you think something is true, although you are uncertain about it
exps_longman: ['I suppose you’re right.', 'So things worked out for the best, I suppose.', '‘Aren’t you pleased?’ ‘Yes, I suppose so.’']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to think or believe that something is true or possible (based on the knowledge that you have)
exps_oxford_advanced: ["Getting a visa isn't as simple as you might suppose.", 'Prices will go up, I suppose.', 'This combination of qualities is generally supposed to be extremely rare.', 'She had supposed him (to be) very rich.', 'I had supposed his wife a younger woman.', "I don't suppose for a minute that he'll agree (= I'm sure that he won't).", 'Why do you suppose he resigned?', 'I suppose all the tickets have been sold now, have they?', "There is no reason to suppose she's lying.", "I suppose you think it's funny, do you? (= showing anger)."]

sentence: No one told me about it , and no one wanted him to have it .
gloss: Communicate information to someone in spoken or written words.
eg_sent: I told her you were coming
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; If you tell someone something, you give them information. ; [Also V of n]
exps_collins: ['In the evening I returned to tell Phyllis our relationship was over.', 'I called Andie to tell her how spectacular the stuff looked.', 'Claire had made me promise to tell her the truth.', 'I only told the truth to the press when the single was released as it seemed the perfect time to do it.', 'Tell us about your moment on the summit.', "Her voice breaking with emotion, she told him: 'It doesn't seem fair'."]
bis_def_longman: if someone tells you something, they communicate information, a story, their feelings etc to you
exps_longman: ['I wish someone had told me the meeting was canceled.', 'The Chief of Police told reporters that two people were killed in the blast.', 'Jack had to go, but he didn’t tell me why.', 'I think you’d better tell me exactly what’s been going on around here.', 'No one had told them about the drug’s side effects.', 'I’ll tell you all about it when I get back.', 'She told us some funny stories about her sister.', 'Sheppard was telling the truth.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to give information to somebody by speaking or writing
exps_oxford_advanced: ['He told the news to everybody he saw.', 'He told everybody he saw the news.', 'Did she tell you her name?', 'What did I tell you? (= you should have listened to my advice)', "Why wasn't I told about the accident?", 'They’ve told us (that) they’re not coming.', 'I kept telling myself (that) everything was OK.', "Are you telling me you didn't have any help with this? (= I don't believe what you have said)", 'Tell me where you live.', "‘I'm ready to go now,’ he told her."]

sentence: At the end of summer , her body stops wanting gin and tonics and suddenly desires whisky .
gloss: Have a desire to possess or do (something); wish for.
eg_sent: I want an apple
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont, no passive] ; If you want something, you feel a desire or a need for it. ;
exps_collins: ['I want a drink.', 'Ian knows exactly what he wants in life.', 'People wanted to know who this talented designer was.', 'They began to want their father to be the same as other daddies.', "They didn't want people staring at them as they sat on the lawn, so they put up high walls.", 'He wanted his power recognised.', 'I want my car this colour.', 'And remember, we want him alive.', "Note that want and wish have similar meanings, but are used differently. If you want something, you feel a need for it or a desire to have it. You can say that you want to do something, that you want someone to do something, or that you want something to happen. If you use wish with a 'to' infinitive, this has the same meaning as want but is more formal. I want to get out of here... She wished to consult him about her future."]
bis_def_longman: to have a desire for something
exps_longman: ['I really want a drink.', 'What do you want for your birthday?', 'She’d always wanted to go to Thailand.', 'I don’t want Linda to  hear about this.', 'He didn’t want the holiday to end.', 'You can order whatever you want.', 'This shampoo is mild enough to use every day if you want.', 'If she doesn’t get what she wants, she’s not happy.', 'He wanted that job so badly he was willing to kill for it.', 'They desperately wanted a son.', 'What I want to know is when we’re going to get paid.', 'All I want is the chance to prove myself.', 'Oh thank you, it’s just what I’ve always wanted.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have a desire or a wish for something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Do you want some more tea?', "She's always wanted a large family.", 'All I want is the truth.', "Thanks for the present—it's just what I wanted.", 'I can do whatever I want.', 'The last thing I wanted was to upset you.', 'The party wants her as leader.', 'What do you want to do tomorrow?', "‘It's time you did your homework.’ ‘I don't want to!’", 'There are two points which I wanted to make.', 'I just wanted to know if everything was all right.', 'You can come too, if you want.', 'Do you want me to help?', "We didn't want this to happen.", 'I want it (to be) done as quickly as possible.', "I don't want you coming home so late.", 'Do you want your coffee black or white?']

sentence: If one manages to find the simplest method at the first attempt that can mostly be attributed to good luck .
gloss: Be in charge of (a business, organization, or undertaking); run.
eg_sent: their elder son managed the farm
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; If you manage an organization, business, or system, or the people who work in it, you are responsible for controlling them. ;;
exps_collins: ['Within two years he was managing the store.', 'Most factories in the area are obsolete and badly managed.', "There is a lack of confidence in the government's ability to manage the economy.", 'Professors are notoriously difficult to manage.']
bis_def_longman: to direct or control a business or department and the people, equipment, and money involved in it
exps_longman: ['He was asked to manage a new department.', 'The company had been very badly managed.', 'a brewery which has been owned and managed by the same family for over 100 years']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to succeed in doing something, especially something difficult
exps_oxford_advanced: ['In spite of his disappointment, he managed a weak smile.', "I don't know exactly how we'll manage it, but we will, somehow.", 'Can you manage another piece of cake? (= eat one)', 'We managed to get to the airport in time.', 'How did you manage to persuade him?', 'He always manages to say the wrong thing.', 'They managed to find a place to stay.', "We couldn't have managed without you.", '‘Need any help?’ ‘No, thanks. I can manage.’']

sentence: That 's what I do n't get .
gloss: Come to have (something); receive.
eg_sent: I got a letter from him the other day
bis_def_collins: You use get with adjectives to mean 'become'. For example, if someone gets cold, they become cold, and if they get angry, they become angry.
exps_collins: ['The boys were getting bored.', "There's no point in getting upset.", 'From here on, it can only get better.']
bis_def_longman: to receive something that someone gives you or sends you
exps_longman: ['She got loads of presents.', 'What did you get for Christmas?', 'We get a lot of junk mail.', 'We got a letter from Pam this morning.', 'I got it off my Dad.', 'I got a few games free when I bought my computer.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to receive something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['I got a letter from Dave this morning.', 'What (= What presents) did you get for your birthday?', 'He gets (= earns) about $40\u2009000 a year.', 'This room gets very little sunshine.', 'I got a shock when I saw the bill.', 'I get the impression that he is bored with his job.']

sentence: Enlargement shows a section through the lenses to show the direction of the field of view .
gloss: Allow or cause (something) to be visible.
eg_sent: a white blouse will show the blood
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; If something shows that a state of affairs exists, it gives information that proves it or makes it clear to people. ;;
exps_collins: ['Research shows that a high-fibre diet may protect you from bowel cancer.', 'He was arrested at his home in Southampton after a breath test showed he had drunk more than twice the legal limit for driving.', 'These figures show an increase of over one million in unemployment.', 'It was only later that the drug was shown to be addictive.', "You'll be given regular blood tests to show whether you have been infected."]
bis_def_longman: to let someone see something
exps_longman: ['The children proudly showed me their presents.', 'The man grinned, showing bad teeth.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to make something clear; to prove something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['The figures clearly show that her claims are false.', "The government's popularity is declining rapidly, as the opinion polls show.", 'Market research has shown us that people want quality, not just low prices.', 'a report showing the company’s current situation', 'His new book shows him to be a first-rate storyteller.', 'This shows how people are influenced by TV advertisements.']

sentence: I , I can remember Mollyrange sixty years ago and it was a very very different place , between you and me it really was .
gloss: Have in or be able to bring to one's mind an awareness of (someone or something from the past)
eg_sent: I remember the screech of the horn as the car came towards me
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; If you remember people or events from the past, you still have an idea of them in your mind and you are able to think about them. ;;
exps_collins: ["You wouldn't remember me. I was in another group.", "I certainly don't remember talking to you at all.", 'I remember her being a dominant figure.', 'I remembered that we had drunk the last of the coffee the week before.', 'I can remember where and when I bought each one.', 'I used to do that when you were a little girl, remember?']
bis_def_longman: to have a picture or idea in your mind of people, events, places etc from the past
exps_longman: ['Do you remember Rosa Davies?', 'I can’t remember her exact words.', 'I remember you two couldn’t stand each other at first!', 'I remember meeting her at a party once.', 'I remember my father bringing home a huge Christmas tree.', 'I remember it well; I’d never seen my mother so angry.', 'She clearly remembers the excitement as they boarded the train.', 'I vaguely remember reading something about it in the paper.', 'They had three children, if I remember rightly.', 'They’ve lived here for as long as I can remember.', 'No one got drunk as far as I can remember.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have or keep an image in your memory of an event, a person, a place, etc. from the past
exps_oxford_advanced: ['This is Carla. Do you remember her?', "I don't remember my first day at school.", "He still remembered her as the lively teenager he'd known years before.", "As far as I can remember, this is the third time we've met.", 'Do you remember switching the lights off before we came out?', 'I vaguely remember hearing him come in.', 'I can still vividly remember my grandfather teaching me to play cards.', "I can't remember his taking a single day off work.", 'I remember (that) we used to go and see them most weekends.']

sentence: Another digs the cream from the centre of a pink fancy and smears it in his hair .
gloss: Coat or mark (something) messily or carelessly with a greasy or sticky substance.
eg_sent: his face was smeared with dirt
bis_def_collins: VERB  ) If you smear a surface with an oily or sticky substance or smear the substance onto the surface, you spread a layer of the substance over the surface. )
exps_collins: ['My sister smeared herself with suntan oil and slept by the swimming pool.', 'Smear a little olive oil over the inside of the salad bowl.']
bis_def_longman: to spread a liquid or soft substance over a surface, especially in a careless or untidy way
exps_longman: ['His face was smeared with mud.', 'Elaine smeared suntan lotion on her shoulders.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to spread an oily or soft substance over a surface in a rough or careless way
exps_oxford_advanced: ['The children had smeared mud on the walls.', 'The children had smeared the walls with mud.', 'His face was smeared with blood.']

sentence: You telling me that all those scientists spent their time in America and could n't wait to get home ?
gloss: Give (money) to pay for goods, services, or so as to benefit someone or something.
eg_sent: the firm has spent £100,000 on hardware
bis_def_collins: VERB  ();() When you spend money, you pay money for things that you want. ();()
exps_collins: ['By the end of the holiday I had spent all my money.', 'Businessmen spend enormous amounts advertising their products.', 'Juventus have spent £23m on new players.', 'The survey may cost at least £100 but is money well spent.']
bis_def_longman: to use your money to pay for goods or services

sentence: Dr Runcie repeated his offer of a limited primacy , involving the limited powers exercised by the popes in the first few centuries of the Christian Church .
gloss: Say again something one has already said.
eg_sent: ‘Are you hurt?’ he repeated
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; If you repeat something, you say or write it again. You can say I repeat to show that you feel strongly about what you are repeating. ;
exps_collins: ['He repeated that he had been misquoted.', 'I repeat that medicine is on the brink of a revolution.', 'The Libyan leader Colonel Gadaffi repeated his call for the release of hostages.', "'You fool,' she kept repeating."]
bis_def_longman: to say or write something again
exps_longman: ['Can you repeat your question?', 'Sorry – could you repeat that?', 'Nick patiently repeated that he had to work that day.', 'It is not, I repeat not, my fault.', '‘I promise, ’ she repeated.', 'Elderly people tend to repeat themselves.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to say or write something again or more than once
exps_oxford_advanced: ['to repeat a question', "I'm sorry—could you repeat that?", 'She kept repeating his name softly over and over again.', "The opposition have been repeating their calls for the president's resignation.", 'Are you prepared to repeat these allegations in court?', "Do say if I'm repeating myself (= if I have already said this).", "He's fond of repeating that the company's success is all down to him."]

sentence: However , the later withdrawal of government support , with the scrapping of the Community Programme as unemployment receded , left many of these voluntary organizations high and dry .
gloss: Discard or remove from service (a redundant, old, or inoperative vehicle, vessel, or machine), especially so as to convert it to scrap metal.
eg_sent: a bold decision was taken to scrap existing plant
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; If you scrap something, you get rid of it or cancel it. ;; [informal, journalism]
exps_collins: ['President Hussein called on all countries in the Middle East to scrap nuclear or chemical weapons.', 'It had been thought that passport controls would be scrapped.']
bis_def_longman: to decide not to use a plan or system because it is not practical
exps_longman: ['We believe that car tax should be scrapped.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to cancel or get rid of something that is no longer practical or useful
exps_oxford_advanced: ['They had been forced to scrap plans for a new school building.', 'The oldest of the aircraft were scrapped.']

sentence: He competed for the Swiss cross-country and ski-jumping team at the Student Winter Games and later concentrated on single sculls .
gloss: Strive to gain or win something by defeating or establishing superiority over others.
eg_sent: universities are competing for applicants
bis_def_collins: When one firm or country competes with another, it tries to get people to buy its own goods in preference to those of the other firm or country. You can also say that two firms or countries compete .  [Also VERB]
exps_collins: ["The banks have long competed with American Express's charge cards and various store cards.", 'The stores will inevitably end up competing with each other in their push for increased market shares.', 'Banks and building societies are competing fiercely for business.', 'The American economy, and its ability to compete abroad, was slowing down according to the report.']
bis_def_longman: if one company or country competes with another, it tries to get people to buy its goods or services rather than those available from another company or country
exps_longman: ['They found themselves competing with foreign companies for a share of the market.', 'The Renault Clio competes against such cars as the Peugeot 206.', 'The stores have to compete for customers in the Christmas season.', 'The company must be able to compete in the international marketplace.', 'Several advertising agencies are competing to get the contract.', 'Small independent bookstores simply can’t compete with the big national chains.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to try to be more successful or better than somebody else who is trying to do the same as you
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Several companies are competing for the contract.', "We can't compete with them on price.", "Young children will usually compete for their mother's attention.", 'Small traders cannot compete in the face of cheap foreign imports.', 'There are too many magazines competing to attract readers.']

sentence: Labour would keep tight rein on spending
gloss: Have or retain possession of.
eg_sent: return one copy to me, keeping the other for your files

exps_collins: ['The noise kept him awake.', 'Reggie was being kept busy behind the bar.', 'To keep warm they burnt wood in a rusty oil barrel.', 'For several years I kept in touch with her.']

exps_longman: ['We huddled around the fire to keep warm.', 'I was struggling to keep awake.', 'some toys to keep the kids amused', 'You won’t be able to keep it secret forever.', 'Peter cycles to work to keep fit.', 'Don’t keep us in suspense any longer!', 'The police put up barriers to keep the crowds back.', 'If I were you, I’d keep away from that area at night.', 'The little boy kept close to his mother.', 'You keep out of this, Mother . It’s no concern of yours.', 'How can I cut your hair if you won’t keep still!', 'Jane kept the engine running.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to stay in a particular condition or position; to make somebody/something do this

sentence: " Once , " said Daniel , " I was in Charing Cross Hospital , someone 's kid had taken an overdose and died , they pump them out there regular as clockwork but this one 's liver could n't take any more .
gloss: Lay hold of (something) with one's hands; reach for and hold.
eg_sent: Mrs Morgan took another biscuit
bis_def_collins: You can use take followed by a noun to talk about an action or event, when it would also be possible to use the verb that is related to that noun. For example, you can say 'she took a shower' instead of 'she showered'.
exps_collins: ['She was too tired to take a shower.', 'Betty took a photograph of us.', "I've never taken a holiday since starting this job.", "There's not enough people willing to take the risk.", 'Walk around the property and take a good look at it from the outside.', 'We took a long walk through the pines.']

sentence: He said oh , he said , what are they celebrating ?
gloss: Utter words so as to convey information, an opinion, a feeling or intention, or an instruction.
eg_sent: ‘Thank you,’ he said

exps_collins: ["'I'm sorry,' he said.", 'She said they were very impressed.', 'Forty-one people are said to have been seriously hurt.', 'I packed and said goodbye to Charlie.', "I hope you didn't say anything about Gretchen.", "You didn't say much when you telephoned.", 'Did he say where he was going?.', "It doesn't sound exactly orthodox, if I may say so."]

Oh, please say yes!', 'He looked as if he was going to say something.', 'I wished I had said nothing about Jordi.', 'Does anyone else have anything to say?', 'Although he didn’t say so, it was clear that he was in pain.', 'What makes you say that (=why do you think that) ? 你怎么会那么说呢？', 'Nina said to meet her at 4.30.', 'I’d like to say a few words.', '‘So what are your plans now?’ ‘I’d rather not say.’']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to speak or tell somebody something, using words
exps_oxford_advanced: ['‘Hello!’ she said.', '‘That was marvellous,’ said Daniel.', 'Be quiet, I have something to say.', "I didn't believe a word she said.", "That's a terrible thing to say.", "He knew that if he wasn't back by midnight, his parents would have something to say about it (= be angry).", 'She said nothing to me about it.', "I said to myself (= thought), ‘That can't be right!’", 'He said (that) his name was Sam.', 'It is said that she lived to be over 100.', 'She finds it hard to say what she feels.', "‘That's impossible!’ ‘So you say (= but I think you may be wrong).’", "‘Why can't I go out now?’ ‘Because I say so.’", "‘What do you want it for?’ ‘I'd rather not say.’", 'He said to meet him here.', 'He is said to have been a brilliant scholar.']

sentence: It argued that in talking about inner cities it was vital to think in terms not just of individuals , but of society ; that the multiple deprivations of the worst hit areas affected all the residents ; that the consequences included a pervasive sense of neglect and decay , a decline in community spirit , a low standard of neighbourhood facilities , and an increase in crime and vandalism ; and that , without government intervention , the future was one of reduced job opportunities , deteriorating housing , and a decline in public services .
gloss: Comprise or contain as part of a whole.
eg_sent: the price includes dinner, bed, and breakfast
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; If one thing includes another thing, it has the other thing as one of its parts. ;
exps_collins: ['A good British breakfast always includes sausages.', 'The trip has been extended to include a few other events.', 'The list includes many British internationals.']
bis_def_longman: if one thing includes another, the second thing is part of the first
exps_longman: ['Does the price include postage?', 'His job includes looking after under-21 teams.', 'The curriculum includes courses in computing.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: if one thing includes another, it has the second thing as one of its parts

sentence: After half a mile he decided to turn off the embankment and walk up the side of the next field and along the path at the top of it , following the horses whom he could still see in the distance .
gloss: Perceive with the eyes; discern visually.
eg_sent: in the distance she could see the blue sea
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont] ; When you see something, you notice it using your eyes. ;
exps_collins: ["You can't see colours at night.", 'I saw a man making his way towards me.', 'She can see, hear, touch, smell, and taste.', 'As he neared the farm, he saw that a police car was parked outside it.', 'Did you see what happened?', 'You use see to talk about things that you are aware of because a visual impression reaches your eyes. You often use can in this case. I can see the fax here on the desk. If you want to say that someone is paying attention to something they can see, you say that they are looking at it or watching it. In general, you look at something that is not moving, while you watch something that is moving or changing. I asked him to look at the picture above his bed... He watched Blake run down the stairs.']
bis_def_longman: to notice or examine someone or something, using your eyes
exps_longman: ['He crouched down so he couldn’t be seen.', 'Can I see your ticket, please?', 'You can see the Houses of Parliament from here.', 'Can you see where the marks are on the wall?', 'The suspect was seen entering the building.', 'As you can see, the house needs some work doing on it.', 'Have you seen Chris ?', 'The accommodation was so awful it had to be seen to be believed.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to become aware of somebody/something by using your eyes
exps_oxford_advanced: ["She looked for him but couldn't see him in the crowd.", 'I looked out of the window but saw nothing.', 'The opera was the place to see and be seen (= by other important or fashionable people).', 'He could see (that) she had been crying.', 'Did you see what happened?', 'If you watch carefully, you’ll see how it is done.', 'I hate to see you unhappy.', 'She was seen running away from the scene of the crime.', 'I saw you put the key in your pocket.', 'He was seen to enter the building about the time the crime was committed.']

sentence: So I said , if you are a good girl you can choose a cake .

sentence: I want you to break the news gently to Gran .
gloss: Have a desire to possess or do (something); wish for.

bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont, no passive] ; If you want something, you feel a desire or a need for it. ;
exps_collins: ['I want a drink.', 'Ian knows exactly what he wants in life.', 'People wanted to know who this talented designer was.', 'They began to want their father to be the same as other daddies.', "They didn't want people staring at them as they sat on the lawn, so they put up high walls.", 'He wanted his power recognised.', 'I want my car this colour.', 'And remember, we want him alive.', "Note that want and wish have similar meanings, but are used differently. If you want something, you feel a need for it or a desire to have it. You can say that you want to do something, that you want someone to do something, or that you want something to happen. If you use wish with a 'to' infinitive, this has the same meaning as want but is more formal. I want to get out of here... She wished to consult him about her future."]

sentence: They may have to be read in the open air , in rain and darkness or within a plant under oily , cramped , poorly lit conditions .

sentence: The situation is further confused when some but not all the operator information support is itself computer-based .
I 'm trying to reduce the number of business administrators : the fewer there are , the simpler the system and the cheaper it will be .

sentence: She keeps kicking her legs and going , ah , ah .
gloss: Have or retain possession of.
eg_sent: return one copy to me, keeping the other for your files
bis_def_collins: If someone keeps or is kept in a particular state, they remain in it.

bis_def_longman: to stay in a particular state, condition, or position, or to make someone or something do this
exps_longman: ['We huddled around the fire to keep warm.', 'I was struggling to keep awake.', 'some toys to keep the kids amused', 'You won’t be able to keep it secret forever.', 'Peter cycles to work to keep fit.', 'Don’t keep us in suspense any longer!', 'The police put up barriers to keep the crowds back.', 'If I were you, I’d keep away from that area at night.', 'The little boy kept close to his mother.', 'You keep out of this, Mother . It’s no concern of yours.', 'How can I cut your hair if you won’t keep still!', 'Jane kept the engine running.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to stay in a particular condition or position; to make somebody/something do this

sentence: It 's hard to tell .

(= you should have listened to my advice)', "Why wasn't I told about the accident?", 'They’ve told us (that) they’re not coming.', 'I kept telling myself (that) everything was OK.', "Are you telling me you didn't have any help with this? (= I don't believe what you have said)", 'Tell me where you live.', "‘I'm ready to go now,’ he told her."]

sentence: This necessitates , in turn , a far more numerous and ubiquitous police presence than in other kinds of area , far more frequent unpleasant contact with the public as potential suspects , and far greater opportunities for police misjudgment or abuse .

sentence: " Not to be mentioned in the same breath with " she said , looking nervously from Frederica to painted signature .
gloss: Refer to (something) briefly and without going into detail.

bis_def_collins: VERB  ) If you mention something, you say something about it, usually briefly. )
exps_collins: ["She did not mention her mother's absence.", 'I may not have mentioned it to her.', "I had mentioned that I didn't really like contemporary music.", "She shouldn't have mentioned how heavy the dress was.", 'I felt as though I should mention it as an option.']

sentence: Buzz never cheated to let Elinor win : she knew that Elinor would immediately sense this and feel humiliated .
gloss: Be aware of through observation, inquiry, or information.
eg_sent: most people know that CFCs can damage the ozone layer
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont]  If you know a fact, a piece of information, or an answer, you have it correctly in your mind.
exps_collins: ["I don't know the name of the place.", 'I know that you led a rifle platoon during the Second World War.', "'People like doing things for nothing.' — 'I know they do.'.", "I don't know what happened to her husband.", "'How did he meet your mother?' — 'I don't know.'.", 'We all know about his early experiments in flying.', 'They looked younger than I knew them to be.', 'Radon is known to be harmful to humans in large quantities.', 'It is not known whether the bomb was originally intended for the capital itself.', "It's always been known that key figures in the government do very well for themselves."]
bis_def_longman: to have information about something
exps_longman: ['Who knows the answer?', 'There are instructions telling you everything you need to know.', 'Didn’t you know that?', 'Do you know what time it is?', 'I don’t know where to go.', 'I need to know more about the job before I decide whether to apply for it.', 'Little is known about the author’s childhood.', 'I know all about David and what he’s been up to!', 'I wonder if he knew of the plan?', 'Do you know of any good restaurants in the area?', 'You know nothing of this business.', 'We know that greenhouse gases can affect the climate.', 'Let me know what time you’re planning to arrive.', 'I thought you’d want to know immediately.', 'If you must know, I was with James last night .', 'He slipped out of the house without his parents knowing .', 'How did he know our names?', '‘I’m divorced, as you know, ’ she said briefly.', 'Smoking is known to increase a person’s risk of developing lung cancer.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have information in your mind as a result of experience or because you have learned or been told it
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Do you know his address?', 'The cause of the fire is not yet known.', 'All I know is that she used to work in a bank (= I have no other information about her).', 'I know (that) people’s handwriting changes as they get older.', 'It is widely known that CFCs can damage the ozone layer.', 'I knew where he was hiding.', "I didn't know what he was talking about.", "‘You've got a flat tyre.’ ‘I know.’", "‘What's the answer?’ ‘I don't know.’", "‘There's no one in.’ ‘How do you know?’", "You know about Amanda's baby, don't you?", "I don't know about you, but I'm ready for something to eat.", 'I know of at least two people who did the same thing.', '‘Is anyone else coming?’ ‘Not that I know of.’', '‘Isn’t that his car?’ ‘I wouldn’t know./How should I know?’ (= I don’t know and I am not the person you should ask.)', "‘What are you two whispering about?’ ‘You don't want to know’ (= because you would be shocked or wouldn't approve).", 'Does he know to come here (= that he should come here) first?', 'We know her to be honest.', 'Two women are known to have died.']
