sentence: So what 's going to happen to the European Plan ? he asked .
gloss: Say something in order to obtain an answer or some information.
eg_sent: I asked her what she meant
bis_def_collins: If you ask someone something, you say something to them in the form of a question because you want to know the answer.  [Also V about n]
exps_collins: ["'How is Frank?' he asked.", 'I asked him his name.', "I wasn't the only one asking questions.", "She asked me if I'd enjoyed my dinner.", 'If Daniel asks what happened in court we will tell him.', 'You will have to ask David about that.', "'I'm afraid to ask what it cost.' — 'Then don't ask.'"]
bis_def_longman: to speak or write to someone in order to get an answer, information, or a solution
exps_longman: ['‘What’s your name?’ she asked.', 'Don’t ask him – he won’t know.', 'That kid’s always asking awkward questions.', 'I asked him where he lived.', 'We’ll have to ask someone the way to the station.', 'Go and ask Tom whether he’s coming tonight.', 'Visitors usually ask about the history of the castle.', 'I’ll ask around, see if I can find you a place to stay.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to say or write something in the form of a question, in order to get information
exps_oxford_advanced: ['How old are you—if you don’t mind me/my asking?', 'He asked about her family.', 'Can I ask a question?', 'Did you ask the price?', '‘Where are you going?’ she asked.', '‘Are you sure?’ he asked her.', 'She asked the students their names.', 'I often get asked that!', 'The interviewer asked me about my future plans.', 'He asked where I lived.', 'I had to ask the teacher what to do next.', 'I was asked if/whether I could drive.']

sentence: I know .
gloss: Be aware of through observation, inquiry, or information.
eg_sent: most people know that CFCs can damage the ozone layer
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont]  If you know a fact, a piece of information, or an answer, you have it correctly in your mind.
exps_collins: ["I don't know the name of the place.", 'I know that you led a rifle platoon during the Second World War.', "'People like doing things for nothing.' — 'I know they do.'.", "I don't know what happened to her husband.", "'How did he meet your mother?' — 'I don't know.'.", 'We all know about his early experiments in flying.', 'They looked younger than I knew them to be.', 'Radon is known to be harmful to humans in large quantities.', 'It is not known whether the bomb was originally intended for the capital itself.', "It's always been known that key figures in the government do very well for themselves."]
bis_def_longman: to have information about something
exps_longman: ['Who knows the answer?', 'There are instructions telling you everything you need to know.', 'Didn’t you know that?', 'Do you know what time it is?', 'I don’t know where to go.', 'I need to know more about the job before I decide whether to apply for it.', 'Little is known about the author’s childhood.', 'I know all about David and what he’s been up to!', 'I wonder if he knew of the plan?', 'Do you know of any good restaurants in the area?', 'You know nothing of this business.', 'We know that greenhouse gases can affect the climate.', 'Let me know what time you’re planning to arrive.', 'I thought you’d want to know immediately.', 'If you must know, I was with James last night .', 'He slipped out of the house without his parents knowing .', 'How did he know our names?', '‘I’m divorced, as you know, ’ she said briefly.', 'Smoking is known to increase a person’s risk of developing lung cancer.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have information in your mind as a result of experience or because you have learned or been told it
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Do you know his address?', 'The cause of the fire is not yet known.', 'All I know is that she used to work in a bank (= I have no other information about her).', 'I know (that) people’s handwriting changes as they get older.', 'It is widely known that CFCs can damage the ozone layer.', 'I knew where he was hiding.', "I didn't know what he was talking about.", "‘You've got a flat tyre.’ ‘I know.’", "‘What's the answer?’ ‘I don't know.’", "‘There's no one in.’ ‘How do you know?’", "You know about Amanda's baby, don't you?", "I don't know about you, but I'm ready for something to eat.", 'I know of at least two people who did the same thing.', '‘Is anyone else coming?’ ‘Not that I know of.’', '‘Isn’t that his car?’ ‘I wouldn’t know./How should I know?’ (= I don’t know and I am not the person you should ask.)', "‘What are you two whispering about?’ ‘You don't want to know’ (= because you would be shocked or wouldn't approve).", 'Does he know to come here (= that he should come here) first?', 'We know her to be honest.', 'Two women are known to have died.']

Let’s go home.', 'Where are you going?', 'We’re going to Canada in the summer.', 'Dinah went into the kitchen.', 'She went over and put her arm around him.', 'I’m going round to her house to find out what’s wrong.', 'I’ll just go up  and ask him what he wants.']

sentence: Elinor frowned slightly at Buzz .

Oh, please say yes!', 'He looked as if he was going to say something.', 'I wished I had said nothing about Jordi.', 'Does anyone else have anything to say?', 'Although he didn’t say so, it was clear that he was in pain.', 'What makes you say that (=why do you think that) ? 你怎么会那么说呢？', 'Nina said to meet her at 4.30.', 'I’d like to say a few words.', '‘So what are your plans now?’ ‘I’d rather not say.’']

sentence: I hope the wind does n't blow them over .

sentence: The Community Health Team aim was to ensure a place of treatment for children from the earliest possible age , to enable them to develop to their fullest potential .

sentence: I know that .
gloss: Be aware of through observation, inquiry, or information.

bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont]  If you know a fact, a piece of information, or an answer, you have it correctly in your mind.
exps_collins: ["I don't know the name of the place.", 'I know that you led a rifle platoon during the Second World War.', "'People like doing things for nothing.' — 'I know they do.'.", "I don't know what happened to her husband.", "'How did he meet your mother?' — 'I don't know.'.", 'We all know about his early experiments in flying.', 'They looked younger than I knew them to be.', 'Radon is known to be harmful to humans in large quantities.', 'It is not known whether the bomb was originally intended for the capital itself.', "It's always been known that key figures in the government do very well for themselves."]
bis_def_longman: to have information about something
exps_longman: ['Who knows the answer?', 'There are instructions telling you everything you need to know.', 'Didn’t you know that?', 'Do you know what time it is?', 'I don’t know where to go.', 'I need to know more about the job before I decide whether to apply for it.', 'Little is known about the author’s childhood.', 'I know all about David and what he’s been up to!', 'I wonder if he knew of the plan?', 'Do you know of any good restaurants in the area?', 'You know nothing of this business.', 'We know that greenhouse gases can affect the climate.', 'Let me know what time you’re planning to arrive.', 'I thought you’d want to know immediately.', 'If you must know, I was with James last night .', 'He slipped out of the house without his parents knowing .', 'How did he know our names?', '‘I’m divorced, as you know, ’ she said briefly.', 'Smoking is known to increase a person’s risk of developing lung cancer.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have information in your mind as a result of experience or because you have learned or been told it
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Do you know his address?', 'The cause of the fire is not yet known.', 'All I know is that she used to work in a bank (= I have no other information about her).', 'I know (that) people’s handwriting changes as they get older.', 'It is widely known that CFCs can damage the ozone layer.', 'I knew where he was hiding.', "I didn't know what he was talking about.", "‘You've got a flat tyre.’ ‘I know.’", "‘What's the answer?’ ‘I don't know.’", "‘There's no one in.’ ‘How do you know?’", "You know about Amanda's baby, don't you?", "I don't know about you, but I'm ready for something to eat.", 'I know of at least two people who did the same thing.', '‘Is anyone else coming?’ ‘Not that I know of.’', '‘Isn’t that his car?’ ‘I wouldn’t know./How should I know?’ (= I don’t know and I am not the person you should ask.)', "‘What are you two whispering about?’ ‘You don't want to know’ (= because you would be shocked or wouldn't approve).", 'Does he know to come here (= that he should come here) first?', 'We know her to be honest.', 'Two women are known to have died.']

gloss: Direct one's gaze toward someone or something or in a specified direction.
eg_sent: people were looking at him
bis_def_collins: If you look in a particular direction, you direct your eyes in that direction, especially so that you can see what is there or see what something is like.
exps_collins: ['I looked down the hallway to room number nine.', 'She turned to look at him.', 'He looked away, apparently enraged.', "If you look, you'll see what was a lake.", 'If you want to say that someone is paying attention to something they can see, you say that they are looking at it or watching it. In general, you look at something that is not moving, while you watch something that is moving or changing. I asked him to look at the picture above his bed... He watched Blake run down the stairs. Look is never followed directly by an object. You must always use at or some other preposition. I looked towards the plane. You use see to talk about things that you are aware of because a visual impression reaches your eyes. You often use can in this case. I can see the fax here on the desk.']
bis_def_longman: to turn your eyes towards something, so that you can see it
exps_longman: ['We sneaked out while Jessie’s mom wasn’t looking.', 'If you look carefully you can see that the painting represents a human figure.', 'Gina covered her eyes, afraid to look.', '‘It’s time we left, ’ Ian said, looking at his watch.', 'The men all turned to look at her as she entered the room.', 'Dad looked up from his paper and smiled.', '‘We can’t go out in this weather, ’ said Bob, looking out of the window.']

sentence: The odds are favourable enough according to Chelsea 's Mike Hazard , who said of his adversary : He could cope in Poland , not just because of his ability to close people down and use the ball well , but temperament you saw when he scored the goal that won Arsenal the League .
gloss: Be successful or victorious in (a contest or conflict)
eg_sent: United won four games in a row
bis_def_collins: If you win something such as a competition, battle, or argument, you defeat those people you are competing or fighting against, or you do better than everyone else involved.
exps_collins: ['He does not have any realistic chance of winning the election.', 'The NCAA basketball championship was won by North Carolina.', '...when Napoleon was winning his great battles in Italy.', 'The top four teams all won.', 'Sanchez Vicario won 2-6, 6-4, 6-3.']
bis_def_longman: to be the best or most successful in a competition, game, election etc
exps_longman: ['Who do you think will win the next election?', 'He won the Tour de France last year.', 'the young pilots who won the Battle of Britain', 'Who’s winning ?', 'I never win at cards.', 'We won by just one point.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to be the most successful in a competition, race, battle, etc.
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Which team won?', 'to win at cards/chess, etc.', 'France won by six goals to two against Denmark.', 'to win an election/a game/a war, etc.', 'She loves to win an argument.']

sentence: Go on then you 'll be able to see mummy from work .
gloss: Move from one place to another; travel.
eg_sent: he went out to the shops
bis_def_collins: When you go somewhere, you move or travel there.

exps_longman: ['There’s nothing more we can do here. Let’s go home.', 'Where are you going?', 'We’re going to Canada in the summer.', 'Dinah went into the kitchen.', 'She went over and put her arm around him.', 'I’m going round to her house to find out what’s wrong.', 'I’ll just go up  and ask him what he wants.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to move or travel from one place to another
exps_oxford_advanced: ['She went into her room and shut the door behind her.', 'He goes to work by bus.', 'I have to go to Rome on business.', 'She has gone to China (= is now in China or is on her way there).', 'She has been to China (= she went to China and has now returned).', "I think you should go to the doctor's.", 'Are you going home for Christmas?', 'She has gone to see her sister this weekend.']

sentence: When he did n't get any response , he patted the Uzi beside him on the steel floor .
gloss: Touch quickly and gently with the flat of the hand.
eg_sent: he patted him consolingly on the shoulder
bis_def_collins: If you pat something or someone, you tap them lightly, usually with your hand held flat.
exps_collins: ["'Don't you worry about any of this,' she said patting me on the knee.", 'The landlady patted her hair nervously.', 'Wash the lettuce and pat it dry.']
bis_def_longman: to lightly touch someone or something several times with your hand flat, especially to give comfort

bis_def_oxford_advanced: to touch somebody/something gently several times with your hand flat, especially as a sign of affection
exps_oxford_advanced: ['She patted the dog on the head.', "He patted his sister's hand consolingly.", 'Pat your face dry with a soft towel.']

sentence: Nell 's transceivered voice crackled in his headphones .
gloss: Make a rapid succession of short sharp noises.
eg_sent: the fire suddenly crackled and spat sparks
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; If something crackles, it makes a rapid series of short, harsh noises. ;
exps_collins: ['The radio crackled again.', '...a crackling fire.']
bis_def_longman: to make repeated short sounds like something burning in a fire
exps_longman: ['logs crackling on the fire', 'An announcement crackled over the tannoy.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to make short sharp sounds like something that is burning in a fire
exps_oxford_advanced: ['A log fire crackled in the hearth.', 'The radio crackled into life.', 'The atmosphere crackled with tension.']

sentence: Then knightly armour grew more elaborate and costly throughout the century .
gloss: (of a living thing) undergo natural development by increasing in size and changing physically.
eg_sent: he would watch Nick grow to manhood
bis_def_collins: When people, animals, and plants grow, they increase in size and change physically over a period of time.
exps_collins: ['We stop growing at maturity.']
bis_def_longman: to increase in amount, size, number, or strength
exps_longman: ['Support for Mr Thompson is growing.', 'Sales of new cars grew by 10% last year.', 'The number of students at the college has grown from 200 to over 500.', 'A growing number of people are taking part-time jobs.', 'The economy has grown steadily.', 'Fears are growing for the crew’s safety.', 'a city that is still growing in size', 'Skiing has really grown in popularity.', 'There is growing concern about climate change.', 'my growing interest in China']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to increase in size, number, strength or quality

sentence: Oh I know what I 've got !
gloss: Come to have (something); receive.
eg_sent: I got a letter from him the other day
bis_def_collins: You use get with adjectives to mean 'become'. For example, if someone gets cold, they become cold, and if they get angry, they become angry.

bis_def_longman: to receive something that someone gives you or sends you

sentence: So I asked him what he was up to and he said he was going to and fro in the earth and walking up and down in it , and then he pushed th " trolley in , and I went in after , and the mother began her howling and shrieking , and Will said , " Well , I 'll walk off and leave you to it . "
gloss: Move at a regular pace by lifting and setting down each foot in turn, never having both feet off the ground at once.
eg_sent: I walked across the lawn
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; When you walk, you move forward by putting one foot in front of the other in a regular way. ;;
exps_collins: ['Rosanna and Forbes walked in silence for some while.', 'We walked into the foyer.', 'She turned and walked away.', 'They would stop the car and walk a few steps.', 'When I was your age I walked five miles to school.']
bis_def_longman: to move forward by putting one foot in front of the other
exps_longman: ['‘How did you get here?’ ‘We walked.’', 'Doctors said he’d never walk again.', 'Carrie walked into the room and sat down in her chair.', 'He loved walking in the hills.', 'We must have walked ten miles today.', 'I walked all the way to San Rafael.', 'There are plenty of bars and restaurants within walking distance of the hotel.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to move or go somewhere by putting one foot in front of the other on the ground, but without running

sentence: Ruth fetched and carried and stirred and whipped , praying every moment that Joss Barnet would return before they left Millfield next day .
gloss: Go for and then bring back (someone or something) for someone.
eg_sent: he ran to fetch help
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; If you fetch something or someone, you go and get them from the place where they are. ;;
exps_collins: ['Sylvia fetched a towel from the bathroom.', 'Fetch me a glass of water.', 'The caddie ran over to fetch something for him.']
bis_def_longman: to go and get something or someone and bring them back
exps_longman: ['Quick! Go and fetch a doctor.', 'Shannon went upstairs to fetch some blankets.', 'Would you mind going to fetch the kids from school?']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to go to where somebody/something is and bring them/it back
exps_oxford_advanced: ['to fetch help/a doctor', 'The inhabitants have to walk a mile to fetch water.', "She's gone to fetch the kids from school.", 'Could you fetch me my bag?']

sentence: This has been a constant theme of Intifada policy : that we wish to build ( Palestine ) , not to destroy ( Israel ) ; that we wish to achieve freedom ( for our people ) , not to deprive others ( Israelis ) of it ; that we wish to protect and save lives ( ours ) , not to endanger the lives of others ( Israelis ) .
gloss: Put (someone or something) at risk or in danger.
eg_sent: he was driving in a manner likely to endanger life
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; To endanger something or someone means to put them in a situation where they might be harmed or destroyed completely. ;
exps_collins: ['The debate could endanger the proposed peace talks.', '...endangered species such as lynx and wolf.']
bis_def_longman: to put someone or something in danger of being hurt, damaged, or destroyed
exps_longman: ['Smoking during pregnancy endangers your baby’s life.', 'The lizards are classed as an endangered species (=  ).', 'charges of child endangerment']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to put somebody/something in a situation in which they could be harmed or damaged
exps_oxford_advanced: ['The health of our children is being endangered by exhaust fumes.', 'That one mistake seriously endangered the future of the company.', 'He denied possessing a rifle with intent to endanger life.', 'Taking these drugs could seriously endanger your health.', 'They are accused of causing an explosion likely to endanger life.']

sentence: I think it could be on the cards .
gloss: Have a particular opinion, belief, or idea about someone or something.
eg_sent: she thought that nothing would be the same again
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont] ; If you think that something is the case, you have the opinion that it is the case. ; [Also VERB n to-infinitive]
exps_collins: ['I certainly think there should be a ban on tobacco advertising.', 'Do you think I ought to seal the boxes up?.', 'A generation ago, it was thought that babies born this small could not survive.', 'Tell me, what do you think of my theory?.', 'Peter is useless, far worse than I thought.', 'He manages a good deal better than I thought possible.', "'It ought to be stopped.' — 'Yes, I think so.'"]
bis_def_longman: to have a particular opinion or to believe that something is true
exps_longman: ['I think that you’re being unfair.', 'I thought I heard something.', 'He didn’t think anyone would believe him.', 'Do you think I should call him?', 'For some reason, I keep thinking it’s Friday today.', 'The recession lasted longer than anyone thought it would.', 'Am I right in thinking that you have a brother?', 'I can’t help thinking that he’s made a mistake.', 'Do you honestly think I would do something so stupid?', 'What do you think of your new school?', 'I thought it best to call first.', 'I thought it appropriate to invite her to speak at the meeting.', 'We must start thinking in terms of reducing costs.', 'Fraud is thought to be costing software companies millions of dollars a year.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have a particular idea or opinion about something/somebody; to believe something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Do you think (that) they’ll come?', 'I thought I heard a scream.', "I didn't think you liked sports.", 'Am I right in thinking that you used to live here?', "I think this is their house, but I'm not sure.", 'He ought to resign, I think.', "We'll need about 20 chairs, I should think.", 'It was once thought that the sun travelled around the earth.', 'What did you think about the idea?', 'Well, I like it. What do you think?', '‘Will we make it in time?’ ‘I think so.’', "‘Is he any good?’ ‘I don't think so.’", "I think it highly unlikely that I'll get the job.", 'She thought him kind and generous.', "He's thought to be one of the richest men in Europe."]

sentence: How you keeping ?
gloss: Have or retain possession of.
eg_sent: return one copy to me, keeping the other for your files
bis_def_collins: If someone keeps or is kept in a particular state, they remain in it.
exps_collins: ['The noise kept him awake.', 'Reggie was being kept busy behind the bar.', 'To keep warm they burnt wood in a rusty oil barrel.', 'For several years I kept in touch with her.']
bis_def_longman: to stay in a particular state, condition, or position, or to make someone or something do this
exps_longman: ['We huddled around the fire to keep warm.', 'I was struggling to keep awake.', 'some toys to keep the kids amused', 'You won’t be able to keep it secret forever.', 'Peter cycles to work to keep fit.', 'Don’t keep us in suspense any longer!', 'The police put up barriers to keep the crowds back.', 'If I were you, I’d keep away from that area at night.', 'The little boy kept close to his mother.', 'You keep out of this, Mother . It’s no concern of yours.', 'How can I cut your hair if you won’t keep still!', 'Jane kept the engine running.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to stay in a particular condition or position; to make somebody/something do this
exps_oxford_advanced: ['We huddled together to keep warm.', 'The notice said ‘Keep off (= Do not walk on) the grass’.', 'Keep left along the wall.', 'She kept the children amused for hours.', 'He kept his coat on.', "Don't keep us in suspense—what happened next?", 'She had trouble keeping her balance.', "I'm very sorry to keep you waiting."]

sentence: But this argument will seem less persuasive when we have discussed cases of manslaughter by reason of diminished responsibility : where a murder is reduced to manslaughter , the judge has a wide sentencing discretion and may , according to the facts of the case , select a determinate prison sentence , a hospital order , or life imprisonment .
gloss: Make or become less.
eg_sent: the new law is expected to diminish the government's chances
bis_def_collins: V-ERG  ;; When something diminishes, or when something diminishes it, it becomes reduced in size, importance, or intensity. ;;
exps_collins: ['The threat of nuclear war has diminished.', 'Federalism is intended to diminish the power of the central state.', 'Universities are facing grave problems because of diminishing resources.', 'This could mean diminished public support for the war.']
bis_def_longman: to become or make something become smaller or less
exps_longman: ['The party’s share of the electorate has diminished steadily.', 'These drugs diminish blood flow to the brain.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to become or to make something become smaller, weaker, etc.
exps_oxford_advanced: ["The world's resources are rapidly diminishing.", 'His influence has diminished with time.', 'Our efforts were producing diminishing returns (= we achieved less although we spent more time or money).']

sentence: They stayed like that for a long moment and then he said , Light the candle .
gloss: Remain in the same place.

bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; If you stay where you are, you continue to be there and do not leave. ;;

sentence: I WRITE in response to Judith Raymont ( November 16 ) who wrote of the cartoon Men A User 's Guide , It is either insulting to men and should not be endorsed by publication , or it is witty and amusing , in which case we , as women , have no right to complain about equivalent portrayals of female stereotypes .

sentence: Foul play was not suspected , " and from conflicting newspapers .
gloss: Have an idea or impression of the existence, presence, or truth of (something) without certain proof.
eg_sent: if you suspect a gas leak, do not turn on an electric light
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; You use suspect when you are stating something that you believe is probably true, in order to make it sound less strong or direct. ; [vagueness]

bis_def_longman: to think that something is probably true, especially something bad

bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have an idea that something is probably true or likely to happen, especially something bad, but without having definite proof

sentence: Yet , despite such revolutionary changes in technology , novel solutions will still be required to make effective use of the new data sets .
gloss: Form (something) by putting parts together or combining substances; create.

gloss: Come or bring to a final point; finish.
eg_sent: when the war ended, policy changed
bis_def_collins: V-ERG  ; When a situation, process, or activity ends, or when something or someone ends it, it reaches its final point and stops. ;
exps_collins: ['The meeting quickly ended and Steve and I left the room.', 'Talks have resumed to try to end the fighting.', 'She began to weep. That ended our discussion.']
bis_def_longman: if an event, activity, or story ends, it stops happening
exps_longman: ['World War II ended in 1945.', 'The festival will end with a spectacular laser show.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to finish; to make something finish
exps_oxford_advanced: ['The road ends here.', 'How does the story end?', 'The speaker ended by suggesting some topics for discussion.', 'Her note ended with the words: ‘See you soon.’', 'They decided to end their relationship.', 'They ended the play with a song.', '‘And that was that,’ she ended.']

sentence: But reading between the lines , I think Clare needs money .
gloss: Require (something) because it is essential or very important rather than just desirable.
eg_sent: I need help now
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont] ) If you need something, or need to do something, you cannot successfully achieve what you want or live properly without it. )
exps_collins: ['He desperately needed money.', 'These diets provide everything your body needs.', 'I need to make a phone call.', 'A baby does not need to wear shoes until he starts to walk.', 'I need you to do something for me.', 'I need you here, Wally.', 'I need you sane and sober.']
bis_def_longman: to have to have something or someone, because you cannot do something without them, or because you cannot continue or cannot exist without them
exps_longman: ['You don’t really need a car.', 'Plants need light in order to survive.', 'The camcorder needs a new battery.', 'Are you sure that you have everything you need?', 'I need glasses for reading.', 'I need you to help me with the cooking.', 'More blood donors are urgently needed.', 'a much needed boost to the local economy']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to require something/somebody because they are essential or very important, not just because you would like to have them
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Do you need any help?', "It's here if you need it.", "Don't go—I might need you.", 'They badly needed a change.', 'Food aid is urgently needed.', 'What do you need your own computer for? You can use ours.', "I don't need your comments, thank you.", 'I need to get some sleep.', 'He needs to win this game to stay in the match.', "You don't need to leave yet, do you?", 'This shirt needs to be washed.', 'This shirt needs washing.']

sentence: Trace gases in the atmosphere are key components of the cycles of such elements as carbon , nitrogen , oxygen , sulphur and the halogens ; as is now well known , their concentrations are much influenced by biogenic and anthropogenic activities and the concentrations of such gases as carbon dioxide , ozone , methane , nitrous oxide and the chlorofluoromethanes ( CFMs ) strongly affect radiative transfer and provide a link with the physical climate system .
gloss: Have an effect on; make a difference to.
eg_sent: the dampness began to affect my health
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; If something affects a person or thing, it influences them or causes them to change in some way. ;
exps_collins: ['Nicotine adversely affects the functioning of the heart and arteries.', 'More than seven million people have been affected by drought.', '...the worst-affected areas of Somalia.']
bis_def_longman: to do something that produces an effect or change in something or in someone’s situation
exps_longman: ['the areas affected by the hurricane', 'a disease that affects the central nervous system', 'decisions which affect our lives', 'Trading has been adversely affected by the downturn in consumer spending.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to produce a change in somebody/something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['How will these changes affect us?', 'Your opinion will not affect my decision.', 'The south of the country was worst affected by the drought.']

sentence: Faced , however , with the catastrophic increase in unemployment and the need to occupy large numbers of workless people without directly employing them ( which would have run counter to the economic doctrine which had led to the redundancy of many of them in the first place ) , the Government poured money into any voluntary agency willing to put in a bid for government-funded cheap labour .
gloss: Reside or have one's place of business in (a building)
eg_sent: the rented flat she occupies in Hampstead
bis_def_collins: The people who occupy a building or a place are the people who live or work there.
exps_collins: ['There were over 40 tenants, all occupying one wing of the hospital.', 'Land is, in most instances, purchased by those who occupy it.']
bis_def_longman: to live or stay in a place
exps_longman: ['He occupies the house without paying any rent.', 'The building was purchased and occupied by its new owners last year.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to fill or use a space, an area or an amount of time
exps_oxford_advanced: ['The bed seemed to occupy most of the room.', 'How much memory does the program occupy?', 'Administrative work occupies half of my time.', 'How do you occupy your time?', 'Their time is fully occupied with their rigorous training regime.']

sentence: If we can get to it , I can learn so much more .
gloss: Gain or acquire knowledge of or skill in (something) by study, experience, or being taught.
eg_sent: they'd started learning French
bis_def_collins: If you learn something, you obtain knowledge or a skill through studying or training.  [Also V + about]
exps_collins: ['Their children were going to learn English.', 'He is learning to play the piano.', '...learning how to use new computer systems.', 'Experienced teachers help you learn quickly.']
bis_def_longman: to gain knowledge of a subject or skill, by experience, by studying it, or by being taught
exps_longman: ['What’s the best way to learn a language?', 'I learnt to drive when I was 17.', 'Hector spent the winter learning how to cope with his blindness.', 'The teacher’s task is to help the pupil learn.', 'I learned a lot from my father.', 'Kids can have fun and learn about music at the same time.', 'Youngsters must learn what is dangerous and what is not to be feared.', 'The student will learn from experience about the importance of planning.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to gain knowledge or skill by studying, from experience, from being taught, etc.
exps_oxford_advanced: ['to learn a language/a musical instrument/a skill', 'I learned a lot from my father.', 'You can learn a great deal just from watching other players.', "She's very keen to learn about Japanese culture.", 'The book is about how children learn.', "He's learning to dance.", 'He’s still learning how to dance.', 'Today we learnt how to use the new software.']

sentence: But people seem to think that stories are written to a prescription , that you sit down and say , you do n't want it to be sexist , you do n't want it to be racist .
gloss: Have a particular opinion, belief, or idea about someone or something.
eg_sent: she thought that nothing would be the same again
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont] ; If you think that something is the case, you have the opinion that it is the case. ; [Also VERB n to-infinitive]
exps_collins: ['I certainly think there should be a ban on tobacco advertising.', 'Do you think I ought to seal the boxes up?.', 'A generation ago, it was thought that babies born this small could not survive.', 'Tell me, what do you think of my theory?.', 'Peter is useless, far worse than I thought.', 'He manages a good deal better than I thought possible.', "'It ought to be stopped.' — 'Yes, I think so.'"]
bis_def_longman: to have a particular opinion or to believe that something is true
exps_longman: ['I think that you’re being unfair.', 'I thought I heard something.', 'He didn’t think anyone would believe him.', 'Do you think I should call him?', 'For some reason, I keep thinking it’s Friday today.', 'The recession lasted longer than anyone thought it would.', 'Am I right in thinking that you have a brother?', 'I can’t help thinking that he’s made a mistake.', 'Do you honestly think I would do something so stupid?', 'What do you think of your new school?', 'I thought it best to call first.', 'I thought it appropriate to invite her to speak at the meeting.', 'We must start thinking in terms of reducing costs.', 'Fraud is thought to be costing software companies millions of dollars a year.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have a particular idea or opinion about something/somebody; to believe something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Do you think (that) they’ll come?', 'I thought I heard a scream.', "I didn't think you liked sports.", 'Am I right in thinking that you used to live here?', "I think this is their house, but I'm not sure.", 'He ought to resign, I think.', "We'll need about 20 chairs, I should think.", 'It was once thought that the sun travelled around the earth.', 'What did you think about the idea?', 'Well, I like it. What do you think?', '‘Will we make it in time?’ ‘I think so.’', "‘Is he any good?’ ‘I don't think so.’", "I think it highly unlikely that I'll get the job.", 'She thought him kind and generous.', "He's thought to be one of the richest men in Europe."]

sentence: The monitoring network has become known as the radioactive incident monitoring network ( RIMNET ) and has , as its prime responsibility , the detection of abnormal increases in radiation levels within the UK of the kind that might arise from an overseas nuclear accident .
gloss: Be aware of through observation, inquiry, or information.
eg_sent: most people know that CFCs can damage the ozone layer
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont]  If you know a fact, a piece of information, or an answer, you have it correctly in your mind.
exps_collins: ["I don't know the name of the place.", 'I know that you led a rifle platoon during the Second World War.', "'People like doing things for nothing.' — 'I know they do.'.", "I don't know what happened to her husband.", "'How did he meet your mother?' — 'I don't know.'.", 'We all know about his early experiments in flying.', 'They looked younger than I knew them to be.', 'Radon is known to be harmful to humans in large quantities.', 'It is not known whether the bomb was originally intended for the capital itself.', "It's always been known that key figures in the government do very well for themselves."]
bis_def_longman: to have information about something
exps_longman: ['Who knows the answer?', 'There are instructions telling you everything you need to know.', 'Didn’t you know that?', 'Do you know what time it is?', 'I don’t know where to go.', 'I need to know more about the job before I decide whether to apply for it.', 'Little is known about the author’s childhood.', 'I know all about David and what he’s been up to!', 'I wonder if he knew of the plan?', 'Do you know of any good restaurants in the area?', 'You know nothing of this business.', 'We know that greenhouse gases can affect the climate.', 'Let me know what time you’re planning to arrive.', 'I thought you’d want to know immediately.', 'If you must know, I was with James last night .', 'He slipped out of the house without his parents knowing .', 'How did he know our names?', '‘I’m divorced, as you know, ’ she said briefly.', 'Smoking is known to increase a person’s risk of developing lung cancer.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have information in your mind as a result of experience or because you have learned or been told it
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Do you know his address?', 'The cause of the fire is not yet known.', 'All I know is that she used to work in a bank (= I have no other information about her).', 'I know (that) people’s handwriting changes as they get older.', 'It is widely known that CFCs can damage the ozone layer.', 'I knew where he was hiding.', "I didn't know what he was talking about.", "‘You've got a flat tyre.’ ‘I know.’", "‘What's the answer?’ ‘I don't know.’", "‘There's no one in.’ ‘How do you know?’", "You know about Amanda's baby, don't you?", "I don't know about you, but I'm ready for something to eat.", 'I know of at least two people who did the same thing.', '‘Is anyone else coming?’ ‘Not that I know of.’', '‘Isn’t that his car?’ ‘I wouldn’t know./How should I know?’ (= I don’t know and I am not the person you should ask.)', "‘What are you two whispering about?’ ‘You don't want to know’ (= because you would be shocked or wouldn't approve).", 'Does he know to come here (= that he should come here) first?', 'We know her to be honest.', 'Two women are known to have died.']

sentence: But they might have to be supplemented by mercenaries from Flanders and the Low Countries , where the rapidly expanding population forced large numbers of young men into military careers .
gloss: Add an extra element or amount to.
eg_sent: I looked for a part-time job to supplement my income
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; If you supplement something, you add something to it in order to improve it. ;
exps_collins: ['...people doing extra jobs outside their regular jobs to supplement their incomes.', 'I suggest supplementing your diet with vitamins E and A.']
bis_def_longman: to add something, especially to what you earn or eat, in order to increase it to an acceptable level
exps_longman: ['Kia supplements her regular salary by tutoring in the evenings.', 'The acquisition will supplement their business strategy to produce higher-margin products.', 'As the number of farmers falls, many are seeking new outlets to supplement their incomes.', 'The staff handbooks will be supplemented with a series of workshops.', 'Thewelfare supplement is payable to employees who retire between Nov. 1 and Dec. 31.', 'The informal discussion groups are a good supplement to the overall training program.', 'a 16-page advertising supplement', 'The actual amount of commission is only disclosed in a supplement to the firm’s prospectus.', 'There is a single room supplement of £10 per night.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to add something to something in order to improve it or make it more complete
exps_oxford_advanced: ['a diet supplemented with vitamin pills', 'He supplements his income by giving private lessons.']

sentence: However , this fails to acknowledge a fundamental axiom of social work practice ; namely that language not only reflects but also shapes social reality .
gloss: Give a particular shape or form to.
eg_sent: most caves are shaped by the flow of water through limestone
bis_def_collins: VERB  …;… Someone or something that shapes a situation or an activity has a very great influence on the way it develops. …;…
exps_collins: ['Christian Democratic leaders are meeting to discuss their role in shaping the future of Europe.', 'Like it or not, our families shape our lives and make us what we are.']
bis_def_longman: to influence something such as a belief, opinion etc and make it develop in a particular way
exps_longman: ['People’s political beliefs are shaped by what they see in the papers.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to make something into a particular shape
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Shape the dough into a ball.', 'This tool is used for shaping wood.']

sentence: Although many deaths arise from natural causes , and many others from illnesses and diseases , each year sees a large number of deaths caused by accidents , and also a number caused by acts or omissions which amount to some form of homicide in English law .
gloss: (of a problem, opportunity, or situation) emerge; become apparent.
eg_sent: new difficulties had arisen
bis_def_collins: If a situation or problem arises, it begins to exist or people start to become aware of it.
exps_collins: ['...if a problem arises later in the pregnancy.', 'The birds also attack crops when the opportunity arises.']
bis_def_longman: if a problem or difficult situation arises, it begins to happen
exps_longman: ['A crisis has arisen in the Foreign Office.', 'More problems like those at the nuclear power plant are certain to arise.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to happen; to start to exist
exps_oxford_advanced: ['A new crisis has arisen.', 'We keep them informed of any changes as they arise.', 'Children should be disciplined when the need arises (= when it is necessary).', 'A storm arose during the night.']

sentence: Second , the worker had an alternative peer group of under-fives workers who were key figures in controlling access to all other under-fives facilities .
gloss: Look with difficulty or concentration at someone or something.
eg_sent: Faye peered at her with suspicion
bis_def_collins: If you peer at something, you look at it very hard, usually because it is difficult to see clearly.
exps_collins: ['I had been peering at a computer print-out that made no sense at all.', "He watched the Customs official peer into the driver's window."]
bis_def_longman: to look very carefully at something, especially because you are having difficulty seeing it
exps_longman: ['He was peering through the wet windscreen at the cars ahead.', 'Philippa peered into the darkness.', 'He believes the company is undervalued relative to its peers.', 'Staff members are trained by their peers.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to look closely or carefully at something, especially when you cannot see it clearly
exps_oxford_advanced: ['We peered into the shadows.', 'He went to the window and peered out.', 'She kept peering over her shoulder.', 'He peered closely at the photograph.']

sentence: corner there
gloss: Force (a person or animal) into a place or situation from which it is hard to escape.
eg_sent: the man was eventually cornered by police dogs
bis_def_collins: VERB  … If you corner a person or animal, you force them into a place they cannot escape from. …
exps_collins: ['A police motorcycle chased his car twelve miles, and cornered him near Rome.', 'He was still sitting huddled like a cornered animal.']
bis_def_longman: to force a person or animal into a position from which they cannot easily escape
exps_longman: ['Once the dog was cornered, he began to growl.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to get a person or an animal into a place or situation from which they cannot escape
exps_oxford_advanced: ['The man was finally cornered by police in a garage.', 'If cornered, the snake will defend itself.']

sentence: Latest corporate unbundler reveals laid-back approach : Roland Franklin , who is leading a 697m pound break-up bid for DRG , talks to Frank Kane
gloss: Make (previously unknown or secret information) known to others.
eg_sent: Brenda was forced to reveal Robbie's whereabouts
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; To reveal something means to make people aware of it. ;; [Also be V-ed as n]
exps_collins: ['She has refused to reveal the whereabouts of her daughter.', 'A survey of the British diet has revealed that a growing number of people are overweight.', 'After the fire, it was revealed that North Carolina officials had never inspected the factory.', 'No test will reveal how much of the drug was taken.']
bis_def_longman: to make known something that was previously secret or unknown
exps_longman: ['He may be prosecuted for revealing secrets about the security agency.', 'a test that can reveal a teacher’s hidden skills', 'He revealed that he had been in prison twice before.', 'The violinist revealed himself as a talented interpreter of classical music.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to make something known to somebody
exps_oxford_advanced: ['to reveal a secret', 'Details of the murder were revealed by the local paper.', 'The doctors did not reveal the truth to him.', 'Salted peanuts were recently revealed as the nation’s favourite snack.', 'Her expression revealed nothing.', 'The report reveals (that) the company made a loss of £20 million last year.', 'It was revealed that important evidence had been suppressed.', 'Officers could not reveal how he died.', "Salted peanuts were recently revealed to be the nation's favourite snack."]

sentence: There are important differences between the chapters in this part both in the nature of the demands that they make on geographic information and also in the relative importance that is attached to geographic criteria as against other issues by planners and decision-makers in these fields .
gloss: Form (something) by putting parts together or combining substances; create.
eg_sent: my grandmother made a dress for me
bis_def_collins: VERB  ) You can use make with a wide range of nouns to indicate that someone performs an action or says something. For example, if you make a suggestion, you suggest something. )
exps_collins: ["I'd just like to make a comment.", 'I made a few phone calls.', "I think you're making a serious mistake.", 'The Pope said the world had made some progress towards peace in 1991.', 'Science and technology have made major changes to the way we live.', 'She had made us an offer too good to refuse.']
bis_def_longman: to produce something, for example by putting the different parts of it together
exps_longman: ['I’m going to show you how to make a box for your tools.', 'A family of mice had made their nest in the roof.', 'She made her own wedding dress.', 'The company has been making quality furniture for over 200 years.', 'They met while they were making a film.', 'He made her a toy horse, using just some straw and bamboo twigs.', 'Paper is made from wood.', 'a shirt made of silk', 'She’s very good at making things from old scraps of material.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to create or prepare something by combining materials or putting parts together
exps_oxford_advanced: ['to make a table/dress/cake', 'to make bread/cement/paper', 'She makes her own clothes.', 'made in France (= on a label)', "What's your shirt made of?", 'Wine is made from grapes.', 'The grapes are made into wine.', 'She made coffee for us all.', 'She made us all coffee.']

sentence: The findings of the analysis are summarized in two sets of research questions for all applications fields .
gloss: Give a brief statement of the main points of (something)
eg_sent: these results can be summarized in the following table
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; If you summarize something, you give a summary of it. ;; [Also VERB with quote]
exps_collins: ['Table 3.1 summarizes the information given above.', 'Basically, the article can be summarized in three sentences.', 'To summarise, this is a clever approach to a common problem.']
bis_def_longman: to make a short statement giving only the main information and not the details of a plan, event, report etc
exps_longman: ['The authors summarize their views in the introduction.', 'To summarize, in most cases the schools were achieving the standards set.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to give a summary of something (= a statement of the main points)
exps_oxford_advanced: ['The results of the research are summarized at the end of the chapter.']

sentence: The environmental systems are effectively regarded as machines whose workings can all be discovered , described in differential equation form and whose future activities can thus be predicted in detail if their initial states are known .
gloss: Consider or think of in a specified way.
eg_sent: she regarded London as her base
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;… If you regard someone or something as being a particular thing or as having a particular quality, you believe that they are that thing or have that quality. ;…
exps_collins: ['He was regarded as the most successful Chancellor of modern times.', 'I regard creativity both as a gift and as a skill.']

sentence: like we 've got the , quite , similar lot
gloss: Come to have (something); receive.
eg_sent: I got a letter from him the other day
bis_def_collins: You use get with adjectives to mean 'become'. For example, if someone gets cold, they become cold, and if they get angry, they become angry.
exps_collins: ['The boys were getting bored.', "There's no point in getting upset.", 'From here on, it can only get better.']
bis_def_longman: to receive something that someone gives you or sends you
exps_longman: ['She got loads of presents.', 'What did you get for Christmas?', 'We get a lot of junk mail.', 'We got a letter from Pam this morning.', 'I got it off my Dad.', 'I got a few games free when I bought my computer.']

sentence: the rain came down and the floods came up and the house on the rocks slid down , but the foolish man built his house upon the sand , the foolish man built his house upon the sand , the foolish man built his house upon the sand and the rain came tumbling down

eg_sent: the ironworks were built in 1736

exps_longman: ['The purpose is to build new houses for local people.', 'The road took many years to build.', 'They needed $3 million to build the bridge.', 'It is the female birds that build the nests.', 'Developers want to build on the site of the old gasworks.', 'a row of recently built houses', 'He’s going to build the children a doll’s house.']

sentence: Mr Justice Hutchison said the 1936 Act primarily envisages a system where the local authority has a power and a duty to try to secure that premises are not in a state which constitutes a statutory nuisance .

sentence: It is as if it is walking through a minefield .
gloss: Move at a regular pace by lifting and setting down each foot in turn, never having both feet off the ground at once.

bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; When you walk, you move forward by putting one foot in front of the other in a regular way. ;;

exps_longman: ['‘How did you get here?’ ‘We walked.’', 'Doctors said he’d never walk again.', 'Carrie walked into the room and sat down in her chair.', 'He loved walking in the hills.', 'We must have walked ten miles today.', 'I walked all the way to San Rafael.', 'There are plenty of bars and restaurants within walking distance of the hotel.']

sentence: D maintained throughout that he had not intended to kill , but there was evidence from which the jury could infer and did infer that he intended to cause grievous bodily harm .
gloss: Have (a course of action) as one's purpose or intention; plan.
eg_sent: the company intends to cut 400 jobs
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; If you intend to do something, you have decided or planned to do it. ;;
exps_collins: ['She intends to do A levels and go to university.', "I didn't intend coming to Germany to work.", 'We had always intended that the new series would be live.']
bis_def_longman: to have something in your mind as a plan or purpose
exps_longman: ['I intend to spend the night there.', 'I didn’t intend her to see the painting until it was finished.', 'I never intended things to turn out the way they did.', 'It is intended that these meetings will become a regular event.', 'We intend looking at the situation again.', 'I fully intend to return home next year.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have a plan, result or purpose in your mind when you do something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['We finished later than we had intended.', 'I fully intended (= definitely intended) to pay for the damage.', 'The writer clearly intends his readers to identify with the main character.', "I don't intend staying long.", 'The company intends a slow-down in expansion.', 'He intended her no harm (= it was not his plan to harm her).', 'It is intended that production will start next month.', 'We intend that production will start next month.']

sentence: Do n't want to rouse any suspicions .
gloss: Have a desire to possess or do (something); wish for.
eg_sent: I want an apple
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont, no passive] ; If you want something, you feel a desire or a need for it. ;
exps_collins: ['I want a drink.', 'Ian knows exactly what he wants in life.', 'People wanted to know who this talented designer was.', 'They began to want their father to be the same as other daddies.', "They didn't want people staring at them as they sat on the lawn, so they put up high walls.", 'He wanted his power recognised.', 'I want my car this colour.', 'And remember, we want him alive.', "Note that want and wish have similar meanings, but are used differently. If you want something, you feel a need for it or a desire to have it. You can say that you want to do something, that you want someone to do something, or that you want something to happen. If you use wish with a 'to' infinitive, this has the same meaning as want but is more formal. I want to get out of here... She wished to consult him about her future."]
bis_def_longman: to have a desire for something
exps_longman: ['I really want a drink.', 'What do you want for your birthday?', 'She’d always wanted to go to Thailand.', 'I don’t want Linda to  hear about this.', 'He didn’t want the holiday to end.', 'You can order whatever you want.', 'This shampoo is mild enough to use every day if you want.', 'If she doesn’t get what she wants, she’s not happy.', 'He wanted that job so badly he was willing to kill for it.', 'They desperately wanted a son.', 'What I want to know is when we’re going to get paid.', 'All I want is the chance to prove myself.', 'Oh thank you, it’s just what I’ve always wanted.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have a desire or a wish for something

sentence: Much environmental prediction is predicated upon a logical positivist or Newtonian deterministic basis .
gloss: State, affirm, or assert (something) about the subject of a sentence or an argument of a proposition.
eg_sent: a word which predicates something about its subject
bis_def_collins: VERB  [usually passive] … If you say that one situation is predicated on another, you mean that the first situation can be true or real only if the second one is true or real. … [formal]

bis_def_longman: if an action or event is predicated on a belief or situation, it is based on it or depends on it

bis_def_oxford_advanced: to base something on a particular belief, idea or principle

sentence: It was , he felt , just too difficult to be at home at all , with Claudia in a permanently bitchy mood and both his teenage children taking their cue from her and behaving intolerably .
gloss: Be aware of (a person or object) through touching or being touched.

sentence: For a song , too , because he had not been able to bear the thought of going back , meeting a valuer , walking about the house , picking things off shelves and out of cupboards .
gloss: Move at a regular pace by lifting and setting down each foot in turn, never having both feet off the ground at once.

exps_longman: ['‘How did you get here?’ ‘We walked.’', 'Doctors said he’d never walk again.', 'Carrie walked into the room and sat down in her chair.', 'He loved walking in the hills.', 'We must have walked ten miles today.', 'I walked all the way to San Rafael.', 'There are plenty of bars and restaurants within walking distance of the hotel.']

sentence: Yet , even if all of this causes great uncertainty among scientists , it is still a reasonable prediction that a decade ahead will see both environmental monitoring and prediction treated as an everyday need and activity in major organizations .
gloss: Perceive with the eyes; discern visually.
eg_sent: in the distance she could see the blue sea
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont] ; When you see something, you notice it using your eyes. ;
exps_collins: ["You can't see colours at night.", 'I saw a man making his way towards me.', 'She can see, hear, touch, smell, and taste.', 'As he neared the farm, he saw that a police car was parked outside it.', 'Did you see what happened?', 'You use see to talk about things that you are aware of because a visual impression reaches your eyes. You often use can in this case. I can see the fax here on the desk. If you want to say that someone is paying attention to something they can see, you say that they are looking at it or watching it. In general, you look at something that is not moving, while you watch something that is moving or changing. I asked him to look at the picture above his bed... He watched Blake run down the stairs.']
bis_def_longman: to notice or examine someone or something, using your eyes
exps_longman: ['He crouched down so he couldn’t be seen.', 'Can I see your ticket, please?', 'You can see the Houses of Parliament from here.', 'Can you see where the marks are on the wall?', 'The suspect was seen entering the building.', 'As you can see, the house needs some work doing on it.', 'Have you seen Chris ?', 'The accommodation was so awful it had to be seen to be believed.']

sentence: Ruth 's fingers trembled as she obeyed him .

sentence: He said this summer that as he gradually wound down his involvement in sport , Henley would be the last thing he would give up .
