sentence: This effectively restricted their use to the wealthy and to those whose claim to assistance under the ban was incontrovertible .
gloss: Put a limit on; keep under control.
eg_sent: some roads may have to be closed at peak times to restrict the number of visitors
bis_def_collins: If you restrict something, you put a limit on it in order to reduce it or prevent it becoming too great.
exps_collins: ['There is talk of raising the admission requirements to restrict the number of students on campus.', 'The French, I believe, restrict Japanese imports to a maximum of 3 per cent of their market.']
bis_def_longman: to limit or control the size, amount, or range of something
exps_longman: ['The new law restricts the sale of hand guns.', 'You may need to restrict access to certain files .', 'The agreement will restrict competition.', 'In future we will restrict class sizes to 20 students.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to limit the size, amount or range of something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Speed is restricted to 30 mph in towns.', 'We restrict the number of students per class to 10.', 'Fog severely restricted visibility.', 'Having small children tends to restrict your freedom.']

sentence: Should n't you wait until Adam gets back ?
gloss: Come to have (something); receive.
eg_sent: I got a letter from him the other day
bis_def_collins: You use get with adjectives to mean 'become'. For example, if someone gets cold, they become cold, and if they get angry, they become angry.
exps_collins: ['The boys were getting bored.', "There's no point in getting upset.", 'From here on, it can only get better.']
bis_def_longman: to receive something that someone gives you or sends you
exps_longman: ['She got loads of presents.', 'What did you get for Christmas?', 'We get a lot of junk mail.', 'We got a letter from Pam this morning.', 'I got it off my Dad.', 'I got a few games free when I bought my computer.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to receive something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['I got a letter from Dave this morning.', 'What (= What presents) did you get for your birthday?', 'He gets (= earns) about $40\u2009000 a year.', 'This room gets very little sunshine.', 'I got a shock when I saw the bill.', 'I get the impression that he is bored with his job.']

sentence: He had virtually no bite , as he had once overheard Adam say to Bridget , and heard it with helpless chagrin .
gloss: Perceive with the ear the sound made by (someone or something)
eg_sent: behind her she could hear men's voices
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; When you hear a sound, you become aware of it through your ears. ;
exps_collins: ['She heard no further sounds.', 'The trumpet can be heard all over their house.', "They heard the protesters shout:'No more fascism!'.", 'And then we heard the bells ringing out.', "I'm not hearing properly."]
bis_def_longman: to know that a sound is being made, using your ears
exps_longman: ['Did anyone see or hear anything last night?', 'Jenny could hear them arguing outside.', 'She heard Tom go upstairs.', 'I couldn’t hear what they were saying most of the time.', 'She didn’t want to be heard to criticize him.', 'Old Zeke doesn’t hear too well anymore.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to be aware of sounds with your ears
exps_oxford_advanced: ["I can't hear very well.", 'She heard footsteps behind her.', 'I couldn’t hear anything.', 'He could hear a dog barking.', 'Did you hear him go out?', 'I heard a car drive off.', "Didn't you hear what I said?", 'She has been heard to make threats to her former lover.']

sentence: Twenty I mean last week there was a hundred sixty in and that was actually up on the previous couple of weeks , just
gloss: Intend to convey or refer to (a particular thing); signify.
eg_sent: I don't know what you mean
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont] ;…;… If you want to know what a word, code, signal, or gesture means, you want to know what it refers to or what its message is. ;…;…
exps_collins: ["In modern Welsh, 'glas' means 'blue'.", "What does 'evidence' mean?.", 'The red signal means you can shoot.']
bis_def_longman: to have or represent a particular meaning
exps_longman: ['What does ‘patronizing’ mean?', 'The red light means ‘Stop’.', 'The report fails to define what is meant by the term ‘key issues’.', 'This light means you’re running low on fuel.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have something as a meaning
exps_oxford_advanced: ['What does this sentence mean?', 'What is meant by ‘batch processing’?', 'Does the name ‘Jos Vos’ mean anything to you (= do you know who he is)?', 'The flashing light means (that) you must stop.']

sentence: Carefully designed case-control studies are therefore required to measure the separate effect of radon exposure after controlling for smoking behaviour and other risk factors .
gloss: Need for a particular purpose.
eg_sent: three patients required operations
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; If you require something or if something is required, you need it or it is necessary. ; [formal]
exps_collins: ['If you require further information, you should consult the registrar.', "This isn't the kind of crisis that requires us to drop everything else.", 'Some of the materials required for this technique may be difficult to obtain.']
bis_def_longman: to need something
exps_longman: ['Campbell’s broken leg will probably require surgery.', 'What’s required is a complete reorganization of the system.', 'Most houseplants require regular watering.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to need something; to depend on somebody/something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['These pets require a lot of care and attention.', 'Deciphering the code requires an expert.', 'This condition requires urgent treatment.', 'Do you require anything else? (= in a shop/store, for example)', 'True marriage requires us to show trust and loyalty.', 'The situation required that he be present.', 'The situation required that he should be present.', 'Lentils do not require soaking before cooking.']

sentence: Somebody 's got to pay for it .
gloss: Give (someone) money that is due for work done, goods received, or a debt incurred.
eg_sent: the traveller paid a guide to show him across
bis_def_collins: When you pay an amount of money to someone, you give it to them because you are buying something from them or because you owe it to them. When you pay something such as a bill or a debt, you pay the amount that you owe.
exps_collins: ['Accommodation is free — all you pay for is breakfast and dinner.', 'We paid £35 for each ticket.', 'The wealthier may have to pay a little more in taxes.', 'He proposes that businesses should pay taxes to the federal government.', 'You can pay by credit card.']
bis_def_longman: to give someone money for something you buy or for a service
exps_longman: ['How would you like to pay?', 'Mum paid for my driving lessons.', 'You’d get a discount for paying cash.', 'Can I pay by credit card?', 'He didn’t even offer to pay me for the ticket.', 'Ray paid some kids to wash the car.', 'I paid him $5 to cut the grass.', 'He wanted to be paid in dollars.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to give somebody money for work, goods, services, etc.
exps_oxford_advanced: ["I'll pay for the tickets.", 'Are you paying in cash or by credit card?', 'My company pays well (= pays high salaries).', 'Her parents paid for her to go to Canada.', 'to pay cash', 'She pays £200 a week for this apartment.', 'Would you mind paying the taxi driver?', "He still hasn't paid me the money he owes me.", "I'm paid $100 a day.", "I don't pay you to sit around all day doing nothing!"]

sentence: Could we borrow , beg or invent one ?
gloss: Take and use (something belonging to someone else) with the intention of returning it.
eg_sent: he had borrowed a car from one of his colleagues
bis_def_collins: If you borrow something that belongs to someone else, you take it or use it for a period of time, usually with their permission.
exps_collins: ['Can I borrow a pen please? .', "He wouldn't let me borrow his clothes."]
bis_def_longman: to use something that belongs to someone else and that you must give back to them later
exps_longman: ['Can I borrow your pen for a minute?', 'You are allowed to borrow six books from the library at a time.', 'They borrowed heavily from the bank to start their new business.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to take and use something that belongs to somebody else, and return it to them at a later time
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Can I borrow your umbrella?', 'Members can borrow up to ten books from the library at any one time.', 'I borrowed the DVD off my brother.']

sentence: Called us all in the lounge and gave us a
gloss: Give (a baby or animal) a specified name.
eg_sent: they called their daughter Hannah
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;;…;… If you call someone or something by a particular name or title, you give them that name or title. ;;…;…
exps_collins: ['I always wanted to call the dog Mufty for some reason.', "'Doctor...' — 'Will you please call me Sarah?'.", 'Everybody called each other by their surnames.']
bis_def_longman: to telephone someone
exps_longman: ['She calls her father every couple of days.', 'I’ll call you soon.', 'What time did Tony call?', 'I think we should call a doctor.', 'I’m gonna call the cops!']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to give somebody/something a particular name; to use a particular name or title when you are talking to somebody
exps_oxford_advanced: ['They decided to call the baby Mark.', "His name's Hiroshi but everyone calls him Hiro.", 'What do they call that new fabric?', 'They called their first daughter after her grandmother.', 'We call each other by our first names here.']

sentence: I do n't see how they 're going to do it .
gloss: Perceive with the eyes; discern visually.
eg_sent: in the distance she could see the blue sea
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont] ; When you see something, you notice it using your eyes. ;
exps_collins: ["You can't see colours at night.", 'I saw a man making his way towards me.', 'She can see, hear, touch, smell, and taste.', 'As he neared the farm, he saw that a police car was parked outside it.', 'Did you see what happened?', 'You use see to talk about things that you are aware of because a visual impression reaches your eyes. You often use can in this case. I can see the fax here on the desk. If you want to say that someone is paying attention to something they can see, you say that they are looking at it or watching it. In general, you look at something that is not moving, while you watch something that is moving or changing. I asked him to look at the picture above his bed... He watched Blake run down the stairs.']
bis_def_longman: to notice or examine someone or something, using your eyes
exps_longman: ['He crouched down so he couldn’t be seen.', 'Can I see your ticket, please?', 'You can see the Houses of Parliament from here.', 'Can you see where the marks are on the wall?', 'The suspect was seen entering the building.', 'As you can see, the house needs some work doing on it.', 'Have you seen Chris ?', 'The accommodation was so awful it had to be seen to be believed.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to become aware of somebody/something by using your eyes
exps_oxford_advanced: ["She looked for him but couldn't see him in the crowd.", 'I looked out of the window but saw nothing.', 'The opera was the place to see and be seen (= by other important or fashionable people).', 'He could see (that) she had been crying.', 'Did you see what happened?', 'If you watch carefully, you’ll see how it is done.', 'I hate to see you unhappy.', 'She was seen running away from the scene of the crime.', 'I saw you put the key in your pocket.', 'He was seen to enter the building about the time the crime was committed.']

sentence: This wo n't hold anything .
gloss: Grasp, carry, or support with one's hands.
eg_sent: she was holding a brown leather suitcase
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; When you hold something, you carry or support it, using your hands or your arms. ;;
exps_collins: ['Hold the knife at an angle.', 'She is holding her journal and a pen.', 'He held the pistol in his right hand.', 'Hold the baby while I load the car.']
bis_def_longman: to have something in your hand, hands, or arms
exps_longman: ['Could you hold my bag for me?', 'He was holding a knife in one hand.', 'I held the baby in my arms.', 'They sat holding hands under a tree.', 'Max held her close and wiped away her tears.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to carry something; to have somebody/something in your hand, arms, etc.
exps_oxford_advanced: ['She was holding a large box.', 'I held the mouse by its tail.', "The girl held her father's hand tightly.", 'He was holding the baby in his arms.', 'The winning captain held the trophy in the air.', "We were holding hands (= holding each other's hands).", 'The lovers held each other close.']

sentence: Yet , the irony of the early 1980s as a deteriorating , but perennial , urban problem rapidly became the most acute aspect of the crisis of mass unemployment was that a Tory government , willy-nilly , found itself presiding over an increase in state intervention through a variety of agencies .
gloss: Be in the position of authority in a meeting or other gathering.
eg_sent: the prime minister will preside at an emergency cabinet meeting
bis_def_collins: If you preside over a meeting or an event, you are in charge.
exps_collins: ['The PM presided over a meeting of his inner Cabinet.', 'He presided at the trial of the Maguire Seven.', 'The presiding officer ruled that the motion was out of order.']
bis_def_longman: to be in charge of a formal event, organization, ceremony etc
exps_longman: ['I shall be pleased to preside at your meetings.', 'Mr Justice Waller, presiding judge for the north east']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to lead or be in charge of a meeting, ceremony, etc.
exps_oxford_advanced: ['the presiding judge', 'They asked if I would preside at the committee meeting.', "The party presided over one of the worst economic declines in the country's history (= it was in power when the decline happened)."]

sentence: Sinclair thus gave an undertaking that his papers would always remain Unionist , but Steel-Maitland doubted if such a promise had any value .
gloss: Freely transfer the possession of (something) to (someone)
eg_sent: she gave him presents and clothes
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont]  You can use give with nouns that refer to physical actions. The whole expression refers to the performing of the action. For example, She gave a smile means almost the same as 'She smiled'.
exps_collins: ['She stretched her arms out and gave a great yawn.', 'Giving a sigh, she fell to her knees at my feet.', 'He gave her a fond smile.', 'He reached for her hand and gave it a reassuring squeeze.']
bis_def_longman: to let someone have something as a present, or to provide something for someone
exps_longman: ['What did Bob give you for your birthday?', 'Researchers were given a £10,000 grant to continue their work.', 'I’ve got some old diaries that my grandmother gave me years ago.', 'a ring which was given to him by his mother', 'I didn’t steal it! Maria gave it to me!', 'Most people are willing to give to charity.', 'The situation is now desperate, so please give generously.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to hand something to somebody so that they can look at it, use it or keep it for a time
exps_oxford_advanced: ["Give the letter to your mother when you've read it.", 'She gave her ticket to the woman at the check-in desk.', 'Give your mother the letter.', 'They were all given a box to carry.']

sentence: Yes , he said , I feel the same .
gloss: Utter words so as to convey information, an opinion, a feeling or intention, or an instruction.
eg_sent: ‘Thank you,’ he said
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; When you say something, you speak words. ; [Also VERB to-infinitive]
exps_collins: ["'I'm sorry,' he said.", 'She said they were very impressed.', 'Forty-one people are said to have been seriously hurt.', 'I packed and said goodbye to Charlie.', "I hope you didn't say anything about Gretchen.", "You didn't say much when you telephoned.", 'Did he say where he was going?.', "It doesn't sound exactly orthodox, if I may say so."]
bis_def_longman: to express an idea, feeling, thought etc using words
exps_longman: ['‘Don’t cry, ’ he said softly.', 'Don’t believe anything he says.', 'A spokesman said that the company had improved its safety standards.', 'I always said I would buy a motorbike when I had enough money.', 'Did she say what happened?', 'I would like to say how much we appreciate your hard work.', '‘Why did she leave?’ ‘I don’t know – she didn’t say.’', 'What did you say to her?', 'What a silly thing to say!', 'She left without saying goodbye.', 'I’ve said I’m sorry – what more do you want?', 'Can I go, Mum? Oh, please say yes!', 'He looked as if he was going to say something.', 'I wished I had said nothing about Jordi.', 'Does anyone else have anything to say?', 'Although he didn’t say so, it was clear that he was in pain.', 'What makes you say that (=why do you think that) ? 你怎么会那么说呢？', 'Nina said to meet her at 4.30.', 'I’d like to say a few words.', '‘So what are your plans now?’ ‘I’d rather not say.’']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to speak or tell somebody something, using words
exps_oxford_advanced: ['‘Hello!’ she said.', '‘That was marvellous,’ said Daniel.', 'Be quiet, I have something to say.', "I didn't believe a word she said.", "That's a terrible thing to say.", "He knew that if he wasn't back by midnight, his parents would have something to say about it (= be angry).", 'She said nothing to me about it.', "I said to myself (= thought), ‘That can't be right!’", 'He said (that) his name was Sam.', 'It is said that she lived to be over 100.', 'She finds it hard to say what she feels.', "‘That's impossible!’ ‘So you say (= but I think you may be wrong).’", "‘Why can't I go out now?’ ‘Because I say so.’", "‘What do you want it for?’ ‘I'd rather not say.’", 'He said to meet him here.', 'He is said to have been a brilliant scholar.']

sentence: A wise man built his house upon the rock , a wise man built his house upon the rock , the wise man built his house upon the rock and the rain came tumbling down , and the rain came down and the flood came up and the rain came down and the flood came up
gloss: Fall suddenly, clumsily, or headlong.
eg_sent: she pitched forward, tumbling down the remaining stairs
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;;; If someone or something tumbles somewhere, they fall there with a rolling or bouncing movement. ;;;
exps_collins: ['A small boy tumbled off a third floor fire escape.', 'The dog had tumbled down the cliff…', 'He fell to the ground, and the gun tumbled out of his hand.']
bis_def_longman: to fall down quickly and suddenly, especially with a rolling movement
exps_longman: ['She lost her balance and tumbled backwards.', 'A few stones came tumbling down the cliff.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to fall downwards, often hitting the ground several times, but usually without serious injury; to make somebody/something fall in this way
exps_oxford_advanced: ['He slipped and tumbled down the stairs.']

sentence: Now that he was able to , he assembled what had happened and laid the facts before himself .
gloss: Put (something) down gently or carefully.
eg_sent: she laid the baby in his cot
bis_def_collins: If you lay something somewhere, you put it there in a careful, gentle, or neat way.
exps_collins: ['Lay a sheet of newspaper on the floor.', "My father's working bench was covered with a cloth and his coffin was laid there.", 'Mothers routinely lay babies on their backs to sleep.']
bis_def_longman: the past tense of lie1
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to put somebody/something in a particular position, especially when it is done gently or carefully
exps_oxford_advanced: ['She laid the baby down gently on the bed.', 'He laid a hand on my arm.', 'The horse laid back its ears.', 'Relatives laid wreaths on the grave.', 'The cloth should be laid flat.']

sentence: There are other things he has , on his own admission , not fully investigated , like the value of the DRG properties , or which part of the DRG business he would keep after the break up .
gloss: Carry out a systematic or formal inquiry to discover and examine the facts of (an incident, allegation, etc.) so as to establish the truth.
eg_sent: police are investigating a claim that the man was beaten unconscious by a gang
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; If someone, especially an official, investigates an event, situation, or claim, they try to find out what happened or what is the truth. ; [Also VERB]
exps_collins: ['Gas officials are investigating the cause of an explosion which badly damaged a house in Hampshire.', 'The two officers were being investigated by the director of public prosecutions.', 'Police are still investigating how the accident happened.']
bis_def_longman: to try to find out the truth about something such as a crime, accident, or scientific problem
exps_longman: ['The state police are investigating the incident.', 'The study investigates the impact of violent TV programming on children.', 'I heard a noise and went downstairs to investigate.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to carefully examine the facts of a situation, an event, a crime, etc. to find out the truth about it or how it happened
exps_oxford_advanced: ['The FBI has been called in to investigate.', "‘What was that noise?’ ‘I'll go and investigate.’", 'Police are investigating possible links between the murders.', 'Police are investigating what happened.']

sentence: I know they do .
gloss: Be aware of through observation, inquiry, or information.
eg_sent: most people know that CFCs can damage the ozone layer
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont]  If you know a fact, a piece of information, or an answer, you have it correctly in your mind.
exps_collins: ["I don't know the name of the place.", 'I know that you led a rifle platoon during the Second World War.', "'People like doing things for nothing.' — 'I know they do.'.", "I don't know what happened to her husband.", "'How did he meet your mother?' — 'I don't know.'.", 'We all know about his early experiments in flying.', 'They looked younger than I knew them to be.', 'Radon is known to be harmful to humans in large quantities.', 'It is not known whether the bomb was originally intended for the capital itself.', "It's always been known that key figures in the government do very well for themselves."]
bis_def_longman: to have information about something
exps_longman: ['Who knows the answer?', 'There are instructions telling you everything you need to know.', 'Didn’t you know that?', 'Do you know what time it is?', 'I don’t know where to go.', 'I need to know more about the job before I decide whether to apply for it.', 'Little is known about the author’s childhood.', 'I know all about David and what he’s been up to!', 'I wonder if he knew of the plan?', 'Do you know of any good restaurants in the area?', 'You know nothing of this business.', 'We know that greenhouse gases can affect the climate.', 'Let me know what time you’re planning to arrive.', 'I thought you’d want to know immediately.', 'If you must know, I was with James last night .', 'He slipped out of the house without his parents knowing .', 'How did he know our names?', '‘I’m divorced, as you know, ’ she said briefly.', 'Smoking is known to increase a person’s risk of developing lung cancer.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have information in your mind as a result of experience or because you have learned or been told it
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Do you know his address?', 'The cause of the fire is not yet known.', 'All I know is that she used to work in a bank (= I have no other information about her).', 'I know (that) people’s handwriting changes as they get older.', 'It is widely known that CFCs can damage the ozone layer.', 'I knew where he was hiding.', "I didn't know what he was talking about.", "‘You've got a flat tyre.’ ‘I know.’", "‘What's the answer?’ ‘I don't know.’", "‘There's no one in.’ ‘How do you know?’", "You know about Amanda's baby, don't you?", "I don't know about you, but I'm ready for something to eat.", 'I know of at least two people who did the same thing.', '‘Is anyone else coming?’ ‘Not that I know of.’', '‘Isn’t that his car?’ ‘I wouldn’t know./How should I know?’ (= I don’t know and I am not the person you should ask.)', "‘What are you two whispering about?’ ‘You don't want to know’ (= because you would be shocked or wouldn't approve).", 'Does he know to come here (= that he should come here) first?', 'We know her to be honest.', 'Two women are known to have died.']

exps_collins: ['I always wanted to call the dog Mufty for some reason.', "'Doctor...' — 'Will you please call me Sarah?'.", 'Everybody called each other by their surnames.']
bis_def_longman: to telephone someone
exps_longman: ['She calls her father every couple of days.', 'I’ll call you soon.', 'What time did Tony call?', 'I think we should call a doctor.', 'I’m gonna call the cops!']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to give somebody/something a particular name; to use a particular name or title when you are talking to somebody
exps_oxford_advanced: ['They decided to call the baby Mark.', "His name's Hiroshi but everyone calls him Hiro.", 'What do they call that new fabric?', 'They called their first daughter after her grandmother.', 'We call each other by our first names here.']

sentence: It does not imply political supremacy , and does not suggest that the Pope should administer the affairs of the Church of England , he said .
gloss: Indicate the truth or existence of (something) by suggestion rather than explicit reference.
eg_sent: salesmen who use jargon to imply superior knowledge
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; If you imply that something is the case, you say something which indicates that it is the case in an indirect way. ; [Also VERB n]
exps_collins: ["'Are you implying that I have something to do with those attacks?' she asked coldly.", 'She felt undermined by the implied criticism.']
bis_def_longman: to suggest that something is true, without saying this directly
exps_longman: ['Cleo blushed. She had not meant to imply that he was lying.', 'an implied threat']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to suggest that something is true or that you feel or think something, without saying so directly
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Are you implying (that) I am wrong?', 'I disliked the implied criticism in his voice.', 'His silence seemed to imply agreement.', 'It was implied that we were at fault.']

sentence: She kept looking over there .
gloss: Have or retain possession of.
eg_sent: return one copy to me, keeping the other for your files
bis_def_collins: If someone keeps or is kept in a particular state, they remain in it.
exps_collins: ['The noise kept him awake.', 'Reggie was being kept busy behind the bar.', 'To keep warm they burnt wood in a rusty oil barrel.', 'For several years I kept in touch with her.']
bis_def_longman: to stay in a particular state, condition, or position, or to make someone or something do this
exps_longman: ['We huddled around the fire to keep warm.', 'I was struggling to keep awake.', 'some toys to keep the kids amused', 'You won’t be able to keep it secret forever.', 'Peter cycles to work to keep fit.', 'Don’t keep us in suspense any longer!', 'The police put up barriers to keep the crowds back.', 'If I were you, I’d keep away from that area at night.', 'The little boy kept close to his mother.', 'You keep out of this, Mother . It’s no concern of yours.', 'How can I cut your hair if you won’t keep still!', 'Jane kept the engine running.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to stay in a particular condition or position; to make somebody/something do this
exps_oxford_advanced: ['We huddled together to keep warm.', 'The notice said ‘Keep off (= Do not walk on) the grass’.', 'Keep left along the wall.', 'She kept the children amused for hours.', 'He kept his coat on.', "Don't keep us in suspense—what happened next?", 'She had trouble keeping her balance.', "I'm very sorry to keep you waiting."]

sentence: Never mind I 'll come
gloss: Move or travel towards or into a place thought of as near or familiar to the speaker.
eg_sent: Jessica came into the kitchen
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; When a person or thing comes to a particular place, especially to a place where you are, they move there. ;
exps_collins: ['Two police officers came into the hall.', 'Come here, Tom.', "You'll have to come with us.", 'We want you to come to lunch.', 'I came over from Ireland to start a new life after my divorce.', 'We heard the train coming.', 'Can I come too?.', 'The impact blew out some of the windows and the sea came rushing in.']
bis_def_longman: to move towards you or arrive at the place where you are
exps_longman: ['Let me know when they come.', 'Can you come here for a minute?', 'What time will you be coming home?', 'There was a knock on the door and a young woman came into the room.', 'I could see a figure coming towards me.', 'As they came down the track, the car skidded.', 'I’ve come to see Philip.', 'I’ll come and help you move the rest of the boxes.', 'Jess came flying round the corner and banged straight into me.', 'What day are your folks coming to dinner?', 'Ah, here comes the bus at last!']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to move to or towards a person or place
exps_oxford_advanced: ['He came into the room and shut the door.', 'She comes to work by bus.', 'My son is coming home soon.', 'Come here!', 'Come and see us soon!', 'Here comes Jo! (= Jo is coming)', "There's a storm coming.", "They're coming to stay for a week."]

sentence: She wants to take over
gloss: Have a desire to possess or do (something); wish for.
eg_sent: I want an apple
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont, no passive] ; If you want something, you feel a desire or a need for it. ;
exps_collins: ['I want a drink.', 'Ian knows exactly what he wants in life.', 'People wanted to know who this talented designer was.', 'They began to want their father to be the same as other daddies.', "They didn't want people staring at them as they sat on the lawn, so they put up high walls.", 'He wanted his power recognised.', 'I want my car this colour.', 'And remember, we want him alive.', "Note that want and wish have similar meanings, but are used differently. If you want something, you feel a need for it or a desire to have it. You can say that you want to do something, that you want someone to do something, or that you want something to happen. If you use wish with a 'to' infinitive, this has the same meaning as want but is more formal. I want to get out of here... She wished to consult him about her future."]
bis_def_longman: to have a desire for something
exps_longman: ['I really want a drink.', 'What do you want for your birthday?', 'She’d always wanted to go to Thailand.', 'I don’t want Linda to  hear about this.', 'He didn’t want the holiday to end.', 'You can order whatever you want.', 'This shampoo is mild enough to use every day if you want.', 'If she doesn’t get what she wants, she’s not happy.', 'He wanted that job so badly he was willing to kill for it.', 'They desperately wanted a son.', 'What I want to know is when we’re going to get paid.', 'All I want is the chance to prove myself.', 'Oh thank you, it’s just what I’ve always wanted.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have a desire or a wish for something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Do you want some more tea?', "She's always wanted a large family.", 'All I want is the truth.', "Thanks for the present—it's just what I wanted.", 'I can do whatever I want.', 'The last thing I wanted was to upset you.', 'The party wants her as leader.', 'What do you want to do tomorrow?', "‘It's time you did your homework.’ ‘I don't want to!’", 'There are two points which I wanted to make.', 'I just wanted to know if everything was all right.', 'You can come too, if you want.', 'Do you want me to help?', "We didn't want this to happen.", 'I want it (to be) done as quickly as possible.', "I don't want you coming home so late.", 'Do you want your coffee black or white?']

sentence: At the NWRRL work is under way ( Flowerdew and Green 1989 ) to solve such problems using the EM algorithm and the statistical modelling package GLIM , which has been interfaced with ARC/INFO .
gloss: Take, hold, or deploy (something) as a means of accomplishing or achieving something; employ.
eg_sent: she used her key to open the front door
bis_def_collins: If you use something, you do something with it in order to do a job or to achieve a particular result or effect.  [written]
exps_collins: ['Trim off the excess pastry using a sharp knife.', 'He had simply used a little imagination.', 'Officials used loud hailers to call for calm.', "The show uses Zondo's trial and execution as its framework."]
bis_def_longman: if you use a particular tool, method, service, ability etc, you do something with that tool, by means of that method etc, for a particular purpose
exps_longman: ['Can I use your phone?', 'I’ll show you which room you can use.', 'I always use the same shampoo.', 'She booked the flight using a false name.', 'Drop-down menus make the program very easy to use.', 'They were using animals for scientific experiments.', 'Bob uses the van for picking up groceries.', 'My parents use the house as a holiday home.', 'Most people now use their cars to go shopping.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to do something with a machine, a method, an object, etc. for a particular purpose
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Can I use your phone?', 'Have you ever used this software before?', 'How often do you use (= travel by) the bus?', 'They were able to achieve a settlement without using military force.', 'The applicator makes the glue easy to use.', 'The oven looked as if it had never been used.', 'I have some information you may be able to use (= to get an advantage from).', 'We used a carrot for the snowman’s nose.', 'The blue files are used for storing old invoices.', 'Police used tear gas to disperse the crowds.', 'The building is currently being used as a warehouse.', "You can't keep using your bad back as an excuse."]

sentence: A considerable amount of research has been undertaken to apply GIS methods to evacuation scenarios around hazardous sites .

bis_def_oxford_advanced: to make yourself responsible for something and start doing it

sentence: Henning Albrechsten reckons that it takes three years for a telecottage to be able to function without subsidy .

sentence: I would n't now , but then I , I , I did n't know er round that area .
gloss: Be aware of through observation, inquiry, or information.
eg_sent: most people know that CFCs can damage the ozone layer
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont]  If you know a fact, a piece of information, or an answer, you have it correctly in your mind.
exps_collins: ["I don't know the name of the place.", 'I know that you led a rifle platoon during the Second World War.', "'People like doing things for nothing.' — 'I know they do.'.", "I don't know what happened to her husband.", "'How did he meet your mother?' — 'I don't know.'.", 'We all know about his early experiments in flying.', 'They looked younger than I knew them to be.', 'Radon is known to be harmful to humans in large quantities.', 'It is not known whether the bomb was originally intended for the capital itself.', "It's always been known that key figures in the government do very well for themselves."]
bis_def_longman: to have information about something
exps_longman: ['Who knows the answer?', 'There are instructions telling you everything you need to know.', 'Didn’t you know that?', 'Do you know what time it is?', 'I don’t know where to go.', 'I need to know more about the job before I decide whether to apply for it.', 'Little is known about the author’s childhood.', 'I know all about David and what he’s been up to!', 'I wonder if he knew of the plan?', 'Do you know of any good restaurants in the area?', 'You know nothing of this business.', 'We know that greenhouse gases can affect the climate.', 'Let me know what time you’re planning to arrive.', 'I thought you’d want to know immediately.', 'If you must know, I was with James last night .', 'He slipped out of the house without his parents knowing .', 'How did he know our names?', '‘I’m divorced, as you know, ’ she said briefly.', 'Smoking is known to increase a person’s risk of developing lung cancer.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have information in your mind as a result of experience or because you have learned or been told it
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Do you know his address?', 'The cause of the fire is not yet known.', 'All I know is that she used to work in a bank (= I have no other information about her).', 'I know (that) people’s handwriting changes as they get older.', 'It is widely known that CFCs can damage the ozone layer.', 'I knew where he was hiding.', "I didn't know what he was talking about.", "‘You've got a flat tyre.’ ‘I know.’", "‘What's the answer?’ ‘I don't know.’", "‘There's no one in.’ ‘How do you know?’", "You know about Amanda's baby, don't you?", "I don't know about you, but I'm ready for something to eat.", 'I know of at least two people who did the same thing.', '‘Is anyone else coming?’ ‘Not that I know of.’', '‘Isn’t that his car?’ ‘I wouldn’t know./How should I know?’ (= I don’t know and I am not the person you should ask.)', "‘What are you two whispering about?’ ‘You don't want to know’ (= because you would be shocked or wouldn't approve).", 'Does he know to come here (= that he should come here) first?', 'We know her to be honest.', 'Two women are known to have died.']

They seemed quite close by.', 'Everyone seems busy except us.', 'To everyone who knew them, they seemed an ideal couple.', '£50 seems a lot to pay.', 'The calming effect seemed to last for about ten minutes.', 'The government seems not to be troubled by its inconsistent policies on minority rights.', 'It was a record that seemed beyond reach.', "The proposal seems designed to break opposition to the government's economic programme.", 'It seems that the attack this morning was very carefully planned to cause few casualties.', 'It seems clear that he has no reasonable alternative.', "It seemed as if she'd been gone forever.", 'There seems to be a lot of support in Congress for this move.', 'There seems no possibility that such action can be averted.', 'This phenomenon is not as outrageous as it seems.']

sentence: When a vacancy arose within this group of social workers in 1983 it was decided to appoint someone specialising in work with under fives with special needs .

sentence: He could n't look Shiva up because he could n't remember his surname .
gloss: Direct one's gaze toward someone or something or in a specified direction.
eg_sent: people were looking at him
bis_def_collins: If you look in a particular direction, you direct your eyes in that direction, especially so that you can see what is there or see what something is like.
exps_collins: ['I looked down the hallway to room number nine.', 'She turned to look at him.', 'He looked away, apparently enraged.', "If you look, you'll see what was a lake.", 'If you want to say that someone is paying attention to something they can see, you say that they are looking at it or watching it. In general, you look at something that is not moving, while you watch something that is moving or changing. I asked him to look at the picture above his bed... He watched Blake run down the stairs. Look is never followed directly by an object. You must always use at or some other preposition. I looked towards the plane. You use see to talk about things that you are aware of because a visual impression reaches your eyes. You often use can in this case. I can see the fax here on the desk.']
bis_def_longman: to turn your eyes towards something, so that you can see it
exps_longman: ['We sneaked out while Jessie’s mom wasn’t looking.', 'If you look carefully you can see that the painting represents a human figure.', 'Gina covered her eyes, afraid to look.', '‘It’s time we left, ’ Ian said, looking at his watch.', 'The men all turned to look at her as she entered the room.', 'Dad looked up from his paper and smiled.', '‘We can’t go out in this weather, ’ said Bob, looking out of the window.']

sentence: Do n't get it .
gloss: Come to have (something); receive.
eg_sent: I got a letter from him the other day
bis_def_collins: You use get with adjectives to mean 'become'. For example, if someone gets cold, they become cold, and if they get angry, they become angry.

exps_longman: ['She got loads of presents.', 'What did you get for Christmas?', 'We get a lot of junk mail.', 'We got a letter from Pam this morning.', 'I got it off my Dad.', 'I got a few games free when I bought my computer.']

sentence: The cities of inner despair were conceived as the breeding ground for disorderly protest , and however hard the Government tried to break the causal link between the two , it was forced to take on board the need to restore order not only through the police but through promises of help for the inner cities .
gloss: Separate or cause to separate into pieces as a result of a blow, shock, or strain.

bis_def_collins: When an object breaks or when you break it, it suddenly separates into two or more pieces, often because it has been hit or dropped.

sentence: The increased scale of operations also ushered in another fashion of the 1980s new management structures .

exps_collins: ["I don't know the name of the place.", 'I know that you led a rifle platoon during the Second World War.', "'People like doing things for nothing.' — 'I know they do.'.", "I don't know what happened to her husband.", "'How did he meet your mother?' — 'I don't know.'.", 'We all know about his early experiments in flying.', 'They looked younger than I knew them to be.', 'Radon is known to be harmful to humans in large quantities.', 'It is not known whether the bomb was originally intended for the capital itself.', "It's always been known that key figures in the government do very well for themselves."]

exps_longman: ['Who knows the answer?', 'There are instructions telling you everything you need to know.', 'Didn’t you know that?', 'Do you know what time it is?', 'I don’t know where to go.', 'I need to know more about the job before I decide whether to apply for it.', 'Little is known about the author’s childhood.', 'I know all about David and what he’s been up to!', 'I wonder if he knew of the plan?', 'Do you know of any good restaurants in the area?', 'You know nothing of this business.', 'We know that greenhouse gases can affect the climate.', 'Let me know what time you’re planning to arrive.', 'I thought you’d want to know immediately.', 'If you must know, I was with James last night .', 'He slipped out of the house without his parents knowing .', 'How did he know our names?', '‘I’m divorced, as you know, ’ she said briefly.', 'Smoking is known to increase a person’s risk of developing lung cancer.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have information in your mind as a result of experience or because you have learned or been told it
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Do you know his address?', 'The cause of the fire is not yet known.', 'All I know is that she used to work in a bank (= I have no other information about her).', 'I know (that) people’s handwriting changes as they get older.', 'It is widely known that CFCs can damage the ozone layer.', 'I knew where he was hiding.', "I didn't know what he was talking about.", "‘You've got a flat tyre.’ ‘I know.’", "‘What's the answer?’ ‘I don't know.’", "‘There's no one in.’ ‘How do you know?’", "You know about Amanda's baby, don't you?", "I don't know about you, but I'm ready for something to eat.", 'I know of at least two people who did the same thing.', '‘Is anyone else coming?’ ‘Not that I know of.’', '‘Isn’t that his car?’ ‘I wouldn’t know./How should I know?’ (= I don’t know and I am not the person you should ask.)', "‘What are you two whispering about?’ ‘You don't want to know’ (= because you would be shocked or wouldn't approve).", 'Does he know to come here (= that he should come here) first?', 'We know her to be honest.', 'Two women are known to have died.']

sentence: Well she takes all these tablet things .
gloss: Lay hold of (something) with one's hands; reach for and hold.
eg_sent: Mrs Morgan took another biscuit
bis_def_collins: You can use take followed by a noun to talk about an action or event, when it would also be possible to use the verb that is related to that noun. For example, you can say 'she took a shower' instead of 'she showered'.
exps_collins: ['She was too tired to take a shower.', 'Betty took a photograph of us.', "I've never taken a holiday since starting this job.", "There's not enough people willing to take the risk.", 'Walk around the property and take a good look at it from the outside.', 'We took a long walk through the pines.']
bis_def_longman: to move or go with someone or something from one place to another
exps_longman: ['Barney took us to the airport.', 'Would you mind taking Susie home?', 'When he refused to give his name, he was taken into custody.', 'My job has taken me all over the world.', 'His wife went to Australia, taking the children with her.', 'I have to take Steve the money tonight.', 'He took me to meet his parents.']

sentence: If it comes to light that I was in that house with Adam and the others , he thought with cold clarity , if someone tells the papers , or the police and thence the papers , that I was there during the summer of 1976 , living there , it will be all up with me .

exps_longman: ['They lived in Holland for ten years.', 'He lives just across the street from me.', 'We live only a few miles from the coast.', 'A rather odd family came to live next door to us.', 'As soon as I saw the place, I knew I didn’t want to live there.', 'Does Paul still live here?', 'We’re still looking for somewhere to live.', 'They’ve finally found a place to live.', 'My grandmother came to live with us when I was ten.', 'Most seventeen-year-olds still live at home.', 'I’m quite happy living alone.', 'The house has 3,600 square feet of living space.', 'I ran away from home and lived rough for nine months.']

sentence: She was a very private woman , I suspect one of those fortunate people who find no other company more agreeable than their own .

sentence: After half a mile he decided to turn off the embankment and walk up the side of the next field and along the path at the top of it , following the horses whom he could still see in the distance .

sentence: Can we just stick to what we 're here to discuss ?

exps_collins: ['I want a drink.', 'Ian knows exactly what he wants in life.', 'People wanted to know who this talented designer was.', 'They began to want their father to be the same as other daddies.', "They didn't want people staring at them as they sat on the lawn, so they put up high walls.", 'He wanted his power recognised.', 'I want my car this colour.', 'And remember, we want him alive.', "Note that want and wish have similar meanings, but are used differently. If you want something, you feel a need for it or a desire to have it. You can say that you want to do something, that you want someone to do something, or that you want something to happen. If you use wish with a 'to' infinitive, this has the same meaning as want but is more formal. I want to get out of here... She wished to consult him about her future."]

bis_def_collins: VERB  , If you avoid something unpleasant that might happen, you take action in order to prevent it from happening. ,
exps_collins: ['The pilots had to take emergency action to avoid a disaster.', 'Women have to dress modestly, to avoid being harassed by the locals.']
bis_def_longman: to prevent something bad from happening
exps_longman: ['Road safety is taught to young children to avoid road accidents.', 'It is important to take measures to avoid the risk of fire.', 'The refugees left to avoid getting bombed.', 'Alan narrowly avoided an accident.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to prevent something bad from happening
exps_oxford_advanced: ['The accident could have been avoided.', 'They narrowly avoided defeat.', 'The name was changed to avoid confusion with another firm.', 'They built a wall to avoid soil being washed away.']

sentence: The party officers and Whips were solidly behind Chamberlain , but Law drew off some of his support among tariff reformers and , urged on by Edward Goulding and Max Aitken , he refused to withdraw unless his continued candidature would allow Long to win .
gloss: Be successful or victorious in (a contest or conflict)
eg_sent: United won four games in a row
bis_def_collins: If you win something such as a competition, battle, or argument, you defeat those people you are competing or fighting against, or you do better than everyone else involved.

bis_def_longman: to be the best or most successful in a competition, game, election etc
exps_longman: ['Who do you think will win the next election?', 'He won the Tour de France last year.', 'the young pilots who won the Battle of Britain', 'Who’s winning ?', 'I never win at cards.', 'We won by just one point.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to be the most successful in a competition, race, battle, etc.
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Which team won?', 'to win at cards/chess, etc.', 'France won by six goals to two against Denmark.', 'to win an election/a game/a war, etc.', 'She loves to win an argument.']

sentence: I only want to know who slashed that picture if you did n't .
gloss: Cut with a wide, sweeping movement, typically using a knife or sword.
eg_sent: for what felt like hours we climbed behind the trackers slashing the undergrowth ahead
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;… If you slash something, you make a long, deep cut in it. ;…
exps_collins: ['He came within two minutes of bleeding to death after slashing his wrists.']
bis_def_longman: to cut or try to cut something violently with a knife, sword etc

sentence: Such a map will enable the reader to work out for himself how to get from one location to another within the town .
gloss: Give (someone) the authority or means to do something; make it possible for.
eg_sent: the evidence would enable us to arrive at firm conclusions
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; If someone or something enables you to do a particular thing, they give you the opportunity to do it. ;
exps_collins: ['The new test should enable doctors to detect the disease early.', '...a new charter for training to enable young people to make the most of their potential.']
bis_def_longman: to make it possible for someone to do something, or for something to happen

bis_def_oxford_advanced: to make it possible for somebody to do something

sentence: She shrugged and looked thoughtful .
gloss: Direct one's gaze toward someone or something or in a specified direction.
eg_sent: people were looking at him
bis_def_collins: If you look in a particular direction, you direct your eyes in that direction, especially so that you can see what is there or see what something is like.
exps_collins: ['I looked down the hallway to room number nine.', 'She turned to look at him.', 'He looked away, apparently enraged.', "If you look, you'll see what was a lake.", 'If you want to say that someone is paying attention to something they can see, you say that they are looking at it or watching it. In general, you look at something that is not moving, while you watch something that is moving or changing. I asked him to look at the picture above his bed... He watched Blake run down the stairs. Look is never followed directly by an object. You must always use at or some other preposition. I looked towards the plane. You use see to talk about things that you are aware of because a visual impression reaches your eyes. You often use can in this case. I can see the fax here on the desk.']
bis_def_longman: to turn your eyes towards something, so that you can see it
exps_longman: ['We sneaked out while Jessie’s mom wasn’t looking.', 'If you look carefully you can see that the painting represents a human figure.', 'Gina covered her eyes, afraid to look.', '‘It’s time we left, ’ Ian said, looking at his watch.', 'The men all turned to look at her as she entered the room.', 'Dad looked up from his paper and smiled.', '‘We can’t go out in this weather, ’ said Bob, looking out of the window.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to turn your eyes in a particular direction
exps_oxford_advanced: ['If you look carefully you can just see our house from here.', 'She looked at me and smiled.', "‘Has the mail come yet?’ ‘I'll look and see.’", "Look! I'm sure that's Brad Pitt!", "Don't look now, but there's someone staring at you!"]

sentence: He was a sensible and capable boy , an eldest child , so he moved closer , trying not to breathe , and stood steadfastly looking until he was confident of what he had seen : a body , must be a girl because it was wearing a skirt , lying face down , head towards the bottom of the embankment as if she had dived off the top .
gloss: Make an attempt or effort to do something.
eg_sent: he tried to regain his breath
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; If you try to do something, you want to do it, and you take action which you hope will help you to do it. ;;
exps_collins: ['He secretly tried to block her advancement in the Party.', 'Try to make the effort to work your way through all of your tasks one at a time…', "Does it annoy you if others do things less well than you would, or don't seem to try hard enough?.", "I tried calling him when I got here but he wasn't at home.", 'No matter how bad you feel, keep trying.']
bis_def_longman: to take action in order to do something that you may not be able to do
exps_longman: ['Let’s have a rest and then we’ll try again.', 'He tried to control his voice.', 'She was trying not to cry.', 'She dabbed at her face and tried hard not to sniff.', 'I tried everything to lose weight with no success.', 'I tried my best to comfort her.', 'I tried and tried and eventually I was offered a job.', 'They didn’t get any goals, but it wasn’t for lack of trying.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to make an attempt or effort to do or get something
exps_oxford_advanced: ["I don't know if I can come but I'll try.", 'What are you trying to do?', 'I tried hard not to laugh.', 'You haven’t even tried to find it.', 'Don’t try to do it too quickly.', 'She tried her best to solve the problem.', 'Just try your hardest.']

sentence: In the early 1980s , at a time when manufacturing industry was collapsing and the outlook for the unskilled looked particularly bleak , frustration boiled over in a series of riots in London , Bristol , Birmingham , Liverpool , and elsewhere .
gloss: (with reference to a liquid) reach or cause to reach the temperature at which it bubbles and turns to vapour.
eg_sent: we asked people to boil their drinking water
bis_def_collins: When a hot liquid boils or when you boil it, bubbles appear in it and it starts to change into steam or vapour.
exps_collins: ['I stood in the kitchen, waiting for the water to boil.', 'Boil the water in the saucepan and add the sage.', '...a saucepan of boiling water.']
bis_def_longman: when a liquid boils, or when you boil it, it becomes hot enough to turn into gas
exps_longman: ['The solution boiled at 57.4°C.', 'Put the spaghetti into plenty of boiling salted water.', 'We were advised to boil the water before drinking it.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: when a liquid boils or when you boil it, it is heated to the point where it forms bubbles and turns to steam or vapour
exps_oxford_advanced: ['The water was bubbling and boiling away.', 'Boil plenty of salted water, then add the spaghetti.']

sentence: Can we not use GIS technology to construct risk mosaics ( Zeigler et al. 1983 ) , at a variety of spatial scales , akin to Hewitt and Burton 's hazardousness of a place ?
gloss: Take, hold, or deploy (something) as a means of accomplishing or achieving something; employ.
eg_sent: she used her key to open the front door
bis_def_collins: If you use something, you do something with it in order to do a job or to achieve a particular result or effect.  [written]
exps_collins: ['Trim off the excess pastry using a sharp knife.', 'He had simply used a little imagination.', 'Officials used loud hailers to call for calm.', "The show uses Zondo's trial and execution as its framework."]
bis_def_longman: if you use a particular tool, method, service, ability etc, you do something with that tool, by means of that method etc, for a particular purpose
exps_longman: ['Can I use your phone?', 'I’ll show you which room you can use.', 'I always use the same shampoo.', 'She booked the flight using a false name.', 'Drop-down menus make the program very easy to use.', 'They were using animals for scientific experiments.', 'Bob uses the van for picking up groceries.', 'My parents use the house as a holiday home.', 'Most people now use their cars to go shopping.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to do something with a machine, a method, an object, etc. for a particular purpose
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Can I use your phone?', 'Have you ever used this software before?', 'How often do you use (= travel by) the bus?', 'They were able to achieve a settlement without using military force.', 'The applicator makes the glue easy to use.', 'The oven looked as if it had never been used.', 'I have some information you may be able to use (= to get an advantage from).', 'We used a carrot for the snowman’s nose.', 'The blue files are used for storing old invoices.', 'Police used tear gas to disperse the crowds.', 'The building is currently being used as a warehouse.', "You can't keep using your bad back as an excuse."]

sentence: Originally , the Programme supplemented existing central and local government schemes designed to meet special needs in urban areas .
gloss: Have objective reality or being.
eg_sent: dossiers existed on almost everyone of prominence
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont] ; If something exists, it is present in the world as a real thing. ;

bis_def_longman: to happen or be present in a particular situation or place

bis_def_oxford_advanced: to be real; to be present in a place or situation
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Does life exist on other planets?', 'The problem only exists in your head, Jane.', 'Few of these monkeys still exist in the wild.', 'On his retirement the post will cease to exist.', 'The charity exists to support victims of crime.']

sentence: His mentor , Enrico Fermi , later to be called the father of the bomb , and Emilio Segre ( who died in California earlier this year ) .
gloss: (of a person, animal, or plant) stop living.

']

sentence: Each step should be simple and complete in itself preferably with some indication that successful completion has been achieved , for example the appearance or the change of colour of a signal light , or the noise of a motor starting or a change of pressure which indicates that there has been a change in the flow of some material .
gloss: Successfully bring about or reach (a desired objective or result) by effort, skill, or courage.
eg_sent: he achieved his ambition to become a press photographer

sentence: While telecottages should become self-financing once established , they do need initial subsidy .

eg_sent: the scheme was established in 1975

gloss: Put, lay, or stand (something) in a specified place or position.

sentence: This chapter deals with the approach of the criminal law to behaviour which causes or risks causing death .

sentence: He coughed , embarrassed and a little pompous , very much conscious of his new status as a father , while McLeish remembered that he was a scant four years older than the delinquent Tristram .
gloss: Have in or be able to bring to one's mind an awareness of (someone or something from the past)

bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; If you remember people or events from the past, you still have an idea of them in your mind and you are able to think about them. ;;
exps_collins: ["You wouldn't remember me. I was in another group.", "I certainly don't remember talking to you at all.", 'I remember her being a dominant figure.', 'I remembered that we had drunk the last of the coffee the week before.', 'I can remember where and when I bought each one.', 'I used to do that when you were a little girl, remember?']
bis_def_longman: to have a picture or idea in your mind of people, events, places etc from the past
exps_longman: ['Do you remember Rosa Davies?', 'I can’t remember her exact words.', 'I remember you two couldn’t stand each other at first!', 'I remember meeting her at a party once.', 'I remember my father bringing home a huge Christmas tree.', 'I remember it well; I’d never seen my mother so angry.', 'She clearly remembers the excitement as they boarded the train.', 'I vaguely remember reading something about it in the paper.', 'They had three children, if I remember rightly.', 'They’ve lived here for as long as I can remember.', 'No one got drunk as far as I can remember.']

sentence: If he had taken his own rule seriously , he would have found out that DRG has a very modest self-service canteen at its Bristol head office .
gloss: Lay hold of (something) with one's hands; reach for and hold.

sentence: Law conceived of the role of the leader in an exactly opposite sense from Balfour : he sought to foster unity by placing himself at the head of the discordant elements where Balfour had thrown the leadership on the side of restraint .

sentence: But I saw no other way out : I did n't know if I would ever have a chance again .
gloss: Be aware of through observation, inquiry, or information.

exps_collins: ["I don't know the name of the place.", 'I know that you led a rifle platoon during the Second World War.', "'People like doing things for nothing.' — 'I know they do.'.", "I don't know what happened to her husband.", "'How did he meet your mother?' — 'I don't know.'.", 'We all know about his early experiments in flying.', 'They looked younger than I knew them to be.', 'Radon is known to be harmful to humans in large quantities.', 'It is not known whether the bomb was originally intended for the capital itself.', "It's always been known that key figures in the government do very well for themselves."]
bis_def_longman: to have information about something
exps_longman: ['Who knows the answer?', 'There are instructions telling you everything you need to know.', 'Didn’t you know that?', 'Do you know what time it is?', 'I don’t know where to go.', 'I need to know more about the job before I decide whether to apply for it.', 'Little is known about the author’s childhood.', 'I know all about David and what he’s been up to!', 'I wonder if he knew of the plan?', 'Do you know of any good restaurants in the area?', 'You know nothing of this business.', 'We know that greenhouse gases can affect the climate.', 'Let me know what time you’re planning to arrive.', 'I thought you’d want to know immediately.', 'If you must know, I was with James last night .', 'He slipped out of the house without his parents knowing .', 'How did he know our names?', '‘I’m divorced, as you know, ’ she said briefly.', 'Smoking is known to increase a person’s risk of developing lung cancer.']

bis_def_oxford_advanced: to stay in a particular condition or position; to make somebody/something do this

sentence: Just cut the damn boat loose , I said vengefully .
gloss: Utter words so as to convey information, an opinion, a feeling or intention, or an instruction.
eg_sent: ‘Thank you,’ he said
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; When you say something, you speak words. ; [Also VERB to-infinitive]
exps_collins: ["'I'm sorry,' he said.", 'She said they were very impressed.', 'Forty-one people are said to have been seriously hurt.', 'I packed and said goodbye to Charlie.', "I hope you didn't say anything about Gretchen.", "You didn't say much when you telephoned.", 'Did he say where he was going?.', "It doesn't sound exactly orthodox, if I may say so."]

exps_longman: ['‘Don’t cry, ’ he said softly.', 'Don’t believe anything he says.', 'A spokesman said that the company had improved its safety standards.', 'I always said I would buy a motorbike when I had enough money.', 'Did she say what happened?', 'I would like to say how much we appreciate your hard work.', '‘Why did she leave?’ ‘I don’t know – she didn’t say.’', 'What did you say to her?', 'What a silly thing to say!', 'She left without saying goodbye.', 'I’ve said I’m sorry – what more do you want?', 'Can I go, Mum? Oh, please say yes!', 'He looked as if he was going to say something.', 'I wished I had said nothing about Jordi.', 'Does anyone else have anything to say?', 'Although he didn’t say so, it was clear that he was in pain.', 'What makes you say that (=why do you think that) ? 你怎么会那么说呢？', 'Nina said to meet her at 4.30.', 'I’d like to say a few words.', '‘So what are your plans now?’ ‘I’d rather not say.’']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to speak or tell somebody something, using words
exps_oxford_advanced: ['‘Hello!’ she said.', '‘That was marvellous,’ said Daniel.', 'Be quiet, I have something to say.', "I didn't believe a word she said.", "That's a terrible thing to say.", "He knew that if he wasn't back by midnight, his parents would have something to say about it (= be angry).", 'She said nothing to me about it.', "I said to myself (= thought), ‘That can't be right!’", 'He said (that) his name was Sam.', 'It is said that she lived to be over 100.', 'She finds it hard to say what she feels.', "‘That's impossible!’ ‘So you say (= but I think you may be wrong).’", "‘Why can't I go out now?’ ‘Because I say so.’", "‘What do you want it for?’ ‘I'd rather not say.’", 'He said to meet him here.', 'He is said to have been a brilliant scholar.']

sentence: She had ruffles ( not swashbuckling ) at the neck and the small velvet hat could , but did not , support a veil .
gloss: Bear all or part of the weight of; hold up.
eg_sent: the dome was supported by a hundred white columns
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; If you support someone or their ideas or aims, you agree with them, and perhaps help them because you want them to succeed. ;;
exps_collins: ['The vice president insisted that he supported the hard-working people of New York.', 'The National Union of Mineworkers pressed the party to support a total ban on imported coal.']
bis_def_longman: to say that you agree with an idea, group, or person, and usually to help them because you want them to succeed
exps_longman: ['The bill was supported by a large majority in the Senate.', 'We need to support our teachers in their efforts to raise standards.', 'We strongly support the peace process.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to help or encourage somebody/something by saying or showing that you agree with them/it
exps_oxford_advanced: ['to support a proposal', 'These measures are strongly supported by environmental groups.', "If you raise it at the meeting, I'll support you.", 'The government supported the unions in their demand for a minimum wage.']

sentence: I 'll go and get one this afternoon .

sentence: And at the end , Conlon drew the one hopeful conclusion : If this stops capital punishment ever coming back , the time I 've spent in prison will be well worth it .
gloss: (of an event, action, or process) come to an end; cease to happen.
eg_sent: his laughter stopped as quickly as it had begun
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; If you have been doing something and then you stop doing it, you no longer do it. ;
exps_collins: ['Stop throwing those stones!.', "He can't stop thinking about it.", "I've been told to lose weight and stop smoking.", 'I stopped working last year to have a baby.', 'Does either of the parties want to stop the fighting?.', 'She stopped in mid-sentence.']
bis_def_longman: to not continue, or to make someone or something not continue
exps_longman: ['By midday the rain had stopped.', 'This is where the path stops.', 'The referee stopped the fight.', 'The doctor advised me to stop the medication.', 'People are fighting to stop the destruction of the rain forests.', 'I couldn’t stop her crying.']

sentence: The pattern caused problems , in that the circumstances which might trigger off renewed fighting were unpredictable ; yet the moment an opportunity offered , princes had to be prepared for invading their enemies ; there was no time for lengthy preparation .
gloss: Cause (a device) to function.

exps_collins: ['The thieves must have deliberately triggered the alarm and hidden inside the house.', 'The one thousand pound bomb was triggered by a wire.', '…nuclear triggering devices.']
bis_def_longman: to make something happen very quickly, especially a series of events
exps_longman: ['The assassination triggered off a wave of rioting.', 'Certain forms of mental illness can be triggered by food allergies.', 'His action triggered a massive response from the government.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to make something happen suddenly
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Nuts can trigger off a violent allergic reaction.']

sentence: But the villages are dying , becoming suburbs or dormitories where few people work but many sleep .

bis_def_oxford_advanced: to do something that involves physical or mental effort, especially as part of a job

sentence: But it will not mean that we are abandoning them .

bis_def_longman: to have or represent a particular meaning

sentence: The armoured or plated dinosaurs include some species that seem too heavily burdened with protective armour to have been very active , but this does not necessarily mean that they had to be cold-blooded .
gloss: Give the impression of being something or having a particular quality.

exps_collins: ['We heard a series of explosions. They seemed quite close by.', 'Everyone seems busy except us.', 'To everyone who knew them, they seemed an ideal couple.', '£50 seems a lot to pay.', 'The calming effect seemed to last for about ten minutes.', 'The government seems not to be troubled by its inconsistent policies on minority rights.', 'It was a record that seemed beyond reach.', "The proposal seems designed to break opposition to the government's economic programme.", 'It seems that the attack this morning was very carefully planned to cause few casualties.', 'It seems clear that he has no reasonable alternative.', "It seemed as if she'd been gone forever.", 'There seems to be a lot of support in Congress for this move.', 'There seems no possibility that such action can be averted.', 'This phenomenon is not as outrageous as it seems.']

exps_oxford_advanced: ['‘Hello!’ she said.', '‘That was marvellous,’ said Daniel.', 'Be quiet, I have something to say.', "I didn't believe a word she said.", "That's a terrible thing to say.", "He knew that if he wasn't back by midnight, his parents would have something to say about it (= be angry).", 'She said nothing to me about it.', "I said to myself (= thought), ‘That can't be right!’", 'He said (that) his name was Sam.', 'It is said that she lived to be over 100.', 'She finds it hard to say what she feels.', "‘That's impossible!’ ‘So you say (= but I think you may be wrong).’", "‘Why can't I go out now?’ ‘Because I say so.’", "‘What do you want it for?’ ‘I'd rather not say.’", 'He said to meet him here.', 'He is said to have been a brilliant scholar.']

gloss: Happen or occur afterwards or as a result.

bis_def_longman: to happen after or as a result of something

sentence: I know .
gloss: Be aware of through observation, inquiry, or information.
eg_sent: most people know that CFCs can damage the ozone layer
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont]  If you know a fact, a piece of information, or an answer, you have it correctly in your mind.
exps_collins: ["I don't know the name of the place.", 'I know that you led a rifle platoon during the Second World War.', "'People like doing things for nothing.' — 'I know they do.'.", "I don't know what happened to her husband.", "'How did he meet your mother?' — 'I don't know.'.", 'We all know about his early experiments in flying.', 'They looked younger than I knew them to be.', 'Radon is known to be harmful to humans in large quantities.', 'It is not known whether the bomb was originally intended for the capital itself.', "It's always been known that key figures in the government do very well for themselves."]
bis_def_longman: to have information about something
exps_longman: ['Who knows the answer?', 'There are instructions telling you everything you need to know.', 'Didn’t you know that?', 'Do you know what time it is?', 'I don’t know where to go.', 'I need to know more about the job before I decide whether to apply for it.', 'Little is known about the author’s childhood.', 'I know all about David and what he’s been up to!', 'I wonder if he knew of the plan?', 'Do you know of any good restaurants in the area?', 'You know nothing of this business.', 'We know that greenhouse gases can affect the climate.', 'Let me know what time you’re planning to arrive.', 'I thought you’d want to know immediately.', 'If you must know, I was with James last night .', 'He slipped out of the house without his parents knowing .', 'How did he know our names?', '‘I’m divorced, as you know, ’ she said briefly.', 'Smoking is known to increase a person’s risk of developing lung cancer.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have information in your mind as a result of experience or because you have learned or been told it
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Do you know his address?', 'The cause of the fire is not yet known.', 'All I know is that she used to work in a bank (= I have no other information about her).', 'I know (that) people’s handwriting changes as they get older.', 'It is widely known that CFCs can damage the ozone layer.', 'I knew where he was hiding.', "I didn't know what he was talking about.", "‘You've got a flat tyre.’ ‘I know.’", "‘What's the answer?’ ‘I don't know.’", "‘There's no one in.’ ‘How do you know?’", "You know about Amanda's baby, don't you?", "I don't know about you, but I'm ready for something to eat.", 'I know of at least two people who did the same thing.', '‘Is anyone else coming?’ ‘Not that I know of.’', '‘Isn’t that his car?’ ‘I wouldn’t know./How should I know?’ (= I don’t know and I am not the person you should ask.)', "‘What are you two whispering about?’ ‘You don't want to know’ (= because you would be shocked or wouldn't approve).", 'Does he know to come here (= that he should come here) first?', 'We know her to be honest.', 'Two women are known to have died.']

sentence: Mark demanded .

sentence: To want to go home ?
gloss: Have a desire to possess or do (something); wish for.
eg_sent: I want an apple
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont, no passive] ; If you want something, you feel a desire or a need for it. ;
exps_collins: ['I want a drink.', 'Ian knows exactly what he wants in life.', 'People wanted to know who this talented designer was.', 'They began to want their father to be the same as other daddies.', "They didn't want people staring at them as they sat on the lawn, so they put up high walls.", 'He wanted his power recognised.', 'I want my car this colour.', 'And remember, we want him alive.', "Note that want and wish have similar meanings, but are used differently. If you want something, you feel a need for it or a desire to have it. You can say that you want to do something, that you want someone to do something, or that you want something to happen. If you use wish with a 'to' infinitive, this has the same meaning as want but is more formal. I want to get out of here... She wished to consult him about her future."]
bis_def_longman: to have a desire for something

bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have information in your mind as a result of experience or because you have learned or been told it
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Do you know his address?', 'The cause of the fire is not yet known.', 'All I know is that she used to work in a bank (= I have no other information about her).', 'I know (that) people’s handwriting changes as they get older.', 'It is widely known that CFCs can damage the ozone layer.', 'I knew where he was hiding.', "I didn't know what he was talking about.", "‘You've got a flat tyre.’ ‘I know.’", "‘What's the answer?’ ‘I don't know.’", "‘There's no one in.’ ‘How do you know?’", "You know about Amanda's baby, don't you?", "I don't know about you, but I'm ready for something to eat.", 'I know of at least two people who did the same thing.', '‘Is anyone else coming?’ ‘Not that I know of.’', '‘Isn’t that his car?’ ‘I wouldn’t know./How should I know?’ (= I don’t know and I am not the person you should ask.)', "‘What are you two whispering about?’ ‘You don't want to know’ (= because you would be shocked or wouldn't approve).", 'Does he know to come here (= that he should come here) first?', 'We know her to be honest.', 'Two women are known to have died.']

sentence: The first of these was written in 1928 and they number about 150 .
gloss: Mark (letters, words, or other symbols) on a surface, typically paper, with a pen, pencil, or similar implement.

sentence: Same as we 've got at home .
gloss: Come to have (something); receive.
eg_sent: I got a letter from him the other day
bis_def_collins: You use get with adjectives to mean 'become'. For example, if someone gets cold, they become cold, and if they get angry, they become angry.

sentence: David Jacobs also points out that the cost of hiring a stage-coach is now prohibitive .

exps_longman: ['I don’t mind the heat, in fact I quite like it.', 'The expression on Dan’s face showed that he did mind, very much.', 'I wouldn’t have minded if she’d asked me first.', 'Did you mind being away from home for so long?', 'Don’t your parents mind you staying out so late?', 'He didn’t mind that other people in the village thought him odd.']
