sentence: He thought , I know what my idea of heaven would be , if by heaven we mean a place of bliss in which to pass eternity : a sanctuary where one might chain-smoke without impairment of breathing , destruction of the lungs or damage to the heart , light each fresh cigarette from the glowing butt of its predecessor , and drink ice-free but hundred-proof chilled vodka laced with two drops of angostura and a gill of newly opened Perrier endlessly , with increasing euphoria until a peak of joy and ease was reached but without any sub-sequent nausea or pain or dehydration or oblivion
gloss: Have a particular opinion, belief, or idea about someone or something.
eg_sent: she thought that nothing would be the same again
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont] ; If you think that something is the case, you have the opinion that it is the case. ; [Also VERB n to-infinitive]
exps_collins: ['I certainly think there should be a ban on tobacco advertising.', 'Do you think I ought to seal the boxes up?.', 'A generation ago, it was thought that babies born this small could not survive.', 'Tell me, what do you think of my theory?.', 'Peter is useless, far worse than I thought.', 'He manages a good deal better than I thought possible.', "'It ought to be stopped.' — 'Yes, I think so.'"]
bis_def_longman: to have a particular opinion or to believe that something is true
exps_longman: ['I think that you’re being unfair.', 'I thought I heard something.', 'He didn’t think anyone would believe him.', 'Do you think I should call him?', 'For some reason, I keep thinking it’s Friday today.', 'The recession lasted longer than anyone thought it would.', 'Am I right in thinking that you have a brother?', 'I can’t help thinking that he’s made a mistake.', 'Do you honestly think I would do something so stupid?', 'What do you think of your new school?', 'I thought it best to call first.', 'I thought it appropriate to invite her to speak at the meeting.', 'We must start thinking in terms of reducing costs.', 'Fraud is thought to be costing software companies millions of dollars a year.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have a particular idea or opinion about something/somebody; to believe something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Do you think (that) they’ll come?', 'I thought I heard a scream.', "I didn't think you liked sports.", 'Am I right in thinking that you used to live here?', "I think this is their house, but I'm not sure.", 'He ought to resign, I think.', "We'll need about 20 chairs, I should think.", 'It was once thought that the sun travelled around the earth.', 'What did you think about the idea?', 'Well, I like it. What do you think?', '‘Will we make it in time?’ ‘I think so.’', "‘Is he any good?’ ‘I don't think so.’", "I think it highly unlikely that I'll get the job.", 'She thought him kind and generous.', "He's thought to be one of the richest men in Europe."]

sentence: I 'm sorry you 're disappointed , she had said to Penelope , but after all there 's a lot of money , quite enough for both of us .
gloss: Utter words so as to convey information, an opinion, a feeling or intention, or an instruction.
eg_sent: ‘Thank you,’ he said
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; When you say something, you speak words. ; [Also VERB to-infinitive]
exps_collins: ["'I'm sorry,' he said.", 'She said they were very impressed.', 'Forty-one people are said to have been seriously hurt.', 'I packed and said goodbye to Charlie.', "I hope you didn't say anything about Gretchen.", "You didn't say much when you telephoned.", 'Did he say where he was going?.', "It doesn't sound exactly orthodox, if I may say so."]
bis_def_longman: to express an idea, feeling, thought etc using words
exps_longman: ['‘Don’t cry, ’ he said softly.', 'Don’t believe anything he says.', 'A spokesman said that the company had improved its safety standards.', 'I always said I would buy a motorbike when I had enough money.', 'Did she say what happened?', 'I would like to say how much we appreciate your hard work.', '‘Why did she leave?’ ‘I don’t know – she didn’t say.’', 'What did you say to her?', 'What a silly thing to say!', 'She left without saying goodbye.', 'I’ve said I’m sorry – what more do you want?', 'Can I go, Mum? Oh, please say yes!', 'He looked as if he was going to say something.', 'I wished I had said nothing about Jordi.', 'Does anyone else have anything to say?', 'Although he didn’t say so, it was clear that he was in pain.', 'What makes you say that (=why do you think that) ? 你怎么会那么说呢？', 'Nina said to meet her at 4.30.', 'I’d like to say a few words.', '‘So what are your plans now?’ ‘I’d rather not say.’']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to speak or tell somebody something, using words
exps_oxford_advanced: ['‘Hello!’ she said.', '‘That was marvellous,’ said Daniel.', 'Be quiet, I have something to say.', "I didn't believe a word she said.", "That's a terrible thing to say.", "He knew that if he wasn't back by midnight, his parents would have something to say about it (= be angry).", 'She said nothing to me about it.', "I said to myself (= thought), ‘That can't be right!’", 'He said (that) his name was Sam.', 'It is said that she lived to be over 100.', 'She finds it hard to say what she feels.', "‘That's impossible!’ ‘So you say (= but I think you may be wrong).’", "‘Why can't I go out now?’ ‘Because I say so.’", "‘What do you want it for?’ ‘I'd rather not say.’", 'He said to meet him here.', 'He is said to have been a brilliant scholar.']

gloss: Use or add in place of.

sentence: In addition , the police were well prepared , stimulated largely by implementing a plan designed more to cope with an emergency at the nearby Toronto International Airport than for the event in question .

gloss: Carry the weight of; support.

sentence: I wo n't be able to see it .
gloss: Perceive with the eyes; discern visually.
eg_sent: in the distance she could see the blue sea
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont] ; When you see something, you notice it using your eyes. ;
exps_collins: ["You can't see colours at night.", 'I saw a man making his way towards me.', 'She can see, hear, touch, smell, and taste.', 'As he neared the farm, he saw that a police car was parked outside it.', 'Did you see what happened?', 'You use see to talk about things that you are aware of because a visual impression reaches your eyes. You often use can in this case. I can see the fax here on the desk. If you want to say that someone is paying attention to something they can see, you say that they are looking at it or watching it. In general, you look at something that is not moving, while you watch something that is moving or changing. I asked him to look at the picture above his bed... He watched Blake run down the stairs.']
bis_def_longman: to notice or examine someone or something, using your eyes
exps_longman: ['He crouched down so he couldn’t be seen.', 'Can I see your ticket, please?', 'You can see the Houses of Parliament from here.', 'Can you see where the marks are on the wall?', 'The suspect was seen entering the building.', 'As you can see, the house needs some work doing on it.', 'Have you seen Chris ?', 'The accommodation was so awful it had to be seen to be believed.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to become aware of somebody/something by using your eyes
exps_oxford_advanced: ["She looked for him but couldn't see him in the crowd.", 'I looked out of the window but saw nothing.', 'The opera was the place to see and be seen (= by other important or fashionable people).', 'He could see (that) she had been crying.', 'Did you see what happened?', 'If you watch carefully, you’ll see how it is done.', 'I hate to see you unhappy.', 'She was seen running away from the scene of the crime.', 'I saw you put the key in your pocket.', 'He was seen to enter the building about the time the crime was committed.']

sentence: Your travel case reminded me of it when we left the hotel .

eg_sent: the dome was supported by a hundred white columns

sentence: I know what you mean .
gloss: Intend to convey or refer to (a particular thing); signify.
eg_sent: I don't know what you mean

sentence: In September 1988 Mrs Bujok laid an information against the council alleging the existence and continuance of a statutory nuisance under section 92(1) of the Public Health Act 1936 .
gloss: Claim or assert that someone has done something illegal or wrong, typically without proof.
eg_sent: he alleged that he had been assaulted
bis_def_collins: If you allege that something bad is true, you say it but do not prove it.  [formal] [Also VERB with quote]
exps_collins: ['She alleged that there was rampant drug use among the male members of the group.', 'The accused is alleged to have killed a man.', 'It was alleged that the restaurant discriminated against black customers.']

sentence: Nevertheless , the high proportion of inner urban populations composed of people from ethnic minorities , and the high incidence among these groups of all the indices of poverty and social and environmental hardship combined with the specific problem of inter-racial rivalry , harassment , and tension make race and ethnicity an aspect that is central to any analysis of the inner cities and of any ameliorative approach .
gloss: Join or merge to form a single unit or substance.

exps_collins: ['The Church has something to say on how to combine freedom with responsibility.', 'If improved education is combined with other factors dramatic results can be achieved.', "Relief workers say it's worse than ever as disease and starvation combine to kill thousands.", 'A stagnant economy combined with a surge in the number of teenagers is likely to have contributed to rising crime levels in the US.']

sentence: Formal condolences , he thought , were never easy to speak or accept and usually sounded either banal or insincere .

How does that sound?', 'faraway places with strange-sounding names']

sentence: Leaves and yellow blossoms obscured the top of the window , while the bottom was covered by aggressive pink hollyhocks , seemingly determined to fight their way inside .
gloss: Put something on top of or in front of (something), especially in order to protect or conceal it.
eg_sent: the table had been covered with a checked tablecloth
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; If you cover something, you place something else over it in order to protect it, hide it, or close it. ;
exps_collins: ['Cover the casserole with a tight-fitting lid.', 'He whimpered and covered his face.', "Keep what's left in a covered container in the fridge."]
bis_def_longman: to put something over or be over something in order to hide, close, or protect it

bis_def_oxford_advanced: to place something over or in front of something in order to hide or protect it
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Cover the chicken loosely with foil.', 'She covered her face with her hands.', 'He laughed to cover (= hide) his nervousness.']

sentence: Support refers to anything which is said or done to help the offender solve or mitigate their personal or social problems : surveillance to anything which is said or done to induce the offender to conform to socially acceptable standards of behaviour .
gloss: Succeed in persuading or leading (someone) to do something.
eg_sent: the pickets induced many workers to stay away
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; To induce a state or condition means to cause it. ;
exps_collins: ['Doctors said surgery could induce a heart attack.', '...an economic crisis induced by high oil prices.']
bis_def_longman: to persuade someone to do something, especially something that does not seem wise

bis_def_oxford_advanced: to persuade or influence somebody to do something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Nothing would induce me to take the job.']

sentence: McLeish expressed qualified enthusiasm and Charlie assured him he felt exactly the same about his younger brother .
gloss: Tell someone something positively to dispel any doubts.
eg_sent: Tony assured me that there was a supermarket in the village
bis_def_collins: VERB  ……… If you assure someone that something is true or will happen, you tell them that it is definitely true or will definitely happen, often in order to make them less worried. ………
exps_collins: ['He hastened to assure me that there was nothing traumatic to report.', "'Are you sure the raft is safe?' she asked anxiously. 'Couldn't be safer,' Max assured her confidently.", 'Government officials recently assured Hindus of protection.']

exps_longman: ['Her doctor has assured us that she’ll be fine.', 'The document is genuine, I can assure you.', 'The dealer had assured me of its quality.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to tell somebody that something is definitely true or is definitely going to happen, especially when they have doubts about it
exps_oxford_advanced: ['You think I did it deliberately, but I assure you (that) I did not.', 'We were assured that everything possible was being done.', "She's perfectly safe, I can assure you.", 'We assured him of our support.', 'I won’t let you down, I can assure you of that.', "‘He'll come back,’ Susan assured her."]

sentence: Manuals for cars , machine tools and so on are poor but at least it is possible to observe the mechanisms and their functions .
gloss: Notice or perceive (something) and register it as being significant.

bis_def_longman: to see and notice something

sentence: She lay quiescent and felt his strong fingers , quicker now , move to unfasten the buttons of her shift one by one .
gloss: Open the fastening of; undo (something)
eg_sent: Allie stands before the mirror unfastening her earrings
bis_def_collins: If you unfasten something that is closed, tied, or held together, or if you unfasten the thing holding it, you loosen or remove the thing holding it.

bis_def_oxford_advanced: to undo something that is fastened

sentence: And he said , " I told you .
gloss: Utter words so as to convey information, an opinion, a feeling or intention, or an instruction.

bis_def_collins: VERB  ; When you say something, you speak words. ; [Also VERB to-infinitive]
exps_collins: ["'I'm sorry,' he said.", 'She said they were very impressed.', 'Forty-one people are said to have been seriously hurt.', 'I packed and said goodbye to Charlie.', "I hope you didn't say anything about Gretchen.", "You didn't say much when you telephoned.", 'Did he say where he was going?.', "It doesn't sound exactly orthodox, if I may say so."]

exps_longman: ['‘Don’t cry, ’ he said softly.', 'Don’t believe anything he says.', 'A spokesman said that the company had improved its safety standards.', 'I always said I would buy a motorbike when I had enough money.', 'Did she say what happened?', 'I would like to say how much we appreciate your hard work.', '‘Why did she leave?’ ‘I don’t know – she didn’t say.’', 'What did you say to her?', 'What a silly thing to say!', 'She left without saying goodbye.', 'I’ve said I’m sorry – what more do you want?', 'Can I go, Mum? Oh, please say yes!', 'He looked as if he was going to say something.', 'I wished I had said nothing about Jordi.', 'Does anyone else have anything to say?', 'Although he didn’t say so, it was clear that he was in pain.', 'What makes you say that (=why do you think that) ? 你怎么会那么说呢？', 'Nina said to meet her at 4.30.', 'I’d like to say a few words.', '‘So what are your plans now?’ ‘I’d rather not say.’']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to speak or tell somebody something, using words
exps_oxford_advanced: ['‘Hello!’ she said.', '‘That was marvellous,’ said Daniel.', 'Be quiet, I have something to say.', "I didn't believe a word she said.", "That's a terrible thing to say.", "He knew that if he wasn't back by midnight, his parents would have something to say about it (= be angry).", 'She said nothing to me about it.', "I said to myself (= thought), ‘That can't be right!’", 'He said (that) his name was Sam.', 'It is said that she lived to be over 100.', 'She finds it hard to say what she feels.', "‘That's impossible!’ ‘So you say (= but I think you may be wrong).’", "‘Why can't I go out now?’ ‘Because I say so.’", "‘What do you want it for?’ ‘I'd rather not say.’", 'He said to meet him here.', 'He is said to have been a brilliant scholar.']

I 'm not staying , he said .

sentence: I think it was because er cos we 'd got Iris ' er er Triumph did n't we ?
gloss: Come to have (something); receive.
eg_sent: I got a letter from him the other day
bis_def_collins: You use get with adjectives to mean 'become'. For example, if someone gets cold, they become cold, and if they get angry, they become angry.
exps_collins: ['The boys were getting bored.', "There's no point in getting upset.", 'From here on, it can only get better.']

exps_longman: ['She got loads of presents.', 'What did you get for Christmas?', 'We get a lot of junk mail.', 'We got a letter from Pam this morning.', 'I got it off my Dad.', 'I got a few games free when I bought my computer.']

sentence: I can not honestly see that a system which would require us to compromise the morning after the election is really so morally inferior to a system which has already obliged us to compromise our policies two years before polling day .
gloss: Make (someone) legally or morally bound to do something.

exps_collins: ['The storm got worse and worse. Finally, I was obliged to abandon the car and continue on foot.', 'This decree obliges unions to delay strikes.']
bis_def_longman: if you are obliged to do something, you have to do it because the situation, the law, a duty etc makes it necessary
exps_longman: ['The minister was obliged to report at least once every six months.', 'Circumstances had obliged him to sell the business.', 'Many parents feel obliged to pay for at least part of the wedding.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to force somebody to do something, by law, because it is a duty, etc.
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Parents are obliged by law to send their children to school.', 'I felt obliged to ask them to dinner.', 'He suffered a serious injury that obliged him to give up work.', 'Libel plaintiffs are virtually obliged to go into the witness box.']

gloss: Come to have (something); receive.

sentence: The work reviewed above suggests that the application of GIS techniques to hazard assessment , emergency planning and environmental monitoring is both actually and potentially an important research area with many challenging problems .

sentence: I 've always wanted to fly .
gloss: Have a desire to possess or do (something); wish for.

exps_collins: ['I want a drink.', 'Ian knows exactly what he wants in life.', 'People wanted to know who this talented designer was.', 'They began to want their father to be the same as other daddies.', "They didn't want people staring at them as they sat on the lawn, so they put up high walls.", 'He wanted his power recognised.', 'I want my car this colour.', 'And remember, we want him alive.', "Note that want and wish have similar meanings, but are used differently. If you want something, you feel a need for it or a desire to have it. You can say that you want to do something, that you want someone to do something, or that you want something to happen. If you use wish with a 'to' infinitive, this has the same meaning as want but is more formal. I want to get out of here... She wished to consult him about her future."]

sentence: When you look at , when you look at the some , all these , a lot of these composers and artists who died long ago and you look the birth range there 's a hell of a lot at seventy five , seventy six
gloss: Direct one's gaze toward someone or something or in a specified direction.
eg_sent: people were looking at him
bis_def_collins: If you look in a particular direction, you direct your eyes in that direction, especially so that you can see what is there or see what something is like.
exps_collins: ['I looked down the hallway to room number nine.', 'She turned to look at him.', 'He looked away, apparently enraged.', "If you look, you'll see what was a lake.", 'If you want to say that someone is paying attention to something they can see, you say that they are looking at it or watching it. In general, you look at something that is not moving, while you watch something that is moving or changing. I asked him to look at the picture above his bed... He watched Blake run down the stairs. Look is never followed directly by an object. You must always use at or some other preposition. I looked towards the plane. You use see to talk about things that you are aware of because a visual impression reaches your eyes. You often use can in this case. I can see the fax here on the desk.']
bis_def_longman: to turn your eyes towards something, so that you can see it
exps_longman: ['We sneaked out while Jessie’s mom wasn’t looking.', 'If you look carefully you can see that the painting represents a human figure.', 'Gina covered her eyes, afraid to look.', '‘It’s time we left, ’ Ian said, looking at his watch.', 'The men all turned to look at her as she entered the room.', 'Dad looked up from his paper and smiled.', '‘We can’t go out in this weather, ’ said Bob, looking out of the window.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to turn your eyes in a particular direction

sentence: Not that this is any excuse , John , I do know .

exps_longman: ['Who knows the answer?', 'There are instructions telling you everything you need to know.', 'Didn’t you know that?', 'Do you know what time it is?', 'I don’t know where to go.', 'I need to know more about the job before I decide whether to apply for it.', 'Little is known about the author’s childhood.', 'I know all about David and what he’s been up to!', 'I wonder if he knew of the plan?', 'Do you know of any good restaurants in the area?', 'You know nothing of this business.', 'We know that greenhouse gases can affect the climate.', 'Let me know what time you’re planning to arrive.', 'I thought you’d want to know immediately.', 'If you must know, I was with James last night .', 'He slipped out of the house without his parents knowing .', 'How did he know our names?', '‘I’m divorced, as you know, ’ she said briefly.', 'Smoking is known to increase a person’s risk of developing lung cancer.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have information in your mind as a result of experience or because you have learned or been told it
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Do you know his address?', 'The cause of the fire is not yet known.', 'All I know is that she used to work in a bank (= I have no other information about her).', 'I know (that) people’s handwriting changes as they get older.', 'It is widely known that CFCs can damage the ozone layer.', 'I knew where he was hiding.', "I didn't know what he was talking about.", "‘You've got a flat tyre.’ ‘I know.’", "‘What's the answer?’ ‘I don't know.’", "‘There's no one in.’ ‘How do you know?’", "You know about Amanda's baby, don't you?", "I don't know about you, but I'm ready for something to eat.", 'I know of at least two people who did the same thing.', '‘Is anyone else coming?’ ‘Not that I know of.’', '‘Isn’t that his car?’ ‘I wouldn’t know./How should I know?’ (= I don’t know and I am not the person you should ask.)', "‘What are you two whispering about?’ ‘You don't want to know’ (= because you would be shocked or wouldn't approve).", 'Does he know to come here (= that he should come here) first?', 'We know her to be honest.', 'Two women are known to have died.']

sentence: A new canvass system was introduced in 1911 so that all county constituencies would operate the same system and so that duplicate records could be kept at area level .
gloss: Make or be an exact copy of.

sentence: The work of Diggle et al. ( 1990 ) examined only a single point source , though it generalizes to multiple sources and to linear hazards as well .

It may be that a study commissioned from contractors by the British National Space Centre will provide useful evidence on the cash value of remote sensing ; it is particularly timely in view of the appointment of Professor Pearce ( see above ) as the adviser to the UK Secretary of State for the Environment .
gloss: Perceive with the eyes; discern visually.
eg_sent: in the distance she could see the blue sea
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont] ; When you see something, you notice it using your eyes. ;
exps_collins: ["You can't see colours at night.", 'I saw a man making his way towards me.', 'She can see, hear, touch, smell, and taste.', 'As he neared the farm, he saw that a police car was parked outside it.', 'Did you see what happened?', 'You use see to talk about things that you are aware of because a visual impression reaches your eyes. You often use can in this case. I can see the fax here on the desk. If you want to say that someone is paying attention to something they can see, you say that they are looking at it or watching it. In general, you look at something that is not moving, while you watch something that is moving or changing. I asked him to look at the picture above his bed... He watched Blake run down the stairs.']
bis_def_longman: to notice or examine someone or something, using your eyes
exps_longman: ['He crouched down so he couldn’t be seen.', 'Can I see your ticket, please?', 'You can see the Houses of Parliament from here.', 'Can you see where the marks are on the wall?', 'The suspect was seen entering the building.', 'As you can see, the house needs some work doing on it.', 'Have you seen Chris ?', 'The accommodation was so awful it had to be seen to be believed.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to become aware of somebody/something by using your eyes
exps_oxford_advanced: ["She looked for him but couldn't see him in the crowd.", 'I looked out of the window but saw nothing.', 'The opera was the place to see and be seen (= by other important or fashionable people).', 'He could see (that) she had been crying.', 'Did you see what happened?', 'If you watch carefully, you’ll see how it is done.', 'I hate to see you unhappy.', 'She was seen running away from the scene of the crime.', 'I saw you put the key in your pocket.', 'He was seen to enter the building about the time the crime was committed.']

sentence: She recalled a promise made by Mr Major when he became Prime Minister : that he would work for a nation at ease with itself .
gloss: Begin to be.
eg_sent: she became angry and sulked all day
bis_def_collins: If someone or something becomes a particular thing, they start to change and develop into that thing, or start to develop the characteristics mentioned.
exps_collins: ['I first became interested in Islam while I was doing my nursing training.', 'The cocoa industry dwindled because it became increasingly difficult to cover costs.', "During the 1980s the world's financial systems became more open.", 'The pilot decided to land, but as we lost altitude the wind became stronger.', 'As she reached the age of thirty she became convinced she would remain single all her life.', 'After leaving school, he became a professional footballer.', 'In 1823 Honduras became a part of the United Provinces of Central America.']
bis_def_longman: to start to have a feeling or quality, or to start to develop into something
exps_longman: ['The weather became warmer.', 'Slowly my eyes became accustomed to the darkness.', 'Helen became increasingly anxious about her husband’s strange behaviour.', 'Pollution from cars has become a major problem.']

sentence: However , if cancers are of interest it is more appropriate to obtain data from regional cancer registries ; these data are morbidity rather than mortality data and are therefore more valuable .
gloss: Get, acquire, or secure (something)

bis_def_collins: VERB  ; To obtain something means to get it or achieve it. ; [formal]

bis_def_oxford_advanced: to get something, especially by making an effort
exps_oxford_advanced: ['to obtain advice/information/permission', 'I finally managed to obtain a copy of the report.', 'Further details can be obtained by writing to the above address.', 'To obtain the overall score, add up the totals in each column.']

sentence: These include the highly specialized nature of much of the technical analysis , the limited capacity for checking the accuracy of many of the findings of this kind of research and the consequent need for the development of knowledge-based inference machines for extracting useful information from secondary and often proxy data .
gloss: Remove or take out, especially by effort or force.

bis_def_oxford_advanced: to remove or obtain a substance from something, for example by using an industrial or a chemical process

sentence: I 'd like that .
gloss: Find agreeable, enjoyable, or satisfactory.
eg_sent: all his classmates liked him
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont] ; If you like something or someone, you think they are interesting, enjoyable, or attractive. ;

exps_longman: ['I like your jacket.', 'I don’t really like classical music.', 'Do you like this colour?', 'I like my coffee quite weak.', 'I don’t like it when you get angry.', 'How do you like living in London ?', 'I don’t like talking in public.', 'I like to see people enjoying themselves.', 'I quite like their new album.', 'We really liked the film.', 'The time I like best is the evening when it’s cool.', 'One of the things I like about John is his sense of humour.', 'I didn’t like the idea of being a single parent.']

exps_oxford_advanced: ["She's nice. I like her.", 'Do you like their new house?', 'Which tie do you like best?', 'How did you like Japan (= did you find it pleasant)?', "I don't like the way he's looking at me.", "You've got to go to school, whether you like it or not.", "She's never liked swimming.", "I didn't like him taking all the credit.", "I didn't like his taking all the credit.", 'I like to see them enjoying themselves.', 'I like it when you do that.']

sentence: But these two wanted to go home .
gloss: Have a desire to possess or do (something); wish for.
eg_sent: I want an apple
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont, no passive] ; If you want something, you feel a desire or a need for it. ;
exps_collins: ['I want a drink.', 'Ian knows exactly what he wants in life.', 'People wanted to know who this talented designer was.', 'They began to want their father to be the same as other daddies.', "They didn't want people staring at them as they sat on the lawn, so they put up high walls.", 'He wanted his power recognised.', 'I want my car this colour.', 'And remember, we want him alive.', "Note that want and wish have similar meanings, but are used differently. If you want something, you feel a need for it or a desire to have it. You can say that you want to do something, that you want someone to do something, or that you want something to happen. If you use wish with a 'to' infinitive, this has the same meaning as want but is more formal. I want to get out of here... She wished to consult him about her future."]
bis_def_longman: to have a desire for something
exps_longman: ['I really want a drink.', 'What do you want for your birthday?', 'She’d always wanted to go to Thailand.', 'I don’t want Linda to  hear about this.', 'He didn’t want the holiday to end.', 'You can order whatever you want.', 'This shampoo is mild enough to use every day if you want.', 'If she doesn’t get what she wants, she’s not happy.', 'He wanted that job so badly he was willing to kill for it.', 'They desperately wanted a son.', 'What I want to know is when we’re going to get paid.', 'All I want is the chance to prove myself.', 'Oh thank you, it’s just what I’ve always wanted.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have a desire or a wish for something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Do you want some more tea?', "She's always wanted a large family.", 'All I want is the truth.', "Thanks for the present—it's just what I wanted.", 'I can do whatever I want.', 'The last thing I wanted was to upset you.', 'The party wants her as leader.', 'What do you want to do tomorrow?', "‘It's time you did your homework.’ ‘I don't want to!’", 'There are two points which I wanted to make.', 'I just wanted to know if everything was all right.', 'You can come too, if you want.', 'Do you want me to help?', "We didn't want this to happen.", 'I want it (to be) done as quickly as possible.', "I don't want you coming home so late.", 'Do you want your coffee black or white?']

sentence: Improved police methods might help , writes Harrison , to contain the problem .
gloss: Make it easier or possible for (someone) to do something by offering one's services or resources.
eg_sent: they helped her with domestic chores
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; If you help someone, you make it easier for them to do something, for example by doing part of the work for them or by giving them advice or money. ;
exps_collins: ['He has helped to raise a lot of money.', 'My mum used to help cook the meals for the children.', "America's priority is to help nations defend themselves.", 'You can of course help by giving them a donation directly.', 'I was only trying to help.', "If you're not willing to help me, I'll find somebody who will."]
bis_def_longman: to make it possible or easier for someone to do something by doing part of their work or by giving them something they need
exps_longman: ['If there’s anything I can do to help, just give me a call.', 'I helped her to carry her cases up the stairs.', 'She helped him choose some new clothes.', 'herbal products that help you to relax and sleep', 'She was coming to help clean the machines.', 'Can I help you with the washing up?', 'My father said he’s going to help me with the fees.', 'Here, let me help you on with your coat.', 'She helped the old man across the road.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to make it easier or possible for somebody to do something by doing something for them or by giving them something that they need
exps_oxford_advanced: ["Help, I'm stuck!", 'He always helps with the housework.', 'We must all try and help each other.', 'Jo will help us with some of the organization.', 'I need contacts that could help in finding a job.', 'The college’s aim is to help students (to) achieve their aspirations.', 'This charity aims to help people (to) help themselves.', 'Come and help me lift this box.', 'She helped (to) organize the party.']

sentence: Today , I was told , villagers living around the great wool churches of Lavenham and Long Melford have to bar their doors and ignore the knocking of tourists , who take them for antique shops and offer to buy their furniture .
gloss: Refuse to take notice of or acknowledge; disregard intentionally.
eg_sent: he ignored her outraged question
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; If you ignore someone or something, you pay no attention to them. ;;
exps_collins: ['She said her husband ignored her.', 'The government had ignored his views on the subject.', 'She ignored legal advice to drop the case.', 'For two decades her theatrical talents were ignored by the film industry.']
bis_def_longman: to deliberately pay no attention to something that you have been told or that you know about
exps_longman: ['You can’t ignore the fact that many criminals never go to prison.', 'problems which we can’t afford to ignore']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to pay no attention to something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['He ignored all the ‘No Smoking’ signs and lit up a cigarette.', 'I made a suggestion but they chose to ignore it.', 'We cannot afford to ignore their advice.', 'She deliberately ignored my question and changed the subject.']

sentence: I 'm sure that if there is an easy way of doing it the Conservatives would have found out and done it .
gloss: Discover or perceive by chance or unexpectedly.
eg_sent: Lindsey looked up to find Neil watching her
bis_def_collins: VERB  … If you find someone or something, you see them or learn where they are. … [Also VERB n + for]
exps_collins: ['The police also found a pistol.', "They have spent ages looking at the map and can't find a trace of anywhere called Darrowby.", 'I wonder if you could find me a deck of cards?']
bis_def_longman: to discover, see, or get something that you have been searching for
exps_longman: ['I can’t find the car keys.', 'Hold on while I find a pen.', 'Her body was later found hidden in the bushes.', 'I have to find somewhere else to live.', 'She had almost given up hope of finding a husband.', 'Tony asked us to find him office facilities in New York.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to discover somebody/something unexpectedly or by chance
exps_oxford_advanced: ["Look what I've found!", "We've found a great new restaurant near the office.", 'A whale was found washed up on the shore.']

sentence: This contrasts with the situation in the USA ( Greenberg and Anderson 1984 ) , where the clean-up of abandoned sites is a priority .
gloss: Differ strikingly.
eg_sent: his friend's success contrasted with his own failure
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; If you contrast one thing with another, you point out or consider the differences between those things. ;
exps_collins: ['She contrasted the situation then with the present crisis.', 'Contrast that approach with what goes on in most organizations.', 'In this section we contrast four possible broad approaches.']
bis_def_longman: if two things contrast, the difference between them is very easy to see and is sometimes surprising
exps_longman: ['The snow was icy and white, contrasting with the brilliant blue sky.', 'These results contrast sharply with other medical tests carried out in Australia.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to compare two things in order to show the differences between them
exps_oxford_advanced: ['It is interesting to contrast the British legal system with the American one.', 'The poem contrasts youth and age.', 'Compare and contrast the two novels.']

sentence: Pass the marge .
gloss: Move or cause to move in a specified direction.
eg_sent: he passed through towns and villages
bis_def_collins: To pass someone or something means to go past them without stopping.
exps_collins: ['As she passed the library door, the telephone began to ring.', 'Jane stood aside to let her pass.', 'I sat in the garden and watched the passing cars.']
bis_def_longman: to come up to a particular place, person, or object and go past them
exps_longman: ['The crowd parted to let the truck pass.', 'He gave me a smile as he passed.', 'We passed a group of students outside the theatre.', 'I pass the sports centre on the way to work.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to move past or to the other side of somebody/something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Several people were passing but nobody offered to help.', 'I hailed a passing taxi.', 'The road was so narrow that cars were unable to pass.', 'to pass a barrier/sentry/checkpoint', "You'll pass a bank on the way to the train station.", 'She passed me in the street without even saying hello.', 'There was a truck behind that was trying to pass me.']

sentence: Thank you .
gloss: Express gratitude to (someone), especially by saying ‘Thank you’
eg_sent: Mac thanked her for the meal and left
bis_def_collins: VERB  …; When you thank someone for something, you express your gratitude to them for it. …;
exps_collins: ['I thanked them for their long and loyal service.', 'When the decision was read out Mrs Gardner thanked the judges.']
bis_def_longman: to tell someone that you are pleased and grateful for something they have done, or to be polite about it
exps_longman: ['I haven’t had a chance to thank him yet.', 'Did you thank Uncle Ron for the present?', 'Madeleine thanked everyone for coming.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to tell somebody that you are grateful for something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['I must write and thank Mary for the present.', 'In his speech, he thanked everyone for all their hard work.', 'She said goodbye and thanked us for coming.', "There's no need to thank me—I enjoyed doing it."]

sentence: A duke can live comfortably in a castle , after all , the architect Cedric Price is quoted as saying .
gloss: Utter words so as to convey information, an opinion, a feeling or intention, or an instruction.
eg_sent: ‘Thank you,’ he said
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; When you say something, you speak words. ; [Also VERB to-infinitive]
exps_collins: ["'I'm sorry,' he said.", 'She said they were very impressed.', 'Forty-one people are said to have been seriously hurt.', 'I packed and said goodbye to Charlie.', "I hope you didn't say anything about Gretchen.", "You didn't say much when you telephoned.", 'Did he say where he was going?.', "It doesn't sound exactly orthodox, if I may say so."]
bis_def_longman: to express an idea, feeling, thought etc using words
exps_longman: ['‘Don’t cry, ’ he said softly.', 'Don’t believe anything he says.', 'A spokesman said that the company had improved its safety standards.', 'I always said I would buy a motorbike when I had enough money.', 'Did she say what happened?', 'I would like to say how much we appreciate your hard work.', '‘Why did she leave?’ ‘I don’t know – she didn’t say.’', 'What did you say to her?', 'What a silly thing to say!', 'She left without saying goodbye.', 'I’ve said I’m sorry – what more do you want?', 'Can I go, Mum? Oh, please say yes!', 'He looked as if he was going to say something.', 'I wished I had said nothing about Jordi.', 'Does anyone else have anything to say?', 'Although he didn’t say so, it was clear that he was in pain.', 'What makes you say that (=why do you think that) ? 你怎么会那么说呢？', 'Nina said to meet her at 4.30.', 'I’d like to say a few words.', '‘So what are your plans now?’ ‘I’d rather not say.’']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to speak or tell somebody something, using words
exps_oxford_advanced: ['‘Hello!’ she said.', '‘That was marvellous,’ said Daniel.', 'Be quiet, I have something to say.', "I didn't believe a word she said.", "That's a terrible thing to say.", "He knew that if he wasn't back by midnight, his parents would have something to say about it (= be angry).", 'She said nothing to me about it.', "I said to myself (= thought), ‘That can't be right!’", 'He said (that) his name was Sam.', 'It is said that she lived to be over 100.', 'She finds it hard to say what she feels.', "‘That's impossible!’ ‘So you say (= but I think you may be wrong).’", "‘Why can't I go out now?’ ‘Because I say so.’", "‘What do you want it for?’ ‘I'd rather not say.’", 'He said to meet him here.', 'He is said to have been a brilliant scholar.']

sentence: The UOC found that " it is patent that some feeling exists among the Unionist Press that , while in the past they have done much for the Party , the Party has not assisted in their work .
gloss: Help (someone), typically by doing a share of the work.
eg_sent: a senior academic would assist him in his work
bis_def_collins: VERB  () If you assist someone, you help them to do a job or task by doing part of the work for them. ()
exps_collins: ['Julia was assisting him to prepare his speech.', 'The family decided to assist me with my chores.', 'Dr Amid was assisted by a young Asian nurse.']
bis_def_longman: to help someone to do something
exps_longman: ['You will be employed to assist in the development of new equipment.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to help somebody to do something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Anyone willing to assist can contact this number.', "We are looking for people who would be willing to assist in the group's work.", "We'll do all we can to assist you.", 'The play was directed by Mike Johnson, assisted by Sharon Gale.', 'We will assist you in finding somewhere to live.', 'Two men are assisting the police with their enquiries (= are being questioned by the police).', 'a course to assist adults to return to the labour market']

sentence: The compilation of a spatially coherent database from mapped information compiled by different organizations at different scales and on different topographic bases ( see Rhind and Clark 1988 ) is often difficult ;
gloss: Represent (an area) on a map; make a map of.
eg_sent: inaccessible parts will be mapped from the air
bis_def_collins: To map an area means to make a map of it.
exps_collins: ['...a spacecraft which is using radar to map the surface of Venus.', '...better mapping of the ocean floor.']
bis_def_longman: to make a map of a particular area
exps_longman: ['He spent the next fifteen years mapping the Isle of Anglesey.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to make a map of an area
exps_oxford_advanced: ['an unexplored region that has not yet been mapped']

sentence: The early 1980s witnessed a radical change in patterns of heroin taking , alongside the global increase .
gloss: See (an event, typically a crime or accident) happen.
eg_sent: staff who witnessed the murder
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; If you witness something, you see it happen. ;
exps_collins: ['Anyone who witnessed the attack should call the police.', "It was the quickest swimming lesson I'd ever witnessed."]
bis_def_longman: to see something happen, especially a crime or accident
exps_longman: ['Several residents claim to have witnessed the attack.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to see something happen (typically a crime or an accident)
exps_oxford_advanced: ['She was shocked by the violent scenes she had witnessed.', 'Police have appealed for anyone who witnessed the incident to contact them.', 'The novel is based on an event that he himself had witnessed.', 'I couldn’t bear to witness their suffering.', 'We are now witnessing an unprecedented increase in violent crime.', 'We had witnessed one of the most outstanding theatrical performances of the decade.']

sentence: He added , She should n't have left the matches within reach of a child .
gloss: Join (something) to something else so as to increase the size, number, or amount.
eg_sent: I've started a petition so if you would like to add your name, email me
bis_def_longman: to put something with something else or with a group of other things
exps_longman: ['If the mixture seems dry, add water.', 'Do you want to add your name to the list?', 'Suzuki has added extra doors to its sports off-roader.', 'Material about recent research has been added to this new edition.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to put something together with something else so as to increase the size, number, amount, etc.
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Next add the flour.', 'The juice contains no added sugar.', 'The plan has the added (= extra) advantage of bringing employment to rural areas.', 'A new wing was added to the building.', 'Shall I add your name to the list?', 'Chlorine is added to the water to kill bacteria.']

sentence: This has itself generated a substantial literature ( see the papers in Elliot 1988 for an overview ) and is nowhere better exemplified than in Openshaw 's geographical analysis machine ( see Ch. 2 ) .
gloss: Perceive with the eyes; discern visually.
eg_sent: in the distance she could see the blue sea
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont] ; When you see something, you notice it using your eyes. ;
exps_collins: ["You can't see colours at night.", 'I saw a man making his way towards me.', 'She can see, hear, touch, smell, and taste.', 'As he neared the farm, he saw that a police car was parked outside it.', 'Did you see what happened?', 'You use see to talk about things that you are aware of because a visual impression reaches your eyes. You often use can in this case. I can see the fax here on the desk. If you want to say that someone is paying attention to something they can see, you say that they are looking at it or watching it. In general, you look at something that is not moving, while you watch something that is moving or changing. I asked him to look at the picture above his bed... He watched Blake run down the stairs.']
bis_def_longman: to notice or examine someone or something, using your eyes
exps_longman: ['He crouched down so he couldn’t be seen.', 'Can I see your ticket, please?', 'You can see the Houses of Parliament from here.', 'Can you see where the marks are on the wall?', 'The suspect was seen entering the building.', 'As you can see, the house needs some work doing on it.', 'Have you seen Chris ?', 'The accommodation was so awful it had to be seen to be believed.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to become aware of somebody/something by using your eyes
exps_oxford_advanced: ["She looked for him but couldn't see him in the crowd.", 'I looked out of the window but saw nothing.', 'The opera was the place to see and be seen (= by other important or fashionable people).', 'He could see (that) she had been crying.', 'Did you see what happened?', 'If you watch carefully, you’ll see how it is done.', 'I hate to see you unhappy.', 'She was seen running away from the scene of the crime.', 'I saw you put the key in your pocket.', 'He was seen to enter the building about the time the crime was committed.']

sentence: No , he wanted a boy .
gloss: Have a desire to possess or do (something); wish for.
eg_sent: I want an apple
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont, no passive] ; If you want something, you feel a desire or a need for it. ;
exps_collins: ['I want a drink.', 'Ian knows exactly what he wants in life.', 'People wanted to know who this talented designer was.', 'They began to want their father to be the same as other daddies.', "They didn't want people staring at them as they sat on the lawn, so they put up high walls.", 'He wanted his power recognised.', 'I want my car this colour.', 'And remember, we want him alive.', "Note that want and wish have similar meanings, but are used differently. If you want something, you feel a need for it or a desire to have it. You can say that you want to do something, that you want someone to do something, or that you want something to happen. If you use wish with a 'to' infinitive, this has the same meaning as want but is more formal. I want to get out of here... She wished to consult him about her future."]
bis_def_longman: to have a desire for something
exps_longman: ['I really want a drink.', 'What do you want for your birthday?', 'She’d always wanted to go to Thailand.', 'I don’t want Linda to  hear about this.', 'He didn’t want the holiday to end.', 'You can order whatever you want.', 'This shampoo is mild enough to use every day if you want.', 'If she doesn’t get what she wants, she’s not happy.', 'He wanted that job so badly he was willing to kill for it.', 'They desperately wanted a son.', 'What I want to know is when we’re going to get paid.', 'All I want is the chance to prove myself.', 'Oh thank you, it’s just what I’ve always wanted.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have a desire or a wish for something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Do you want some more tea?', "She's always wanted a large family.", 'All I want is the truth.', "Thanks for the present—it's just what I wanted.", 'I can do whatever I want.', 'The last thing I wanted was to upset you.', 'The party wants her as leader.', 'What do you want to do tomorrow?', "‘It's time you did your homework.’ ‘I don't want to!’", 'There are two points which I wanted to make.', 'I just wanted to know if everything was all right.', 'You can come too, if you want.', 'Do you want me to help?', "We didn't want this to happen.", 'I want it (to be) done as quickly as possible.', "I don't want you coming home so late.", 'Do you want your coffee black or white?']

sentence: I do n't know .
gloss: Be aware of through observation, inquiry, or information.
eg_sent: most people know that CFCs can damage the ozone layer
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont]  If you know a fact, a piece of information, or an answer, you have it correctly in your mind.
exps_collins: ["I don't know the name of the place.", 'I know that you led a rifle platoon during the Second World War.', "'People like doing things for nothing.' — 'I know they do.'.", "I don't know what happened to her husband.", "'How did he meet your mother?' — 'I don't know.'.", 'We all know about his early experiments in flying.', 'They looked younger than I knew them to be.', 'Radon is known to be harmful to humans in large quantities.', 'It is not known whether the bomb was originally intended for the capital itself.', "It's always been known that key figures in the government do very well for themselves."]
bis_def_longman: to have information about something
exps_longman: ['Who knows the answer?', 'There are instructions telling you everything you need to know.', 'Didn’t you know that?', 'Do you know what time it is?', 'I don’t know where to go.', 'I need to know more about the job before I decide whether to apply for it.', 'Little is known about the author’s childhood.', 'I know all about David and what he’s been up to!', 'I wonder if he knew of the plan?', 'Do you know of any good restaurants in the area?', 'You know nothing of this business.', 'We know that greenhouse gases can affect the climate.', 'Let me know what time you’re planning to arrive.', 'I thought you’d want to know immediately.', 'If you must know, I was with James last night .', 'He slipped out of the house without his parents knowing .', 'How did he know our names?', '‘I’m divorced, as you know, ’ she said briefly.', 'Smoking is known to increase a person’s risk of developing lung cancer.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have information in your mind as a result of experience or because you have learned or been told it
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Do you know his address?', 'The cause of the fire is not yet known.', 'All I know is that she used to work in a bank (= I have no other information about her).', 'I know (that) people’s handwriting changes as they get older.', 'It is widely known that CFCs can damage the ozone layer.', 'I knew where he was hiding.', "I didn't know what he was talking about.", "‘You've got a flat tyre.’ ‘I know.’", "‘What's the answer?’ ‘I don't know.’", "‘There's no one in.’ ‘How do you know?’", "You know about Amanda's baby, don't you?", "I don't know about you, but I'm ready for something to eat.", 'I know of at least two people who did the same thing.', '‘Is anyone else coming?’ ‘Not that I know of.’', '‘Isn’t that his car?’ ‘I wouldn’t know./How should I know?’ (= I don’t know and I am not the person you should ask.)', "‘What are you two whispering about?’ ‘You don't want to know’ (= because you would be shocked or wouldn't approve).", 'Does he know to come here (= that he should come here) first?', 'We know her to be honest.', 'Two women are known to have died.']

sentence: A large sports-fishing boat was moored alongside Wavebreaker , but moored so crudely that whoever had brought the powerboat alongside the schooner had not bothered to put out fenders , but instead had gouged long ugly gashes in Wavebreaker 's white paint .
gloss: Move to or place in a particular position.
eg_sent: I put my hand out towards her
bis_def_collins: When you put something in a particular place or position, you move it into that place or position.

sentence: Keep your mouth closed when you 've got something in it or we 'll take something away .
gloss: Come to have (something); receive.
eg_sent: I got a letter from him the other day
bis_def_collins: You use get with adjectives to mean 'become'. For example, if someone gets cold, they become cold, and if they get angry, they become angry.
exps_collins: ['The boys were getting bored.', "There's no point in getting upset.", 'From here on, it can only get better.']
bis_def_longman: to receive something that someone gives you or sends you
exps_longman: ['She got loads of presents.', 'What did you get for Christmas?', 'We get a lot of junk mail.', 'We got a letter from Pam this morning.', 'I got it off my Dad.', 'I got a few games free when I bought my computer.']

sentence: Using what would now be called GIS skills , Openshaw ( 1980 ) examined over 13 000 1 km grid squares in the UK which intersect the coastline and related these to data from the 1971 Census ( which were made available for such grid squares ) .
gloss: Make or show a connection between.
eg_sent: the study examines social change within the city and relates it to developments in the country as a whole
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; If something relates to a particular subject, it concerns that subject. ;
exps_collins: ['Other recommendations relate to the details of how such data is stored.', 'It does not matter whether the problem you have relates to food, drink, smoking or just living.', 'I had papers relating to the children which my wife and I had to sign.']
bis_def_longman: if two things relate, they are connected in some way
exps_longman: ['I don’t understand how the two ideas relate.', 'The charges of fraud relate to events that took place over ten years ago.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: show or make a connection between two or more things
exps_oxford_advanced: ['I found it difficult to relate the two ideas in my mind.', 'In the future, pay increases will be related to productivity.']

sentence: I thought you 'd finished your cake , have n't you finished ?
gloss: Have a particular opinion, belief, or idea about someone or something.
eg_sent: she thought that nothing would be the same again
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont] ; If you think that something is the case, you have the opinion that it is the case. ; [Also VERB n to-infinitive]
exps_collins: ['I certainly think there should be a ban on tobacco advertising.', 'Do you think I ought to seal the boxes up?.', 'A generation ago, it was thought that babies born this small could not survive.', 'Tell me, what do you think of my theory?.', 'Peter is useless, far worse than I thought.', 'He manages a good deal better than I thought possible.', "'It ought to be stopped.' — 'Yes, I think so.'"]
bis_def_longman: to have a particular opinion or to believe that something is true
exps_longman: ['I think that you’re being unfair.', 'I thought I heard something.', 'He didn’t think anyone would believe him.', 'Do you think I should call him?', 'For some reason, I keep thinking it’s Friday today.', 'The recession lasted longer than anyone thought it would.', 'Am I right in thinking that you have a brother?', 'I can’t help thinking that he’s made a mistake.', 'Do you honestly think I would do something so stupid?', 'What do you think of your new school?', 'I thought it best to call first.', 'I thought it appropriate to invite her to speak at the meeting.', 'We must start thinking in terms of reducing costs.', 'Fraud is thought to be costing software companies millions of dollars a year.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have a particular idea or opinion about something/somebody; to believe something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Do you think (that) they’ll come?', 'I thought I heard a scream.', "I didn't think you liked sports.", 'Am I right in thinking that you used to live here?', "I think this is their house, but I'm not sure.", 'He ought to resign, I think.', "We'll need about 20 chairs, I should think.", 'It was once thought that the sun travelled around the earth.', 'What did you think about the idea?', 'Well, I like it. What do you think?', '‘Will we make it in time?’ ‘I think so.’', "‘Is he any good?’ ‘I don't think so.’", "I think it highly unlikely that I'll get the job.", 'She thought him kind and generous.', "He's thought to be one of the richest men in Europe."]

sentence: Let us hope that G1S can , in some small way , help mitigate the suffering and hardship felt by all those afflicted by the effects of hazards which , as we have learnt with bitter recent experience in the UK , can occur in an untimely fashion in the most improbable of places .
gloss: Want something to happen or be the case.
eg_sent: he's hoping for an offer of compensation
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; If you hope that something is true, or if you hope for something, you want it to be true or to happen, and you usually believe that it is possible or likely. ;
exps_collins: ['She had decided she must go on as usual, follow her normal routine, and hope and pray.', 'He hesitates before leaving, almost as though he had been hoping for conversation.', 'I hope to get a job within the next two weeks.', "The researchers hope that such a vaccine could be available in about ten years' time.", "'We'll speak again.' — 'I hope so.'", "'Will it happen again?' — 'I hope not, but you never know.'"]
bis_def_longman: to want something to happen or be true and to believe that it is possible or likely
exps_longman: ['We hope that more women will decide to join the course.', 'I do hope everything goes well.', 'It was hoped that the job would be filled by a local person.', 'Let’s just hope someone finds her bag.', 'I hope to God I haven’t left the car window open.', 'Liam decided to ignore the warning and just hope for the best.', 'I rang my parents, hoping against hope that they hadn’t left yet.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to want something to happen and think that it is possible
exps_oxford_advanced: ['We are hoping for good weather on Sunday.', 'All we can do now is wait and hope.', '‘Do you think it will rain?’ ‘I hope not.’', '‘Will you be back before dark?’ ‘I hope so, yes.’', 'The exam went better than I’d dared hope.', 'I’ll see you next week, I hope.', 'I hope (that) you’re okay.', 'I can only hope (that) there has been some mistake.', 'Detectives are hoping (that) witnesses will come forward.', "Let's hope we can find a parking space.", 'It is hoped that over £10\u2009000 will be raised.', 'She is hoping to win the gold medal.', 'We hope to arrive around two.', 'What had he hoped to achieve?']

I was in another group.", "I certainly don't remember talking to you at all.", 'I remember her being a dominant figure.', 'I remembered that we had drunk the last of the coffee the week before.', 'I can remember where and when I bought each one.', 'I used to do that when you were a little girl, remember?']

gloss: Direct one's gaze toward someone or something or in a specified direction.
eg_sent: people were looking at him
bis_def_collins: If you look in a particular direction, you direct your eyes in that direction, especially so that you can see what is there or see what something is like.
exps_collins: ['I looked down the hallway to room number nine.', 'She turned to look at him.', 'He looked away, apparently enraged.', "If you look, you'll see what was a lake.", 'If you want to say that someone is paying attention to something they can see, you say that they are looking at it or watching it. In general, you look at something that is not moving, while you watch something that is moving or changing. I asked him to look at the picture above his bed... He watched Blake run down the stairs. Look is never followed directly by an object. You must always use at or some other preposition. I looked towards the plane. You use see to talk about things that you are aware of because a visual impression reaches your eyes. You often use can in this case. I can see the fax here on the desk.']
bis_def_longman: to turn your eyes towards something, so that you can see it
exps_longman: ['We sneaked out while Jessie’s mom wasn’t looking.', 'If you look carefully you can see that the painting represents a human figure.', 'Gina covered her eyes, afraid to look.', '‘It’s time we left, ’ Ian said, looking at his watch.', 'The men all turned to look at her as she entered the room.', 'Dad looked up from his paper and smiled.', '‘We can’t go out in this weather, ’ said Bob, looking out of the window.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to turn your eyes in a particular direction

exps_collins: ['In the evening I returned to tell Phyllis our relationship was over.', 'I called Andie to tell her how spectacular the stuff looked.', 'Claire had made me promise to tell her the truth.', 'I only told the truth to the press when the single was released as it seemed the perfect time to do it.', 'Tell us about your moment on the summit.', "Her voice breaking with emotion, she told him: 'It doesn't seem fair'."]

exps_longman: ['I wish someone had told me the meeting was canceled.', 'The Chief of Police told reporters that two people were killed in the blast.', 'Jack had to go, but he didn’t tell me why.', 'I think you’d better tell me exactly what’s been going on around here.', 'No one had told them about the drug’s side effects.', 'I’ll tell you all about it when I get back.', 'She told us some funny stories about her sister.', 'Sheppard was telling the truth.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to give information to somebody by speaking or writing
exps_oxford_advanced: ['He told the news to everybody he saw.', 'He told everybody he saw the news.', 'Did she tell you her name?', 'What did I tell you? (= you should have listened to my advice)', "Why wasn't I told about the accident?", 'They’ve told us (that) they’re not coming.', 'I kept telling myself (that) everything was OK.', "Are you telling me you didn't have any help with this? (= I don't believe what you have said)", 'Tell me where you live.', "‘I'm ready to go now,’ he told her."]

sentence: While the first wave of popular interest arose with the 1982 Whitechapel exhibition instigated by Laura Mulvey and Peter Wollen , it was the publication of Hayden Herrera 's biography of Kahlo in 1983 which has led to her current cult status .

sentence: Mr Dobbs , who is chairman of Telecottages UK , warns possible users not to get bogged down with the technology : The equipment is a tool to overcome what needs to be done .

sentence: MORE than 800 Lloyd 's of London members on syndicates managed by the loss-making Gooda Walker agency have failed in their legal attempt to prevent Lloyd 's and members ' agents from drawing down their funds .

Oh, please say yes!', 'He looked as if he was going to say something.', 'I wished I had said nothing about Jordi.', 'Does anyone else have anything to say?', 'Although he didn’t say so, it was clear that he was in pain.', 'What makes you say that (=why do you think that) ? 你怎么会那么说呢？', 'Nina said to meet her at 4.30.', 'I’d like to say a few words.', '‘So what are your plans now?’ ‘I’d rather not say.’']

sentence: You see they 've got a short concentration .

bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont] ; When you see something, you notice it using your eyes. ;
exps_collins: ["You can't see colours at night.", 'I saw a man making his way towards me.', 'She can see, hear, touch, smell, and taste.', 'As he neared the farm, he saw that a police car was parked outside it.', 'Did you see what happened?', 'You use see to talk about things that you are aware of because a visual impression reaches your eyes. You often use can in this case. I can see the fax here on the desk. If you want to say that someone is paying attention to something they can see, you say that they are looking at it or watching it. In general, you look at something that is not moving, while you watch something that is moving or changing. I asked him to look at the picture above his bed... He watched Blake run down the stairs.']

sentence: They all worked with some under fives attending the schools they covered .
gloss: Put something on top of or in front of (something), especially in order to protect or conceal it.
eg_sent: the table had been covered with a checked tablecloth
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; If you cover something, you place something else over it in order to protect it, hide it, or close it. ;

sentence: People like me , who 've worked their guts out to expand the business while the militant bastards have been working their guts out to destroy it .
gloss: Be engaged in physical or mental activity in order to achieve a result; do work.

bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; People who work have a job, usually one which they are paid to do. ;;

exps_longman: ['Where do you work?', 'Many young people in the area have never worked.', 'The injury means he’ll probably never work again.', 'He works for a law firm.', 'I work at the university.', 'She works as a consultant for a design company.', 'The studies were undertaken by people working in education.', 'I work part-time in a library.']

sentence: Foul play was not suspected , " and from conflicting newspapers .
gloss: Be incompatible or at variance; clash.
eg_sent: parents' and children's interests sometimes conflict
bis_def_collins: V-RECIP  ) If ideas, beliefs, or accounts conflict, they are very different from each other and it seems impossible for them to exist together or to each be true. )
exps_collins: ['Personal ethics and professional ethics sometimes conflict.', 'He held firm opinions which usually conflicted with my own.', 'There are conflicting reports about the identity of the hostage.', '...three powers with conflicting interests.']
bis_def_longman: if two ideas, beliefs, opinions etc conflict, they cannot exist together or both be true

bis_def_oxford_advanced: if two ideas, beliefs, stories, etc. conflict, it is not possible for them to exist together or for them both to be true

sentence: But I did go out or something .

Let’s go home.', 'Where are you going?', 'We’re going to Canada in the summer.', 'Dinah went into the kitchen.', 'She went over and put her arm around him.', 'I’m going round to her house to find out what’s wrong.', 'I’ll just go up  and ask him what he wants.']

sentence: The material on which the information is printed , the typeface used , the sequence , the structure and the format generally should reflect the conditions of use , ( Easterby and Zwaga , 1984 ) .
gloss: Produce (books, newspapers, etc.), especially in large quantities, by a mechanical process involving the transfer of text or designs to paper.

sentence: He had seen these ample fields , as he had seen Cezanne 's geometric brown and green undergrowth in more than one mental hospital day room .
gloss: Perceive with the eyes; discern visually.
eg_sent: in the distance she could see the blue sea
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont] ; When you see something, you notice it using your eyes. ;
exps_collins: ["You can't see colours at night.", 'I saw a man making his way towards me.', 'She can see, hear, touch, smell, and taste.', 'As he neared the farm, he saw that a police car was parked outside it.', 'Did you see what happened?', 'You use see to talk about things that you are aware of because a visual impression reaches your eyes. You often use can in this case. I can see the fax here on the desk. If you want to say that someone is paying attention to something they can see, you say that they are looking at it or watching it. In general, you look at something that is not moving, while you watch something that is moving or changing. I asked him to look at the picture above his bed... He watched Blake run down the stairs.']
bis_def_longman: to notice or examine someone or something, using your eyes
exps_longman: ['He crouched down so he couldn’t be seen.', 'Can I see your ticket, please?', 'You can see the Houses of Parliament from here.', 'Can you see where the marks are on the wall?', 'The suspect was seen entering the building.', 'As you can see, the house needs some work doing on it.', 'Have you seen Chris ?', 'The accommodation was so awful it had to be seen to be believed.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to become aware of somebody/something by using your eyes

sentence: The thin , capable woman who was taking the riding-class looked at him in amazement as he leaned panting on the gate to the ring , the dog whining beside him .

sentence: Erm and it did n't work and you know
gloss: Be aware of through observation, inquiry, or information.

bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont]  If you know a fact, a piece of information, or an answer, you have it correctly in your mind.
exps_collins: ["I don't know the name of the place.", 'I know that you led a rifle platoon during the Second World War.', "'People like doing things for nothing.' — 'I know they do.'.", "I don't know what happened to her husband.", "'How did he meet your mother?' — 'I don't know.'.", 'We all know about his early experiments in flying.', 'They looked younger than I knew them to be.', 'Radon is known to be harmful to humans in large quantities.', 'It is not known whether the bomb was originally intended for the capital itself.', "It's always been known that key figures in the government do very well for themselves."]
bis_def_longman: to have information about something
exps_longman: ['Who knows the answer?', 'There are instructions telling you everything you need to know.', 'Didn’t you know that?', 'Do you know what time it is?', 'I don’t know where to go.', 'I need to know more about the job before I decide whether to apply for it.', 'Little is known about the author’s childhood.', 'I know all about David and what he’s been up to!', 'I wonder if he knew of the plan?', 'Do you know of any good restaurants in the area?', 'You know nothing of this business.', 'We know that greenhouse gases can affect the climate.', 'Let me know what time you’re planning to arrive.', 'I thought you’d want to know immediately.', 'If you must know, I was with James last night .', 'He slipped out of the house without his parents knowing .', 'How did he know our names?', '‘I’m divorced, as you know, ’ she said briefly.', 'Smoking is known to increase a person’s risk of developing lung cancer.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have information in your mind as a result of experience or because you have learned or been told it
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Do you know his address?', 'The cause of the fire is not yet known.', 'All I know is that she used to work in a bank (= I have no other information about her).', 'I know (that) people’s handwriting changes as they get older.', 'It is widely known that CFCs can damage the ozone layer.', 'I knew where he was hiding.', "I didn't know what he was talking about.", "‘You've got a flat tyre.’ ‘I know.’", "‘What's the answer?’ ‘I don't know.’", "‘There's no one in.’ ‘How do you know?’", "You know about Amanda's baby, don't you?", "I don't know about you, but I'm ready for something to eat.", 'I know of at least two people who did the same thing.', '‘Is anyone else coming?’ ‘Not that I know of.’', '‘Isn’t that his car?’ ‘I wouldn’t know./How should I know?’ (= I don’t know and I am not the person you should ask.)', "‘What are you two whispering about?’ ‘You don't want to know’ (= because you would be shocked or wouldn't approve).", 'Does he know to come here (= that he should come here) first?', 'We know her to be honest.', 'Two women are known to have died.']

sentence: High arched walls of pale , honey-coloured stone were hung with bluish-green tapestries ; around the big stone fireplace , where logs burned in winter , stood sofas covered in the blues and greens of the tapestries ; here and there were lamps , flowers , books , and piles of parlour games .

gloss: Move at a regular pace by lifting and setting down each foot in turn, never having both feet off the ground at once.

bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; When you walk, you move forward by putting one foot in front of the other in a regular way. ;;
exps_collins: ['Rosanna and Forbes walked in silence for some while.', 'We walked into the foyer.', 'She turned and walked away.', 'They would stop the car and walk a few steps.', 'When I was your age I walked five miles to school.']
bis_def_longman: to move forward by putting one foot in front of the other
exps_longman: ['‘How did you get here?’ ‘We walked.’', 'Doctors said he’d never walk again.', 'Carrie walked into the room and sat down in her chair.', 'He loved walking in the hills.', 'We must have walked ten miles today.', 'I walked all the way to San Rafael.', 'There are plenty of bars and restaurants within walking distance of the hotel.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to move or go somewhere by putting one foot in front of the other on the ground, but without running
exps_oxford_advanced: ['The baby is just learning to walk.', '‘How did you get here?’ ‘I walked.’', 'He walked slowly away from her.', 'The door opened and Jo walked in.', 'She missed the bus and had to walk home.', 'The school is within easy walking distance of the train station.', 'Children here walk several miles to school.']

sentence: During the 1985 riots and their immediate aftermath , the imagery of race was used by sections of the press without the sense of ambiguity which could still be found in 1980Î__ê1 .
gloss: Take, hold, or deploy (something) as a means of accomplishing or achieving something; employ.
eg_sent: she used her key to open the front door
bis_def_collins: If you use something, you do something with it in order to do a job or to achieve a particular result or effect.  [written]
exps_collins: ['Trim off the excess pastry using a sharp knife.', 'He had simply used a little imagination.', 'Officials used loud hailers to call for calm.', "The show uses Zondo's trial and execution as its framework."]
bis_def_longman: if you use a particular tool, method, service, ability etc, you do something with that tool, by means of that method etc, for a particular purpose
exps_longman: ['Can I use your phone?', 'I’ll show you which room you can use.', 'I always use the same shampoo.', 'She booked the flight using a false name.', 'Drop-down menus make the program very easy to use.', 'They were using animals for scientific experiments.', 'Bob uses the van for picking up groceries.', 'My parents use the house as a holiday home.', 'Most people now use their cars to go shopping.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to do something with a machine, a method, an object, etc. for a particular purpose
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Can I use your phone?', 'Have you ever used this software before?', 'How often do you use (= travel by) the bus?', 'They were able to achieve a settlement without using military force.', 'The applicator makes the glue easy to use.', 'The oven looked as if it had never been used.', 'I have some information you may be able to use (= to get an advantage from).', 'We used a carrot for the snowman’s nose.', 'The blue files are used for storing old invoices.', 'Police used tear gas to disperse the crowds.', 'The building is currently being used as a warehouse.', "You can't keep using your bad back as an excuse."]

sentence: Damn it , you knew about it for long enough , snapped the Exec Director .
gloss: (in Christian belief) be condemned by God to suffer eternal punishment in hell.
eg_sent: be forever damned with Lucifer
bis_def_collins: VERB  () If you say that a person or a news report damns something such as a policy or action, you mean that they are very critical of it. ()
exps_collins: ['...a sensational book in which she damns the ultra-right party.', '...a report damning the chocolate advertising people for targeting women in their campaigns.']
bis_def_longman: used when you are extremely angry or annoyed with someone or something
exps_longman: ['Stop, damn you!']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: used when swearing at somebody/something to show that you are angry
exps_oxford_advanced: ["Damn you! I'm not going to let you bully me.", "Damn this machine! Why won't it work?"]

sentence: John of Marmoutier 's life of Geoffrey le Bel offers a glimpse of how strong bonds were created between the prince and his followers within the household , and how a high level of training was maintained at all times .
gloss: Present or proffer (something) for (someone) to accept or reject as desired.
eg_sent: may I offer you a drink?
bis_def_collins: If you offer something to someone, you ask them if they would like to have it or use it.
exps_collins: ['He has offered seats at the conference table to the Russian leader and the president of Kazakhstan.', 'The number of companies offering them work increased.', 'Rhys offered him an apple.', 'Western governments have offered aid.']
