exps_longman: ['Can I offer you something to drink?', 'They offered him a very good job, but he turned it down.', 'Maureen lit a cigarette and offered one to Lucy.', 'The drama school offers places to students who can show talent.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to say that you are willing to do something for somebody or give something to somebody
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Josie had offered her services as a guide.', 'He offered some useful advice.', "I don't think they need help, but I think I should offer anyway.", 'He offered $4\u2009000 for the car.', 'They are offering a reward for the return of their cat.', 'They decided to offer the job to Jo.', 'They decided to offer Jo the job.', 'I gratefully took the cup of coffee she offered me.', 'Taylor offered him 500 dollars to do the work.', 'The kids offered to do the dishes.', "‘I'll do it,’ she offered."]

sentence: We goes up town the following week then to get and I forget what I was looking for , oh it was I was looking for your blouse
gloss: Come to have (something); receive.
eg_sent: I got a letter from him the other day
bis_def_collins: You use get with adjectives to mean 'become'. For example, if someone gets cold, they become cold, and if they get angry, they become angry.

sentence: But the rule was confirmed by the Criminal Law Revision Committee in 1980 , on the ground that a defendant should not be left in peril of a homicide conviction indefinitely .

sentence: At Battersea , Scott could not alter the basic design of the building and he much disliked the upturned table appearance created by the four corner chimneys .

gloss: Move or travel towards or into a place thought of as near or familiar to the speaker.

sentence: I do n't know she just said
gloss: Be aware of through observation, inquiry, or information.
eg_sent: most people know that CFCs can damage the ozone layer
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont]  If you know a fact, a piece of information, or an answer, you have it correctly in your mind.
exps_collins: ["I don't know the name of the place.", 'I know that you led a rifle platoon during the Second World War.', "'People like doing things for nothing.' — 'I know they do.'.", "I don't know what happened to her husband.", "'How did he meet your mother?' — 'I don't know.'.", 'We all know about his early experiments in flying.', 'They looked younger than I knew them to be.', 'Radon is known to be harmful to humans in large quantities.', 'It is not known whether the bomb was originally intended for the capital itself.', "It's always been known that key figures in the government do very well for themselves."]
bis_def_longman: to have information about something
exps_longman: ['Who knows the answer?', 'There are instructions telling you everything you need to know.', 'Didn’t you know that?', 'Do you know what time it is?', 'I don’t know where to go.', 'I need to know more about the job before I decide whether to apply for it.', 'Little is known about the author’s childhood.', 'I know all about David and what he’s been up to!', 'I wonder if he knew of the plan?', 'Do you know of any good restaurants in the area?', 'You know nothing of this business.', 'We know that greenhouse gases can affect the climate.', 'Let me know what time you’re planning to arrive.', 'I thought you’d want to know immediately.', 'If you must know, I was with James last night .', 'He slipped out of the house without his parents knowing .', 'How did he know our names?', '‘I’m divorced, as you know, ’ she said briefly.', 'Smoking is known to increase a person’s risk of developing lung cancer.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have information in your mind as a result of experience or because you have learned or been told it
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Do you know his address?', 'The cause of the fire is not yet known.', 'All I know is that she used to work in a bank (= I have no other information about her).', 'I know (that) people’s handwriting changes as they get older.', 'It is widely known that CFCs can damage the ozone layer.', 'I knew where he was hiding.', "I didn't know what he was talking about.", "‘You've got a flat tyre.’ ‘I know.’", "‘What's the answer?’ ‘I don't know.’", "‘There's no one in.’ ‘How do you know?’", "You know about Amanda's baby, don't you?", "I don't know about you, but I'm ready for something to eat.", 'I know of at least two people who did the same thing.', '‘Is anyone else coming?’ ‘Not that I know of.’', '‘Isn’t that his car?’ ‘I wouldn’t know./How should I know?’ (= I don’t know and I am not the person you should ask.)', "‘What are you two whispering about?’ ‘You don't want to know’ (= because you would be shocked or wouldn't approve).", 'Does he know to come here (= that he should come here) first?', 'We know her to be honest.', 'Two women are known to have died.']

Oh, please say yes!', 'He looked as if he was going to say something.', 'I wished I had said nothing about Jordi.', 'Does anyone else have anything to say?', 'Although he didn’t say so, it was clear that he was in pain.', 'What makes you say that (=why do you think that) ? 你怎么会那么说呢？', 'Nina said to meet her at 4.30.', 'I’d like to say a few words.', '‘So what are your plans now?’ ‘I’d rather not say.’']

sentence: People had been shocked , by numbers as well as by gratuitous death itself , as people will be , and Mrs Maguire 's sister and a friend had founded the Peace People , whose brave beginning and sad end will not be chronicled here .

sentence: Do you want it , do you want a bungalow ?
gloss: Have a desire to possess or do (something); wish for.
eg_sent: I want an apple
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont, no passive] ; If you want something, you feel a desire or a need for it. ;
exps_collins: ['I want a drink.', 'Ian knows exactly what he wants in life.', 'People wanted to know who this talented designer was.', 'They began to want their father to be the same as other daddies.', "They didn't want people staring at them as they sat on the lawn, so they put up high walls.", 'He wanted his power recognised.', 'I want my car this colour.', 'And remember, we want him alive.', "Note that want and wish have similar meanings, but are used differently. If you want something, you feel a need for it or a desire to have it. You can say that you want to do something, that you want someone to do something, or that you want something to happen. If you use wish with a 'to' infinitive, this has the same meaning as want but is more formal. I want to get out of here... She wished to consult him about her future."]
bis_def_longman: to have a desire for something
exps_longman: ['I really want a drink.', 'What do you want for your birthday?', 'She’d always wanted to go to Thailand.', 'I don’t want Linda to  hear about this.', 'He didn’t want the holiday to end.', 'You can order whatever you want.', 'This shampoo is mild enough to use every day if you want.', 'If she doesn’t get what she wants, she’s not happy.', 'He wanted that job so badly he was willing to kill for it.', 'They desperately wanted a son.', 'What I want to know is when we’re going to get paid.', 'All I want is the chance to prove myself.', 'Oh thank you, it’s just what I’ve always wanted.']

sentence: Because of this , he had never seen the Oxford and Cambridge boat race until this year .
gloss: Perceive with the eyes; discern visually.
eg_sent: in the distance she could see the blue sea
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont] ; When you see something, you notice it using your eyes. ;
exps_collins: ["You can't see colours at night.", 'I saw a man making his way towards me.', 'She can see, hear, touch, smell, and taste.', 'As he neared the farm, he saw that a police car was parked outside it.', 'Did you see what happened?', 'You use see to talk about things that you are aware of because a visual impression reaches your eyes. You often use can in this case. I can see the fax here on the desk. If you want to say that someone is paying attention to something they can see, you say that they are looking at it or watching it. In general, you look at something that is not moving, while you watch something that is moving or changing. I asked him to look at the picture above his bed... He watched Blake run down the stairs.']
bis_def_longman: to notice or examine someone or something, using your eyes
exps_longman: ['He crouched down so he couldn’t be seen.', 'Can I see your ticket, please?', 'You can see the Houses of Parliament from here.', 'Can you see where the marks are on the wall?', 'The suspect was seen entering the building.', 'As you can see, the house needs some work doing on it.', 'Have you seen Chris ?', 'The accommodation was so awful it had to be seen to be believed.']

sentence: You know , like you said this and you have n't done it , you said that and you have n't done it and all that sort of .
gloss: Be aware of through observation, inquiry, or information.
eg_sent: most people know that CFCs can damage the ozone layer
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont]  If you know a fact, a piece of information, or an answer, you have it correctly in your mind.
exps_collins: ["I don't know the name of the place.", 'I know that you led a rifle platoon during the Second World War.', "'People like doing things for nothing.' — 'I know they do.'.", "I don't know what happened to her husband.", "'How did he meet your mother?' — 'I don't know.'.", 'We all know about his early experiments in flying.', 'They looked younger than I knew them to be.', 'Radon is known to be harmful to humans in large quantities.', 'It is not known whether the bomb was originally intended for the capital itself.', "It's always been known that key figures in the government do very well for themselves."]
bis_def_longman: to have information about something
exps_longman: ['Who knows the answer?', 'There are instructions telling you everything you need to know.', 'Didn’t you know that?', 'Do you know what time it is?', 'I don’t know where to go.', 'I need to know more about the job before I decide whether to apply for it.', 'Little is known about the author’s childhood.', 'I know all about David and what he’s been up to!', 'I wonder if he knew of the plan?', 'Do you know of any good restaurants in the area?', 'You know nothing of this business.', 'We know that greenhouse gases can affect the climate.', 'Let me know what time you’re planning to arrive.', 'I thought you’d want to know immediately.', 'If you must know, I was with James last night .', 'He slipped out of the house without his parents knowing .', 'How did he know our names?', '‘I’m divorced, as you know, ’ she said briefly.', 'Smoking is known to increase a person’s risk of developing lung cancer.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have information in your mind as a result of experience or because you have learned or been told it
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Do you know his address?', 'The cause of the fire is not yet known.', 'All I know is that she used to work in a bank (= I have no other information about her).', 'I know (that) people’s handwriting changes as they get older.', 'It is widely known that CFCs can damage the ozone layer.', 'I knew where he was hiding.', "I didn't know what he was talking about.", "‘You've got a flat tyre.’ ‘I know.’", "‘What's the answer?’ ‘I don't know.’", "‘There's no one in.’ ‘How do you know?’", "You know about Amanda's baby, don't you?", "I don't know about you, but I'm ready for something to eat.", 'I know of at least two people who did the same thing.', '‘Is anyone else coming?’ ‘Not that I know of.’', '‘Isn’t that his car?’ ‘I wouldn’t know./How should I know?’ (= I don’t know and I am not the person you should ask.)', "‘What are you two whispering about?’ ‘You don't want to know’ (= because you would be shocked or wouldn't approve).", 'Does he know to come here (= that he should come here) first?', 'We know her to be honest.', 'Two women are known to have died.']

sentence: The use of role play , incorporating previously discussed difficulties ( i.e. homework assignment session 4 ) in real or set up situations provides an opportunity for testing these skills .
gloss: Talk about (something) with a person or people.

sentence: Mr Smith 's warning coincided with a call by Ken Livingstone , the Labour MP for Brent East , who said on London Weekend Television 's The Walden Interview : You can be miles ahead in the polls , but when you get to the last three weeks , people think , Can I afford a Labour government ?
gloss: Come to have (something); receive.
eg_sent: I got a letter from him the other day
bis_def_collins: You use get with adjectives to mean 'become'. For example, if someone gets cold, they become cold, and if they get angry, they become angry.
exps_collins: ['The boys were getting bored.', "There's no point in getting upset.", 'From here on, it can only get better.']
bis_def_longman: to receive something that someone gives you or sends you
exps_longman: ['She got loads of presents.', 'What did you get for Christmas?', 'We get a lot of junk mail.', 'We got a letter from Pam this morning.', 'I got it off my Dad.', 'I got a few games free when I bought my computer.']

sentence: It 's all so ridiculous that we 're not going to even think about it any more , she said firmly , hiding her fears .

bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont] ; If you think that something is the case, you have the opinion that it is the case. ; [Also VERB n to-infinitive]

exps_longman: ['I think that you’re being unfair.', 'I thought I heard something.', 'He didn’t think anyone would believe him.', 'Do you think I should call him?', 'For some reason, I keep thinking it’s Friday today.', 'The recession lasted longer than anyone thought it would.', 'Am I right in thinking that you have a brother?', 'I can’t help thinking that he’s made a mistake.', 'Do you honestly think I would do something so stupid?', 'What do you think of your new school?', 'I thought it best to call first.', 'I thought it appropriate to invite her to speak at the meeting.', 'We must start thinking in terms of reducing costs.', 'Fraud is thought to be costing software companies millions of dollars a year.']

exps_collins: ["'I'm sorry,' he said.", 'She said they were very impressed.', 'Forty-one people are said to have been seriously hurt.', 'I packed and said goodbye to Charlie.', "I hope you didn't say anything about Gretchen.", "You didn't say much when you telephoned.", 'Did he say where he was going?.', "It doesn't sound exactly orthodox, if I may say so."]

Oh, please say yes!', 'He looked as if he was going to say something.', 'I wished I had said nothing about Jordi.', 'Does anyone else have anything to say?', 'Although he didn’t say so, it was clear that he was in pain.', 'What makes you say that (=why do you think that) ? 你怎么会那么说呢？', 'Nina said to meet her at 4.30.', 'I’d like to say a few words.', '‘So what are your plans now?’ ‘I’d rather not say.’']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to speak or tell somebody something, using words
exps_oxford_advanced: ['‘Hello!’ she said.', '‘That was marvellous,’ said Daniel.', 'Be quiet, I have something to say.', "I didn't believe a word she said.", "That's a terrible thing to say.", "He knew that if he wasn't back by midnight, his parents would have something to say about it (= be angry).", 'She said nothing to me about it.', "I said to myself (= thought), ‘That can't be right!’", 'He said (that) his name was Sam.', 'It is said that she lived to be over 100.', 'She finds it hard to say what she feels.', "‘That's impossible!’ ‘So you say (= but I think you may be wrong).’", "‘Why can't I go out now?’ ‘Because I say so.’", "‘What do you want it for?’ ‘I'd rather not say.’", 'He said to meet him here.', 'He is said to have been a brilliant scholar.']

sentence: Straightening up beside the dog , he looked where she was looking , and blinked .
gloss: Direct one's gaze toward someone or something or in a specified direction.
eg_sent: people were looking at him
bis_def_collins: If you look in a particular direction, you direct your eyes in that direction, especially so that you can see what is there or see what something is like.
exps_collins: ['I looked down the hallway to room number nine.', 'She turned to look at him.', 'He looked away, apparently enraged.', "If you look, you'll see what was a lake.", 'If you want to say that someone is paying attention to something they can see, you say that they are looking at it or watching it. In general, you look at something that is not moving, while you watch something that is moving or changing. I asked him to look at the picture above his bed... He watched Blake run down the stairs. Look is never followed directly by an object. You must always use at or some other preposition. I looked towards the plane. You use see to talk about things that you are aware of because a visual impression reaches your eyes. You often use can in this case. I can see the fax here on the desk.']
bis_def_longman: to turn your eyes towards something, so that you can see it
exps_longman: ['We sneaked out while Jessie’s mom wasn’t looking.', 'If you look carefully you can see that the painting represents a human figure.', 'Gina covered her eyes, afraid to look.', '‘It’s time we left, ’ Ian said, looking at his watch.', 'The men all turned to look at her as she entered the room.', 'Dad looked up from his paper and smiled.', '‘We can’t go out in this weather, ’ said Bob, looking out of the window.']

sentence: The Imperial Cancer Research Fund and the Cancer Research Campaign are conducting a joint study of the Bristol Cancer Help Centre , which offers a holistic programme dietary advice and emotional counselling to complement medical treatment .
gloss: Present or proffer (something) for (someone) to accept or reject as desired.

bis_def_collins: If you offer something to someone, you ask them if they would like to have it or use it.
exps_collins: ['He has offered seats at the conference table to the Russian leader and the president of Kazakhstan.', 'The number of companies offering them work increased.', 'Rhys offered him an apple.', 'Western governments have offered aid.']

sentence: This species is preserved in a soft shale , but one which allows for the skeletal anatomy to be preserved in its entirety .

Let’s go home.', 'Where are you going?', 'We’re going to Canada in the summer.', 'Dinah went into the kitchen.', 'She went over and put her arm around him.', 'I’m going round to her house to find out what’s wrong.', 'I’ll just go up  and ask him what he wants.']

sentence: Delaney averted his gaze from her , afraid of what he had seen in her eyes .
gloss: Perceive with the eyes; discern visually.
eg_sent: in the distance she could see the blue sea
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont] ; When you see something, you notice it using your eyes. ;
exps_collins: ["You can't see colours at night.", 'I saw a man making his way towards me.', 'She can see, hear, touch, smell, and taste.', 'As he neared the farm, he saw that a police car was parked outside it.', 'Did you see what happened?', 'You use see to talk about things that you are aware of because a visual impression reaches your eyes. You often use can in this case. I can see the fax here on the desk. If you want to say that someone is paying attention to something they can see, you say that they are looking at it or watching it. In general, you look at something that is not moving, while you watch something that is moving or changing. I asked him to look at the picture above his bed... He watched Blake run down the stairs.']
bis_def_longman: to notice or examine someone or something, using your eyes
exps_longman: ['He crouched down so he couldn’t be seen.', 'Can I see your ticket, please?', 'You can see the Houses of Parliament from here.', 'Can you see where the marks are on the wall?', 'The suspect was seen entering the building.', 'As you can see, the house needs some work doing on it.', 'Have you seen Chris ?', 'The accommodation was so awful it had to be seen to be believed.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to become aware of somebody/something by using your eyes
exps_oxford_advanced: ["She looked for him but couldn't see him in the crowd.", 'I looked out of the window but saw nothing.', 'The opera was the place to see and be seen (= by other important or fashionable people).', 'He could see (that) she had been crying.', 'Did you see what happened?', 'If you watch carefully, you’ll see how it is done.', 'I hate to see you unhappy.', 'She was seen running away from the scene of the crime.', 'I saw you put the key in your pocket.', 'He was seen to enter the building about the time the crime was committed.']

sentence: Take a look for yourself .

sentence: But people seem to think that stories are written to a prescription , that you sit down and say , you do n't want it to be sexist , you do n't want it to be racist .
gloss: Have a desire to possess or do (something); wish for.

bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont, no passive] ; If you want something, you feel a desire or a need for it. ;
exps_collins: ['I want a drink.', 'Ian knows exactly what he wants in life.', 'People wanted to know who this talented designer was.', 'They began to want their father to be the same as other daddies.', "They didn't want people staring at them as they sat on the lawn, so they put up high walls.", 'He wanted his power recognised.', 'I want my car this colour.', 'And remember, we want him alive.', "Note that want and wish have similar meanings, but are used differently. If you want something, you feel a need for it or a desire to have it. You can say that you want to do something, that you want someone to do something, or that you want something to happen. If you use wish with a 'to' infinitive, this has the same meaning as want but is more formal. I want to get out of here... She wished to consult him about her future."]

sentence: An argument by many atmospheric physicists , for example , is that shortcomings in the accuracy of weather prediction over periods of more than a few days largely results from the unsophisticated nature of existing models , the lack of suitable data and inadequate computer power ( see Fig. 9.3 , derived from Tyler 1989 ) .
gloss: Have objective reality or being.
eg_sent: dossiers existed on almost everyone of prominence
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont] ; If something exists, it is present in the world as a real thing. ;
exps_collins: ["He thought that if he couldn't see something, it didn't exist.", 'Research opportunities exist in a wide range of pure and applied areas of entomology.', 'When Alfred Adler first postulated in 1908 that there existed an inborn instinct of aggression Freud argued against it.']
bis_def_longman: to happen or be present in a particular situation or place
exps_longman: ['The custom of arranged marriages still exists in many countries.', 'Opportunities exist for students to gain sponsorship.', 'Stop pretending that the problem doesn’t exist.', 'The club will cease to exist if financial help is not found.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to be real; to be present in a place or situation
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Does life exist on other planets?', 'The problem only exists in your head, Jane.', 'Few of these monkeys still exist in the wild.', 'On his retirement the post will cease to exist.', 'The charity exists to support victims of crime.']

sentence: getting paid again .
gloss: Come to have (something); receive.
eg_sent: I got a letter from him the other day
bis_def_collins: You use get with adjectives to mean 'become'. For example, if someone gets cold, they become cold, and if they get angry, they become angry.
exps_collins: ['The boys were getting bored.', "There's no point in getting upset.", 'From here on, it can only get better.']
bis_def_longman: to receive something that someone gives you or sends you
exps_longman: ['She got loads of presents.', 'What did you get for Christmas?', 'We get a lot of junk mail.', 'We got a letter from Pam this morning.', 'I got it off my Dad.', 'I got a few games free when I bought my computer.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to receive something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['I got a letter from Dave this morning.', 'What (= What presents) did you get for your birthday?', 'He gets (= earns) about $40\u2009000 a year.', 'This room gets very little sunshine.', 'I got a shock when I saw the bill.', 'I get the impression that he is bored with his job.']

sentence: While the entire network of popular committees , local institutions and the general public constitute the field commanders in the battle of civilian disobedience and of constructing a political infrastructure , a rotating Unified National Command acts in the role of field-general , issuing a bi-monthly directive outlining policy and determining specific resistance programmes .
gloss: Be (a part) of a whole.
eg_sent: lone parents constitute a great proportion of the poor
bis_def_collins: V-LINK  [no cont] ; If something constitutes a particular thing, it can be regarded as being that thing. ;
exps_collins: ['Testing patients without their consent would constitute a professional and legal offence.', 'The vote hardly constitutes a victory.', 'What constitutes abuse?']
bis_def_longman: to be considered to be something
exps_longman: ['Failing to complete the work constitutes a breach of the employment contract.', 'The rise in crime constitutes a threat to society.']

sentence: The National 's Boris Godunov was built around Ognovenko ; he had to stay home .
gloss: Remain in the same place.

bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; If you stay where you are, you continue to be there and do not leave. ;;
exps_collins: ["'Stay here,' Trish said. 'I'll bring the car down the drive to take you back.'.", 'In the old days the woman stayed at home and the man earned the money.']

exps_longman: ['They stayed all afternoon chatting.', 'I decided to stay home.', 'Isabel stayed for a year in Paris to study.', 'She stayed late to finish the report.', 'Why don’t you stay for supper?', 'Some of the students stayed after class  to talk.', 'I should stay and help.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to continue to be in a particular place for a period of time without moving away
exps_oxford_advanced: ['to stay in bed', "‘Do you want a drink?’ ‘No, thanks, I can't stay.’", "Stay there and don't move!", 'We ended up staying for lunch.', 'She stayed at home (= did not go out to work) while the children were young.', "I'm staying late at the office tonight.", "My hat won't stay on!", 'Can you stay behind after the others have gone and help me clear up?', 'I can stay a few minutes longer.', 'We stayed to see what would happen.', 'They stayed talking until well into the night.']

sentence: Consider the structure of their legs .
gloss: Think carefully about (something), typically before making a decision.
eg_sent: each application is considered on its merits
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; If you consider a person or thing to be something, you have the opinion that this is what they are. ;
exps_collins: ["We don't consider our customers to be mere consumers; we consider them to be our friends.", 'I had always considered myself a strong, competent woman.', 'The paper does not explain why foreign ownership should be considered bad.', 'I consider activities such as jogging and weightlifting as unnatural.', 'Barbara considers that pet shops which sell customers these birds are very unfair.']
bis_def_longman: to think about something carefully, especially before making a choice or decision
exps_longman: ['I seriously considered resigning .', 'Have you considered the possibility of retraining?', 'We are considering whether to change our advice to tourists.', 'We’re still considering where to move to.', 'We will have to consider your offer carefully.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to think about something carefully, especially in order to make a decision
exps_oxford_advanced: ["I'd like some time to consider.", 'She considered her options.', 'Let us consider the facts.', 'He was considering an appeal.', 'a carefully considered response', 'The company is being actively considered as a potential partner (= it is thought possible that it could become one).', "We're considering buying a new car.", 'You wouldn’t consider marrying a man for his money, then?', 'We need to consider how the law might be reformed.', 'He was considering what to do next.']

sentence: If , in addition to finding a tenant , the agency is managing the let , you should be paid every month , less a tenant-finding fee of between two and four weeks ' rent .
gloss: Give (someone) money that is due for work done, goods received, or a debt incurred.
eg_sent: the traveller paid a guide to show him across
bis_def_collins: When you pay an amount of money to someone, you give it to them because you are buying something from them or because you owe it to them. When you pay something such as a bill or a debt, you pay the amount that you owe.
exps_collins: ['Accommodation is free — all you pay for is breakfast and dinner.', 'We paid £35 for each ticket.', 'The wealthier may have to pay a little more in taxes.', 'He proposes that businesses should pay taxes to the federal government.', 'You can pay by credit card.']
bis_def_longman: to give someone money for something you buy or for a service
exps_longman: ['How would you like to pay?', 'Mum paid for my driving lessons.', 'You’d get a discount for paying cash.', 'Can I pay by credit card?', 'He didn’t even offer to pay me for the ticket.', 'Ray paid some kids to wash the car.', 'I paid him $5 to cut the grass.', 'He wanted to be paid in dollars.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to give somebody money for work, goods, services, etc.
exps_oxford_advanced: ["I'll pay for the tickets.", 'Are you paying in cash or by credit card?', 'My company pays well (= pays high salaries).', 'Her parents paid for her to go to Canada.', 'to pay cash', 'She pays £200 a week for this apartment.', 'Would you mind paying the taxi driver?', "He still hasn't paid me the money he owes me.", "I'm paid $100 a day.", "I don't pay you to sit around all day doing nothing!"]

exps_longman: ['There’s nothing more we can do here. Let’s go home.', 'Where are you going?', 'We’re going to Canada in the summer.', 'Dinah went into the kitchen.', 'She went over and put her arm around him.', 'I’m going round to her house to find out what’s wrong.', 'I’ll just go up  and ask him what he wants.']

sentence: " Not to be mentioned in the same breath with " she said , looking nervously from Frederica to painted signature .
gloss: Direct one's gaze toward someone or something or in a specified direction.
eg_sent: people were looking at him
bis_def_collins: If you look in a particular direction, you direct your eyes in that direction, especially so that you can see what is there or see what something is like.
exps_collins: ['I looked down the hallway to room number nine.', 'She turned to look at him.', 'He looked away, apparently enraged.', "If you look, you'll see what was a lake.", 'If you want to say that someone is paying attention to something they can see, you say that they are looking at it or watching it. In general, you look at something that is not moving, while you watch something that is moving or changing. I asked him to look at the picture above his bed... He watched Blake run down the stairs. Look is never followed directly by an object. You must always use at or some other preposition. I looked towards the plane. You use see to talk about things that you are aware of because a visual impression reaches your eyes. You often use can in this case. I can see the fax here on the desk.']
bis_def_longman: to turn your eyes towards something, so that you can see it
exps_longman: ['We sneaked out while Jessie’s mom wasn’t looking.', 'If you look carefully you can see that the painting represents a human figure.', 'Gina covered her eyes, afraid to look.', '‘It’s time we left, ’ Ian said, looking at his watch.', 'The men all turned to look at her as she entered the room.', 'Dad looked up from his paper and smiled.', '‘We can’t go out in this weather, ’ said Bob, looking out of the window.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to turn your eyes in a particular direction
exps_oxford_advanced: ['If you look carefully you can just see our house from here.', 'She looked at me and smiled.', "‘Has the mail come yet?’ ‘I'll look and see.’", "Look! I'm sure that's Brad Pitt!", "Don't look now, but there's someone staring at you!"]

sentence: And I suppose I better get er Carl 's birthday card while I 'm at it .
gloss: Come to have (something); receive.

bis_def_collins: You use get with adjectives to mean 'become'. For example, if someone gets cold, they become cold, and if they get angry, they become angry.

bis_def_longman: to receive something that someone gives you or sends you
exps_longman: ['She got loads of presents.', 'What did you get for Christmas?', 'We get a lot of junk mail.', 'We got a letter from Pam this morning.', 'I got it off my Dad.', 'I got a few games free when I bought my computer.']

sentence: No one appeared as he drew up and , before lifting his hand to the bell , he paused to read the words of a stone plaque embedded in the flints to the right of the door .

sentence: Putting it into gear , his arm brushed her knee .
gloss: Remove (dust or dirt) by sweeping or scrubbing.

sentence: The armed robber might say that he had no intention of using the firearm , that he carried it with him simply to frighten the victim , and that it went off accidentally : if the jury believes that , should he be convicted of murder ?
gloss: Accept that (something) is true, especially without proof.

sentence: It 's still , you know silly little things
gloss: Be aware of through observation, inquiry, or information.

exps_longman: ['Who knows the answer?', 'There are instructions telling you everything you need to know.', 'Didn’t you know that?', 'Do you know what time it is?', 'I don’t know where to go.', 'I need to know more about the job before I decide whether to apply for it.', 'Little is known about the author’s childhood.', 'I know all about David and what he’s been up to!', 'I wonder if he knew of the plan?', 'Do you know of any good restaurants in the area?', 'You know nothing of this business.', 'We know that greenhouse gases can affect the climate.', 'Let me know what time you’re planning to arrive.', 'I thought you’d want to know immediately.', 'If you must know, I was with James last night .', 'He slipped out of the house without his parents knowing .', 'How did he know our names?', '‘I’m divorced, as you know, ’ she said briefly.', 'Smoking is known to increase a person’s risk of developing lung cancer.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have information in your mind as a result of experience or because you have learned or been told it
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Do you know his address?', 'The cause of the fire is not yet known.', 'All I know is that she used to work in a bank (= I have no other information about her).', 'I know (that) people’s handwriting changes as they get older.', 'It is widely known that CFCs can damage the ozone layer.', 'I knew where he was hiding.', "I didn't know what he was talking about.", "‘You've got a flat tyre.’ ‘I know.’", "‘What's the answer?’ ‘I don't know.’", "‘There's no one in.’ ‘How do you know?’", "You know about Amanda's baby, don't you?", "I don't know about you, but I'm ready for something to eat.", 'I know of at least two people who did the same thing.', '‘Is anyone else coming?’ ‘Not that I know of.’', '‘Isn’t that his car?’ ‘I wouldn’t know./How should I know?’ (= I don’t know and I am not the person you should ask.)', "‘What are you two whispering about?’ ‘You don't want to know’ (= because you would be shocked or wouldn't approve).", 'Does he know to come here (= that he should come here) first?', 'We know her to be honest.', 'Two women are known to have died.']

eg_sent: a white blouse will show the blood
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; If something shows that a state of affairs exists, it gives information that proves it or makes it clear to people. ;;
exps_collins: ['Research shows that a high-fibre diet may protect you from bowel cancer.', 'He was arrested at his home in Southampton after a breath test showed he had drunk more than twice the legal limit for driving.', 'These figures show an increase of over one million in unemployment.', 'It was only later that the drug was shown to be addictive.', "You'll be given regular blood tests to show whether you have been infected."]
bis_def_longman: to let someone see something
exps_longman: ['The children proudly showed me their presents.', 'The man grinned, showing bad teeth.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to make something clear; to prove something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['The figures clearly show that her claims are false.', "The government's popularity is declining rapidly, as the opinion polls show.", 'Market research has shown us that people want quality, not just low prices.', 'a report showing the company’s current situation', 'His new book shows him to be a first-rate storyteller.', 'This shows how people are influenced by TV advertisements.']

sentence: Party organisers want the conference to show that the party is united as never before , leaving Mr Kinnock free for the first time to sell the policy package to voters without worrying about splits .
gloss: Come or bring together for a common purpose or action.
eg_sent: he called on the party to unite
bis_def_collins: If a group of people or things unite or if something unites them, they join together and act as a group.
exps_collins: ['The two parties have been trying to unite since the New Year.', 'The vast majority of nations have agreed to unite their efforts to bring peace.']
bis_def_longman: if different people or organizations unite, or if something unites them, they join together in order to achieve something
exps_longman: ['Our goal is to unite the opposition parties and defeat the president.', 'Party members united behind their leader.', 'In 1960, the regions united to form the Somali Republic.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to join together with other people in order to do something as a group
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Local resident groups have united in opposition to the plan.', 'We will unite in fighting crime.', 'Will they unite behind the new leader?', "Nationalist parties united to oppose the government's plans."]

sentence: Oh I did n't show you it .
gloss: Allow or cause (something) to be visible.

sentence: Children , after all , he thought , looking at Abigail , were happy wherever they were , so long as they were loved
gloss: Have a particular opinion, belief, or idea about someone or something.
eg_sent: she thought that nothing would be the same again
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont] ; If you think that something is the case, you have the opinion that it is the case. ; [Also VERB n to-infinitive]
exps_collins: ['I certainly think there should be a ban on tobacco advertising.', 'Do you think I ought to seal the boxes up?.', 'A generation ago, it was thought that babies born this small could not survive.', 'Tell me, what do you think of my theory?.', 'Peter is useless, far worse than I thought.', 'He manages a good deal better than I thought possible.', "'It ought to be stopped.' — 'Yes, I think so.'"]
bis_def_longman: to have a particular opinion or to believe that something is true
exps_longman: ['I think that you’re being unfair.', 'I thought I heard something.', 'He didn’t think anyone would believe him.', 'Do you think I should call him?', 'For some reason, I keep thinking it’s Friday today.', 'The recession lasted longer than anyone thought it would.', 'Am I right in thinking that you have a brother?', 'I can’t help thinking that he’s made a mistake.', 'Do you honestly think I would do something so stupid?', 'What do you think of your new school?', 'I thought it best to call first.', 'I thought it appropriate to invite her to speak at the meeting.', 'We must start thinking in terms of reducing costs.', 'Fraud is thought to be costing software companies millions of dollars a year.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have a particular idea or opinion about something/somebody; to believe something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Do you think (that) they’ll come?', 'I thought I heard a scream.', "I didn't think you liked sports.", 'Am I right in thinking that you used to live here?', "I think this is their house, but I'm not sure.", 'He ought to resign, I think.', "We'll need about 20 chairs, I should think.", 'It was once thought that the sun travelled around the earth.', 'What did you think about the idea?', 'Well, I like it. What do you think?', '‘Will we make it in time?’ ‘I think so.’', "‘Is he any good?’ ‘I don't think so.’", "I think it highly unlikely that I'll get the job.", 'She thought him kind and generous.', "He's thought to be one of the richest men in Europe."]

sentence: Olives , Frederica agreed with Alexander , could not recall the Mount of Olives , the Garden of Gethsemane , in the day of Van Gogh the pastor 's son , the lay preacher .
gloss: Bring (a fact, event, or situation) back into one's mind; remember.
eg_sent: I can still vaguely recall being taken to the hospital
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; When you recall something, you remember it and tell others about it. ;;
exps_collins: ['Henderson recalled that he first met Pollard during a business trip to Washington.', "Her teacher recalled: 'She was always on about modelling.'.", 'Colleagues today recall with humor how meetings would crawl into the early morning hours.', 'I recalled the way they had been dancing together.', 'I have no idea what she said, something about airline travel, I seem to recall.']
bis_def_longman: to remember a particular fact, event, or situation from the past
exps_longman: ['You don’t happen to recall his name, do you?', 'I seem to recall I’ve met him before somewhere.', 'I don’t recall seeing any cars parked outside.', 'I can’t recall who gave me the information.', 'As I recall, it was you who suggested this idea in the first place.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to remember something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['She could not recall his name.', 'If I recall correctly, he lives in Luton.', "I can't recall meeting her before.", 'He recalled that she always came home late on Wednesdays.', 'Can you recall exactly what happened?', '‘It was on a Thursday in March,’ he recalled. ']

sentence: There she was in a conventional two-piece suit , fine dark wool , muted geometrical pattern in greens and unexpected straw browns , caught in at the waist still very thin to give the effect of a bustle , the skirt long and straight to the knee .
gloss: Intercept and hold (something which has been thrown, propelled, or dropped)
eg_sent: she threw the bottle into the air and caught it again
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; If you catch a person or animal, you capture them after chasing them, or by using a trap, net, or other device. ;;
exps_collins: ['Police say they are confident of catching the gunman.', 'Where did you catch the fish?.', 'I wondered if it was an animal caught in a trap.']
bis_def_longman: to get hold of and stop an object such as a ball that is moving through the air
exps_longman: ['Stephen leapt up and caught the ball in one hand.', 'The kids were throwing and catching a Frisbee down on the beach.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to stop and hold a moving object, especially in your hands
exps_oxford_advanced: ['She managed to catch the keys as they fell.', '‘Throw me over that towel, will you?’ ‘OK. Catch!’', 'The dog caught the stick in its mouth.']

sentence: It proposed a network of under-fives centres throughout the borough an idea which the under-fives workers had been anxious to promote for some time .
gloss: Put forward (a plan or suggestion) for consideration by others.
eg_sent: he proposed a new nine-point peace plan
bis_def_collins: If you propose something such as a plan or an idea, you suggest it for people to think about and decide upon.
exps_collins: ['Britain is about to propose changes to some institutions.', 'It was George who first proposed that we dry clothes in that locker.']
bis_def_longman: to suggest something as a plan or course of action
exps_longman: ['the proposed budget cuts', 'In his speech he proposed that the UN should set up an emergency centre for the environment.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to suggest a plan, an idea, etc. for people to think about and decide on
exps_oxford_advanced: ['The government proposed changes to the voting system.', 'What would you propose?', 'She proposed that the book be banned.', 'She proposed that the book should be banned.', 'It was proposed that the president be elected for a period of two years.', 'He proposed changing the name of the company.', 'It was proposed to pay the money from public funds.']

sentence: The following morning , Clare 's playgroup was ordered to close .
gloss: Give an authoritative instruction to do something.
eg_sent: she ordered me to leave
bis_def_collins: VERB  … If a person in authority orders someone to do something, they tell them to do it. …
bis_def_longman: to ask for food or a drink in a restaurant, bar etc
exps_longman: ['Anne ordered another glass of wine.', 'Are you ready to order?', 'He sat down and ordered a meal.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to use your position of authority to tell somebody to do something or say that something must happen
exps_oxford_advanced: ['The company was ordered to pay compensation to its former employees.', 'The officer ordered them to fire.', 'They were ordered out of the class for fighting.', 'The government has ordered an investigation into the accident.', 'The judge ordered a retrial.', 'They ordered that for every tree cut down two more be planted.', 'They ordered that for every tree cut down two more should be planted.', '‘Sit down and be quiet,’ she ordered.']

sentence: The Englishman returned to his own palatial office and sat with his head in hands .
gloss: Come or go back to a place or person.
eg_sent: he returned to America in the late autumn
bis_def_collins: When you return to a place, you go back there after you have been away.  [Also VERB]
exps_collins: ['Blair will return to London tonight.', 'Our correspondent Stephen Sackur has just returned from the camps on the border.', 'So far more than 350,000 people have returned home.']
bis_def_longman: to go or come back to a place where you were before
exps_longman: ['It was forty five minutes before she returned.', 'Are you planning to return to Spain?', 'I have just returned from five months in Zimbabwe.', 'Alison decided to return home.', 'He left his country, never to return.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to come or go back from one place to another
exps_oxford_advanced: ['I waited a long time for him to return.', "She's returning to Australia tomorrow after six months in Europe.", 'I returned from work to find the house empty.', 'When did she return home from the trip?', 'I had to return to the store to look for my purse.']

sentence: Because Edith now Edith was going away for some unknown reason , I do n't know , she must have been going on another holiday anyhow .
gloss: Move from one place to another; travel.
eg_sent: he went out to the shops
bis_def_collins: When you go somewhere, you move or travel there.
exps_collins: ['We went to Rome.', 'Gladys had just gone into the kitchen.', 'I went home at the weekend.', 'Four of them had gone off to find help.', 'It took us an hour to go three miles.']

exps_longman: ['There’s nothing more we can do here. Let’s go home.', 'Where are you going?', 'We’re going to Canada in the summer.', 'Dinah went into the kitchen.', 'She went over and put her arm around him.', 'I’m going round to her house to find out what’s wrong.', 'I’ll just go up  and ask him what he wants.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to move or travel from one place to another
exps_oxford_advanced: ['She went into her room and shut the door behind her.', 'He goes to work by bus.', 'I have to go to Rome on business.', 'She has gone to China (= is now in China or is on her way there).', 'She has been to China (= she went to China and has now returned).', "I think you should go to the doctor's.", 'Are you going home for Christmas?', 'She has gone to see her sister this weekend.']

sentence: The patient can explain only what the problem is .
gloss: Make (an idea or situation) clear to someone by describing it in more detail or revealing relevant facts.
eg_sent: they explained that their lives centred on the religious rituals
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; If you explain something, you give details about it or describe it so that it can be understood. ; [Also VERB]
exps_collins: ['Not every judge, however, has the ability to explain the law in simple terms.', "Don't sign anything until your solicitor has explained the contract to you.", 'Professor Griffiths explained how the drug appears to work.', "'He and Mrs Stein have a plan,' she explained.", 'I explained that each person has different ideas of what freedom is.']
bis_def_longman: to tell someone about something in a way that is clear or easy to understand
exps_longman: ['He carefully explained the procedure.', 'The librarian will explain how to use the catalogue system.', 'Let me explain what I mean.', 'He explained that it had been a difficult film to make.', 'I explained the situation to my bank manager.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to tell somebody about something in a way that makes it easy to understand
exps_oxford_advanced: ["First, I'll explain the rules of the game.", 'It was difficult to explain the problem to beginners.', '‘Let me explain!’ he added helpfully.', 'I explained that an ambulance would be coming soon.', 'He explained who each person in the photo was.', 'Can you explain how the email system works?', 'She explained to them what to do in an emergency.', '‘It works like this,’ she explained.', 'It was explained that attendance was compulsory.']

sentence: Double glazing ! !
gloss: Fit panes of glass into (a window or door frame or similar structure)
eg_sent: windows can be glazed using laminated glass
bis_def_collins: When you glaze food such as bread or pastry, you spread a layer of beaten egg, milk, or other liquid onto it before you cook it in order to make its surface shine and look attractive.
exps_collins: ['Glaze the pie with beaten egg.']
bis_def_longman: if your eyes glaze over, they show no expression, usually because you are very bored or tired
exps_longman: ['Sometimes his eyes would glaze over for a second or two.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: if a person’s eyes glaze or glaze over, the person begins to look bored or tired
exps_oxford_advanced: ["A lot of people's eyes glaze over if you say you are a feminist.", "‘I'm feeling rather tired,’ he said, his eyes glazing."]

sentence: Barton worked a sixteen-hour day , which began with careful , detailed consideration of the trading figures and key ratios for every one of his forty-three major shops and the output of both factories , and continued , usually by helicopter , with a detailed aerial survey of a particular area as the quick way of identifying new sites , interspersed with unheralded descents on the manager of any shop he took a fancy to visit .
gloss: Go to see and spend time with (someone) socially.
eg_sent: I came to visit my grandmother
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; If you visit someone, you go to see them and spend time with them. ;
exps_collins: ['He wanted to visit his brother in Worcester.', 'He was visited by an old friend from Iraq.', 'Bill would visit on weekends.']
bis_def_longman: to go and spend time in a place or with someone, especially for pleasure or interest
exps_longman: ['Eric went to Seattle to visit his cousins.', 'I was really pleased that they came to visit me.', 'Which cities did you visit in Spain?', 'A recent trip to London gave me the opportunity to visit the Science Museum.', 'She doesn’t visit very often.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to go to see a person or a place for a period of time
exps_oxford_advanced: ['She went to visit relatives in Wales.', 'The Prime Minister is visiting Japan at the moment.', 'You should visit your dentist at least twice a year.', 'This is an area rarely visited by Europeans.']

sentence: Frantically she tore open the door to Elinor 's apartment .
gloss: Pull (something) apart or to pieces with force.
eg_sent: I tore up the letter
bis_def_collins: V-ERG  ;; If you tear paper, cloth, or another material, or if it tears, you pull it into two pieces or you pull it so that a hole appears in it. ;;
bis_def_longman: to damage something such as paper or cloth by pulling it hard or letting it touch something sharp
exps_longman: ['Be careful not to tear the paper.', 'She realized she had torn her jacket on a nail.', 'He tore a page out of his notebook and handed it to her.', 'The dog had torn a huge hole in the tent.', 'He picked up the envelope and tore it open.', 'She tore the letter to pieces and threw it in the bin.', 'Most of her clothes had been torn to shreds.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to damage something by pulling it apart or into pieces or by cutting it on something sharp; to become damaged in this way
exps_oxford_advanced: ['I tore my jeans on the fence.', 'I tore a hole in my jeans.', 'He tore the letter in two.', 'a torn handkerchief', 'Careful—the fabric tears very easily.', 'I tore the package open.', 'I tore open the package.']

sentence: To illustrate the paradigm , reference is made to an alcohol education course developed for offenders in trouble through drink .
gloss: Provide (a book, newspaper, etc.) with pictures.
eg_sent: the guide is illustrated with full-colour photographs
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; If you say that something illustrates a situation that you are drawing attention to, you mean that it shows that the situation exists. ;;
exps_collins: ['The example of the United States illustrates this point.', 'This change is neatly illustrated by what has happened to the Arab League.', 'The incident graphically illustrates how parlous their position is.', 'The case also illustrates that some women are now trying to fight back.']
bis_def_longman: to make the meaning of something clearer by giving examples
exps_longman: ['Let me give an example to illustrate the point.', 'She illustrated her discussion with diagrams.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to use pictures, photographs, diagrams, etc. in a book, etc.
exps_oxford_advanced: ['an illustrated textbook', 'His lecture was illustrated with photos taken during the expedition.']

sentence: We have seen Brittany .
gloss: Perceive with the eyes; discern visually.
eg_sent: in the distance she could see the blue sea
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont] ; When you see something, you notice it using your eyes. ;
exps_collins: ["You can't see colours at night.", 'I saw a man making his way towards me.', 'She can see, hear, touch, smell, and taste.', 'As he neared the farm, he saw that a police car was parked outside it.', 'Did you see what happened?', 'You use see to talk about things that you are aware of because a visual impression reaches your eyes. You often use can in this case. I can see the fax here on the desk. If you want to say that someone is paying attention to something they can see, you say that they are looking at it or watching it. In general, you look at something that is not moving, while you watch something that is moving or changing. I asked him to look at the picture above his bed... He watched Blake run down the stairs.']
bis_def_longman: to notice or examine someone or something, using your eyes
exps_longman: ['He crouched down so he couldn’t be seen.', 'Can I see your ticket, please?', 'You can see the Houses of Parliament from here.', 'Can you see where the marks are on the wall?', 'The suspect was seen entering the building.', 'As you can see, the house needs some work doing on it.', 'Have you seen Chris ?', 'The accommodation was so awful it had to be seen to be believed.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to become aware of somebody/something by using your eyes
exps_oxford_advanced: ["She looked for him but couldn't see him in the crowd.", 'I looked out of the window but saw nothing.', 'The opera was the place to see and be seen (= by other important or fashionable people).', 'He could see (that) she had been crying.', 'Did you see what happened?', 'If you watch carefully, you’ll see how it is done.', 'I hate to see you unhappy.', 'She was seen running away from the scene of the crime.', 'I saw you put the key in your pocket.', 'He was seen to enter the building about the time the crime was committed.']

sentence: There is a rich tradition of epidemiological work in geography and with the increasing availability of spatially referenced medical data the scope for GIS applications is wide ( Gatrell 1987 ) .
gloss: Become or make greater in size, amount, or degree.
eg_sent: car use is increasing at an alarming rate
bis_def_collins: V-ERG  ;; If something increases or you increase it, it becomes greater in number, level, or amount. ;;
exps_collins: ['The population continues to increase.', "Japan's industrial output increased by 2%.", 'The company has increased the price of its cars.', 'The increased investment will help stabilise the economy.', 'We are experiencing an increasing number of problems.']
bis_def_longman: if you increase something, or if it increases, it becomes bigger in amount, number, or degree
exps_longman: ['The population increased dramatically in the first half of the century.', 'political tensions that might increase the likelihood of war', 'Visits to the site have increased threefold since May.', 'Investments are certain to increase in value.', 'Food prices increased by 10% in less than a year.', 'The salary is £18,600 a year, increasing to £23,000.', 'the increasing difficulty of finding trained staff', 'European leaders watched events unfold with increasing alarm.', 'an increased incidence of childhood leukaemia']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to become or to make something greater in amount, number, value, etc.
exps_oxford_advanced: ['The population has increased from 1.2 million to 1.8 million.', 'increasing levels of carbon dioxide in the earth’s atmosphere', 'Increasing numbers of people are using handheld devices to access the Internet.', 'The price of oil increased.', 'Oil increased in price.', 'The rate of inflation increased by 2%.', 'Disability increases with age (= the older somebody is, the more likely they are to be disabled).', 'We need to increase productivity.', "They've increased the price by 50%."]

gloss: Utter words so as to convey information, an opinion, a feeling or intention, or an instruction.

Oh, please say yes!', 'He looked as if he was going to say something.', 'I wished I had said nothing about Jordi.', 'Does anyone else have anything to say?', 'Although he didn’t say so, it was clear that he was in pain.', 'What makes you say that (=why do you think that) ? 你怎么会那么说呢？', 'Nina said to meet her at 4.30.', 'I’d like to say a few words.', '‘So what are your plans now?’ ‘I’d rather not say.’']

sentence: He did n't want to take his eyes from it equally he wanted somebody else to see it .
gloss: Perceive with the eyes; discern visually.
eg_sent: in the distance she could see the blue sea
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont] ; When you see something, you notice it using your eyes. ;
exps_collins: ["You can't see colours at night.", 'I saw a man making his way towards me.', 'She can see, hear, touch, smell, and taste.', 'As he neared the farm, he saw that a police car was parked outside it.', 'Did you see what happened?', 'You use see to talk about things that you are aware of because a visual impression reaches your eyes. You often use can in this case. I can see the fax here on the desk. If you want to say that someone is paying attention to something they can see, you say that they are looking at it or watching it. In general, you look at something that is not moving, while you watch something that is moving or changing. I asked him to look at the picture above his bed... He watched Blake run down the stairs.']
bis_def_longman: to notice or examine someone or something, using your eyes
exps_longman: ['He crouched down so he couldn’t be seen.', 'Can I see your ticket, please?', 'You can see the Houses of Parliament from here.', 'Can you see where the marks are on the wall?', 'The suspect was seen entering the building.', 'As you can see, the house needs some work doing on it.', 'Have you seen Chris ?', 'The accommodation was so awful it had to be seen to be believed.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to become aware of somebody/something by using your eyes
exps_oxford_advanced: ["She looked for him but couldn't see him in the crowd.", 'I looked out of the window but saw nothing.', 'The opera was the place to see and be seen (= by other important or fashionable people).', 'He could see (that) she had been crying.', 'Did you see what happened?', 'If you watch carefully, you’ll see how it is done.', 'I hate to see you unhappy.', 'She was seen running away from the scene of the crime.', 'I saw you put the key in your pocket.', 'He was seen to enter the building about the time the crime was committed.']

sentence: Do you remember ? "
gloss: Have in or be able to bring to one's mind an awareness of (someone or something from the past)
eg_sent: I remember the screech of the horn as the car came towards me
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; If you remember people or events from the past, you still have an idea of them in your mind and you are able to think about them. ;;
exps_collins: ["You wouldn't remember me. I was in another group.", "I certainly don't remember talking to you at all.", 'I remember her being a dominant figure.', 'I remembered that we had drunk the last of the coffee the week before.', 'I can remember where and when I bought each one.', 'I used to do that when you were a little girl, remember?']
bis_def_longman: to have a picture or idea in your mind of people, events, places etc from the past
exps_longman: ['Do you remember Rosa Davies?', 'I can’t remember her exact words.', 'I remember you two couldn’t stand each other at first!', 'I remember meeting her at a party once.', 'I remember my father bringing home a huge Christmas tree.', 'I remember it well; I’d never seen my mother so angry.', 'She clearly remembers the excitement as they boarded the train.', 'I vaguely remember reading something about it in the paper.', 'They had three children, if I remember rightly.', 'They’ve lived here for as long as I can remember.', 'No one got drunk as far as I can remember.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have or keep an image in your memory of an event, a person, a place, etc. from the past
exps_oxford_advanced: ['This is Carla. Do you remember her?', "I don't remember my first day at school.", "He still remembered her as the lively teenager he'd known years before.", "As far as I can remember, this is the third time we've met.", 'Do you remember switching the lights off before we came out?', 'I vaguely remember hearing him come in.', 'I can still vividly remember my grandfather teaching me to play cards.', "I can't remember his taking a single day off work.", 'I remember (that) we used to go and see them most weekends.']

sentence: Hill expresses the way time has cheated them : his daughter was born while he was remanded in custody , and is now 14 : She would change dramatically and I did n't feel a change in myself mentally .
gloss: Place (a defendant) on bail or in custody, especially when a trial is adjourned.

bis_def_collins: VERB  [usually passive] …; If a person who is accused of a crime is remanded in custody or on bail, they are told to return to the court at a later date, when their trial will take place. …;

sentence: No I 'm really impressed .

sentence: I do n't know .
gloss: Be aware of through observation, inquiry, or information.
eg_sent: most people know that CFCs can damage the ozone layer
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont]  If you know a fact, a piece of information, or an answer, you have it correctly in your mind.
exps_collins: ["I don't know the name of the place.", 'I know that you led a rifle platoon during the Second World War.', "'People like doing things for nothing.' — 'I know they do.'.", "I don't know what happened to her husband.", "'How did he meet your mother?' — 'I don't know.'.", 'We all know about his early experiments in flying.', 'They looked younger than I knew them to be.', 'Radon is known to be harmful to humans in large quantities.', 'It is not known whether the bomb was originally intended for the capital itself.', "It's always been known that key figures in the government do very well for themselves."]
bis_def_longman: to have information about something
exps_longman: ['Who knows the answer?', 'There are instructions telling you everything you need to know.', 'Didn’t you know that?', 'Do you know what time it is?', 'I don’t know where to go.', 'I need to know more about the job before I decide whether to apply for it.', 'Little is known about the author’s childhood.', 'I know all about David and what he’s been up to!', 'I wonder if he knew of the plan?', 'Do you know of any good restaurants in the area?', 'You know nothing of this business.', 'We know that greenhouse gases can affect the climate.', 'Let me know what time you’re planning to arrive.', 'I thought you’d want to know immediately.', 'If you must know, I was with James last night .', 'He slipped out of the house without his parents knowing .', 'How did he know our names?', '‘I’m divorced, as you know, ’ she said briefly.', 'Smoking is known to increase a person’s risk of developing lung cancer.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have information in your mind as a result of experience or because you have learned or been told it
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Do you know his address?', 'The cause of the fire is not yet known.', 'All I know is that she used to work in a bank (= I have no other information about her).', 'I know (that) people’s handwriting changes as they get older.', 'It is widely known that CFCs can damage the ozone layer.', 'I knew where he was hiding.', "I didn't know what he was talking about.", "‘You've got a flat tyre.’ ‘I know.’", "‘What's the answer?’ ‘I don't know.’", "‘There's no one in.’ ‘How do you know?’", "You know about Amanda's baby, don't you?", "I don't know about you, but I'm ready for something to eat.", 'I know of at least two people who did the same thing.', '‘Is anyone else coming?’ ‘Not that I know of.’', '‘Isn’t that his car?’ ‘I wouldn’t know./How should I know?’ (= I don’t know and I am not the person you should ask.)', "‘What are you two whispering about?’ ‘You don't want to know’ (= because you would be shocked or wouldn't approve).", 'Does he know to come here (= that he should come here) first?', 'We know her to be honest.', 'Two women are known to have died.']

sentence: However , the Pope 's account of the role of the papacy went a great deal farther than that : Christian unity , he said , must be founded on the faith in Christ that was handed on by the Apostles ; what this faith is must be determined by the Roman Catholic Church .

sentence: The club owners , the casinos , and the multinational bookmakers knew which professional gamblers successfully played games that contained an element of skill such as backgammon and poker- and they preferred to have nothing to do with them ; ideally , the house welcomed inexperienced , rich idiots .
gloss: Like (one thing or person) better than another or others; tend to choose.
eg_sent: I prefer Venice to Rome
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont]  If you prefer someone or something, you like that person or thing better than another, and so you are more likely to choose them if there is a choice.  [Also VERB that]
exps_collins: ['Does he prefer a particular sort of music?.', 'I became a teacher because I preferred books and people to politics.', 'I prefer to go on self-catering holidays.', 'I would prefer him to be with us next season.', 'Bob prefers making original pieces rather than reproductions.', "The woodwork's green now. I preferred it blue.", 'Her own preferred methods of exercise are hiking and long cycle rides.', "Note that prefer can often sound rather formal in ordinary conversation. Verbal expressions such as like…better and would rather are used more frequently. For example, instead of saying 'I prefer football to tennis', you can say 'I like football better than tennis', instead of 'I'd prefer an apple', you can say 'I'd rather have an apple', and instead of 'I'd prefer to walk', you can say 'I'd rather walk'."]
bis_def_longman: to like someone or something more than someone or something else, so that you would choose it if you could
exps_longman: ['This type of owl prefers a desert habitat.', 'She prefers her coffee black.', 'the government’s preferred option', 'a child that prefers his imaginary world to reality', 'Employees said they would prefer more flexible working hours.', 'I prefer to wear clothes made of natural fibers.', 'Or, if you prefer, you can email us.', 'Chantal prefers travelling by train.', 'We prefer that our teachers have a degree in early childhood education.']

sentence: they re , revamped it or whatever .

On Saturday the two prelates attended a service of vespers at the Church of San Gregorio , which stands on the site where Pope Gregory sent St Augustine of Canterbury off to become the first Archbishop of Canterbury in 597 .
gloss: Begin to be.
eg_sent: she became angry and sulked all day
bis_def_collins: If someone or something becomes a particular thing, they start to change and develop into that thing, or start to develop the characteristics mentioned.
exps_collins: ['I first became interested in Islam while I was doing my nursing training.', 'The cocoa industry dwindled because it became increasingly difficult to cover costs.', "During the 1980s the world's financial systems became more open.", 'The pilot decided to land, but as we lost altitude the wind became stronger.', 'As she reached the age of thirty she became convinced she would remain single all her life.', 'After leaving school, he became a professional footballer.', 'In 1823 Honduras became a part of the United Provinces of Central America.']
bis_def_longman: to start to have a feeling or quality, or to start to develop into something
exps_longman: ['The weather became warmer.', 'Slowly my eyes became accustomed to the darkness.', 'Helen became increasingly anxious about her husband’s strange behaviour.', 'Pollution from cars has become a major problem.']

sentence: I said I did n't think so , as you were rather busy , but I 'd pass the message on .
gloss: Have a particular opinion, belief, or idea about someone or something.
eg_sent: she thought that nothing would be the same again
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont] ; If you think that something is the case, you have the opinion that it is the case. ; [Also VERB n to-infinitive]
exps_collins: ['I certainly think there should be a ban on tobacco advertising.', 'Do you think I ought to seal the boxes up?.', 'A generation ago, it was thought that babies born this small could not survive.', 'Tell me, what do you think of my theory?.', 'Peter is useless, far worse than I thought.', 'He manages a good deal better than I thought possible.', "'It ought to be stopped.' — 'Yes, I think so.'"]
bis_def_longman: to have a particular opinion or to believe that something is true
exps_longman: ['I think that you’re being unfair.', 'I thought I heard something.', 'He didn’t think anyone would believe him.', 'Do you think I should call him?', 'For some reason, I keep thinking it’s Friday today.', 'The recession lasted longer than anyone thought it would.', 'Am I right in thinking that you have a brother?', 'I can’t help thinking that he’s made a mistake.', 'Do you honestly think I would do something so stupid?', 'What do you think of your new school?', 'I thought it best to call first.', 'I thought it appropriate to invite her to speak at the meeting.', 'We must start thinking in terms of reducing costs.', 'Fraud is thought to be costing software companies millions of dollars a year.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have a particular idea or opinion about something/somebody; to believe something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Do you think (that) they’ll come?', 'I thought I heard a scream.', "I didn't think you liked sports.", 'Am I right in thinking that you used to live here?', "I think this is their house, but I'm not sure.", 'He ought to resign, I think.', "We'll need about 20 chairs, I should think.", 'It was once thought that the sun travelled around the earth.', 'What did you think about the idea?', 'Well, I like it. What do you think?', '‘Will we make it in time?’ ‘I think so.’', "‘Is he any good?’ ‘I don't think so.’", "I think it highly unlikely that I'll get the job.", 'She thought him kind and generous.', "He's thought to be one of the richest men in Europe."]

sentence: IN THE crusade to make everyone guilty about everything , there is a new technique : tetranalysis , the study of colour , sound , motion and form in movies .
gloss: Form (something) by putting parts together or combining substances; create.

bis_def_collins: VERB  ) You can use make with a wide range of nouns to indicate that someone performs an action or says something. For example, if you make a suggestion, you suggest something. )

exps_oxford_advanced: ['to make a table/dress/cake', 'to make bread/cement/paper', 'She makes her own clothes.', 'made in France (= on a label)', "What's your shirt made of?", 'Wine is made from grapes.', 'The grapes are made into wine.', 'She made coffee for us all.', 'She made us all coffee.']

sentence: These teenagers were in his experience a lot less tough than they looked .
gloss: Direct one's gaze toward someone or something or in a specified direction.
eg_sent: people were looking at him
bis_def_collins: If you look in a particular direction, you direct your eyes in that direction, especially so that you can see what is there or see what something is like.
exps_collins: ['I looked down the hallway to room number nine.', 'She turned to look at him.', 'He looked away, apparently enraged.', "If you look, you'll see what was a lake.", 'If you want to say that someone is paying attention to something they can see, you say that they are looking at it or watching it. In general, you look at something that is not moving, while you watch something that is moving or changing. I asked him to look at the picture above his bed... He watched Blake run down the stairs. Look is never followed directly by an object. You must always use at or some other preposition. I looked towards the plane. You use see to talk about things that you are aware of because a visual impression reaches your eyes. You often use can in this case. I can see the fax here on the desk.']
bis_def_longman: to turn your eyes towards something, so that you can see it
exps_longman: ['We sneaked out while Jessie’s mom wasn’t looking.', 'If you look carefully you can see that the painting represents a human figure.', 'Gina covered her eyes, afraid to look.', '‘It’s time we left, ’ Ian said, looking at his watch.', 'The men all turned to look at her as she entered the room.', 'Dad looked up from his paper and smiled.', '‘We can’t go out in this weather, ’ said Bob, looking out of the window.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to turn your eyes in a particular direction
exps_oxford_advanced: ['If you look carefully you can just see our house from here.', 'She looked at me and smiled.', "‘Has the mail come yet?’ ‘I'll look and see.’", "Look! I'm sure that's Brad Pitt!", "Don't look now, but there's someone staring at you!"]

sentence: Now that he was able to , he assembled what had happened and laid the facts before himself .

sentence: For example , are we satisfied that the 600 deaths recorded as homicide are in fact more culpable than all , or even most , of the deaths recorded as accidents ?
gloss: Set down in writing or some other permanent form for later reference.

sentence: In theory , validation meant that the user had read the specification , imagined how the system would work in practice , and agreed the design .

sentence: One never quite knew what he was going to say next .
gloss: Be aware of through observation, inquiry, or information.

bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont]  If you know a fact, a piece of information, or an answer, you have it correctly in your mind.
exps_collins: ["I don't know the name of the place.", 'I know that you led a rifle platoon during the Second World War.', "'People like doing things for nothing.' — 'I know they do.'.", "I don't know what happened to her husband.", "'How did he meet your mother?' — 'I don't know.'.", 'We all know about his early experiments in flying.', 'They looked younger than I knew them to be.', 'Radon is known to be harmful to humans in large quantities.', 'It is not known whether the bomb was originally intended for the capital itself.', "It's always been known that key figures in the government do very well for themselves."]
