exps_longman: ['Who knows the answer?', 'There are instructions telling you everything you need to know.', 'Didn’t you know that?', 'Do you know what time it is?', 'I don’t know where to go.', 'I need to know more about the job before I decide whether to apply for it.', 'Little is known about the author’s childhood.', 'I know all about David and what he’s been up to!', 'I wonder if he knew of the plan?', 'Do you know of any good restaurants in the area?', 'You know nothing of this business.', 'We know that greenhouse gases can affect the climate.', 'Let me know what time you’re planning to arrive.', 'I thought you’d want to know immediately.', 'If you must know, I was with James last night .', 'He slipped out of the house without his parents knowing .', 'How did he know our names?', '‘I’m divorced, as you know, ’ she said briefly.', 'Smoking is known to increase a person’s risk of developing lung cancer.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have information in your mind as a result of experience or because you have learned or been told it
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Do you know his address?', 'The cause of the fire is not yet known.', 'All I know is that she used to work in a bank (= I have no other information about her).', 'I know (that) people’s handwriting changes as they get older.', 'It is widely known that CFCs can damage the ozone layer.', 'I knew where he was hiding.', "I didn't know what he was talking about.", "‘You've got a flat tyre.’ ‘I know.’", "‘What's the answer?’ ‘I don't know.’", "‘There's no one in.’ ‘How do you know?’", "You know about Amanda's baby, don't you?", "I don't know about you, but I'm ready for something to eat.", 'I know of at least two people who did the same thing.', '‘Is anyone else coming?’ ‘Not that I know of.’', '‘Isn’t that his car?’ ‘I wouldn’t know./How should I know?’ (= I don’t know and I am not the person you should ask.)', "‘What are you two whispering about?’ ‘You don't want to know’ (= because you would be shocked or wouldn't approve).", 'Does he know to come here (= that he should come here) first?', 'We know her to be honest.', 'Two women are known to have died.']

sentence: Some urban gardeners , as short of space inside as they are out , want their gardens to be extensions of their homes , with a great deal of hard paving , good furniture and lighting .
gloss: Have a desire to possess or do (something); wish for.
eg_sent: I want an apple
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont, no passive] ; If you want something, you feel a desire or a need for it. ;
exps_collins: ['I want a drink.', 'Ian knows exactly what he wants in life.', 'People wanted to know who this talented designer was.', 'They began to want their father to be the same as other daddies.', "They didn't want people staring at them as they sat on the lawn, so they put up high walls.", 'He wanted his power recognised.', 'I want my car this colour.', 'And remember, we want him alive.', "Note that want and wish have similar meanings, but are used differently. If you want something, you feel a need for it or a desire to have it. You can say that you want to do something, that you want someone to do something, or that you want something to happen. If you use wish with a 'to' infinitive, this has the same meaning as want but is more formal. I want to get out of here... She wished to consult him about her future."]
bis_def_longman: to have a desire for something
exps_longman: ['I really want a drink.', 'What do you want for your birthday?', 'She’d always wanted to go to Thailand.', 'I don’t want Linda to  hear about this.', 'He didn’t want the holiday to end.', 'You can order whatever you want.', 'This shampoo is mild enough to use every day if you want.', 'If she doesn’t get what she wants, she’s not happy.', 'He wanted that job so badly he was willing to kill for it.', 'They desperately wanted a son.', 'What I want to know is when we’re going to get paid.', 'All I want is the chance to prove myself.', 'Oh thank you, it’s just what I’ve always wanted.']

exps_collins: ["'I'm sorry,' he said.", 'She said they were very impressed.', 'Forty-one people are said to have been seriously hurt.', 'I packed and said goodbye to Charlie.', "I hope you didn't say anything about Gretchen.", "You didn't say much when you telephoned.", 'Did he say where he was going?.', "It doesn't sound exactly orthodox, if I may say so."]

exps_longman: ['‘Don’t cry, ’ he said softly.', 'Don’t believe anything he says.', 'A spokesman said that the company had improved its safety standards.', 'I always said I would buy a motorbike when I had enough money.', 'Did she say what happened?', 'I would like to say how much we appreciate your hard work.', '‘Why did she leave?’ ‘I don’t know – she didn’t say.’', 'What did you say to her?', 'What a silly thing to say!', 'She left without saying goodbye.', 'I’ve said I’m sorry – what more do you want?', 'Can I go, Mum? Oh, please say yes!', 'He looked as if he was going to say something.', 'I wished I had said nothing about Jordi.', 'Does anyone else have anything to say?', 'Although he didn’t say so, it was clear that he was in pain.', 'What makes you say that (=why do you think that) ? 你怎么会那么说呢？', 'Nina said to meet her at 4.30.', 'I’d like to say a few words.', '‘So what are your plans now?’ ‘I’d rather not say.’']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to speak or tell somebody something, using words
exps_oxford_advanced: ['‘Hello!’ she said.', '‘That was marvellous,’ said Daniel.', 'Be quiet, I have something to say.', "I didn't believe a word she said.", "That's a terrible thing to say.", "He knew that if he wasn't back by midnight, his parents would have something to say about it (= be angry).", 'She said nothing to me about it.', "I said to myself (= thought), ‘That can't be right!’", 'He said (that) his name was Sam.', 'It is said that she lived to be over 100.', 'She finds it hard to say what she feels.', "‘That's impossible!’ ‘So you say (= but I think you may be wrong).’", "‘Why can't I go out now?’ ‘Because I say so.’", "‘What do you want it for?’ ‘I'd rather not say.’", 'He said to meet him here.', 'He is said to have been a brilliant scholar.']

sentence: Yes well you see ?
gloss: Perceive with the eyes; discern visually.
eg_sent: in the distance she could see the blue sea
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont] ; When you see something, you notice it using your eyes. ;
exps_collins: ["You can't see colours at night.", 'I saw a man making his way towards me.', 'She can see, hear, touch, smell, and taste.', 'As he neared the farm, he saw that a police car was parked outside it.', 'Did you see what happened?', 'You use see to talk about things that you are aware of because a visual impression reaches your eyes. You often use can in this case. I can see the fax here on the desk. If you want to say that someone is paying attention to something they can see, you say that they are looking at it or watching it. In general, you look at something that is not moving, while you watch something that is moving or changing. I asked him to look at the picture above his bed... He watched Blake run down the stairs.']
bis_def_longman: to notice or examine someone or something, using your eyes
exps_longman: ['He crouched down so he couldn’t be seen.', 'Can I see your ticket, please?', 'You can see the Houses of Parliament from here.', 'Can you see where the marks are on the wall?', 'The suspect was seen entering the building.', 'As you can see, the house needs some work doing on it.', 'Have you seen Chris ?', 'The accommodation was so awful it had to be seen to be believed.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to become aware of somebody/something by using your eyes
exps_oxford_advanced: ["She looked for him but couldn't see him in the crowd.", 'I looked out of the window but saw nothing.', 'The opera was the place to see and be seen (= by other important or fashionable people).', 'He could see (that) she had been crying.', 'Did you see what happened?', 'If you watch carefully, you’ll see how it is done.', 'I hate to see you unhappy.', 'She was seen running away from the scene of the crime.', 'I saw you put the key in your pocket.', 'He was seen to enter the building about the time the crime was committed.']

sentence: I do n't want to go back to Mrs Gutermann 's .
gloss: Have a desire to possess or do (something); wish for.
eg_sent: I want an apple
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont, no passive] ; If you want something, you feel a desire or a need for it. ;
exps_collins: ['I want a drink.', 'Ian knows exactly what he wants in life.', 'People wanted to know who this talented designer was.', 'They began to want their father to be the same as other daddies.', "They didn't want people staring at them as they sat on the lawn, so they put up high walls.", 'He wanted his power recognised.', 'I want my car this colour.', 'And remember, we want him alive.', "Note that want and wish have similar meanings, but are used differently. If you want something, you feel a need for it or a desire to have it. You can say that you want to do something, that you want someone to do something, or that you want something to happen. If you use wish with a 'to' infinitive, this has the same meaning as want but is more formal. I want to get out of here... She wished to consult him about her future."]
bis_def_longman: to have a desire for something
exps_longman: ['I really want a drink.', 'What do you want for your birthday?', 'She’d always wanted to go to Thailand.', 'I don’t want Linda to  hear about this.', 'He didn’t want the holiday to end.', 'You can order whatever you want.', 'This shampoo is mild enough to use every day if you want.', 'If she doesn’t get what she wants, she’s not happy.', 'He wanted that job so badly he was willing to kill for it.', 'They desperately wanted a son.', 'What I want to know is when we’re going to get paid.', 'All I want is the chance to prove myself.', 'Oh thank you, it’s just what I’ve always wanted.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have a desire or a wish for something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Do you want some more tea?', "She's always wanted a large family.", 'All I want is the truth.', "Thanks for the present—it's just what I wanted.", 'I can do whatever I want.', 'The last thing I wanted was to upset you.', 'The party wants her as leader.', 'What do you want to do tomorrow?', "‘It's time you did your homework.’ ‘I don't want to!’", 'There are two points which I wanted to make.', 'I just wanted to know if everything was all right.', 'You can come too, if you want.', 'Do you want me to help?', "We didn't want this to happen.", 'I want it (to be) done as quickly as possible.', "I don't want you coming home so late.", 'Do you want your coffee black or white?']

It can wait.", 'I nearly killed myself carrying that suitcase all the way here.', 'Tiredness while driving can kill.']

sentence: The environmental systems are effectively regarded as machines whose workings can all be discovered , described in differential equation form and whose future activities can thus be predicted in detail if their initial states are known .
gloss: Give a detailed account in words of.

sentence: The leaf is excellently preserved on the flat bedding-plane of a limestone laid down under fresh water .

sentence: And when I see these people in nursing homes all sat round a wall in chairs oh God !

I fully expect that and I’m ready.', '‘Who are you?’ he murmured, only half expecting her to answer.', 'He didn’t get his expected pay rise.', 'As expected, the whole family was shocked by the news.', 'A little nervousness is only to be expected when you are starting a new job.']

sentence: Delaney averted his gaze from her , afraid of what he had seen in her eyes .

sentence: Michael Heseltine ( 1987 , p. 138 ) has since claimed that we set a new objective : to make the inner cities places where people would want to live and work and where the private investor would be willing to put his money .
gloss: State or assert that something is the case, typically without providing evidence or proof.
eg_sent: the Prime Minister claimed that he was concerned about Third World debt
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; If you say that someone claims that something is true, you mean they say that it is true but you are not sure whether or not they are telling the truth. ;
exps_collins: ['He claimed that it was all a conspiracy against him.', 'A man claiming to be a journalist threatened to reveal details about her private life.', "'I had never received one single complaint against me,' claimed the humiliated doctor.", 'He claims a 70 to 80 per cent success rate.']
bis_def_longman: to state that something is true, even though it has not been proved
exps_longman: ['The product claims that it can make you thin without dieting.', 'No responsible therapist will claim to cure your insomnia.', 'I don’t claim to be a feminist, but I’d like to see more women in top jobs.', 'The girls claim to have seen the fairies.', 'The group claimed responsibility for the bombings.', 'Opposition leaders will claim victory if the turnout is lower than 50%.', 'A letter appeared in ‘The Times’ claiming Fleming as the discoverer of penicillin.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to say that something is true although it has not been proved and other people may not believe it

sentence: The secret of a successful outcome depends partly on setting the right reserve price , a task the auctioneer undertakes in conjunction with the seller .

sentence: Come and clean my windows and I owed him from the last time .
gloss: Have an obligation to pay or repay (something, especially money) in return for something received.
eg_sent: they have denied they owe money to the company
bis_def_collins: If you owe money to someone, they have lent it to you and you have not yet paid it back. You can also say that the money is owing .
exps_collins: ['The company owes money to more than 60 banks.', 'Blake already owed him nearly £50.', "I'm broke, Livy, and I owe a couple of million dollars.", 'He could take what was owing for the rent.']
bis_def_longman: to need to pay someone for something that they have done for you or sold to you, or to need to give someone back money that they have lent you
exps_longman: ['I owe my brother $50.', 'I still owe you for the taxi.', 'How much do I owe you ?', 'the money owed to credit card companies']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have to pay somebody for something that you have already received or return money that you have borrowed
exps_oxford_advanced: ['She still owes her father £3\u2009000.', "I'm still owed three days' leave.", 'How much do I owe you for the groceries?', 'She still owes £3\u2009000 to her father', 'The country owes billions of dollars to foreign creditors.']

sentence: And is there anything there , I mean can you dry your clothes out there at all ?
gloss: Intend to convey or refer to (a particular thing); signify.
eg_sent: I don't know what you mean
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont] ;…;… If you want to know what a word, code, signal, or gesture means, you want to know what it refers to or what its message is. ;…;…
exps_collins: ["In modern Welsh, 'glas' means 'blue'.", "What does 'evidence' mean?.", 'The red signal means you can shoot.']
bis_def_longman: to have or represent a particular meaning
exps_longman: ['What does ‘patronizing’ mean?', 'The red light means ‘Stop’.', 'The report fails to define what is meant by the term ‘key issues’.', 'This light means you’re running low on fuel.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have something as a meaning
exps_oxford_advanced: ['What does this sentence mean?', 'What is meant by ‘batch processing’?', 'Does the name ‘Jos Vos’ mean anything to you (= do you know who he is)?', 'The flashing light means (that) you must stop.']

sentence: He looked , in this setting , a little like some painter .
gloss: Direct one's gaze toward someone or something or in a specified direction.
eg_sent: people were looking at him
bis_def_collins: If you look in a particular direction, you direct your eyes in that direction, especially so that you can see what is there or see what something is like.
exps_collins: ['I looked down the hallway to room number nine.', 'She turned to look at him.', 'He looked away, apparently enraged.', "If you look, you'll see what was a lake.", 'If you want to say that someone is paying attention to something they can see, you say that they are looking at it or watching it. In general, you look at something that is not moving, while you watch something that is moving or changing. I asked him to look at the picture above his bed... He watched Blake run down the stairs. Look is never followed directly by an object. You must always use at or some other preposition. I looked towards the plane. You use see to talk about things that you are aware of because a visual impression reaches your eyes. You often use can in this case. I can see the fax here on the desk.']
bis_def_longman: to turn your eyes towards something, so that you can see it
exps_longman: ['We sneaked out while Jessie’s mom wasn’t looking.', 'If you look carefully you can see that the painting represents a human figure.', 'Gina covered her eyes, afraid to look.', '‘It’s time we left, ’ Ian said, looking at his watch.', 'The men all turned to look at her as she entered the room.', 'Dad looked up from his paper and smiled.', '‘We can’t go out in this weather, ’ said Bob, looking out of the window.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to turn your eyes in a particular direction
exps_oxford_advanced: ['If you look carefully you can just see our house from here.', 'She looked at me and smiled.', "‘Has the mail come yet?’ ‘I'll look and see.’", "Look! I'm sure that's Brad Pitt!", "Don't look now, but there's someone staring at you!"]

sentence: Paul Harrison 's Inside the Inner City : Life under the Cutting Edge focused on Hackney , a London borough ranked among the worst off on any scale of urban deprivation ( Harrison , 1983 ) .
gloss: Make an opening, incision, or wound in (something) with a sharp-edged tool or object.
eg_sent: he cut his toe on a sharp stone
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;;;;; If you cut something, you use a knife or a similar tool to divide it into pieces, or to mark it or damage it. If you cut a shape or a hole in something, you make the shape or hole by using a knife or similar tool. ;;;;;
exps_collins: ['Mrs. Haines stood nearby, holding scissors to cut a ribbon.', 'Cut the tomatoes in half vertically.', 'The thieves cut a hole in the fence.', 'Mr. Long was now cutting himself a piece of the pink cake.', 'You can hear the saw as it cuts through the bones.', '...thinly cut cucumber sandwiches.']
bis_def_longman: to reduce the amount of something
exps_longman: ['They’re introducing CCTV cameras in an attempt to cut street crime in the area.', 'You need to cut the amount of fat and sugar in your diet.', 'Scientists are warning that unless carbon emissions are cut, we could be heading for an environmental catastrophe.', 'Seven hundred jobs will be lost in order to cut costs and boost profits.', 'The major aviation companies need to cut prices if they are to compete with budget airlines.', 'The welfare budget has been cut by $56 billion.', 'A new direct service will cut two hours off the flying time between London and Seoul.', 'Staffing levels had already been cut to the bone.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to make an opening or a wound in something, especially with a sharp tool such as a knife or scissors
exps_oxford_advanced: ['She cut her finger on a piece of glass.', 'He cut himself (= his face) shaving.', 'She had fallen and cut her head open.', 'You need a powerful saw to cut through metal.', 'The canoe cut through the water.']

sentence: Take what you want and leave the rest , your mother 'll get rid of it .
gloss: Come to have (something); receive.
eg_sent: I got a letter from him the other day
bis_def_collins: You use get with adjectives to mean 'become'. For example, if someone gets cold, they become cold, and if they get angry, they become angry.
exps_collins: ['The boys were getting bored.', "There's no point in getting upset.", 'From here on, it can only get better.']
bis_def_longman: to receive something that someone gives you or sends you
exps_longman: ['She got loads of presents.', 'What did you get for Christmas?', 'We get a lot of junk mail.', 'We got a letter from Pam this morning.', 'I got it off my Dad.', 'I got a few games free when I bought my computer.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to receive something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['I got a letter from Dave this morning.', 'What (= What presents) did you get for your birthday?', 'He gets (= earns) about $40\u2009000 a year.', 'This room gets very little sunshine.', 'I got a shock when I saw the bill.', 'I get the impression that he is bored with his job.']

sentence: Daniel asked , for politeness really , why Van Gogh had been mad , was it just that he was driven ?
gloss: Say something in order to obtain an answer or some information.
eg_sent: I asked her what she meant
bis_def_collins: If you ask someone something, you say something to them in the form of a question because you want to know the answer.  [Also V about n]
exps_collins: ["'How is Frank?' he asked.", 'I asked him his name.', "I wasn't the only one asking questions.", "She asked me if I'd enjoyed my dinner.", 'If Daniel asks what happened in court we will tell him.', 'You will have to ask David about that.', "'I'm afraid to ask what it cost.' — 'Then don't ask.'"]
bis_def_longman: to speak or write to someone in order to get an answer, information, or a solution
exps_longman: ['‘What’s your name?’ she asked.', 'Don’t ask him – he won’t know.', 'That kid’s always asking awkward questions.', 'I asked him where he lived.', 'We’ll have to ask someone the way to the station.', 'Go and ask Tom whether he’s coming tonight.', 'Visitors usually ask about the history of the castle.', 'I’ll ask around, see if I can find you a place to stay.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to say or write something in the form of a question, in order to get information
exps_oxford_advanced: ['How old are you—if you don’t mind me/my asking?', 'He asked about her family.', 'Can I ask a question?', 'Did you ask the price?', '‘Where are you going?’ she asked.', '‘Are you sure?’ he asked her.', 'She asked the students their names.', 'I often get asked that!', 'The interviewer asked me about my future plans.', 'He asked where I lived.', 'I had to ask the teacher what to do next.', 'I was asked if/whether I could drive.']

sentence: Their fossil remains seem to occur with other animals and plants , which are generally accepted as terrestrial .
gloss: Happen; take place.
eg_sent: the accident occurred at about 3.30 p.m.
bis_def_collins: When something occurs, it happens.
exps_collins: ['If headaches only occur at night, lack of fresh air and oxygen is often the cause.', 'The crash occurred when the crew shut down the wrong engine.', 'In March 1770, there occurred what became known as the Boston Massacre.']
bis_def_longman: to happen
exps_longman: ['A third of accidental deaths occur in the home.', 'The explosion occurred at 5.30 a.m.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to happen
exps_oxford_advanced: ['When exactly did the incident occur?', 'Something unexpected occurred.']

sentence: As the Rallye droned towards the lighthouse on the tip of Cap Camerat , Miranda felt as if she were breathing the air of the gods .
gloss: Take air into the lungs and then expel it, especially as a regular physiological process.
eg_sent: she was breathing deeply
bis_def_collins: When people or animals breathe, they take air into their lungs and let it out again. When they breathe smoke or a particular kind of air, they take it into their lungs and let it out again as they breathe.  [Also V out n]
exps_collins: ['He stood there breathing deeply and evenly.', 'Always breathe through your nose.', 'No American should have to drive out of town to breathe clean air.', 'A thirteen year old girl is being treated after breathing in smoke.']
bis_def_longman: to take air into your lungs and send it out again
exps_longman: ['The room filled with smoke, and it was becoming difficult to breathe.', 'People are concerned about the quality of the air they breathe.', 'Relax and breathe deeply.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to take air into your lungs and send it out again through your nose or mouth
exps_oxford_advanced: ['He breathed deeply before speaking again.', 'The air was so cold we could hardly breathe.', 'She was beginning to breathe more easily.', 'He was breathing heavily after his exertions.', "Most people don't realize that they are breathing polluted air."]

sentence: The other conclusion ( as far as it is permissible to generalize from a single example ) is more important in principle .
gloss: Make a general or broad statement by inferring from specific cases.
eg_sent: it is not easy to generalize about the poor
bis_def_collins: If you generalize, you say something that seems to be true in most situations or for most people, but that may not be completely true in all cases.
exps_collins: ["'In my day, children were a lot better behaved'. — 'It's not true, you're generalizing'.", "It's hard to generalize about Cole Porter because he wrote so many great songs that were so varied."]
bis_def_longman: to form a general principle or opinion after considering only a small number of facts or examples
exps_longman: ['She has a tendency to generalize from her husband to all men.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to use a particular set of facts or ideas in order to form an opinion that is considered valid for a different situation
exps_oxford_advanced: ['It would be foolish to generalize from a single example.', 'We cannot generalize from these few examples.']

sentence: Looking at those lists provides interesting reading and bears out the used-car trade 's view that having a lead-only car could prove to be a liability .
gloss: Carry the weight of; support.
eg_sent: the bees form large colonies and need the thick branches of tall trees to bear the weight of their nests
bis_def_collins: If you bear something somewhere, you carry it there or take it there.  [literary]
exps_collins: ['They bore the oblong hardwood box into the kitchen and put it on the table.']
bis_def_longman: to bravely accept or deal with a painful, difficult, or upsetting situation
exps_longman: ['She was afraid she wouldn’t be able to bear the pain.', 'Overcrowding makes prison life even harder to bear.', 'Make the water as hot as you can bear.', 'The humiliation was more than he could bear.', 'Black people continue to bear the brunt of most racial violence .', 'Passengers could be insulting, and stewardesses just had to grin and bear it.', 'Experts were worried the financial system would not be able to bear the strain.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to be able to accept and deal with something unpleasant
exps_oxford_advanced: ['The pain was almost more than he could bear.', "She couldn't bear the thought of losing him.", "I can't bear having cats in the house.", "He can't bear being laughed at.", "He can't bear to be laughed at.", 'How can you bear to eat that stuff?', "I can't bear you doing that."]

sentence: When I was n't excited
gloss: Cause (someone) to feel very enthusiastic and eager.
eg_sent: flying still excites me
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; If something excites you, it makes you feel very happy, eager, or enthusiastic. ;;
exps_collins: ['I only take on work that excites me, even if it means turning down lots of money.', "We'd not been excited by anything for about three years.", 'Where the show really excites is in the display of avant-garde photography.']
bis_def_longman: to make someone feel happy, interested, or eager
exps_longman: ['His playing is technically brilliant, but it doesn’t excite me.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to make somebody feel very pleased, interested or enthusiastic, especially about something that is going to happen
exps_oxford_advanced: ['The prospect of a year in India greatly excited her.']

sentence: In 1914 a register of car owners was compiled , also important when some voters could cast several votes in an election when polling went several days .
gloss: Move from one place to another; travel.
eg_sent: he went out to the shops
bis_def_collins: When you go somewhere, you move or travel there.

exps_longman: ['There’s nothing more we can do here. Let’s go home.', 'Where are you going?', 'We’re going to Canada in the summer.', 'Dinah went into the kitchen.', 'She went over and put her arm around him.', 'I’m going round to her house to find out what’s wrong.', 'I’ll just go up  and ask him what he wants.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to move or travel from one place to another
exps_oxford_advanced: ['She went into her room and shut the door behind her.', 'He goes to work by bus.', 'I have to go to Rome on business.', 'She has gone to China (= is now in China or is on her way there).', 'She has been to China (= she went to China and has now returned).', "I think you should go to the doctor's.", 'Are you going home for Christmas?', 'She has gone to see her sister this weekend.']

sentence: The need to know criterion is crucial because unless it is applied , the operator can be overburdened with unnecessary material .
gloss: Be aware of through observation, inquiry, or information.
eg_sent: most people know that CFCs can damage the ozone layer
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont]  If you know a fact, a piece of information, or an answer, you have it correctly in your mind.
exps_collins: ["I don't know the name of the place.", 'I know that you led a rifle platoon during the Second World War.', "'People like doing things for nothing.' — 'I know they do.'.", "I don't know what happened to her husband.", "'How did he meet your mother?' — 'I don't know.'.", 'We all know about his early experiments in flying.', 'They looked younger than I knew them to be.', 'Radon is known to be harmful to humans in large quantities.', 'It is not known whether the bomb was originally intended for the capital itself.', "It's always been known that key figures in the government do very well for themselves."]
bis_def_longman: to have information about something
exps_longman: ['Who knows the answer?', 'There are instructions telling you everything you need to know.', 'Didn’t you know that?', 'Do you know what time it is?', 'I don’t know where to go.', 'I need to know more about the job before I decide whether to apply for it.', 'Little is known about the author’s childhood.', 'I know all about David and what he’s been up to!', 'I wonder if he knew of the plan?', 'Do you know of any good restaurants in the area?', 'You know nothing of this business.', 'We know that greenhouse gases can affect the climate.', 'Let me know what time you’re planning to arrive.', 'I thought you’d want to know immediately.', 'If you must know, I was with James last night .', 'He slipped out of the house without his parents knowing .', 'How did he know our names?', '‘I’m divorced, as you know, ’ she said briefly.', 'Smoking is known to increase a person’s risk of developing lung cancer.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have information in your mind as a result of experience or because you have learned or been told it
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Do you know his address?', 'The cause of the fire is not yet known.', 'All I know is that she used to work in a bank (= I have no other information about her).', 'I know (that) people’s handwriting changes as they get older.', 'It is widely known that CFCs can damage the ozone layer.', 'I knew where he was hiding.', "I didn't know what he was talking about.", "‘You've got a flat tyre.’ ‘I know.’", "‘What's the answer?’ ‘I don't know.’", "‘There's no one in.’ ‘How do you know?’", "You know about Amanda's baby, don't you?", "I don't know about you, but I'm ready for something to eat.", 'I know of at least two people who did the same thing.', '‘Is anyone else coming?’ ‘Not that I know of.’', '‘Isn’t that his car?’ ‘I wouldn’t know./How should I know?’ (= I don’t know and I am not the person you should ask.)', "‘What are you two whispering about?’ ‘You don't want to know’ (= because you would be shocked or wouldn't approve).", 'Does he know to come here (= that he should come here) first?', 'We know her to be honest.', 'Two women are known to have died.']

sentence: The hole in the head , ai n't you ?

sentence: The trade union question would cease to haunt the Labour Party and while that might upset some Conservatives it would be good for the country .
gloss: (of a ghost) manifest itself at (a place) regularly.

sentence: Beyond that worst happening you think there can be nothing , the unimaginable has taken place , and on the other side is death , destruction , the end .
gloss: Have a particular opinion, belief, or idea about someone or something.
eg_sent: she thought that nothing would be the same again
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont] ; If you think that something is the case, you have the opinion that it is the case. ; [Also VERB n to-infinitive]
exps_collins: ['I certainly think there should be a ban on tobacco advertising.', 'Do you think I ought to seal the boxes up?.', 'A generation ago, it was thought that babies born this small could not survive.', 'Tell me, what do you think of my theory?.', 'Peter is useless, far worse than I thought.', 'He manages a good deal better than I thought possible.', "'It ought to be stopped.' — 'Yes, I think so.'"]
bis_def_longman: to have a particular opinion or to believe that something is true
exps_longman: ['I think that you’re being unfair.', 'I thought I heard something.', 'He didn’t think anyone would believe him.', 'Do you think I should call him?', 'For some reason, I keep thinking it’s Friday today.', 'The recession lasted longer than anyone thought it would.', 'Am I right in thinking that you have a brother?', 'I can’t help thinking that he’s made a mistake.', 'Do you honestly think I would do something so stupid?', 'What do you think of your new school?', 'I thought it best to call first.', 'I thought it appropriate to invite her to speak at the meeting.', 'We must start thinking in terms of reducing costs.', 'Fraud is thought to be costing software companies millions of dollars a year.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have a particular idea or opinion about something/somebody; to believe something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Do you think (that) they’ll come?', 'I thought I heard a scream.', "I didn't think you liked sports.", 'Am I right in thinking that you used to live here?', "I think this is their house, but I'm not sure.", 'He ought to resign, I think.', "We'll need about 20 chairs, I should think.", 'It was once thought that the sun travelled around the earth.', 'What did you think about the idea?', 'Well, I like it. What do you think?', '‘Will we make it in time?’ ‘I think so.’', "‘Is he any good?’ ‘I don't think so.’", "I think it highly unlikely that I'll get the job.", 'She thought him kind and generous.', "He's thought to be one of the richest men in Europe."]

sentence: You 're gon na kill somebody one day you know using that !
gloss: Take, hold, or deploy (something) as a means of accomplishing or achieving something; employ.

sentence: This is a typical coal shale ; shales and silts occurring between productive coal seams often contain impressions of the plants that went to form the coal .

sentence: Similarly the spread of violence in London to areas such as the Broadwater Farm Estate in Tottenham was seen as a break from previous experience , which had centred on areas such as Brixton .
gloss: Perceive with the eyes; discern visually.
eg_sent: in the distance she could see the blue sea
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont] ; When you see something, you notice it using your eyes. ;
exps_collins: ["You can't see colours at night.", 'I saw a man making his way towards me.', 'She can see, hear, touch, smell, and taste.', 'As he neared the farm, he saw that a police car was parked outside it.', 'Did you see what happened?', 'You use see to talk about things that you are aware of because a visual impression reaches your eyes. You often use can in this case. I can see the fax here on the desk. If you want to say that someone is paying attention to something they can see, you say that they are looking at it or watching it. In general, you look at something that is not moving, while you watch something that is moving or changing. I asked him to look at the picture above his bed... He watched Blake run down the stairs.']
bis_def_longman: to notice or examine someone or something, using your eyes
exps_longman: ['He crouched down so he couldn’t be seen.', 'Can I see your ticket, please?', 'You can see the Houses of Parliament from here.', 'Can you see where the marks are on the wall?', 'The suspect was seen entering the building.', 'As you can see, the house needs some work doing on it.', 'Have you seen Chris ?', 'The accommodation was so awful it had to be seen to be believed.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to become aware of somebody/something by using your eyes
exps_oxford_advanced: ["She looked for him but couldn't see him in the crowd.", 'I looked out of the window but saw nothing.', 'The opera was the place to see and be seen (= by other important or fashionable people).', 'He could see (that) she had been crying.', 'Did you see what happened?', 'If you watch carefully, you’ll see how it is done.', 'I hate to see you unhappy.', 'She was seen running away from the scene of the crime.', 'I saw you put the key in your pocket.', 'He was seen to enter the building about the time the crime was committed.']

sentence: We told her that a mud hut would do , but she said no , she 'd build something pukka .
gloss: Utter words so as to convey information, an opinion, a feeling or intention, or an instruction.
eg_sent: ‘Thank you,’ he said
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; When you say something, you speak words. ; [Also VERB to-infinitive]
exps_collins: ["'I'm sorry,' he said.", 'She said they were very impressed.', 'Forty-one people are said to have been seriously hurt.', 'I packed and said goodbye to Charlie.', "I hope you didn't say anything about Gretchen.", "You didn't say much when you telephoned.", 'Did he say where he was going?.', "It doesn't sound exactly orthodox, if I may say so."]
bis_def_longman: to express an idea, feeling, thought etc using words
exps_longman: ['‘Don’t cry, ’ he said softly.', 'Don’t believe anything he says.', 'A spokesman said that the company had improved its safety standards.', 'I always said I would buy a motorbike when I had enough money.', 'Did she say what happened?', 'I would like to say how much we appreciate your hard work.', '‘Why did she leave?’ ‘I don’t know – she didn’t say.’', 'What did you say to her?', 'What a silly thing to say!', 'She left without saying goodbye.', 'I’ve said I’m sorry – what more do you want?', 'Can I go, Mum? Oh, please say yes!', 'He looked as if he was going to say something.', 'I wished I had said nothing about Jordi.', 'Does anyone else have anything to say?', 'Although he didn’t say so, it was clear that he was in pain.', 'What makes you say that (=why do you think that) ? 你怎么会那么说呢？', 'Nina said to meet her at 4.30.', 'I’d like to say a few words.', '‘So what are your plans now?’ ‘I’d rather not say.’']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to speak or tell somebody something, using words
exps_oxford_advanced: ['‘Hello!’ she said.', '‘That was marvellous,’ said Daniel.', 'Be quiet, I have something to say.', "I didn't believe a word she said.", "That's a terrible thing to say.", "He knew that if he wasn't back by midnight, his parents would have something to say about it (= be angry).", 'She said nothing to me about it.', "I said to myself (= thought), ‘That can't be right!’", 'He said (that) his name was Sam.', 'It is said that she lived to be over 100.', 'She finds it hard to say what she feels.', "‘That's impossible!’ ‘So you say (= but I think you may be wrong).’", "‘Why can't I go out now?’ ‘Because I say so.’", "‘What do you want it for?’ ‘I'd rather not say.’", 'He said to meet him here.', 'He is said to have been a brilliant scholar.']

sentence: This means in practice that district medical officers are charged with preparing an annual report , presenting and interpreting epidemiological data , identifying local health problems and evaluating service outcomes .
gloss: Demand (an amount) as a price for a service rendered or goods supplied.
eg_sent: wedding planners may charge an hourly fee of up to £150
bis_def_collins: VERB  …;(); If you charge someone an amount of money, you ask them to pay that amount for something that you have sold to them or done for them. …;();
exps_collins: ['Even local nurseries charge £100 a week.', 'The majority of stalls charged a fair price.', 'The hospitals charge the patients for every aspirin.', 'Some banks charge if you access your account to determine your balance.', '...the architect who charged us a fee of seven hundred and fifty pounds.']
bis_def_longman: to ask someone for a particular amount of money for something you are selling
exps_longman: ['The hotel charges $125 a night.', 'The restaurant charged us £40 for the wine.', 'Calls will be charged at 44p per minute.', 'We won’t charge for delivery if you pay now.', 'The gallery charges an entrance fee.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to ask an amount of money for goods or a service
exps_oxford_advanced: ['What did they charge for the repairs?', 'The restaurant charged £20 for dinner.', 'They’re charging £3 for the catalogue.', "We won't charge you for delivery.", 'Calls are charged at 36p per minute.', 'He only charged me half price.', 'Do you think museums should charge for admission?', "The bank doesn't charge to stop a payment."]

sentence: Disillusion swiftly followed .
gloss: Go or come after (a person or thing proceeding ahead); move or travel behind.
eg_sent: she went back into the house, and Ben followed her
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; If you follow someone who is going somewhere, you move along behind them because you want to go to the same place. ; [Also V + after]
exps_collins: ['We followed him up the steps into a large hall.', 'Please follow me, madam.', 'They took him into a small room and I followed.']
bis_def_longman: to go, walk, drive etc behind or after someone else
exps_longman: ['Are those men following us?', 'The patrol car followed the BMW for a few miles and then lost it.', 'Tom’s already gone out to Rome and his wife and children will follow shortly.', 'Peggy followed her out onto the landing.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to come or go after or behind somebody/something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['He followed her into the house.', "Follow me please. I'll show you the way.", "I think we're being followed.", 'She followed her mother into the medical profession.', 'Wherever she led, they followed.', 'Sam walked in, with the rest of the boys following closely behind.']

sentence: We are not going to enquire into the details how such beams can be produced ( it belongs to the subject of physical electronics ) ; we shall accept the fact that the beam exists and will try to work out the forces on the outermost electrons .
gloss: Ask for information from someone.
eg_sent: he inquired about cottages for sale
bis_def_longman: another spelling of inquire
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to ask somebody for some information
exps_oxford_advanced: ['I called the station to enquire about train times.', 'She enquired as to your whereabouts.', 'Might I enquire why you have not mentioned this until now?', 'He enquired her name.', '‘What is your name?’ he enquired.']

sentence: Their South Molton cottage ( guide price ÇÎ£44,000-ÇÎ£46,000 ) is one of more than 20 lots to be put up for sale at the Barnstaple auction by Bristol and West Property Services , and one of more than a hundred which the building society subsidiary will be auctioning in eight West Country venues over a three-day period .

exps_longman: ['Sotheby’s estimated that its Impressionist paintings auction would take in about $80 million.', 'The buildings will be sold at auction next month.', 'The house was put up for auction.', 'Repossessed houses are often auctioned.', 'Fleet arranged to auction off the company’s inventory and equipment.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to sell something at an auction
exps_oxford_advanced: ['The costumes from the movie are to be auctioned for charity.']

sentence: One of the examples of work in progress discusses research that has been carried out for the European Commission as part of the CORINE Project .
gloss: Support and move (someone or something) from one place to another.
eg_sent: medics were carrying a wounded man on a stretcher
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;;;; If you carry something, you take it with you, holding it so that it does not touch the ground. ;;;;
exps_collins: ['He was carrying a briefcase.', 'He carried the plate through to the dining room.', 'She carried her son to the car.', "If your job involves a lot of paperwork, you're going to need something to carry it all in."]
bis_def_longman: to hold something in your hand or arms, or support it as you take it somewhere

sentence: I 've seen the photographs .
gloss: Perceive with the eyes; discern visually.
eg_sent: in the distance she could see the blue sea
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont] ; When you see something, you notice it using your eyes. ;
exps_collins: ["You can't see colours at night.", 'I saw a man making his way towards me.', 'She can see, hear, touch, smell, and taste.', 'As he neared the farm, he saw that a police car was parked outside it.', 'Did you see what happened?', 'You use see to talk about things that you are aware of because a visual impression reaches your eyes. You often use can in this case. I can see the fax here on the desk. If you want to say that someone is paying attention to something they can see, you say that they are looking at it or watching it. In general, you look at something that is not moving, while you watch something that is moving or changing. I asked him to look at the picture above his bed... He watched Blake run down the stairs.']
bis_def_longman: to notice or examine someone or something, using your eyes
exps_longman: ['He crouched down so he couldn’t be seen.', 'Can I see your ticket, please?', 'You can see the Houses of Parliament from here.', 'Can you see where the marks are on the wall?', 'The suspect was seen entering the building.', 'As you can see, the house needs some work doing on it.', 'Have you seen Chris ?', 'The accommodation was so awful it had to be seen to be believed.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to become aware of somebody/something by using your eyes
exps_oxford_advanced: ["She looked for him but couldn't see him in the crowd.", 'I looked out of the window but saw nothing.', 'The opera was the place to see and be seen (= by other important or fashionable people).', 'He could see (that) she had been crying.', 'Did you see what happened?', 'If you watch carefully, you’ll see how it is done.', 'I hate to see you unhappy.', 'She was seen running away from the scene of the crime.', 'I saw you put the key in your pocket.', 'He was seen to enter the building about the time the crime was committed.']

sentence: Did you try it did you ?
gloss: Make an attempt or effort to do something.
eg_sent: he tried to regain his breath
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; If you try to do something, you want to do it, and you take action which you hope will help you to do it. ;;
exps_collins: ['He secretly tried to block her advancement in the Party.', 'Try to make the effort to work your way through all of your tasks one at a time…', "Does it annoy you if others do things less well than you would, or don't seem to try hard enough?.", "I tried calling him when I got here but he wasn't at home.", 'No matter how bad you feel, keep trying.']
bis_def_longman: to take action in order to do something that you may not be able to do
exps_longman: ['Let’s have a rest and then we’ll try again.', 'He tried to control his voice.', 'She was trying not to cry.', 'She dabbed at her face and tried hard not to sniff.', 'I tried everything to lose weight with no success.', 'I tried my best to comfort her.', 'I tried and tried and eventually I was offered a job.', 'They didn’t get any goals, but it wasn’t for lack of trying.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to make an attempt or effort to do or get something
exps_oxford_advanced: ["I don't know if I can come but I'll try.", 'What are you trying to do?', 'I tried hard not to laugh.', 'You haven’t even tried to find it.', 'Don’t try to do it too quickly.', 'She tried her best to solve the problem.', 'Just try your hardest.']

sentence: Yet they are saved from sentimentality by the wry humour of both text and pictures .
gloss: Keep safe or rescue (someone or something) from harm or danger.
eg_sent: they brought him in to help save the club from bankruptcy
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;;; If you save someone or something, you help them to avoid harm or to escape from a dangerous or unpleasant situation. ;;;
exps_collins: ["...a final attempt to save 40,000 jobs in Britain's troubled aero industry.", 'One man was still missing last night after the Belgian trawler Lucky capsized off the Dutch coast. Three other men were saved.', 'A new machine no bigger than a 10p piece could help save babies from cot death.', 'The national health system saved him from becoming a cripple.']
bis_def_longman: to make someone or something safe from danger, harm, or destruction
exps_longman: ['Emergency aid could save millions threatened with starvation.', 'a new treatment that could save his life', 'She was determined to save her marriage.', 'the campaign to save the rain forests', 'He saved the child from drowning.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to keep somebody/something safe from death, harm, loss, etc.
exps_oxford_advanced: ['to save somebody’s life', 'Doctors were unable to save her.', "He's trying to save their marriage.", 'She needs to win the next two games to save the match.', 'Thanks for doing that. You saved my life (= helped me a lot).', 'to save a rare species (from extinction)', 'Money from local businesses helped save the school from closure.', 'She saved a little girl from falling into the water.']

sentence: This was the essence of the problem : the press could only be managed by someone who knew their methods and who would not expect them to come round to Central Office to search for news .
gloss: Move or travel towards or into a place thought of as near or familiar to the speaker.
eg_sent: Jessica came into the kitchen
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; When a person or thing comes to a particular place, especially to a place where you are, they move there. ;
exps_collins: ['Two police officers came into the hall.', 'Come here, Tom.', "You'll have to come with us.", 'We want you to come to lunch.', 'I came over from Ireland to start a new life after my divorce.', 'We heard the train coming.', 'Can I come too?.', 'The impact blew out some of the windows and the sea came rushing in.']
bis_def_longman: to move towards you or arrive at the place where you are
exps_longman: ['Let me know when they come.', 'Can you come here for a minute?', 'What time will you be coming home?', 'There was a knock on the door and a young woman came into the room.', 'I could see a figure coming towards me.', 'As they came down the track, the car skidded.', 'I’ve come to see Philip.', 'I’ll come and help you move the rest of the boxes.', 'Jess came flying round the corner and banged straight into me.', 'What day are your folks coming to dinner?', 'Ah, here comes the bus at last!']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to move to or towards a person or place
exps_oxford_advanced: ['He came into the room and shut the door.', 'She comes to work by bus.', 'My son is coming home soon.', 'Come here!', 'Come and see us soon!', 'Here comes Jo! (= Jo is coming)', "There's a storm coming.", "They're coming to stay for a week."]

sentence: So , so so I said well we 'll go to the N E C or she said oh I 'm not traipsing all that way , you know , just for the concert .
gloss: Move from one place to another; travel.
eg_sent: he went out to the shops
bis_def_collins: When you go somewhere, you move or travel there.
exps_collins: ['We went to Rome.', 'Gladys had just gone into the kitchen.', 'I went home at the weekend.', 'Four of them had gone off to find help.', 'It took us an hour to go three miles.']
bis_def_longman: to travel or move to a place that is away from where you are or where you live
exps_longman: ['There’s nothing more we can do here. Let’s go home.', 'Where are you going?', 'We’re going to Canada in the summer.', 'Dinah went into the kitchen.', 'She went over and put her arm around him.', 'I’m going round to her house to find out what’s wrong.', 'I’ll just go up  and ask him what he wants.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to move or travel from one place to another
exps_oxford_advanced: ['She went into her room and shut the door behind her.', 'He goes to work by bus.', 'I have to go to Rome on business.', 'She has gone to China (= is now in China or is on her way there).', 'She has been to China (= she went to China and has now returned).', "I think you should go to the doctor's.", 'Are you going home for Christmas?', 'She has gone to see her sister this weekend.']

sentence: Changes in political priorities may simply result in the need for informed guesswork if suitable data are not available .
gloss: Give (someone) facts or information; tell.
eg_sent: he wrote to her, informing her of the situation
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; If you inform someone of something, you tell them about it. ; [Also VERB n]
exps_collins: ['They would inform him of any progress they had made.', 'My daughter informed me that she was pregnant.', "'I just added a little soy sauce,' he informs us."]
bis_def_longman: to officially tell someone about something or give them information
exps_longman: ['They decided to inform the police', 'Please inform us of any change of address as soon as possible.', 'We regret to inform you that your application has been rejected.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to tell somebody about something, especially in an official way
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Please inform us of any changes of address.', 'The leaflet informs customers about healthy eating.', 'He went to inform them of his decision.', 'Inform me at once if there are any changes in her condition.', 'Have the police been informed?', 'I have been reliably informed (= somebody I trust has told me) that the couple will marry next year.', 'A notice informed the guests that formal dress was required.', 'I am pleased to inform you that you have won first prize in this month’s competition.', "‘He's already left,’ she informed us.", 'I have not been informed when the ceremony will take place.']

sentence: This is plainly evident from the section of the contract signed by each participant where what is expected of them is spelt out :
gloss: Regard (something) as likely to happen.
eg_sent: it's as well to expect the worst
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; If you expect something to happen, you believe that it will happen. ;;
exps_collins: ['...a council workman who expects to lose his job in the next few weeks.', 'They no longer expect corporate profits to improve.', 'The talks are expected to continue until tomorrow.', 'Few expected that he would declare his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for the presidency.', "It is expected that the new owner will change the yacht's name.", 'They expect a gradual improvement in sales of new cars.']
bis_def_longman: to think that something will happen because it seems likely or has been planned
exps_longman: ['I expect to be back within a week.', 'The company expects to complete work in April.', 'Emergency repairs were expected to take three weeks.', 'I didn’t expect him to stay so long.', 'There’s the doorbell – I expect it’ll be my mother.', 'He will be hard to beat. I fully expect that and I’m ready.', '‘Who are you?’ he murmured, only half expecting her to answer.', 'He didn’t get his expected pay rise.', 'As expected, the whole family was shocked by the news.', 'A little nervousness is only to be expected when you are starting a new job.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to think or believe that something will happen or that somebody will do something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['We are expecting a rise in food prices this month.', "Don't expect sympathy from me!", "That's not the sort of behaviour I expect of you!", "You can't expect to learn a foreign language in a few months.", 'I looked back, half expecting to see someone following me.', 'House prices are expected to rise sharply.', 'I didn’t expect him to become a successful writer.', 'Do you really expect me to believe you?', 'Many people were expecting (that) the peace talks would break down.', 'It is expected that the report will suggest some major reforms.']

sentence: The problem is that normally potential purchasers have to incur the expense of undertaking surveys and arranging mortgage finance , without any idea whether they will be able to afford the final selling price .
gloss: Become subject to (something unwelcome or unpleasant) as a result of one's own behaviour or actions.
eg_sent: I will pay any expenses incurred
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; If you incur something unpleasant, it happens to you because of something you have done. ;; [written]
exps_collins: ['The government had also incurred huge debts.', 'She falls in love and incurs the wrath of her father.', '...the terrible damage incurred during the past decade.']
bis_def_longman: if you incur a cost, debt, or a fine, you have to pay money because of something you have done
exps_longman: ['If the council loses the appeal, it will incur all the legal costs.', 'the heavy losses incurred by airlines since September 11th']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: if you incur something unpleasant, you are in a situation in which you have to deal with it
exps_oxford_advanced: ['She had incurred the wrath of her father by marrying without his consent']

sentence: Her priorities include giving more encouragement to medical research ; emphasis on preventive health to make the NHS a health as well as a sickness service , with the publication shortly of new national targets for reducing deaths from heart disease and cancers ; and pressing ahead with care in the community .
gloss: Freely transfer the possession of (something) to (someone)
eg_sent: she gave him presents and clothes
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont]  You can use give with nouns that refer to physical actions. The whole expression refers to the performing of the action. For example, She gave a smile means almost the same as 'She smiled'.
exps_collins: ['She stretched her arms out and gave a great yawn.', 'Giving a sigh, she fell to her knees at my feet.', 'He gave her a fond smile.', 'He reached for her hand and gave it a reassuring squeeze.']
bis_def_longman: to let someone have something as a present, or to provide something for someone
exps_longman: ['What did Bob give you for your birthday?', 'Researchers were given a £10,000 grant to continue their work.', 'I’ve got some old diaries that my grandmother gave me years ago.', 'a ring which was given to him by his mother', 'I didn’t steal it! Maria gave it to me!', 'Most people are willing to give to charity.', 'The situation is now desperate, so please give generously.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to hand something to somebody so that they can look at it, use it or keep it for a time
exps_oxford_advanced: ["Give the letter to your mother when you've read it.", 'She gave her ticket to the woman at the check-in desk.', 'Give your mother the letter.', 'They were all given a box to carry.']

sentence: You need a secure situation with someone you can trust , who you know will stick around because he loves you .

bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have confidence in somebody; to believe that somebody is good, sincere, honest, etc.
exps_oxford_advanced: ['She trusts Alan implicitly.', 'You can trust me not to tell anyone.']

sentence: I think it 's half the point !
gloss: Have a particular opinion, belief, or idea about someone or something.
eg_sent: she thought that nothing would be the same again

You often use can in this case. I can see the fax here on the desk. If you want to say that someone is paying attention to something they can see, you say that they are looking at it or watching it. In general, you look at something that is not moving, while you watch something that is moving or changing. I asked him to look at the picture above his bed... He watched Blake run down the stairs.']

bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont]  If you know a fact, a piece of information, or an answer, you have it correctly in your mind.
exps_collins: ["I don't know the name of the place.", 'I know that you led a rifle platoon during the Second World War.', "'People like doing things for nothing.' — 'I know they do.'.", "I don't know what happened to her husband.", "'How did he meet your mother?' — 'I don't know.'.", 'We all know about his early experiments in flying.', 'They looked younger than I knew them to be.', 'Radon is known to be harmful to humans in large quantities.', 'It is not known whether the bomb was originally intended for the capital itself.', "It's always been known that key figures in the government do very well for themselves."]
bis_def_longman: to have information about something
exps_longman: ['Who knows the answer?', 'There are instructions telling you everything you need to know.', 'Didn’t you know that?', 'Do you know what time it is?', 'I don’t know where to go.', 'I need to know more about the job before I decide whether to apply for it.', 'Little is known about the author’s childhood.', 'I know all about David and what he’s been up to!', 'I wonder if he knew of the plan?', 'Do you know of any good restaurants in the area?', 'You know nothing of this business.', 'We know that greenhouse gases can affect the climate.', 'Let me know what time you’re planning to arrive.', 'I thought you’d want to know immediately.', 'If you must know, I was with James last night .', 'He slipped out of the house without his parents knowing .', 'How did he know our names?', '‘I’m divorced, as you know, ’ she said briefly.', 'Smoking is known to increase a person’s risk of developing lung cancer.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have information in your mind as a result of experience or because you have learned or been told it
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Do you know his address?', 'The cause of the fire is not yet known.', 'All I know is that she used to work in a bank (= I have no other information about her).', 'I know (that) people’s handwriting changes as they get older.', 'It is widely known that CFCs can damage the ozone layer.', 'I knew where he was hiding.', "I didn't know what he was talking about.", "‘You've got a flat tyre.’ ‘I know.’", "‘What's the answer?’ ‘I don't know.’", "‘There's no one in.’ ‘How do you know?’", "You know about Amanda's baby, don't you?", "I don't know about you, but I'm ready for something to eat.", 'I know of at least two people who did the same thing.', '‘Is anyone else coming?’ ‘Not that I know of.’', '‘Isn’t that his car?’ ‘I wouldn’t know./How should I know?’ (= I don’t know and I am not the person you should ask.)', "‘What are you two whispering about?’ ‘You don't want to know’ (= because you would be shocked or wouldn't approve).", 'Does he know to come here (= that he should come here) first?', 'We know her to be honest.', 'Two women are known to have died.']

sentence: This is a clear example of the extension of the Prevention of Terrorism Act where criteria for stopping , questioning and searching are purely subjective to the official involved .
gloss: Try to find something by looking or otherwise seeking carefully and thoroughly.
eg_sent: I searched among the rocks, but there was nothing
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;;; If you search for something or someone, you look carefully for them. ;;; [Also VERB]
exps_collins: ['The Turkish security forces have started searching for the missing men.', 'They searched for a spot where they could sit on the floor.', 'Nonetheless there are signs that both sides may be searching for a compromise.']
bis_def_longman: to try to find someone or something by looking very carefully
exps_longman: ['It was too dark to search further.', 'The area was thoroughly searched.', 'An RAF plane searched for the missing men.', 'I’ve searched high and low for my glasses.', 'Detectives are searching the yard for clues.', 'Alice bent to search through a heap of clothes.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to look carefully for something/somebody; to examine a particular place when looking for somebody/something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['She searched in vain for her passport.', 'Police searched for clues in the area.', 'The customs officers searched through our bags.', "I've searched high and low for those files.", 'I found these photos while searching among some old papers.', 'His house had clearly been searched and the book was missing.', 'Police searched the area for clues.', 'Firefighters searched the buildings for survivors.', 'searching the Web for interesting sites']

sentence: When asked why he did it , D replied : Just to wake her up and frighten her .
gloss: Emerge or cause to emerge from sleep; stop sleeping.
eg_sent: she woke up feeling better
bis_def_collins: V-ERG  ;;; When you wake or when someone or something wakes you, you become conscious again after being asleep. ;;;
exps_collins: ['It was cold and dark when I woke at 6.30.', 'Bob woke slowly to sunshine pouring in his window.', 'She woke to find her dark room lit by flashing lights.', 'She went upstairs to wake Milton.', 'One morning I woke up and felt something was wrong.', 'At dawn I woke him up and said we were leaving.']
bis_def_longman: to stop sleeping, or to make someone stop sleeping
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to stop sleeping; to make somebody stop sleeping
exps_oxford_advanced: ['What time do you usually wake up in the morning?', 'I always wake early in the summer.', "Wake up! It's eight o'clock.", 'They woke to a clear blue sky.', 'She had just woken from a deep sleep.', 'He woke up to find himself alone in the house.', 'Try not to wake the baby up.', 'I was woken by the sound of someone moving around.']

sentence: Finally the checklist may have reprographic limitations such as inadequate vertical or horizontal structure , poor typefaces and insufficient linking of requirements , descriptions , remarks and tick-off points .
gloss: Make, form, or suggest a connection with or between.
eg_sent: rumours that linked his name with Judith
bis_def_collins: If someone or something links two things or situations, there is a relationship between them, for example because one thing causes or affects the other.  [Also + V n with]
exps_collins: ['The UN Security Council has linked any lifting of sanctions to compliance with the ceasefire terms.', 'The study further strengthens the evidence linking smoking with early death.', 'Liver cancer is linked to the hepatitis B virus.', 'The detention raised two distinct but closely linked questions.']
bis_def_longman: if two things are linked, they are related in some way
exps_longman: ['Police think the murders are linked.', 'Some birth defects are linked to smoking during pregnancy.', 'Our economy is inextricably linked with America’s.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to make a physical or electronic connection between one object, machine, place, etc. and another
exps_oxford_advanced: ['The video cameras are linked to a powerful computer.', 'The Channel Tunnel links Britain with the rest of Europe.', 'When computers are networked, they are linked together so that information can be transferred between them.']

sentence: Let us briefly consider some of the possibilities .
gloss: Think carefully about (something), typically before making a decision.
eg_sent: each application is considered on its merits
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; If you consider a person or thing to be something, you have the opinion that this is what they are. ;
exps_collins: ["We don't consider our customers to be mere consumers; we consider them to be our friends.", 'I had always considered myself a strong, competent woman.', 'The paper does not explain why foreign ownership should be considered bad.', 'I consider activities such as jogging and weightlifting as unnatural.', 'Barbara considers that pet shops which sell customers these birds are very unfair.']
bis_def_longman: to think about something carefully, especially before making a choice or decision
exps_longman: ['I seriously considered resigning .', 'Have you considered the possibility of retraining?', 'We are considering whether to change our advice to tourists.', 'We’re still considering where to move to.', 'We will have to consider your offer carefully.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to think about something carefully, especially in order to make a decision
exps_oxford_advanced: ["I'd like some time to consider.", 'She considered her options.', 'Let us consider the facts.', 'He was considering an appeal.', 'a carefully considered response', 'The company is being actively considered as a potential partner (= it is thought possible that it could become one).', "We're considering buying a new car.", 'You wouldn’t consider marrying a man for his money, then?', 'We need to consider how the law might be reformed.', 'He was considering what to do next.']

sentence: She squared up to him , defiantly ,
gloss: Make square or rectangular; give a square or rectangular cross section to.
eg_sent: you can square off the other edge
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;() To square a number means to multiply it by itself. For example, 3 squared is 3 x 3, or 9. 3 squared is usually written as 32. ;()
exps_collins: ['Take the time in seconds, square it, and multiply by 5.12.', 'A squared plus B squared equals C squared.']
bis_def_longman: to multiply a number by itself
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to make something have straight edges and corners
exps_oxford_advanced: ['It was like trying to square a circle. That is, it was impossible.', 'The boat is rounded at the front but squared off at the back.']

sentence: Existing GIS techniques usually base the estimates on area-weighted shares , so that a new polygon created by slicing an existing area in half is assigned half the population of that source unit .
gloss: Have objective reality or being.
eg_sent: dossiers existed on almost everyone of prominence
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont] ; If something exists, it is present in the world as a real thing. ;
exps_collins: ["He thought that if he couldn't see something, it didn't exist.", 'Research opportunities exist in a wide range of pure and applied areas of entomology.', 'When Alfred Adler first postulated in 1908 that there existed an inborn instinct of aggression Freud argued against it.']
bis_def_longman: to happen or be present in a particular situation or place
exps_longman: ['The custom of arranged marriages still exists in many countries.', 'Opportunities exist for students to gain sponsorship.', 'Stop pretending that the problem doesn’t exist.', 'The club will cease to exist if financial help is not found.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to be real; to be present in a place or situation
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Does life exist on other planets?', 'The problem only exists in your head, Jane.', 'Few of these monkeys still exist in the wild.', 'On his retirement the post will cease to exist.', 'The charity exists to support victims of crime.']

sentence: Shut the door there we are .
gloss: Move (something) into position so as to block an opening; close.
eg_sent: shut the window, please
bis_def_collins: V-ERG  ;; If you shut something such as a door or if it shuts, it moves so that it fills a hole or a space. ;;
exps_collins: ['Just make sure you shut the gate after you.', 'The screen door shut gently.']
bis_def_longman: to close something, or to become closed
exps_longman: ['I heard his bedroom door shut.', 'She lay down on her bed and shut her eyes.', 'She walked quickly in and shut the door behind her.', 'He shut the drawer and turned the key.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to make something close; to become closed
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Philip went into his room and shut the door behind him.', "I can't shut my suitcase—it's too full.", 'She shut her eyes and fell asleep immediately.', 'He shut his book and looked up.', "The window won't shut.", 'The doors open and shut automatically.']

sentence: Right , just , she said she 's going to be head of department , it starts at ten OK , so she 'll be ahead of herself , then as she 'll be responsible for getting staff said she still has n't , got she said , little love
gloss: Utter words so as to convey information, an opinion, a feeling or intention, or an instruction.
eg_sent: ‘Thank you,’ he said
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; When you say something, you speak words. ; [Also VERB to-infinitive]
exps_collins: ["'I'm sorry,' he said.", 'She said they were very impressed.', 'Forty-one people are said to have been seriously hurt.', 'I packed and said goodbye to Charlie.', "I hope you didn't say anything about Gretchen.", "You didn't say much when you telephoned.", 'Did he say where he was going?.', "It doesn't sound exactly orthodox, if I may say so."]
bis_def_longman: to express an idea, feeling, thought etc using words
exps_longman: ['‘Don’t cry, ’ he said softly.', 'Don’t believe anything he says.', 'A spokesman said that the company had improved its safety standards.', 'I always said I would buy a motorbike when I had enough money.', 'Did she say what happened?', 'I would like to say how much we appreciate your hard work.', '‘Why did she leave?’ ‘I don’t know – she didn’t say.’', 'What did you say to her?', 'What a silly thing to say!', 'She left without saying goodbye.', 'I’ve said I’m sorry – what more do you want?', 'Can I go, Mum? Oh, please say yes!', 'He looked as if he was going to say something.', 'I wished I had said nothing about Jordi.', 'Does anyone else have anything to say?', 'Although he didn’t say so, it was clear that he was in pain.', 'What makes you say that (=why do you think that) ? 你怎么会那么说呢？', 'Nina said to meet her at 4.30.', 'I’d like to say a few words.', '‘So what are your plans now?’ ‘I’d rather not say.’']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to speak or tell somebody something, using words
exps_oxford_advanced: ['‘Hello!’ she said.', '‘That was marvellous,’ said Daniel.', 'Be quiet, I have something to say.', "I didn't believe a word she said.", "That's a terrible thing to say.", "He knew that if he wasn't back by midnight, his parents would have something to say about it (= be angry).", 'She said nothing to me about it.', "I said to myself (= thought), ‘That can't be right!’", 'He said (that) his name was Sam.', 'It is said that she lived to be over 100.', 'She finds it hard to say what she feels.', "‘That's impossible!’ ‘So you say (= but I think you may be wrong).’", "‘Why can't I go out now?’ ‘Because I say so.’", "‘What do you want it for?’ ‘I'd rather not say.’", 'He said to meet him here.', 'He is said to have been a brilliant scholar.']

sentence: Sometimes he felt that he was the person he was because of them and acted the way he did because of their effects .
gloss: Be aware of (a person or object) through touching or being touched.
eg_sent: she felt someone touch her shoulder
bis_def_collins: V-LINK  ;; If you feel a particular emotion or physical sensation, you experience it. ;;
exps_collins: ['I am feeling very depressed.', 'I will always feel grateful to that little guy.', 'I remember feeling sick.', '...soldiers who once felt proud to wear their uniforms.', 'Suddenly I felt a sharp pain in my shoulder.', "You won't feel a thing.", 'I felt as if all my strength had gone.', 'I felt like I was being kicked in the teeth every day.']

sentence: Given very wide regional and local variations in deposition , questions must be raised about the effectiveness of such a small network ; local authorities will need to supplement it with their own networks .
gloss: Add an extra element or amount to.
eg_sent: I looked for a part-time job to supplement my income
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; If you supplement something, you add something to it in order to improve it. ;
exps_collins: ['...people doing extra jobs outside their regular jobs to supplement their incomes.', 'I suggest supplementing your diet with vitamins E and A.']
bis_def_longman: to add something, especially to what you earn or eat, in order to increase it to an acceptable level
exps_longman: ['Kia supplements her regular salary by tutoring in the evenings.', 'The acquisition will supplement their business strategy to produce higher-margin products.', 'As the number of farmers falls, many are seeking new outlets to supplement their incomes.', 'The staff handbooks will be supplemented with a series of workshops.', 'Thewelfare supplement is payable to employees who retire between Nov. 1 and Dec. 31.', 'The informal discussion groups are a good supplement to the overall training program.', 'a 16-page advertising supplement', 'The actual amount of commission is only disclosed in a supplement to the firm’s prospectus.', 'There is a single room supplement of £10 per night.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to add something to something in order to improve it or make it more complete
exps_oxford_advanced: ['a diet supplemented with vitamin pills', 'He supplements his income by giving private lessons.']

sentence: Howard Rosenberg , TV critic of the Los Angeles Times , said : Just look at the re-runs of the old western series .
gloss: Direct one's gaze toward someone or something or in a specified direction.
eg_sent: people were looking at him
bis_def_collins: If you look in a particular direction, you direct your eyes in that direction, especially so that you can see what is there or see what something is like.
exps_collins: ['I looked down the hallway to room number nine.', 'She turned to look at him.', 'He looked away, apparently enraged.', "If you look, you'll see what was a lake.", 'If you want to say that someone is paying attention to something they can see, you say that they are looking at it or watching it. In general, you look at something that is not moving, while you watch something that is moving or changing. I asked him to look at the picture above his bed... He watched Blake run down the stairs. Look is never followed directly by an object. You must always use at or some other preposition. I looked towards the plane. You use see to talk about things that you are aware of because a visual impression reaches your eyes. You often use can in this case. I can see the fax here on the desk.']
bis_def_longman: to turn your eyes towards something, so that you can see it
exps_longman: ['We sneaked out while Jessie’s mom wasn’t looking.', 'If you look carefully you can see that the painting represents a human figure.', 'Gina covered her eyes, afraid to look.', '‘It’s time we left, ’ Ian said, looking at his watch.', 'The men all turned to look at her as she entered the room.', 'Dad looked up from his paper and smiled.', '‘We can’t go out in this weather, ’ said Bob, looking out of the window.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to turn your eyes in a particular direction
exps_oxford_advanced: ['If you look carefully you can just see our house from here.', 'She looked at me and smiled.', "‘Has the mail come yet?’ ‘I'll look and see.’", "Look! I'm sure that's Brad Pitt!", "Don't look now, but there's someone staring at you!"]
