sentence: They get a bit carried away actually .
gloss: Come to have (something); receive.
eg_sent: I got a letter from him the other day
bis_def_collins: You use get with adjectives to mean 'become'. For example, if someone gets cold, they become cold, and if they get angry, they become angry.
exps_collins: ['The boys were getting bored.', "There's no point in getting upset.", 'From here on, it can only get better.']
bis_def_longman: to receive something that someone gives you or sends you
exps_longman: ['She got loads of presents.', 'What did you get for Christmas?', 'We get a lot of junk mail.', 'We got a letter from Pam this morning.', 'I got it off my Dad.', 'I got a few games free when I bought my computer.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to receive something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['I got a letter from Dave this morning.', 'What (= What presents) did you get for your birthday?', 'He gets (= earns) about $40\u2009000 a year.', 'This room gets very little sunshine.', 'I got a shock when I saw the bill.', 'I get the impression that he is bored with his job.']

sentence: These flowers have five oval petals , finely veined .

sentence: In reality you just invent a tale , as if you were sitting round a fire in a cave .

sentence: It is generally accepted ( p. 145 ) that hygiene type variables such as pay and working conditions can , if they are inappropriately specified , depress morale and motivation but they will not in themselves result in very high levels of these parameters .
gloss: Identify clearly and definitely.
eg_sent: he did not specify a reason for leaving

exps_longman: ['Payments will be made for a specified number of months.', 'Regulations specify how long maintenance crews can work.', 'The rules clearly specify that competitors must not accept payment.', 'It is useful to specify the due date for payment.', 'The work must be completed within the specified period agreed in the contract.', 'The manufacturer specifies that the cement must be left for 72 hours.']

sentence: She laughed at him and said gravely that she would be happy to indulge him , and he went away , grinning .
gloss: Smile broadly.
eg_sent: Dennis appeared, grinning cheerfully
bis_def_collins: When you grin, you smile broadly.
exps_collins: ['He grins, delighted at the memory.', "Sarah tried several times to catch Philip's eye, but he just grinned at her.", '...a statue of a grinning old man cutting the throat of a deer.']
bis_def_longman: to smile widely
exps_longman: ['She grinned at me, her eyes sparkling.', 'He walked out of the pool, grinning widely.', 'He was grinning like an idiot .']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to smile widely
exps_oxford_advanced: ['They grinned with delight when they heard our news.', 'Stop grinning and tell me what happened!', 'He was grinning from ear to ear.', 'She grinned amiably at us.', 'He grinned a wide grin.']

sentence: Put it on alright ?
gloss: Move to or place in a particular position.
eg_sent: I put my hand out towards her
bis_def_collins: When you put something in a particular place or position, you move it into that place or position.
exps_collins: ['Leaphorn put the photograph on the desk.', "She hesitated, then put her hand on Grace's arm.", 'Mishka put down a heavy shopping bag.']
bis_def_longman: to move something to a particular place or position, especially using your hands
exps_longman: ['He put the coffee on the table.', 'Where did you put the programmes?']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to move something into a particular place or position
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Put the cases down there, please.', 'Did you put sugar in my coffee?', 'Put your hand up if you need more paper.']

sentence: Once the hammer has fallen , the successful bidder for a house must exchange contracts immediately and pay a deposit .
gloss: Give something and receive something of the same kind in return.
eg_sent: we exchanged addresses
bis_def_collins: V-RECIP  ; If two or more people exchange things of a particular kind, they give them to each other at the same time. ;
exps_collins: ['We exchanged addresses and Christmas cards.', 'The two men exchanged glances.', 'He exchanged a quick smile with her then entered the lift.']
bis_def_longman: to give someone something and receive the same kind of thing from them at the same time
exps_longman: ['We exchange gifts at Christmas.', 'At the end of the game, players traditionally exchange shirts with each other.', 'We exchanged phone numbers.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to give something to somebody and at the same time receive the same type of thing from them
exps_oxford_advanced: ['to exchange ideas/news/information', 'Juliet and David exchanged glances (= they looked at each other).', 'Everyone in the group exchanged email addresses.', 'I shook hands and exchanged a few words with the manager.', 'The two men exchanged blows (= hit each other).', 'I heard them exchange words(= argue).']

sentence: Ellen 's voice was cold , as though she disliked satisfying his curiosity .
gloss: Feel distaste for or hostility towards.
eg_sent: she disliked any kind of unnecessary rudeness
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; If you dislike someone or something, you consider them to be unpleasant and do not like them. ;
exps_collins: ["We don't serve liver often because so many people dislike it.", 'David began to dislike all his television heroes who smoked.']
bis_def_longman: to think someone or something is unpleasant and not like them
exps_longman: ['Why do you dislike her so much?', 'I dislike being the centre of attention.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to not like somebody/something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Why do you dislike him so much?', 'He disliked it when she behaved badly in front of his mother.', 'I dislike being away from my family.', 'Much as she disliked going to funerals (= although she did not like it at all), she knew she had to be there.', 'He disliked her staying away from home.']

sentence: Ellen , usually so quick with a scornful reply , just stood and stared at the elegant stranger who stopped one pace away from her , took her hand , then bowed above her fingers .
gloss: Have or maintain an upright position, supported by one's feet.
eg_sent: Lionel stood in the doorway
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; When you are standing, your body is upright, your legs are straight, and your weight is supported by your feet. ;;
exps_collins: ['She was standing beside my bed staring down at me.', 'They told me to stand still and not to turn round.', 'Overcrowding is so bad that prisoners have to sleep in shifts, while others have to stand.', 'We waited, standing up, for an hour.', '...Mrs Fletcher, a shop assistant who has to stand up all day.']
bis_def_longman: to support yourself on your feet or be in an upright position
exps_longman: ['It looks like we’ll have to stand – there are no seats left.', 'She stood in the doorway.', 'Don’t just stand there – help me!', 'If he stood on tiptoe, he could reach the shelf.', 'They just stood there laughing.', 'We stood watching the rain fall.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to be on your feet; to be in a vertical position
exps_oxford_advanced: ['She was too weak to stand.', 'a bird standing on one leg', "Don't just stand there—do something!", 'I was standing only a few feet away.', 'We all stood around in the corridor waiting.', 'to stand on your head/hands (= to be upside down, balancing on your head/hands)', 'After the earthquake, only a few houses were left standing.', 'Stand still while I take your photo.']

sentence: Buzz never cheated to let Elinor win : she knew that Elinor would immediately sense this and feel humiliated .
gloss: Perceive by a sense or senses.
eg_sent: with the first frost, they could sense a change in the days
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; If you sense something, you become aware of it or you realize it, although it is not very obvious. ;;
exps_collins: ["She probably sensed that I wasn't telling her the whole story...", 'He looks about him, sensing danger...', 'Prost had sensed what might happen.']
bis_def_longman: if you sense something, you feel that it exists or is true, without being told or having proof
exps_longman: ['Perhaps he sensed your distrust.', 'I could sense that something was wrong.', 'Hugo had already sensed how unhappy she was.', 'If a prairie dog senses danger, he whistles a warning.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to become aware of something even though you cannot see it, hear it, etc.
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Sensing danger, they started to run.', 'I sensed a note of tension in his voice.', 'Lisa sensed that he did not believe her.', 'Thomas, she sensed, could convince anyone of anything.', 'He sensed someone moving around behind him.', 'He sensed something move in the bushes.', 'She could sense how nervous he was.']

sentence: It will be fascinating to see how Smith , a gifted all-round footballer , shapes up in his prospective international partnership with Aherne .
gloss: Give a particular shape or form to.
eg_sent: most caves are shaped by the flow of water through limestone
bis_def_collins: VERB  …;… Someone or something that shapes a situation or an activity has a very great influence on the way it develops. …;…
exps_collins: ['Christian Democratic leaders are meeting to discuss their role in shaping the future of Europe.', 'Like it or not, our families shape our lives and make us what we are.']
bis_def_longman: to influence something such as a belief, opinion etc and make it develop in a particular way
exps_longman: ['People’s political beliefs are shaped by what they see in the papers.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to make something into a particular shape
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Shape the dough into a ball.', 'This tool is used for shaping wood.']

sentence: After Handsworth part of the press response was to blame the riot on rivalry between West Indians and Asians , and even after the arguments were criticized by local residents ; and community leaders , they were used to explain ' what happened .
gloss: Feel or declare that (someone or something) is responsible for a fault or wrong.
eg_sent: the inquiry blamed the train driver for the accident
bis_def_collins: If you blame a person or thing for something bad, you believe or say that they are responsible for it or that they caused it.
exps_collins: ['The commission is expected to blame the army for many of the atrocities.', "Ms Carey appeared to blame her breakdown on EMI's punishing work schedule.", "If it wasn't Sam's fault, why was I blaming him?"]
bis_def_longman: to say or think that someone or something is responsible for something bad
exps_longman: ['Don’t blame me – it’s not my fault.', 'I blame his mother. She does everything for him.', 'Marie still blames herself for Patrick’s death.', 'The report blames poor safety standards for the accident.', 'The decision to increase interest rates was widely blamed for the crisis.', 'One of the computers is broken and she’s blaming it on me.', 'The crash was blamed on pilot error.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to think or say that somebody/something is responsible for something bad
exps_oxford_advanced: ["She doesn't blame anyone for her father's death.", 'A dropped cigarette is being blamed for the fire.', 'Police are blaming the accident on dangerous driving.']

sentence: Well he said well it seems funny they 're going out does n't it ?
gloss: Give the impression of being something or having a particular quality.
eg_sent: Dawn seemed annoyed
bis_def_collins: V-LINK  [no cont] ;; You use seem to say that someone or something gives the impression of having a particular quality, or of happening in the way you describe. ;;
exps_collins: ['We heard a series of explosions. They seemed quite close by.', 'Everyone seems busy except us.', 'To everyone who knew them, they seemed an ideal couple.', '£50 seems a lot to pay.', 'The calming effect seemed to last for about ten minutes.', 'The government seems not to be troubled by its inconsistent policies on minority rights.', 'It was a record that seemed beyond reach.', "The proposal seems designed to break opposition to the government's economic programme.", 'It seems that the attack this morning was very carefully planned to cause few casualties.', 'It seems clear that he has no reasonable alternative.', "It seemed as if she'd been gone forever.", 'There seems to be a lot of support in Congress for this move.', 'There seems no possibility that such action can be averted.', 'This phenomenon is not as outrageous as it seems.']
bis_def_longman: if something seems to be true, there are things that make people think it is true
exps_longman: ['Ann didn’t seem very pleased.', 'It seems a foolish decision now.', 'Teri seemed like a nice girl.', 'We waited for what seemed like hours.', 'It seems like you’re catching a cold, Taylor.', 'It seemed as if the end of the world had come.', 'It seemed that Freeman had killed the man, and dumped the body in the lake.', 'It seems likely that he will miss the team’s next game.', 'The rainbow seemed to end on the hillside.', 'Doesn’t that seem weird to you?', 'It seems to me you don’t have much choice.', '‘So Bill’s leaving her?’ ‘So it seems.’']

sentence: Whether the life sentence is regarded as a sufficient denunciation in society depends on the public 's perception of what life imprisonment means : if it is widely believed that it results in an average of nine years ' imprisonment , the effect will be somewhat blunted .
gloss: Make or become less sharp.
eg_sent: wood can blunt your axe
bis_def_collins: If something blunts an emotion, a feeling or a need, it weakens it.
exps_collins: ['The constant repetition of violence has blunted the human response to it.', 'Our appetite was blunted by the beer.']
bis_def_longman: to make a feeling less strong
exps_longman: ['The bad weather blunted their enthusiasm for camping.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to make something weaker or less effective
exps_oxford_advanced: ["Age hadn't blunted his passion for adventure.", 'Living alone in the country had blunted her wits.']

sentence: The mandatory penalty does indeed serve to mark out murder from other crimes , but whether the definition of murder is sufficiently refined to capture the worst killings , and only the worst killings , remains to be discussed below .
gloss: Continue to exist, especially after other similar people or things have ceased to do so.
eg_sent: a cloister is all that remains of the monastery
bis_def_collins: V-LINK  ;; If someone or something remains in a particular state or condition, they stay in that state or condition and do not change. ;; [Also it V n that]
exps_collins: ['The three men remained silent.', 'The situation remains tense.', 'The government remained in control.', 'He remained a formidable opponent.', "It remains possible that bad weather could tear more holes in the tanker's hull."]
bis_def_longman: to continue to be in the same state or condition
exps_longman: ['Please remain seated until all the lights are on.', 'We remained friends.', 'The boy remained silent.', 'Despite the job losses, Parker remained as manager.', 'Many scientists remain unconvinced by the current evidence.']

sentence: Go and paint something .

eg_sent: he went out to the shops
bis_def_collins: When you go somewhere, you move or travel there.
exps_collins: ['We went to Rome.', 'Gladys had just gone into the kitchen.', 'I went home at the weekend.', 'Four of them had gone off to find help.', 'It took us an hour to go three miles.']
bis_def_longman: to travel or move to a place that is away from where you are or where you live
exps_longman: ['There’s nothing more we can do here. Let’s go home.', 'Where are you going?', 'We’re going to Canada in the summer.', 'Dinah went into the kitchen.', 'She went over and put her arm around him.', 'I’m going round to her house to find out what’s wrong.', 'I’ll just go up  and ask him what he wants.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to move or travel from one place to another
exps_oxford_advanced: ['She went into her room and shut the door behind her.', 'He goes to work by bus.', 'I have to go to Rome on business.', 'She has gone to China (= is now in China or is on her way there).', 'She has been to China (= she went to China and has now returned).', "I think you should go to the doctor's.", 'Are you going home for Christmas?', 'She has gone to see her sister this weekend.']

sentence: In general , efforts to ensure better coordination were a matter of the patient building up of contacts , although the improved party morale and the greater efficiency of Central Office had removed their justification for existence .
gloss: Make certain that (something) will occur or be the case.

bis_def_oxford_advanced: to make sure that something happens or is definite

sentence: Analyse policy options for dealing with global environmental change and promoting the goal of sustainable development .
gloss: Support or actively encourage (a cause, venture, etc.); further the progress of.

Let’s go home.', 'Where are you going?', 'We’re going to Canada in the summer.', 'Dinah went into the kitchen.', 'She went over and put her arm around him.', 'I’m going round to her house to find out what’s wrong.', 'I’ll just go up  and ask him what he wants.']

sentence: Law conceived of the role of the leader in an exactly opposite sense from Balfour : he sought to foster unity by placing himself at the head of the discordant elements where Balfour had thrown the leadership on the side of restraint .

sentence: Sir : If Labour is to suggest the setting up of a specialist labour court ( 30 September ) , then such a momentous change in the industrial relations system deserves more discussion , and needs to be taken out of the hot-house of Labour Party conference politics .
gloss: Require (something) because it is essential or very important rather than just desirable.
eg_sent: I need help now
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont] ) If you need something, or need to do something, you cannot successfully achieve what you want or live properly without it. )
exps_collins: ['He desperately needed money.', 'These diets provide everything your body needs.', 'I need to make a phone call.', 'A baby does not need to wear shoes until he starts to walk.', 'I need you to do something for me.', 'I need you here, Wally.', 'I need you sane and sober.']
bis_def_longman: to have to have something or someone, because you cannot do something without them, or because you cannot continue or cannot exist without them
exps_longman: ['You don’t really need a car.', 'Plants need light in order to survive.', 'The camcorder needs a new battery.', 'Are you sure that you have everything you need?', 'I need glasses for reading.', 'I need you to help me with the cooking.', 'More blood donors are urgently needed.', 'a much needed boost to the local economy']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to require something/somebody because they are essential or very important, not just because you would like to have them
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Do you need any help?', "It's here if you need it.", "Don't go—I might need you.", 'They badly needed a change.', 'Food aid is urgently needed.', 'What do you need your own computer for? You can use ours.', "I don't need your comments, thank you.", 'I need to get some sleep.', 'He needs to win this game to stay in the match.', "You don't need to leave yet, do you?", 'This shirt needs to be washed.', 'This shirt needs washing.']

sentence: I mean pinched one of for starters , that makes a difference .
gloss: Grip (something, typically a person's flesh) tightly and sharply between finger and thumb.
eg_sent: she pinched his cheek
bis_def_collins: If you pinch a part of someone's body, you take a piece of their skin between your thumb and first finger and give it a short squeeze.
exps_collins: ['She pinched his arm as hard as she could.', "We both kept pinching ourselves to prove that it wasn't all a dream."]
bis_def_longman: to press a part of someone’s skin very tightly between your finger and thumb, especially so that it hurts
exps_longman: ['We have to stop her pinching her baby brother.', 'He pinched her cheek.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to take a piece of somebody’s skin between your thumb and first finger and squeeze hard, especially to hurt the person
exps_oxford_advanced: ["My sister's always pinching me and it really hurts.", "He pinched the baby's cheek playfully.", 'She had to pinch herself to make sure she was not dreaming.']

sentence: Muldoon made a face .
gloss: Form (something) by putting parts together or combining substances; create.
eg_sent: my grandmother made a dress for me
bis_def_collins: VERB  ) You can use make with a wide range of nouns to indicate that someone performs an action or says something. For example, if you make a suggestion, you suggest something. )
exps_collins: ["I'd just like to make a comment.", 'I made a few phone calls.', "I think you're making a serious mistake.", 'The Pope said the world had made some progress towards peace in 1991.', 'Science and technology have made major changes to the way we live.', 'She had made us an offer too good to refuse.']
bis_def_longman: to produce something, for example by putting the different parts of it together
exps_longman: ['I’m going to show you how to make a box for your tools.', 'A family of mice had made their nest in the roof.', 'She made her own wedding dress.', 'The company has been making quality furniture for over 200 years.', 'They met while they were making a film.', 'He made her a toy horse, using just some straw and bamboo twigs.', 'Paper is made from wood.', 'a shirt made of silk', 'She’s very good at making things from old scraps of material.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to create or prepare something by combining materials or putting parts together
exps_oxford_advanced: ['to make a table/dress/cake', 'to make bread/cement/paper', 'She makes her own clothes.', 'made in France (= on a label)', "What's your shirt made of?", 'Wine is made from grapes.', 'The grapes are made into wine.', 'She made coffee for us all.', 'She made us all coffee.']

sentence: The objective is to revise and almost reverse the traditional accountancy concept of man-power as a resource consuming factor requiring regular payments , overheads in the form of heated , lighted , equipped workspaces and so on .
gloss: Examine and make corrections or alterations to (written or printed matter)
eg_sent: the book was published in 1960 and revised in 1968
bis_def_collins: VERB  () If you revise the way you think about something, you adjust your thoughts, usually in order to make them better or more suited to how things are. ()
exps_collins: ['He soon came to revise his opinion of the profession.']
bis_def_longman: to change something because of new information or ideas
exps_longman: ['The college has revised its plans because of local objections.', 'We have revised our estimates of population growth.', 'Forecasts of economic growth are being revised downwards.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to change your opinions or plans, for example because of something you have learned
exps_oxford_advanced: ['I can see I will have to revise my opinions of his abilities now.', 'The government may need to revise its policy in the light of this report.']

sentence: This large data set , to which grid references have now been added , comprises information about nearly 40 000 individuals .
gloss: Join (something) to something else so as to increase the size, number, or amount.
eg_sent: I've started a petition so if you would like to add your name, email me
bis_def_longman: to put something with something else or with a group of other things
exps_longman: ['If the mixture seems dry, add water.', 'Do you want to add your name to the list?', 'Suzuki has added extra doors to its sports off-roader.', 'Material about recent research has been added to this new edition.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to put something together with something else so as to increase the size, number, amount, etc.

sentence: They were in the audience shouting and cheering from what I saw .
gloss: Perceive with the eyes; discern visually.
eg_sent: in the distance she could see the blue sea
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont] ; When you see something, you notice it using your eyes. ;
exps_collins: ["You can't see colours at night.", 'I saw a man making his way towards me.', 'She can see, hear, touch, smell, and taste.', 'As he neared the farm, he saw that a police car was parked outside it.', 'Did you see what happened?', 'You use see to talk about things that you are aware of because a visual impression reaches your eyes. You often use can in this case. I can see the fax here on the desk. If you want to say that someone is paying attention to something they can see, you say that they are looking at it or watching it. In general, you look at something that is not moving, while you watch something that is moving or changing. I asked him to look at the picture above his bed... He watched Blake run down the stairs.']
bis_def_longman: to notice or examine someone or something, using your eyes
exps_longman: ['He crouched down so he couldn’t be seen.', 'Can I see your ticket, please?', 'You can see the Houses of Parliament from here.', 'Can you see where the marks are on the wall?', 'The suspect was seen entering the building.', 'As you can see, the house needs some work doing on it.', 'Have you seen Chris ?', 'The accommodation was so awful it had to be seen to be believed.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to become aware of somebody/something by using your eyes
exps_oxford_advanced: ["She looked for him but couldn't see him in the crowd.", 'I looked out of the window but saw nothing.', 'The opera was the place to see and be seen (= by other important or fashionable people).', 'He could see (that) she had been crying.', 'Did you see what happened?', 'If you watch carefully, you’ll see how it is done.', 'I hate to see you unhappy.', 'She was seen running away from the scene of the crime.', 'I saw you put the key in your pocket.', 'He was seen to enter the building about the time the crime was committed.']

sentence: George Armstrong Edoardo Amaldi , born Carpaneto Piacentino September 5 , 1908 ; died Rome , December 5 , 1989 .

']

sentence: After Handsworth part of the press response was to blame the riot on rivalry between West Indians and Asians , and even after the arguments were criticized by local residents ; and community leaders , they were used to explain ' what happened .
gloss: Indicate the faults of (someone or something) in a disapproving way.
eg_sent: the opposition criticized the government's failure to consult adequately
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; If you criticize someone or something, you express your disapproval of them by saying what you think is wrong with them. ;;
exps_collins: ['His mother had rarely criticized him or any of her children.', 'The minister criticised the police for failing to come up with any leads.', 'The regime has been harshly criticized for serious human rights violations.']
bis_def_longman: to express your disapproval of someone or something, or to talk about their faults
exps_longman: ['Ron does nothing but criticize and complain all the time.', 'The decision has been strongly criticized by teachers.', 'The new law has been widely criticized.', 'He has been criticized for incompetence.', 'Doctors have criticized the government for failing to invest enough in the health service.', 'The report has been criticized as inaccurate and incomplete.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to say that you disapprove of somebody/something; to say what you do not like or think is wrong about somebody/something

sentence: It 's no use living like a cabbage , I do n't think so anyhow .
gloss: Remain alive.
eg_sent: I'll never forget it as long as I live
bis_def_collins: If someone lives in a particular place or with a particular person, their home is in that place or with that person.

sentence: A further example is work by von Braun ( 1988 ) who uses pMAP to look at exposure of organic and metallic compounds in groundwater in the vicinity of Tucson airport , Arizona .
gloss: Direct one's gaze toward someone or something or in a specified direction.
eg_sent: people were looking at him
bis_def_collins: If you look in a particular direction, you direct your eyes in that direction, especially so that you can see what is there or see what something is like.
exps_collins: ['I looked down the hallway to room number nine.', 'She turned to look at him.', 'He looked away, apparently enraged.', "If you look, you'll see what was a lake.", 'If you want to say that someone is paying attention to something they can see, you say that they are looking at it or watching it. In general, you look at something that is not moving, while you watch something that is moving or changing. I asked him to look at the picture above his bed... He watched Blake run down the stairs. Look is never followed directly by an object. You must always use at or some other preposition. I looked towards the plane. You use see to talk about things that you are aware of because a visual impression reaches your eyes. You often use can in this case. I can see the fax here on the desk.']

exps_longman: ['We sneaked out while Jessie’s mom wasn’t looking.', 'If you look carefully you can see that the painting represents a human figure.', 'Gina covered her eyes, afraid to look.', '‘It’s time we left, ’ Ian said, looking at his watch.', 'The men all turned to look at her as she entered the room.', 'Dad looked up from his paper and smiled.', '‘We can’t go out in this weather, ’ said Bob, looking out of the window.']

exps_longman: ['I wish someone had told me the meeting was canceled.', 'The Chief of Police told reporters that two people were killed in the blast.', 'Jack had to go, but he didn’t tell me why.', 'I think you’d better tell me exactly what’s been going on around here.', 'No one had told them about the drug’s side effects.', 'I’ll tell you all about it when I get back.', 'She told us some funny stories about her sister.', 'Sheppard was telling the truth.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to give information to somebody by speaking or writing
exps_oxford_advanced: ['He told the news to everybody he saw.', 'He told everybody he saw the news.', 'Did she tell you her name?', 'What did I tell you? (= you should have listened to my advice)', "Why wasn't I told about the accident?", 'They’ve told us (that) they’re not coming.', 'I kept telling myself (that) everything was OK.', "Are you telling me you didn't have any help with this? (= I don't believe what you have said)", 'Tell me where you live.', "‘I'm ready to go now,’ he told her."]

sentence: From the description of the AEC already given the demanding and disciplined nature of the course can be appreciated .
gloss: Ask authoritatively or brusquely.
eg_sent: ‘Where is she?’ he demanded
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; If you demand something such as information or action, you ask for it in a very forceful way. ;
exps_collins: ['Mr Byers last night demanded an immediate explanation from the Education Secretary.', 'Russia demanded that Unita send a delegation to the peace talks.', 'The hijackers are demanding to speak to representatives of both governments.', "'What did you expect me to do about it?' she demanded."]
bis_def_longman: to ask for something very firmly, especially because you think you have a right to do this
exps_longman: ['Angry demonstrators demanded the resignation of two senior officials.', 'I demand to know what’s going on.', 'They demanded that the military government free all political prisoners.', 'It seemed that no matter what she did, more was demanded of her.', '‘Where are you going?’ she demanded angrily.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to ask for something very firmly
exps_oxford_advanced: ['She demanded an immediate explanation.', 'The UN has demanded that all troops be withdrawn.', 'They are demanding that all troops should be withdrawn.', 'I demand to see the manager.', '‘Who the hell are you?’ he demanded angrily.']

sentence: From 1940 to 1954 he wrote regularly for the New York Herald Tribune and four volumes of his notices have appeared in book form .
gloss: Come into sight; become visible or noticeable, especially without apparent cause.
eg_sent: smoke appeared on the horizon
bis_def_collins: V-LINK  [no cont] ;; If you say that something appears to be the way you describe it, you are reporting what you believe or what you have been told, though you cannot be sure it is true. ;; [vagueness]
exps_collins: ['There appears to be increasing support for the leadership to take a more aggressive stance.', 'The aircraft appears to have crashed near Katmandu.', 'It appears that some missiles have been moved.', 'It appears unlikely that the UN would consider making such a move.', 'The presidency is beginning to appear a political irrelevance.', 'Nine months later, those talks appear as distant as ever.', 'He appeared willing to reach an agreement.']
bis_def_longman: used when saying how someone or something seems. Appear is more formal than seem
exps_longman: ['It appears that all the files have been deleted.', 'Police have found what appear to be human remains.', 'He tried to make it appear that she had committed suicide.', 'It may be less useful than it first appears.', 'I don’t want to appear rude.']

sentence: Saying that you now ahm replace the bones of crippled fingers
gloss: Utter words so as to convey information, an opinion, a feeling or intention, or an instruction.
eg_sent: ‘Thank you,’ he said
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; When you say something, you speak words. ; [Also VERB to-infinitive]
exps_collins: ["'I'm sorry,' he said.", 'She said they were very impressed.', 'Forty-one people are said to have been seriously hurt.', 'I packed and said goodbye to Charlie.', "I hope you didn't say anything about Gretchen.", "You didn't say much when you telephoned.", 'Did he say where he was going?.', "It doesn't sound exactly orthodox, if I may say so."]

exps_longman: ['‘Don’t cry, ’ he said softly.', 'Don’t believe anything he says.', 'A spokesman said that the company had improved its safety standards.', 'I always said I would buy a motorbike when I had enough money.', 'Did she say what happened?', 'I would like to say how much we appreciate your hard work.', '‘Why did she leave?’ ‘I don’t know – she didn’t say.’', 'What did you say to her?', 'What a silly thing to say!', 'She left without saying goodbye.', 'I’ve said I’m sorry – what more do you want?', 'Can I go, Mum? Oh, please say yes!', 'He looked as if he was going to say something.', 'I wished I had said nothing about Jordi.', 'Does anyone else have anything to say?', 'Although he didn’t say so, it was clear that he was in pain.', 'What makes you say that (=why do you think that) ? 你怎么会那么说呢？', 'Nina said to meet her at 4.30.', 'I’d like to say a few words.', '‘So what are your plans now?’ ‘I’d rather not say.’']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to speak or tell somebody something, using words
exps_oxford_advanced: ['‘Hello!’ she said.', '‘That was marvellous,’ said Daniel.', 'Be quiet, I have something to say.', "I didn't believe a word she said.", "That's a terrible thing to say.", "He knew that if he wasn't back by midnight, his parents would have something to say about it (= be angry).", 'She said nothing to me about it.', "I said to myself (= thought), ‘That can't be right!’", 'He said (that) his name was Sam.', 'It is said that she lived to be over 100.', 'She finds it hard to say what she feels.', "‘That's impossible!’ ‘So you say (= but I think you may be wrong).’", "‘Why can't I go out now?’ ‘Because I say so.’", "‘What do you want it for?’ ‘I'd rather not say.’", 'He said to meet him here.', 'He is said to have been a brilliant scholar.']

sentence: A chemical fire in Switzerland caused toxic materials to be transported by the Rhine at least as far as the Netherlands ;
gloss: Take or carry (people or goods) from one place to another by means of a vehicle, aircraft, or ship.

bis_def_collins: VERB  ; To transport people or goods somewhere is to take them from one place to another in a vehicle. ;

sentence: He had metaphorically shaken a large fist , impotently , at some looming energy-field , and got on with his work , his work .
gloss: Appear as a vague or shadowy form, especially one that is large or threatening.
eg_sent: vehicles loomed out of the darkness

bis_def_oxford_advanced: to appear as a large shape that is not clear, especially in a frightening or threatening way

sentence: Are n't you going to eat your meat , dear ? said Beryl .

eg_sent: he went out to the shops
bis_def_collins: When you go somewhere, you move or travel there.

Let’s go home.', 'Where are you going?', 'We’re going to Canada in the summer.', 'Dinah went into the kitchen.', 'She went over and put her arm around him.', 'I’m going round to her house to find out what’s wrong.', 'I’ll just go up  and ask him what he wants.']

sentence: In open battle and in the plundering expeditions that constituted the normal form of aggressive warfare , they needed the backing of archers , both mounted and on foot , and of numerous infantrymen .

sentence: She was happy to wait for him , certain that soon she would see him riding towards her .
gloss: Stay where one is or delay action until a particular time or event.

exps_collins: ['I walk to a street corner and wait for the school bus.', 'Stop waiting for things to happen. Make them happen.', 'I waited to see how she responded.', 'Angus got out of the car to wait.', 'We will have to wait a week or so before we know whether the operation is a success.', 'He told waiting journalists that he did not expect a referendum to be held for several months.']

We're waiting to go.", "You'll just have to wait your turn (= wait until your turn comes)."]

gloss: Move from one place to another.

sentence: At a time when the Home Secretary is inviting the Probation Service to move centre stage in the Criminal Justice System ( NACRO , 1990 , p. 17 ) it may seem misguided and unnecessarily pedantic to take issue with the White Paper 's notion of punishment .
gloss: Give the impression of being something or having a particular quality.
eg_sent: Dawn seemed annoyed
bis_def_collins: V-LINK  [no cont] ;; You use seem to say that someone or something gives the impression of having a particular quality, or of happening in the way you describe. ;;
exps_collins: ['We heard a series of explosions. They seemed quite close by.', 'Everyone seems busy except us.', 'To everyone who knew them, they seemed an ideal couple.', '£50 seems a lot to pay.', 'The calming effect seemed to last for about ten minutes.', 'The government seems not to be troubled by its inconsistent policies on minority rights.', 'It was a record that seemed beyond reach.', "The proposal seems designed to break opposition to the government's economic programme.", 'It seems that the attack this morning was very carefully planned to cause few casualties.', 'It seems clear that he has no reasonable alternative.', "It seemed as if she'd been gone forever.", 'There seems to be a lot of support in Congress for this move.', 'There seems no possibility that such action can be averted.', 'This phenomenon is not as outrageous as it seems.']
bis_def_longman: if something seems to be true, there are things that make people think it is true
exps_longman: ['Ann didn’t seem very pleased.', 'It seems a foolish decision now.', 'Teri seemed like a nice girl.', 'We waited for what seemed like hours.', 'It seems like you’re catching a cold, Taylor.', 'It seemed as if the end of the world had come.', 'It seemed that Freeman had killed the man, and dumped the body in the lake.', 'It seems likely that he will miss the team’s next game.', 'The rainbow seemed to end on the hillside.', 'Doesn’t that seem weird to you?', 'It seems to me you don’t have much choice.', '‘So Bill’s leaving her?’ ‘So it seems.’']

sentence: You do n't have to to watch out Scones .
gloss: Look at or observe attentively over a period of time.

bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; If you watch someone or something, you look at them, usually for a period of time, and pay attention to what is happening. ;;
exps_collins: ['The man was standing in his doorway watching him.', 'He watched the barman prepare the beer he had ordered.', 'Chris watched him sipping his brandy.', 'I watched as Amy ate a few nuts.']
bis_def_longman: to look at someone or something for a period of time, paying attention to what is happening
exps_longman: ['Do you mind if I watch?', 'We sat and watched the sunset.', 'He watched helplessly as Paula fell into the icy water.', 'Harriet watched him with interest.', 'I watched him go, then went home.', 'Ruth could not bear to watch her parents arguing.', 'I watched to see how he’d react.', 'The debate was watched by 97 million viewers.', 'Most parents don’t know what their kids are watching on TV.', 'It’s useful to watch how other pilots handle the glider.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to look at somebody/something for a time, paying attention to what happens

sentence: I could n't do the Forties bit at all , padded shoulders and crÎpy things , ugh , and pageboys I think it must have been purely Oedipal , those were my parents ' things , dammit , what I was getting away from .

sentence: and take and her card and then her folder comes out as you take it .
gloss: Lay hold of (something) with one's hands; reach for and hold.

sentence: He really hates our guts !

exps_collins: ['One of the prisoners has carved a beautiful wooden chess set.', 'He carves his figures from white pine.', 'I picked up a piece of wood and started carving.', '...carved stone figures.']

sentence: Who 's coming to see you today ?
gloss: Perceive with the eyes; discern visually.
eg_sent: in the distance she could see the blue sea
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont] ; When you see something, you notice it using your eyes. ;
exps_collins: ["You can't see colours at night.", 'I saw a man making his way towards me.', 'She can see, hear, touch, smell, and taste.', 'As he neared the farm, he saw that a police car was parked outside it.', 'Did you see what happened?', 'You use see to talk about things that you are aware of because a visual impression reaches your eyes. You often use can in this case. I can see the fax here on the desk. If you want to say that someone is paying attention to something they can see, you say that they are looking at it or watching it. In general, you look at something that is not moving, while you watch something that is moving or changing. I asked him to look at the picture above his bed... He watched Blake run down the stairs.']

gloss: Direct one's gaze toward someone or something or in a specified direction.
eg_sent: people were looking at him
bis_def_collins: If you look in a particular direction, you direct your eyes in that direction, especially so that you can see what is there or see what something is like.
exps_collins: ['I looked down the hallway to room number nine.', 'She turned to look at him.', 'He looked away, apparently enraged.', "If you look, you'll see what was a lake.", 'If you want to say that someone is paying attention to something they can see, you say that they are looking at it or watching it. In general, you look at something that is not moving, while you watch something that is moving or changing. I asked him to look at the picture above his bed... He watched Blake run down the stairs. Look is never followed directly by an object. You must always use at or some other preposition. I looked towards the plane. You use see to talk about things that you are aware of because a visual impression reaches your eyes. You often use can in this case. I can see the fax here on the desk.']
bis_def_longman: to turn your eyes towards something, so that you can see it
exps_longman: ['We sneaked out while Jessie’s mom wasn’t looking.', 'If you look carefully you can see that the painting represents a human figure.', 'Gina covered her eyes, afraid to look.', '‘It’s time we left, ’ Ian said, looking at his watch.', 'The men all turned to look at her as she entered the room.', 'Dad looked up from his paper and smiled.', '‘We can’t go out in this weather, ’ said Bob, looking out of the window.']

sentence: I mean I think er , when your blood pressure was found out and you 'd been taking tablets ever , so , I think it 's kept it all under control and you 've , you , we eat a sensible diet .
gloss: Have a particular opinion, belief, or idea about someone or something.

sentence: But you wo n't , he assured her .

sentence: Early research at the NWRRL focused on developing a GIS for use by the police and county emergency planning officers in Cumbria that would aid in the management of a possible explosion at a chemical factory in Whitehaven , west Cumbria ( Vincent et al. 1988 ; Dunn 1989 ) .

sentence: Moreover , recent work has shown that much of the heat energy in the seas of the North Atlantic ( every square kilometre of which gives off as much energy as a nuclear power station and hence influences our weather ) is absorbed from sunlight in the tropical Pacific and is carried by ocean currents through the Drake Passage and up into the Atlantic .

sentence: Party organisers want the conference to show that the party is united as never before , leaving Mr Kinnock free for the first time to sell the policy package to voters without worrying about splits .
gloss: Have a desire to possess or do (something); wish for.

bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont, no passive] ; If you want something, you feel a desire or a need for it. ;
exps_collins: ['I want a drink.', 'Ian knows exactly what he wants in life.', 'People wanted to know who this talented designer was.', 'They began to want their father to be the same as other daddies.', "They didn't want people staring at them as they sat on the lawn, so they put up high walls.", 'He wanted his power recognised.', 'I want my car this colour.', 'And remember, we want him alive.', "Note that want and wish have similar meanings, but are used differently. If you want something, you feel a need for it or a desire to have it. You can say that you want to do something, that you want someone to do something, or that you want something to happen. If you use wish with a 'to' infinitive, this has the same meaning as want but is more formal. I want to get out of here... She wished to consult him about her future."]
bis_def_longman: to have a desire for something
exps_longman: ['I really want a drink.', 'What do you want for your birthday?', 'She’d always wanted to go to Thailand.', 'I don’t want Linda to  hear about this.', 'He didn’t want the holiday to end.', 'You can order whatever you want.', 'This shampoo is mild enough to use every day if you want.', 'If she doesn’t get what she wants, she’s not happy.', 'He wanted that job so badly he was willing to kill for it.', 'They desperately wanted a son.', 'What I want to know is when we’re going to get paid.', 'All I want is the chance to prove myself.', 'Oh thank you, it’s just what I’ve always wanted.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have a desire or a wish for something

sentence: Thus the algal bloom off the Italian Adriatic shore in 1989 is reckoned to have caused the holiday trade and local fisherman losses running into tens if not hundreds of millions of pounds .

bis_def_longman: to think or suppose something

sentence: The inevitable sufferers , of course , are the poor , of whom those who actually commit the offences that concern the police are a tiny minority and whom , indeed , it should be the purpose of the police to protect .
gloss: Relate to; be about.

bis_def_longman: if a story, book, report etc concerns someone or something, it is about them

sentence: They stayed like that for a long moment and then he said , Light the candle .

exps_collins: ["'I'm sorry,' he said.", 'She said they were very impressed.', 'Forty-one people are said to have been seriously hurt.', 'I packed and said goodbye to Charlie.', "I hope you didn't say anything about Gretchen.", "You didn't say much when you telephoned.", 'Did he say where he was going?.', "It doesn't sound exactly orthodox, if I may say so."]

exps_longman: ['‘Don’t cry, ’ he said softly.', 'Don’t believe anything he says.', 'A spokesman said that the company had improved its safety standards.', 'I always said I would buy a motorbike when I had enough money.', 'Did she say what happened?', 'I would like to say how much we appreciate your hard work.', '‘Why did she leave?’ ‘I don’t know – she didn’t say.’', 'What did you say to her?', 'What a silly thing to say!', 'She left without saying goodbye.', 'I’ve said I’m sorry – what more do you want?', 'Can I go, Mum? Oh, please say yes!', 'He looked as if he was going to say something.', 'I wished I had said nothing about Jordi.', 'Does anyone else have anything to say?', 'Although he didn’t say so, it was clear that he was in pain.', 'What makes you say that (=why do you think that) ? 你怎么会那么说呢？', 'Nina said to meet her at 4.30.', 'I’d like to say a few words.', '‘So what are your plans now?’ ‘I’d rather not say.’']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to speak or tell somebody something, using words
exps_oxford_advanced: ['‘Hello!’ she said.', '‘That was marvellous,’ said Daniel.', 'Be quiet, I have something to say.', "I didn't believe a word she said.", "That's a terrible thing to say.", "He knew that if he wasn't back by midnight, his parents would have something to say about it (= be angry).", 'She said nothing to me about it.', "I said to myself (= thought), ‘That can't be right!’", 'He said (that) his name was Sam.', 'It is said that she lived to be over 100.', 'She finds it hard to say what she feels.', "‘That's impossible!’ ‘So you say (= but I think you may be wrong).’", "‘Why can't I go out now?’ ‘Because I say so.’", "‘What do you want it for?’ ‘I'd rather not say.’", 'He said to meet him here.', 'He is said to have been a brilliant scholar.']

sentence: Yeah I know .
gloss: Be aware of through observation, inquiry, or information.
eg_sent: most people know that CFCs can damage the ozone layer
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont]  If you know a fact, a piece of information, or an answer, you have it correctly in your mind.
exps_collins: ["I don't know the name of the place.", 'I know that you led a rifle platoon during the Second World War.', "'People like doing things for nothing.' — 'I know they do.'.", "I don't know what happened to her husband.", "'How did he meet your mother?' — 'I don't know.'.", 'We all know about his early experiments in flying.', 'They looked younger than I knew them to be.', 'Radon is known to be harmful to humans in large quantities.', 'It is not known whether the bomb was originally intended for the capital itself.', "It's always been known that key figures in the government do very well for themselves."]
bis_def_longman: to have information about something
exps_longman: ['Who knows the answer?', 'There are instructions telling you everything you need to know.', 'Didn’t you know that?', 'Do you know what time it is?', 'I don’t know where to go.', 'I need to know more about the job before I decide whether to apply for it.', 'Little is known about the author’s childhood.', 'I know all about David and what he’s been up to!', 'I wonder if he knew of the plan?', 'Do you know of any good restaurants in the area?', 'You know nothing of this business.', 'We know that greenhouse gases can affect the climate.', 'Let me know what time you’re planning to arrive.', 'I thought you’d want to know immediately.', 'If you must know, I was with James last night .', 'He slipped out of the house without his parents knowing .', 'How did he know our names?', '‘I’m divorced, as you know, ’ she said briefly.', 'Smoking is known to increase a person’s risk of developing lung cancer.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have information in your mind as a result of experience or because you have learned or been told it
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Do you know his address?', 'The cause of the fire is not yet known.', 'All I know is that she used to work in a bank (= I have no other information about her).', 'I know (that) people’s handwriting changes as they get older.', 'It is widely known that CFCs can damage the ozone layer.', 'I knew where he was hiding.', "I didn't know what he was talking about.", "‘You've got a flat tyre.’ ‘I know.’", "‘What's the answer?’ ‘I don't know.’", "‘There's no one in.’ ‘How do you know?’", "You know about Amanda's baby, don't you?", "I don't know about you, but I'm ready for something to eat.", 'I know of at least two people who did the same thing.', '‘Is anyone else coming?’ ‘Not that I know of.’', '‘Isn’t that his car?’ ‘I wouldn’t know./How should I know?’ (= I don’t know and I am not the person you should ask.)', "‘What are you two whispering about?’ ‘You don't want to know’ (= because you would be shocked or wouldn't approve).", 'Does he know to come here (= that he should come here) first?', 'We know her to be honest.', 'Two women are known to have died.']

sentence: You can bet your bottom dollar on that !
gloss: Risk a sum of money or valued item against someone else's on the basis of the outcome of an unpredictable event such as a race or game.

bis_def_collins: If you bet on the result of a horse race, football game, or other event, you give someone a sum of money which they give you back with extra money if the result is what you predicted, or which they keep if it is not.

sentence: His play , The Yellow Chair , had first been presented in 1957 ; he did not like to think too closely about it , as he did not like to think too closely about any of his past work .
gloss: Give or award formally or ceremonially.

sentence: I 've written it all down .

sentence: As has been demonstrated elsewhere with regard to the generic probation setting ( Singer , 1989 ) , the supervision of offenders involves two overarching aims : namely support and surveillance .
gloss: Give a practical exhibition and explanation of (how a machine, skill, or craft works or is performed)

bis_def_longman: to show or prove something clearly

sentence: Once they go it seems for a moment that neither it nor we have any real existence .

They seemed quite close by.', 'Everyone seems busy except us.', 'To everyone who knew them, they seemed an ideal couple.', '£50 seems a lot to pay.', 'The calming effect seemed to last for about ten minutes.', 'The government seems not to be troubled by its inconsistent policies on minority rights.', 'It was a record that seemed beyond reach.', "The proposal seems designed to break opposition to the government's economic programme.", 'It seems that the attack this morning was very carefully planned to cause few casualties.', 'It seems clear that he has no reasonable alternative.', "It seemed as if she'd been gone forever.", 'There seems to be a lot of support in Congress for this move.', 'There seems no possibility that such action can be averted.', 'This phenomenon is not as outrageous as it seems.']

sentence: Get your coat and we 'll rattle it , ah , your keys are there .

sentence: The DDI reminded them all of the secret police who had run East Germany with an iron fist .

sentence: A junior spin doctor is reported to have muttered , though admittedly out of my earshot : We 've been snubbed .

sentence: Robin Cook , a member of the national executive and the health spokesman , said that a Labour government which sought to force its programme on an unwilling nation would be unsocialist .

sentence: These give details of present site locations and some indication of permitted wastes , though little or no information on closed and abandoned sites .

sentence: London 's leading pair , as if piqued by this , turned 30 September into the longest afternoon .

Let’s go home.', 'Where are you going?', 'We’re going to Canada in the summer.', 'Dinah went into the kitchen.', 'She went over and put her arm around him.', 'I’m going round to her house to find out what’s wrong.', 'I’ll just go up  and ask him what he wants.']

sentence: Jamie , through a renewed queasiness , just observed that the police driver was instantly reduced to half his age by Miss Williams 's greeting .

sentence: And now although her whole body cried out for fulfilment and she longed for Joss Barnet to complete what he had surely come to do , she knew that she must not let it happen .
gloss: Not prevent or forbid; allow.

sentence: Since popular ideas of life in the past are often founded on vividly coloured reconstructions of The World in the Jurassic Period and the like , it is important to remember that these imaginative scenes are all inferences from bones , and similar fragments .

sentence: Miss Williams took him to meet the police Land Rover at the stable gate , a bone-thin , wiry woman in her late fifties , her expression sufficiently forbidding to prevent the parents , edging cars through the gate to collect children from the ten o'clock ride , from asking any questions .
gloss: Arrange or happen to come into the presence or company of (someone)

sentence: He said , Elinor , you allowed ample provision in the trust for helping Clare if the trustees consider that help is needed .
gloss: Think carefully about (something), typically before making a decision.

exps_collins: ["We don't consider our customers to be mere consumers; we consider them to be our friends.", 'I had always considered myself a strong, competent woman.', 'The paper does not explain why foreign ownership should be considered bad.', 'I consider activities such as jogging and weightlifting as unnatural.', 'Barbara considers that pet shops which sell customers these birds are very unfair.']

sentence: I know .
gloss: Be aware of through observation, inquiry, or information.
eg_sent: most people know that CFCs can damage the ozone layer
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont]  If you know a fact, a piece of information, or an answer, you have it correctly in your mind.
exps_collins: ["I don't know the name of the place.", 'I know that you led a rifle platoon during the Second World War.', "'People like doing things for nothing.' — 'I know they do.'.", "I don't know what happened to her husband.", "'How did he meet your mother?' — 'I don't know.'.", 'We all know about his early experiments in flying.', 'They looked younger than I knew them to be.', 'Radon is known to be harmful to humans in large quantities.', 'It is not known whether the bomb was originally intended for the capital itself.', "It's always been known that key figures in the government do very well for themselves."]
bis_def_longman: to have information about something
exps_longman: ['Who knows the answer?', 'There are instructions telling you everything you need to know.', 'Didn’t you know that?', 'Do you know what time it is?', 'I don’t know where to go.', 'I need to know more about the job before I decide whether to apply for it.', 'Little is known about the author’s childhood.', 'I know all about David and what he’s been up to!', 'I wonder if he knew of the plan?', 'Do you know of any good restaurants in the area?', 'You know nothing of this business.', 'We know that greenhouse gases can affect the climate.', 'Let me know what time you’re planning to arrive.', 'I thought you’d want to know immediately.', 'If you must know, I was with James last night .', 'He slipped out of the house without his parents knowing .', 'How did he know our names?', '‘I’m divorced, as you know, ’ she said briefly.', 'Smoking is known to increase a person’s risk of developing lung cancer.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have information in your mind as a result of experience or because you have learned or been told it
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Do you know his address?', 'The cause of the fire is not yet known.', 'All I know is that she used to work in a bank (= I have no other information about her).', 'I know (that) people’s handwriting changes as they get older.', 'It is widely known that CFCs can damage the ozone layer.', 'I knew where he was hiding.', "I didn't know what he was talking about.", "‘You've got a flat tyre.’ ‘I know.’", "‘What's the answer?’ ‘I don't know.’", "‘There's no one in.’ ‘How do you know?’", "You know about Amanda's baby, don't you?", "I don't know about you, but I'm ready for something to eat.", 'I know of at least two people who did the same thing.', '‘Is anyone else coming?’ ‘Not that I know of.’', '‘Isn’t that his car?’ ‘I wouldn’t know./How should I know?’ (= I don’t know and I am not the person you should ask.)', "‘What are you two whispering about?’ ‘You don't want to know’ (= because you would be shocked or wouldn't approve).", 'Does he know to come here (= that he should come here) first?', 'We know her to be honest.', 'Two women are known to have died.']

sentence: It was alleged that the council , being the owners of the premises , were the persons by whose act , default or sufferance the nuisance arose .

bis_def_longman: to say that something is true or that someone has done something wrong, although it has not been proved

gloss: Come to have (something); receive.

exps_longman: ['She got loads of presents.', 'What did you get for Christmas?', 'We get a lot of junk mail.', 'We got a letter from Pam this morning.', 'I got it off my Dad.', 'I got a few games free when I bought my computer.']

sentence: In terms of principle , the rule requires justification because it departs from the principle of correspondence ( see Chapter 5.2(a) ) , namely that the fault element in a crime should relate to the consequences prohibited by that crime .
gloss: Leave, especially in order to start a journey.

bis_def_collins: VERB  ;;; When something or someone departs from a place, they leave it and start a journey to another place. ;;; [Also VERB]

bis_def_longman: to leave, especially when you are starting a journey

sentence: The tradition for diesel cars is far better established on the Continent and that is where the best buys come from .
gloss: Set up on a firm or permanent basis.
eg_sent: the scheme was established in 1975
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; If someone establishes something such as an organization, a type of activity, or a set of rules, they create it or introduce it in such a way that it is likely to last for a long time. ;;
exps_collins: ['The UN has established detailed criteria for who should be allowed to vote.', 'The School was established in 1989 by an Italian professor.']

bis_def_oxford_advanced: to start or create an organization, a system, etc. that is meant to last for a long time

sentence: when she was only a second year therefore that means , she 's not given enough work , but I mean
gloss: Intend to convey or refer to (a particular thing); signify.
eg_sent: I don't know what you mean
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont] ;…;… If you want to know what a word, code, signal, or gesture means, you want to know what it refers to or what its message is. ;…;…
exps_collins: ["In modern Welsh, 'glas' means 'blue'.", "What does 'evidence' mean?.", 'The red signal means you can shoot.']
bis_def_longman: to have or represent a particular meaning

bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have something as a meaning

sentence: A hazard is a threat which , given a set of circumstances , may become translated into a realized event .
gloss: Freely transfer the possession of (something) to (someone)
eg_sent: she gave him presents and clothes
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont]  You can use give with nouns that refer to physical actions. The whole expression refers to the performing of the action. For example, She gave a smile means almost the same as 'She smiled'.
exps_collins: ['She stretched her arms out and gave a great yawn.', 'Giving a sigh, she fell to her knees at my feet.', 'He gave her a fond smile.', 'He reached for her hand and gave it a reassuring squeeze.']
bis_def_longman: to let someone have something as a present, or to provide something for someone
exps_longman: ['What did Bob give you for your birthday?', 'Researchers were given a £10,000 grant to continue their work.', 'I’ve got some old diaries that my grandmother gave me years ago.', 'a ring which was given to him by his mother', 'I didn’t steal it! Maria gave it to me!', 'Most people are willing to give to charity.', 'The situation is now desperate, so please give generously.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to hand something to somebody so that they can look at it, use it or keep it for a time
exps_oxford_advanced: ["Give the letter to your mother when you've read it.", 'She gave her ticket to the woman at the check-in desk.', 'Give your mother the letter.', 'They were all given a box to carry.']

sentence: Lately , Georgina had been worried by the general deterioration in his appearance .
gloss: Feel or cause to feel anxious or troubled about actual or potential problems.
eg_sent: he worried about his soldier sons in the war
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; If you worry, you keep thinking about problems that you have or about unpleasant things that might happen. ;
exps_collins: ["Don't worry, your luggage will come on afterwards by taxi.", 'I worry about her constantly.', "I work in a school so I don't have to worry about finding someone to look after my little boy.", 'They worry that extremists might gain control.']
bis_def_longman: to be anxious or unhappy about someone or something, so that you think about them a lot
exps_longman: ['I worry about my daughter.', 'You’ve really got no need to worry about your weight.', 'She worried that she wasn’t doing enough to help.', 'Dad worries over the slightest thing.', 'Don’t tell Mum about this – she’s got enough to worry about.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to keep thinking about unpleasant things that might happen or about problems that you have
exps_oxford_advanced: ["Don't worry. We have plenty of time.", "Don't worry about me. I'll be all right.", "He's always worrying about his weight.", "There's no point in worrying over things you can't change.", "I worry that I won't get into college."]

sentence: So I asked him what he was up to and he said he was going to and fro in the earth and walking up and down in it , and then he pushed th " trolley in , and I went in after , and the mother began her howling and shrieking , and Will said , " Well , I 'll walk off and leave you to it . "
gloss: Perform or undergo the first part of (an action or activity)

bis_def_longman: to start doing something

sentence: There are also outstanding bits of Indian stone monuments , with gods and goddesses sensuously entwined in spiritual embrace ; they start with the Gandhara grey schist carvings of the third/fourth century .

exps_oxford_advanced: ['They strolled through the park, with arms entwined.', 'The balcony was entwined with roses.']

sentence: Well our milkman , to be honest with you , it got to the stage where he would n't collect milk at night to collect the cash at night .
gloss: Come to have (something); receive.
eg_sent: I got a letter from him the other day

sentence: In his sermon , Dr Runcie said : We should ever recognise the scandal that Anglicans and Roman Catholics must celebrate two eucharists to make one memorial of our redemption on the day of our Lord .
gloss: Utter words so as to convey information, an opinion, a feeling or intention, or an instruction.
eg_sent: ‘Thank you,’ he said
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; When you say something, you speak words. ; [Also VERB to-infinitive]
exps_collins: ["'I'm sorry,' he said.", 'She said they were very impressed.', 'Forty-one people are said to have been seriously hurt.', 'I packed and said goodbye to Charlie.', "I hope you didn't say anything about Gretchen.", "You didn't say much when you telephoned.", 'Did he say where he was going?.', "It doesn't sound exactly orthodox, if I may say so."]

exps_longman: ['‘Don’t cry, ’ he said softly.', 'Don’t believe anything he says.', 'A spokesman said that the company had improved its safety standards.', 'I always said I would buy a motorbike when I had enough money.', 'Did she say what happened?', 'I would like to say how much we appreciate your hard work.', '‘Why did she leave?’ ‘I don’t know – she didn’t say.’', 'What did you say to her?', 'What a silly thing to say!', 'She left without saying goodbye.', 'I’ve said I’m sorry – what more do you want?', 'Can I go, Mum? Oh, please say yes!', 'He looked as if he was going to say something.', 'I wished I had said nothing about Jordi.', 'Does anyone else have anything to say?', 'Although he didn’t say so, it was clear that he was in pain.', 'What makes you say that (=why do you think that) ? 你怎么会那么说呢？', 'Nina said to meet her at 4.30.', 'I’d like to say a few words.', '‘So what are your plans now?’ ‘I’d rather not say.’']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to speak or tell somebody something, using words
exps_oxford_advanced: ['‘Hello!’ she said.', '‘That was marvellous,’ said Daniel.', 'Be quiet, I have something to say.', "I didn't believe a word she said.", "That's a terrible thing to say.", "He knew that if he wasn't back by midnight, his parents would have something to say about it (= be angry).", 'She said nothing to me about it.', "I said to myself (= thought), ‘That can't be right!’", 'He said (that) his name was Sam.', 'It is said that she lived to be over 100.', 'She finds it hard to say what she feels.', "‘That's impossible!’ ‘So you say (= but I think you may be wrong).’", "‘Why can't I go out now?’ ‘Because I say so.’", "‘What do you want it for?’ ‘I'd rather not say.’", 'He said to meet him here.', 'He is said to have been a brilliant scholar.']

sentence: From the resulting corner Rhodes made another fine save , hurtling to his right to deflect away Dixon 's rising shot .
gloss: Cause (something) to change direction; turn aside from a straight course.
eg_sent: the bullet was deflected harmlessly into the ceiling
bis_def_collins: VERB  () If you deflect something such as criticism or attention, you act in a way that prevents it from being directed towards you or affecting you. ()

sentence: An example of environmental modelling and prediction where the interactions between different processes and dynamic feedback is taken into account is given by Haber and Schaller ( 1988 ) .
gloss: Lay hold of (something) with one's hands; reach for and hold.
eg_sent: Mrs Morgan took another biscuit
bis_def_collins: You can use take followed by a noun to talk about an action or event, when it would also be possible to use the verb that is related to that noun. For example, you can say 'she took a shower' instead of 'she showered'.
exps_collins: ['She was too tired to take a shower.', 'Betty took a photograph of us.', "I've never taken a holiday since starting this job.", "There's not enough people willing to take the risk.", 'Walk around the property and take a good look at it from the outside.', 'We took a long walk through the pines.']
bis_def_longman: to move or go with someone or something from one place to another
exps_longman: ['Barney took us to the airport.', 'Would you mind taking Susie home?', 'When he refused to give his name, he was taken into custody.', 'My job has taken me all over the world.', 'His wife went to Australia, taking the children with her.', 'I have to take Steve the money tonight.', 'He took me to meet his parents.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to carry or move something from one place to another

sentence: Paths and boundaries vanished , allowing the tides of street life to wash right up to the doorsteps .
gloss: Disappear suddenly and completely.

bis_def_longman: to disappear suddenly, especially in a way that cannot be easily explained

sentence: The tradition for diesel cars is far better established on the Continent and that is where the best buys come from .
gloss: Move or travel towards or into a place thought of as near or familiar to the speaker.

sentence: The one line sort of sets it all off , you can remember .
gloss: Have in or be able to bring to one's mind an awareness of (someone or something from the past)
eg_sent: I remember the screech of the horn as the car came towards me

I was in another group.", "I certainly don't remember talking to you at all.", 'I remember her being a dominant figure.', 'I remembered that we had drunk the last of the coffee the week before.', 'I can remember where and when I bought each one.', 'I used to do that when you were a little girl, remember?']
bis_def_longman: to have a picture or idea in your mind of people, events, places etc from the past

sentence: See him .

eg_sent: in the distance she could see the blue sea
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont] ; When you see something, you notice it using your eyes. ;
exps_collins: ["You can't see colours at night.", 'I saw a man making his way towards me.', 'She can see, hear, touch, smell, and taste.', 'As he neared the farm, he saw that a police car was parked outside it.', 'Did you see what happened?', 'You use see to talk about things that you are aware of because a visual impression reaches your eyes. You often use can in this case. I can see the fax here on the desk. If you want to say that someone is paying attention to something they can see, you say that they are looking at it or watching it. In general, you look at something that is not moving, while you watch something that is moving or changing. I asked him to look at the picture above his bed... He watched Blake run down the stairs.']

sentence: Do you want it , do you want a bungalow ?
gloss: Have a desire to possess or do (something); wish for.
eg_sent: I want an apple
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont, no passive] ; If you want something, you feel a desire or a need for it. ;
exps_collins: ['I want a drink.', 'Ian knows exactly what he wants in life.', 'People wanted to know who this talented designer was.', 'They began to want their father to be the same as other daddies.', "They didn't want people staring at them as they sat on the lawn, so they put up high walls.", 'He wanted his power recognised.', 'I want my car this colour.', 'And remember, we want him alive.', "Note that want and wish have similar meanings, but are used differently. If you want something, you feel a need for it or a desire to have it. You can say that you want to do something, that you want someone to do something, or that you want something to happen. If you use wish with a 'to' infinitive, this has the same meaning as want but is more formal. I want to get out of here... She wished to consult him about her future."]
bis_def_longman: to have a desire for something

bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have a particular idea or opinion about something/somebody; to believe something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Do you think (that) they’ll come?', 'I thought I heard a scream.', "I didn't think you liked sports.", 'Am I right in thinking that you used to live here?', "I think this is their house, but I'm not sure.", 'He ought to resign, I think.', "We'll need about 20 chairs, I should think.", 'It was once thought that the sun travelled around the earth.', 'What did you think about the idea?', 'Well, I like it. What do you think?', '‘Will we make it in time?’ ‘I think so.’', "‘Is he any good?’ ‘I don't think so.’", "I think it highly unlikely that I'll get the job.", 'She thought him kind and generous.', "He's thought to be one of the richest men in Europe."]

sentence: The 1989-90 season , which started this month , brought another new prime-time western series , ABC 's Young Riders , which tells the story of the Pony Express .
gloss: Take or go with (someone or something) to a place.

sentence: She died six weeks ago .

']

sentence: Did you tell her we 'll wait here ?

sentence: Clare felt cheered to be back among like-minded people , doing something worth while .

sentence: In Glasgow he had picked up many of the skills that a more highly-born politician might have acquired in the Oxford Union or at the Bar , but skills that were very different in appearance .

sentence: The other side of press management , depending on informal contacts , is less easy to assess .
gloss: Be controlled or determined by.
eg_sent: differences in earnings depended on a wide variety of factors
bis_def_collins: VERB  ();() If you say that one thing depends on another, you mean that the first thing will be affected or determined by the second. ();()

sentence: As different layers are added sequentially we see how the proportion of available land shrinks ( Pl. 10.3 ) ; for instance , when geological criteria are set in the search for a deep repository , 25 per cent of land area remains and the addition of the population density layer reduces this to 24 per cent .
gloss: Continue to exist, especially after other similar people or things have ceased to do so.

sentence: If , for instance , the concentrations of certain trace gases ( see above ) continue to increase , it has been predicted that the earth 's surface temperature will increase by an amount comparable to that since the last major phase of the most recent glaciation ( about 18 000 years BP ) though there is some dispute about the magnitude of the likely change .
gloss: Become or make greater in size, amount, or degree.

exps_collins: ['The population continues to increase.', "Japan's industrial output increased by 2%.", 'The company has increased the price of its cars.', 'The increased investment will help stabilise the economy.', 'We are experiencing an increasing number of problems.']

bis_def_oxford_advanced: to become or to make something greater in amount, number, value, etc.
exps_oxford_advanced: ['The population has increased from 1.2 million to 1.8 million.', 'increasing levels of carbon dioxide in the earth’s atmosphere', 'Increasing numbers of people are using handheld devices to access the Internet.', 'The price of oil increased.', 'Oil increased in price.', 'The rate of inflation increased by 2%.', 'Disability increases with age (= the older somebody is, the more likely they are to be disabled).', 'We need to increase productivity.', "They've increased the price by 50%."]

sentence: It swung open at his touch but closing it , as always , was more difficult and he lugged and half lifted it into place and slipped the circle of wire over the gatepost with a familiar sensation of having turned his back on the workaday world and entered country which , no matter how frequent his visits , would always be alien territory .
gloss: Raise to a higher position or level.
eg_sent: he lifted his trophy over his head
bis_def_collins: If you lift something, you move it to another position, especially upwards.
exps_collins: ['The Colonel lifted the phone and dialed his superior.', 'She lifted the last of her drink to her lips.', 'She put her arms around him and lifted him up.', 'Curious shoppers lifted up their children to take a closer look at the parade.', 'Do not confuse lift and carry. When you carry something, you move it from one place to another without letting it touch the ground. When you lift something, you move it upwards using your hands or a machine. After you have lifted it, you may carry it to a different place.']
bis_def_longman: to move something or someone upwards into the air

sentence: This did not , however , stop the question of political marginality and the need to reform existing policies from being raised at all , as can be seen subsequently by the attempts after 1981 to introduce both locally and nationally measures which were meant to address some of the grievances of the rioters and to ensure that further disturbances did not occur .
