sentence: It argued that in talking about inner cities it was vital to think in terms not just of individuals , but of society ; that the multiple deprivations of the worst hit areas affected all the residents ; that the consequences included a pervasive sense of neglect and decay , a decline in community spirit , a low standard of neighbourhood facilities , and an increase in crime and vandalism ; and that , without government intervention , the future was one of reduced job opportunities , deteriorating housing , and a decline in public services .
gloss: Give reasons or cite evidence in support of an idea, action, or theory, typically with the aim of persuading others to share one's view.
eg_sent: sociologists argue that inequalities in industrial societies are being reduced

bis_def_oxford_advanced: to speak angrily to somebody because you disagree with them

sentence: His speech , however , came aftera 24-4 vote in the national executive to oppose a proportional representation motion which will be debated on Thursday .

sentence: Another recent auction in Leeds saw a run-down stone farmhouse without water or other amenities finally fall under the hammer for ÇÎ£330,500 .
gloss: Perceive with the eyes; discern visually.
eg_sent: in the distance she could see the blue sea
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont] ; When you see something, you notice it using your eyes. ;
exps_collins: ["You can't see colours at night.", 'I saw a man making his way towards me.', 'She can see, hear, touch, smell, and taste.', 'As he neared the farm, he saw that a police car was parked outside it.', 'Did you see what happened?', 'You use see to talk about things that you are aware of because a visual impression reaches your eyes. You often use can in this case. I can see the fax here on the desk. If you want to say that someone is paying attention to something they can see, you say that they are looking at it or watching it. In general, you look at something that is not moving, while you watch something that is moving or changing. I asked him to look at the picture above his bed... He watched Blake run down the stairs.']

bis_def_longman: to move towards you or arrive at the place where you are
exps_longman: ['Let me know when they come.', 'Can you come here for a minute?', 'What time will you be coming home?', 'There was a knock on the door and a young woman came into the room.', 'I could see a figure coming towards me.', 'As they came down the track, the car skidded.', 'I’ve come to see Philip.', 'I’ll come and help you move the rest of the boxes.', 'Jess came flying round the corner and banged straight into me.', 'What day are your folks coming to dinner?', 'Ah, here comes the bus at last!']

sentence: . Go and look at the garden . .
gloss: Direct one's gaze toward someone or something or in a specified direction.
eg_sent: people were looking at him
bis_def_collins: If you look in a particular direction, you direct your eyes in that direction, especially so that you can see what is there or see what something is like.
exps_collins: ['I looked down the hallway to room number nine.', 'She turned to look at him.', 'He looked away, apparently enraged.', "If you look, you'll see what was a lake.", 'If you want to say that someone is paying attention to something they can see, you say that they are looking at it or watching it. In general, you look at something that is not moving, while you watch something that is moving or changing. I asked him to look at the picture above his bed... He watched Blake run down the stairs. Look is never followed directly by an object. You must always use at or some other preposition. I looked towards the plane. You use see to talk about things that you are aware of because a visual impression reaches your eyes. You often use can in this case. I can see the fax here on the desk.']
bis_def_longman: to turn your eyes towards something, so that you can see it
exps_longman: ['We sneaked out while Jessie’s mom wasn’t looking.', 'If you look carefully you can see that the painting represents a human figure.', 'Gina covered her eyes, afraid to look.', '‘It’s time we left, ’ Ian said, looking at his watch.', 'The men all turned to look at her as she entered the room.', 'Dad looked up from his paper and smiled.', '‘We can’t go out in this weather, ’ said Bob, looking out of the window.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to turn your eyes in a particular direction
exps_oxford_advanced: ['If you look carefully you can just see our house from here.', 'She looked at me and smiled.', "‘Has the mail come yet?’ ‘I'll look and see.’", "Look! I'm sure that's Brad Pitt!", "Don't look now, but there's someone staring at you!"]

sentence: In a takeover campaign that has already seen vitriolic language , he responds to the charge that he is mounting the bid to enrich himself and his friends by saying : Nobody could take that as a criticism this is an investor group .
gloss: Lay hold of (something) with one's hands; reach for and hold.
eg_sent: Mrs Morgan took another biscuit
bis_def_collins: You can use take followed by a noun to talk about an action or event, when it would also be possible to use the verb that is related to that noun. For example, you can say 'she took a shower' instead of 'she showered'.
exps_collins: ['She was too tired to take a shower.', 'Betty took a photograph of us.', "I've never taken a holiday since starting this job.", "There's not enough people willing to take the risk.", 'Walk around the property and take a good look at it from the outside.', 'We took a long walk through the pines.']
bis_def_longman: to move or go with someone or something from one place to another
exps_longman: ['Barney took us to the airport.', 'Would you mind taking Susie home?', 'When he refused to give his name, he was taken into custody.', 'My job has taken me all over the world.', 'His wife went to Australia, taking the children with her.', 'I have to take Steve the money tonight.', 'He took me to meet his parents.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to carry or move something from one place to another
exps_oxford_advanced: ['I forgot to take my bag with me when I got off the bus.', 'Take this to the bank for me, would you?', 'Shall I take a gift to my host family?', 'Shall I take my host family a gift?']

sentence: Once people overcome their fears about computers and begin to use them in telecottages , they acquire their own equipment .
gloss: Succeed in dealing with (a problem or difficulty)
eg_sent: he overcame his pain for a time
bis_def_collins: If you overcome a problem or a feeling, you successfully deal with it and control it.
exps_collins: ['Molly had fought and overcome her fear of flying.', 'Find a way to overcome your difficulties.']
bis_def_longman: to successfully control a feeling or problem that prevents you from achieving something
exps_longman: ['He struggled to overcome his shyness.', 'Her financial problems could no longer be overcome.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to succeed in dealing with or controlling a problem that has been preventing you from achieving something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['She overcame injury to win the Olympic gold medal.', 'The two parties managed to overcome their differences on the issue.', 'He finally managed to overcome his fear of flying', 'He overcame a strong temptation to run away.']

sentence: Probation officers , it is argued , are concerned with establishing rules for probationers and not inflicting pain on them .
gloss: Set up on a firm or permanent basis.
eg_sent: the scheme was established in 1975
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; If someone establishes something such as an organization, a type of activity, or a set of rules, they create it or introduce it in such a way that it is likely to last for a long time. ;;
exps_collins: ['The UN has established detailed criteria for who should be allowed to vote.', 'The School was established in 1989 by an Italian professor.']
bis_def_longman: to start a company, organization, system, etc that is intended to exist or continue for a long time
exps_longman: ['The city of Boerne was established by German settlers in the 1840s.', 'Our goal is to establish a new research centre in the North.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to start or create an organization, a system, etc. that is meant to last for a long time
exps_oxford_advanced: ['The committee was established in 1912.', 'The new treaty establishes a free trade zone.', 'Let’s establish some ground rules.']

sentence: Penelope was looking particularly discontented and disaffected , picking at her food .
gloss: Direct one's gaze toward someone or something or in a specified direction.
eg_sent: people were looking at him
bis_def_collins: If you look in a particular direction, you direct your eyes in that direction, especially so that you can see what is there or see what something is like.
exps_collins: ['I looked down the hallway to room number nine.', 'She turned to look at him.', 'He looked away, apparently enraged.', "If you look, you'll see what was a lake.", 'If you want to say that someone is paying attention to something they can see, you say that they are looking at it or watching it. In general, you look at something that is not moving, while you watch something that is moving or changing. I asked him to look at the picture above his bed... He watched Blake run down the stairs. Look is never followed directly by an object. You must always use at or some other preposition. I looked towards the plane. You use see to talk about things that you are aware of because a visual impression reaches your eyes. You often use can in this case. I can see the fax here on the desk.']
bis_def_longman: to turn your eyes towards something, so that you can see it
exps_longman: ['We sneaked out while Jessie’s mom wasn’t looking.', 'If you look carefully you can see that the painting represents a human figure.', 'Gina covered her eyes, afraid to look.', '‘It’s time we left, ’ Ian said, looking at his watch.', 'The men all turned to look at her as she entered the room.', 'Dad looked up from his paper and smiled.', '‘We can’t go out in this weather, ’ said Bob, looking out of the window.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to turn your eyes in a particular direction
exps_oxford_advanced: ['If you look carefully you can just see our house from here.', 'She looked at me and smiled.', "‘Has the mail come yet?’ ‘I'll look and see.’", "Look! I'm sure that's Brad Pitt!", "Don't look now, but there's someone staring at you!"]

sentence: Other recently depressed stores , and companies with businesses similar to Dixons , rose in sympathy .
gloss: Make (someone) feel utterly dispirited or dejected.
eg_sent: that first day at school depressed me
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;; If someone or something depresses you, they make you feel sad and disappointed. ;;
exps_collins: ['I must admit the state of the country depresses me.', "I know he is too optimistic but I don't want to depress him."]
bis_def_longman: to make someone feel very unhappy
exps_longman: ['The thought of taking the exam again depressed him.', 'It depresses me that nobody seems to care.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to make somebody sad and without enthusiasm or hope
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Wet weather always depresses me.', 'The prospect of staying single depressed her.', 'What depresses me most is that I never see you.', 'It depresses me to see so many young girls smoking.']

sentence: Carl will speak to Michael now .
gloss: Say something in order to convey information or to express a feeling.
eg_sent: in his agitation he was unable to speak
bis_def_collins: VERB  ; When you speak, you use your voice in order to say something. ;
exps_collins: ['He tried to speak, but for once, his voice had left him.', 'He speaks with a lisp.', 'I rang the hotel and spoke to Louie.', 'She says she must speak with you at once.', 'She cried when she spoke of Oliver.', '...as I spoke these idiotic words.']
bis_def_longman: to talk to someone about something
exps_longman: ['I spoke to her last Wednesday.', '‘Hello, may I speak to Jim Smith?’ ‘Yes, speaking’.', 'I know her by sight, but not to speak to.', 'I haven’t spoken to Steve about all this.', 'They did not want to speak with reporters.', 'It was the first time she had ever spoken of marriage.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to talk to somebody about something; to have a conversation with somebody
exps_oxford_advanced: ["I've spoken to the manager about it.", 'The President refused to speak to the waiting journalists.', '‘Can I speak to Susan?’ ‘Speaking.’ (= at the beginning of a telephone conversation)', '‘Do you know him?’ ‘Not to speak to.’ (= only by sight)', "I saw her in the street but we didn't speak.", 'Can I speak with you for a minute?']

sentence: Do n't you think it 's horrible round here ?
gloss: Have a particular opinion, belief, or idea about someone or something.
eg_sent: she thought that nothing would be the same again
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont] ; If you think that something is the case, you have the opinion that it is the case. ; [Also VERB n to-infinitive]
exps_collins: ['I certainly think there should be a ban on tobacco advertising.', 'Do you think I ought to seal the boxes up?.', 'A generation ago, it was thought that babies born this small could not survive.', 'Tell me, what do you think of my theory?.', 'Peter is useless, far worse than I thought.', 'He manages a good deal better than I thought possible.', "'It ought to be stopped.' — 'Yes, I think so.'"]
bis_def_longman: to have a particular opinion or to believe that something is true
exps_longman: ['I think that you’re being unfair.', 'I thought I heard something.', 'He didn’t think anyone would believe him.', 'Do you think I should call him?', 'For some reason, I keep thinking it’s Friday today.', 'The recession lasted longer than anyone thought it would.', 'Am I right in thinking that you have a brother?', 'I can’t help thinking that he’s made a mistake.', 'Do you honestly think I would do something so stupid?', 'What do you think of your new school?', 'I thought it best to call first.', 'I thought it appropriate to invite her to speak at the meeting.', 'We must start thinking in terms of reducing costs.', 'Fraud is thought to be costing software companies millions of dollars a year.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have a particular idea or opinion about something/somebody; to believe something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Do you think (that) they’ll come?', 'I thought I heard a scream.', "I didn't think you liked sports.", 'Am I right in thinking that you used to live here?', "I think this is their house, but I'm not sure.", 'He ought to resign, I think.', "We'll need about 20 chairs, I should think.", 'It was once thought that the sun travelled around the earth.', 'What did you think about the idea?', 'Well, I like it. What do you think?', '‘Will we make it in time?’ ‘I think so.’', "‘Is he any good?’ ‘I don't think so.’", "I think it highly unlikely that I'll get the job.", 'She thought him kind and generous.', "He's thought to be one of the richest men in Europe."]

sentence: Well you 're pulling , you little bugger !
gloss: Exert force on (someone or something) so as to cause movement towards oneself.
eg_sent: he pulled them down on to the couch
bis_def_collins: When you pull something, you hold it firmly and use force in order to move it towards you or away from its previous position.
exps_collins: ["They have pulled out patients' teeth unnecessarily.", 'He pulled on a jersey.', 'Erica was solemn, pulling at her blonde curls.', 'I helped pull him out of the water.', 'Someone pulled her hair.', 'He knew he should pull the trigger, but he was suddenly paralysed by fear.', 'Pull as hard as you can.', 'I let myself out into the street and pulled the door shut.']
bis_def_longman: to use your hands to make something or someone move towards you or in the direction that your hands are moving
exps_longman: ['Mom! Davey’s pulling my hair!', 'He pulled her down into her seat.', 'She pulled open the door and hurried inside.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to hold something firmly and use force in order to move it or try to move it towards yourself
exps_oxford_advanced: ["You push and I'll pull.", "Don't pull so hard or the handle will come off.", 'I pulled on the rope to see if it was secure.', 'Stop pulling her hair!', 'She pulled him gently towards her.', 'Pull the door shut.']

sentence: Frederica listened attentively ; went on and signed the Visitors ' Book .
gloss: Write one's name on (a letter, card, document, etc.) to identify oneself as the writer or sender.
eg_sent: the card was signed by the whole class
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;() If you sign, you communicate with someone using sign language. If a programme or performance is signed, someone uses sign language so that deaf people can understand it. ;()
exps_collins: ["All programmes will be either 'signed' or subtitled."]
bis_def_longman: to write your signature on something to show that you wrote it, agree with it, or were present
exps_longman: ['The artist had signed his name in the corner of the painting.', 'You forgot to sign the cheque.', 'Over a hundred people have signed the petition.', 'Serena signs her autograph every time she’s asked.', 'a signed photo of Paul McCartney']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to write your name on a document, letter, etc. to show that you have written it, that you agree with what it says, or that it is genuine
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Sign here, please.', 'Sign your name here, please.', "You haven't signed the letter.", 'to sign a cheque', 'The treaty was signed on 24 March.', 'The player was signing autographs for a group of fans.', 'He signed himself ‘Jimmy’.']

sentence: His instinct was to pile the children into the car and drive them home but that , he knew , was hardly sensible .
gloss: Be aware of through observation, inquiry, or information.
eg_sent: most people know that CFCs can damage the ozone layer
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont]  If you know a fact, a piece of information, or an answer, you have it correctly in your mind.
exps_collins: ["I don't know the name of the place.", 'I know that you led a rifle platoon during the Second World War.', "'People like doing things for nothing.' — 'I know they do.'.", "I don't know what happened to her husband.", "'How did he meet your mother?' — 'I don't know.'.", 'We all know about his early experiments in flying.', 'They looked younger than I knew them to be.', 'Radon is known to be harmful to humans in large quantities.', 'It is not known whether the bomb was originally intended for the capital itself.', "It's always been known that key figures in the government do very well for themselves."]
bis_def_longman: to have information about something
exps_longman: ['Who knows the answer?', 'There are instructions telling you everything you need to know.', 'Didn’t you know that?', 'Do you know what time it is?', 'I don’t know where to go.', 'I need to know more about the job before I decide whether to apply for it.', 'Little is known about the author’s childhood.', 'I know all about David and what he’s been up to!', 'I wonder if he knew of the plan?', 'Do you know of any good restaurants in the area?', 'You know nothing of this business.', 'We know that greenhouse gases can affect the climate.', 'Let me know what time you’re planning to arrive.', 'I thought you’d want to know immediately.', 'If you must know, I was with James last night .', 'He slipped out of the house without his parents knowing .', 'How did he know our names?', '‘I’m divorced, as you know, ’ she said briefly.', 'Smoking is known to increase a person’s risk of developing lung cancer.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have information in your mind as a result of experience or because you have learned or been told it
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Do you know his address?', 'The cause of the fire is not yet known.', 'All I know is that she used to work in a bank (= I have no other information about her).', 'I know (that) people’s handwriting changes as they get older.', 'It is widely known that CFCs can damage the ozone layer.', 'I knew where he was hiding.', "I didn't know what he was talking about.", "‘You've got a flat tyre.’ ‘I know.’", "‘What's the answer?’ ‘I don't know.’", "‘There's no one in.’ ‘How do you know?’", "You know about Amanda's baby, don't you?", "I don't know about you, but I'm ready for something to eat.", 'I know of at least two people who did the same thing.', '‘Is anyone else coming?’ ‘Not that I know of.’', '‘Isn’t that his car?’ ‘I wouldn’t know./How should I know?’ (= I don’t know and I am not the person you should ask.)', "‘What are you two whispering about?’ ‘You don't want to know’ (= because you would be shocked or wouldn't approve).", 'Does he know to come here (= that he should come here) first?', 'We know her to be honest.', 'Two women are known to have died.']

sentence: I 'll give it some paint .
gloss: Freely transfer the possession of (something) to (someone)
eg_sent: she gave him presents and clothes
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont]  You can use give with nouns that refer to physical actions. The whole expression refers to the performing of the action. For example, She gave a smile means almost the same as 'She smiled'.
exps_collins: ['She stretched her arms out and gave a great yawn.', 'Giving a sigh, she fell to her knees at my feet.', 'He gave her a fond smile.', 'He reached for her hand and gave it a reassuring squeeze.']

exps_longman: ['What did Bob give you for your birthday?', 'Researchers were given a £10,000 grant to continue their work.', 'I’ve got some old diaries that my grandmother gave me years ago.', 'a ring which was given to him by his mother', 'I didn’t steal it! Maria gave it to me!', 'Most people are willing to give to charity.', 'The situation is now desperate, so please give generously.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to hand something to somebody so that they can look at it, use it or keep it for a time
exps_oxford_advanced: ["Give the letter to your mother when you've read it.", 'She gave her ticket to the woman at the check-in desk.', 'Give your mother the letter.', 'They were all given a box to carry.']

sentence: For most systems the manual is best divided into parts as indicated in Table 1.17 .
gloss: Point out; show.

sentence: The project was controversial and the power station was only permitted providing the smoke was clean and the building did not challenge the visual dominance of St Paul 's .

sentence: There seems to be a growing interest in examining associations between ill health and the geological environment .

sentence: When Tony could n't get me to climax , he wanted to ask another girl over , Clare said .
gloss: Have a desire to possess or do (something); wish for.
eg_sent: I want an apple
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont, no passive] ; If you want something, you feel a desire or a need for it. ;
exps_collins: ['I want a drink.', 'Ian knows exactly what he wants in life.', 'People wanted to know who this talented designer was.', 'They began to want their father to be the same as other daddies.', "They didn't want people staring at them as they sat on the lawn, so they put up high walls.", 'He wanted his power recognised.', 'I want my car this colour.', 'And remember, we want him alive.', "Note that want and wish have similar meanings, but are used differently. If you want something, you feel a need for it or a desire to have it. You can say that you want to do something, that you want someone to do something, or that you want something to happen. If you use wish with a 'to' infinitive, this has the same meaning as want but is more formal. I want to get out of here... She wished to consult him about her future."]
bis_def_longman: to have a desire for something
exps_longman: ['I really want a drink.', 'What do you want for your birthday?', 'She’d always wanted to go to Thailand.', 'I don’t want Linda to  hear about this.', 'He didn’t want the holiday to end.', 'You can order whatever you want.', 'This shampoo is mild enough to use every day if you want.', 'If she doesn’t get what she wants, she’s not happy.', 'He wanted that job so badly he was willing to kill for it.', 'They desperately wanted a son.', 'What I want to know is when we’re going to get paid.', 'All I want is the chance to prove myself.', 'Oh thank you, it’s just what I’ve always wanted.']

sentence: Improved morale would also make possible organizational advances outside parliament , all linked to the issue of Ulster , and with the sights fixed firmly on the next election , an election that would make or break the Union , the Empire and Law 's leadership of the party .
gloss: Make, form, or suggest a connection with or between.

exps_collins: ['The UN Security Council has linked any lifting of sanctions to compliance with the ceasefire terms.', 'The study further strengthens the evidence linking smoking with early death.', 'Liver cancer is linked to the hepatitis B virus.', 'The detention raised two distinct but closely linked questions.']

sentence: There was nothing wrong with the boat 's lines , which were sleekly functional , but her long powerful hull , her upperworks , and even the interior of her capacious working deck had all been painted with a wartime dazzle paint .
gloss: Cover the surface of (something) with paint.

bis_def_oxford_advanced: to cover a surface or object with paint

sentence: Moreover , as Newby ( 1990 ) has pointed out , the complexities of environmental research have created a new kind of relationship between research and policy : in the past , the relationship was predicated on the belief that science provided decision-makers with objective hard facts on which to base their soft , value-ridden policies .
gloss: Direct someone's attention towards something by extending one's finger or something held in one's hand.

bis_def_oxford_advanced: to stretch out your finger or something held in your hand towards somebody/something in order to show somebody where a person or thing is

sentence: Some of the stupid bastards wo n't be satisfied until we no longer make a single vehicle in the UK .

sentence: Two goals from the irrepressible Andy Ritchie , his 13th and 14th this season , and a third by the 20-year-old midfield player Nick Henry , and Arsenal were sunk with only the trace of a last-minute goal by Quinn .
gloss: Go down below the surface of something, especially of a liquid; become submerged.

exps_collins: ["In a naval battle your aim is to sink the enemy's ship.", 'The boat was beginning to sink fast.', 'The lifeboat crashed against the side of the sinking ship.']
bis_def_longman: to go down below the surface of water, mud etc

sentence: The Community Health Team aim was to ensure a place of treatment for children from the earliest possible age , to enable them to develop to their fullest potential .
gloss: Make certain that (something) will occur or be the case.

bis_def_oxford_advanced: to make sure that something happens or is definite

sentence: He was reaching-for the blue directory when Anne came back with Abigail in her arms , so Adam took her and carried her back to bed himself and tucked her in and kissed her .
gloss: Support and move (someone or something) from one place to another.

exps_collins: ['He was carrying a briefcase.', 'He carried the plate through to the dining room.', 'She carried her son to the car.', "If your job involves a lot of paperwork, you're going to need something to carry it all in."]
bis_def_longman: to hold something in your hand or arms, or support it as you take it somewhere
exps_longman: ['Gina was carrying a small bunch of flowers.', 'Angela carried the child in her arms.', 'Let me carry that for you.', 'Jack carried his grandson up the stairs.', 'The waiter carried our drinks to the table.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to support the weight of somebody/something and take them or it from place to place; to take somebody/something from one place to another

sentence: Thrusts of resistance ( mass demonstrations , resignations , tax rebellions , etc ) would come in crests .
gloss: Move or travel towards or into a place thought of as near or familiar to the speaker.

sentence: In 1936 , three years before Aaron Copland , Thomson started writing film scores which were a model of unobtrusive clarity and pertinence , combining American materials to suit documentaries such as The Plow that Broke the Plains and The River with the musique d'ameublement approach of Satie .

sentence: Then he sat on her bed and , without a word from either of them , she went willingly into his arms and was held close in his embrace .

Let’s go home.', 'Where are you going?', 'We’re going to Canada in the summer.', 'Dinah went into the kitchen.', 'She went over and put her arm around him.', 'I’m going round to her house to find out what’s wrong.', 'I’ll just go up  and ask him what he wants.']

sentence: I do n't know , I did n't go today .
gloss: Be aware of through observation, inquiry, or information.
eg_sent: most people know that CFCs can damage the ozone layer
bis_def_collins: VERB  [no cont]  If you know a fact, a piece of information, or an answer, you have it correctly in your mind.
exps_collins: ["I don't know the name of the place.", 'I know that you led a rifle platoon during the Second World War.', "'People like doing things for nothing.' — 'I know they do.'.", "I don't know what happened to her husband.", "'How did he meet your mother?' — 'I don't know.'.", 'We all know about his early experiments in flying.', 'They looked younger than I knew them to be.', 'Radon is known to be harmful to humans in large quantities.', 'It is not known whether the bomb was originally intended for the capital itself.', "It's always been known that key figures in the government do very well for themselves."]
bis_def_longman: to have information about something
exps_longman: ['Who knows the answer?', 'There are instructions telling you everything you need to know.', 'Didn’t you know that?', 'Do you know what time it is?', 'I don’t know where to go.', 'I need to know more about the job before I decide whether to apply for it.', 'Little is known about the author’s childhood.', 'I know all about David and what he’s been up to!', 'I wonder if he knew of the plan?', 'Do you know of any good restaurants in the area?', 'You know nothing of this business.', 'We know that greenhouse gases can affect the climate.', 'Let me know what time you’re planning to arrive.', 'I thought you’d want to know immediately.', 'If you must know, I was with James last night .', 'He slipped out of the house without his parents knowing .', 'How did he know our names?', '‘I’m divorced, as you know, ’ she said briefly.', 'Smoking is known to increase a person’s risk of developing lung cancer.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to have information in your mind as a result of experience or because you have learned or been told it
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Do you know his address?', 'The cause of the fire is not yet known.', 'All I know is that she used to work in a bank (= I have no other information about her).', 'I know (that) people’s handwriting changes as they get older.', 'It is widely known that CFCs can damage the ozone layer.', 'I knew where he was hiding.', "I didn't know what he was talking about.", "‘You've got a flat tyre.’ ‘I know.’", "‘What's the answer?’ ‘I don't know.’", "‘There's no one in.’ ‘How do you know?’", "You know about Amanda's baby, don't you?", "I don't know about you, but I'm ready for something to eat.", 'I know of at least two people who did the same thing.', '‘Is anyone else coming?’ ‘Not that I know of.’', '‘Isn’t that his car?’ ‘I wouldn’t know./How should I know?’ (= I don’t know and I am not the person you should ask.)', "‘What are you two whispering about?’ ‘You don't want to know’ (= because you would be shocked or wouldn't approve).", 'Does he know to come here (= that he should come here) first?', 'We know her to be honest.', 'Two women are known to have died.']

sentence: He was unsurprised to find her packed off firmly to take his sister home , leaving him as a person of major importance in what he instantly assumed to be a real murder .

bis_def_collins: VERB  ; When a person or thing comes to a particular place, especially to a place where you are, they move there. ;
exps_collins: ['Two police officers came into the hall.', 'Come here, Tom.', "You'll have to come with us.", 'We want you to come to lunch.', 'I came over from Ireland to start a new life after my divorce.', 'We heard the train coming.', 'Can I come too?.', 'The impact blew out some of the windows and the sea came rushing in.']
bis_def_longman: to move towards you or arrive at the place where you are
exps_longman: ['Let me know when they come.', 'Can you come here for a minute?', 'What time will you be coming home?', 'There was a knock on the door and a young woman came into the room.', 'I could see a figure coming towards me.', 'As they came down the track, the car skidded.', 'I’ve come to see Philip.', 'I’ll come and help you move the rest of the boxes.', 'Jess came flying round the corner and banged straight into me.', 'What day are your folks coming to dinner?', 'Ah, here comes the bus at last!']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to move to or towards a person or place
exps_oxford_advanced: ['He came into the room and shut the door.', 'She comes to work by bus.', 'My son is coming home soon.', 'Come here!', 'Come and see us soon!', 'Here comes Jo! (= Jo is coming)', "There's a storm coming.", "They're coming to stay for a week."]

sentence: The pattern caused problems , in that the circumstances which might trigger off renewed fighting were unpredictable ; yet the moment an opportunity offered , princes had to be prepared for invading their enemies ; there was no time for lengthy preparation .
gloss: Present or proffer (something) for (someone) to accept or reject as desired.
eg_sent: may I offer you a drink?
bis_def_collins: If you offer something to someone, you ask them if they would like to have it or use it.
exps_collins: ['He has offered seats at the conference table to the Russian leader and the president of Kazakhstan.', 'The number of companies offering them work increased.', 'Rhys offered him an apple.', 'Western governments have offered aid.']
bis_def_longman: to ask someone if they would like to have something, or to hold something out to them so that they can take it
exps_longman: ['Can I offer you something to drink?', 'They offered him a very good job, but he turned it down.', 'Maureen lit a cigarette and offered one to Lucy.', 'The drama school offers places to students who can show talent.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to say that you are willing to do something for somebody or give something to somebody
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Josie had offered her services as a guide.', 'He offered some useful advice.', "I don't think they need help, but I think I should offer anyway.", 'He offered $4\u2009000 for the car.', 'They are offering a reward for the return of their cat.', 'They decided to offer the job to Jo.', 'They decided to offer Jo the job.', 'I gratefully took the cup of coffee she offered me.', 'Taylor offered him 500 dollars to do the work.', 'The kids offered to do the dishes.', "‘I'll do it,’ she offered."]

sentence: When Austen sat down Chaplin suggested that he had better put the question at once and on getting an affirmative shout did so .
gloss: Come to have (something); receive.
eg_sent: I got a letter from him the other day
bis_def_collins: You use get with adjectives to mean 'become'. For example, if someone gets cold, they become cold, and if they get angry, they become angry.
exps_collins: ['The boys were getting bored.', "There's no point in getting upset.", 'From here on, it can only get better.']
bis_def_longman: to receive something that someone gives you or sends you
exps_longman: ['She got loads of presents.', 'What did you get for Christmas?', 'We get a lot of junk mail.', 'We got a letter from Pam this morning.', 'I got it off my Dad.', 'I got a few games free when I bought my computer.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to receive something
exps_oxford_advanced: ['I got a letter from Dave this morning.', 'What (= What presents) did you get for your birthday?', 'He gets (= earns) about $40\u2009000 a year.', 'This room gets very little sunshine.', 'I got a shock when I saw the bill.', 'I get the impression that he is bored with his job.']

sentence: By examining the way these animals were put together it is possible to suggest a likely mode of life .
gloss: Move to or place in a particular position.
eg_sent: I put my hand out towards her
bis_def_collins: When you put something in a particular place or position, you move it into that place or position.
exps_collins: ['Leaphorn put the photograph on the desk.', "She hesitated, then put her hand on Grace's arm.", 'Mishka put down a heavy shopping bag.']
bis_def_longman: to move something to a particular place or position, especially using your hands
exps_longman: ['He put the coffee on the table.', 'Where did you put the programmes?']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to move something into a particular place or position
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Put the cases down there, please.', 'Did you put sugar in my coffee?', 'Put your hand up if you need more paper.']

sentence: My Mum brought up five of us in a flat far worse than what these immigrants complain about .
gloss: Take or go with (someone or something) to a place.
eg_sent: she brought Luke home from hospital
bis_def_collins: If you bring someone or something with you when you come to a place, they come with you or you have them with you.
exps_collins: ['Remember to bring an apron or an old shirt to protect your clothes.', 'Come to my party and bring a girl with you.', 'Someone went upstairs and brought down a huge kettle.', 'My father brought home a book for me.']
bis_def_longman: to take something or someone with you to the place where you are now, or to the place you are talking about
exps_longman: ['Did you bring an umbrella?', 'It was the first time Joey had ever brought a girl home.', 'They brought news of further fighting along the border.', 'Is it OK if I bring some friends to the party?', 'For some reason, Jesse had brought a tape recorder with him.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to come to a place with somebody/something
exps_oxford_advanced: ["Don't forget to bring your books with you.", 'She brought her boyfriend to the party.', 'Bring a present for Helen.', 'Bring Helen a present.']

sentence: The problem arises in connection with section 99 which adapts or applies the provisions to cases where an individual rather than the local authority wishes to make the complaint .
gloss: Form (something) by putting parts together or combining substances; create.
eg_sent: my grandmother made a dress for me
bis_def_collins: VERB  ) You can use make with a wide range of nouns to indicate that someone performs an action or says something. For example, if you make a suggestion, you suggest something. )
exps_collins: ["I'd just like to make a comment.", 'I made a few phone calls.', "I think you're making a serious mistake.", 'The Pope said the world had made some progress towards peace in 1991.', 'Science and technology have made major changes to the way we live.', 'She had made us an offer too good to refuse.']
bis_def_longman: to produce something, for example by putting the different parts of it together
exps_longman: ['I’m going to show you how to make a box for your tools.', 'A family of mice had made their nest in the roof.', 'She made her own wedding dress.', 'The company has been making quality furniture for over 200 years.', 'They met while they were making a film.', 'He made her a toy horse, using just some straw and bamboo twigs.', 'Paper is made from wood.', 'a shirt made of silk', 'She’s very good at making things from old scraps of material.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to create or prepare something by combining materials or putting parts together
exps_oxford_advanced: ['to make a table/dress/cake', 'to make bread/cement/paper', 'She makes her own clothes.', 'made in France (= on a label)', "What's your shirt made of?", 'Wine is made from grapes.', 'The grapes are made into wine.', 'She made coffee for us all.', 'She made us all coffee.']

sentence: To complicate matters still further , however , it seems at least possible that the components of the earth system may best be predicted deterministically at some spatial and temporal scales but stochastically at others and that the basis of prediction will differ for different components .
gloss: Make (something) more complicated.
eg_sent: increased choice will complicate matters for the consumer
bis_def_collins: To complicate something means to make it more difficult to understand or deal with.
exps_collins: ['What complicates the issue is the burden of history.', "The day's events, he said, would only complicate the task of the peacekeeping forces.", "To complicate matters further, everybody's vitamin requirements vary.", 'Bad weather continues to complicate efforts to deal with oil spilling from the tanker.']
bis_def_longman: to make a problem or situation more difficult
exps_longman: ['The situation is complicated by the fact that I’ve got to work late on Friday.', 'To complicate matters further, differences exist as regards legal systems, trade customs, and language.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to make something more difficult to do, understand or deal with
exps_oxford_advanced: ['I do not wish to complicate the task more than is necessary.', "To complicate matters further, there will be no transport available till 8 o'clock.", 'The issue is complicated by the fact that a vital document is missing.']

sentence: The section describing the operation of the system should cover not only how the system operates but also how the user can operate it .
gloss: Give a detailed account in words of.
eg_sent: he described his experiences in a letter to his parents
bis_def_collins: VERB  ;;; If you describe a person, object, event, or situation, you say what they are like or what happened. ;;;
exps_collins: ['We asked her to describe what kind of things she did in her spare time.', 'She broke down describing how she was arrested for refusing a breath test.', 'She read a poem by Carver which describes their life together.', "The myth of Narcissus is described in Ovid's work.", 'Just before his death he described seeing their son in a beautiful garden.']
bis_def_longman: to say what something or someone is like by giving details about them
exps_longman: ['The police asked her to describe the man.', 'Another approach to the problem is described in Chapter 3.', 'After the operation her condition was described as comfortable.', 'The youth is described as being 18 to 19 years old.', 'It’s difficult to describe how I feel.', 'So describe this new boyfriend to me!', 'He described finding his mother lying on the floor.']
bis_def_oxford_advanced: to say what somebody/something is like
exps_oxford_advanced: ['Can you describe him to me?', 'The current political situation in Vietnam is described in chapter 8.', 'The man was described as tall and dark, and aged about 20.', 'Jim was described by his colleagues as ‘unusual’.', 'Describe how you did it.', 'Several people described seeing strange lights in the sky.']
